TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from five citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian National Flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from five citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Coastline
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest, in the strongest possible terms, at the Federal Government's inaction to take legislative measures to protect our coast.

We the surfriders and TRACKS readers of Australia have watched our coastal treasures, the ecology, biodiversity and beauty of the Australian coast marred by urban development, poor planning and pollution, especially over the last 25 years.
The ALP has been in government for half that time and we've lost double our resources.
We (not so humbly) demand that you urge the Federal Government to act now to establish a national coastal agency with national powers to stop the destruction of our Australian coastline.
We also demand that the Federal Government recognise and include surfriders in the major decision making forums and call on you to contribute resources toward those who protect our surfing coast.
Finally, we demand that the environment be recognised in the Australian Constitution.
We are tired of waiting! You must act now. Please write to me and inform me of what you are going to do to save our surf.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest in the strongest possible terms against the resumption of Nuclear Testing. Therefore we request:
1. the immediate and permanent cessation of mining and the export of Uranium as a signal to all nations that we will not accept nuclear weapons in any form,
2. the use of all means possible to dissuade France and any other nation from Nuclear Weapons Testing, and
3. that the Minister for Foreign Affairs make a submission arguing the illegality of Nuclear Weapons to the International Court of Justice.

PETITION.TITLE: Jarosite Dumping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to (a) reverse the decision to extend the time allowed Pasminco EZ to dump jarosite at sea, and (b) endorse and comply with the December 1995 deadline established by the London Dumping Convention.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to abolish Austudy for 16 year olds living at home; to erode Austudy payments in favour of student loans and to reduce the income thresholds for repayment of the loan supplement.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that the Independent Rate Age be decreased to 21 years immediately; that full Austudy payments be raised to the same level as unemployment benefits; and, that the taxable income threshold be increased to $8000 pa.

PETITION.TITLE: Recycled Paper: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the Government to reintroduce sales tax of 22% on the following recycled paper products from 1 November 1995 to include:

PARA.TAB: writing, drawing or printing paper (including pads of writing, drawing or printing paper), paper of a kind ordinarily used in accounting ledgers or accounting journals and envelopes.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reject this proposed change.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: Afghanistan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate assembled, the petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Parliament that many members Afghan born Australians continue to suffer due to trials of separation from family members who have sought refuge in Pakistan, Iran, India and Russia.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners draw to your attention the state of unrest and political instability current in Afghanistan and the resultant trauma being suffered by people within Afghanistan, displaced Afghan people living outside the country and Australians of Afghan background.
Your petitioners respectuflly draw your attention to the impossibility of displaced Afghans being repatriated in the near future and call on the Australian Government to:
work with the United Nations to achieve peace in Afghanistan;
provide support to Afghans wishing to migrate to Australia by making access to a Special Assistance Category; and Women at Risk;
work with NGO's to achieve reconstruction in Afghanistan.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, as students, staff or friends of Edith Cowan University express our community's outrage at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.
To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate Federal Government intervention, to comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in cooperation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal resources.
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp and cane;
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned,
(1) wish to express our anger and dismay in regard to the French government's decision to resume nuclear testing,

(2) are appalled at the Australian Government's and Opposition's gagging of debate on Senator Coulter's bill calling for a ban on the export of uranium to France especially as the Government can give no guarantee that this uranium is not used for nuclear weapons, and

(3) call on the Australian Government and Opposition to support Senator Coulter's bill to ban the export of uranium to France as the most effective way of stating to the French government, `Your decision to resume nuclear testing is totally unacceptable'.

PETITION.TITLE: Papua New Guinea
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned recognises that there is an urgent need for Papua New Guinea to address their economic ills. This needs to occur with the involvement of the people of that country so a model of development that is appropriate socially and environmentally is adopted.

Your petitioners request that the Senate should direct the executive director representing Australia at the World Bank, Mr Peter Nichols, work for the renegotiation of the Structural Adjustment Program that has been imposed on PNG by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, with the support of the Australian government. Further we request that the National Coalition for Socio-Economic Justice, representing trade unions and community groups opposing the current SAPs, be consulted on adjustment measures advocated by the international finance institutions.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are;

disturbed by the fact that every month between 600 and 1200 people (most of them civilians) are killed or maimed by landmines, and their health and maintenance costs are being incurred in countries with insufficient resources to meet the most basic needs of all their people,

concerned that the cost of clearing and de-activating of landmines is one hundred times the financial cost of manufacture, and the human cost is being borne by people who have suffered displacement, war, tribulation and hunger,

and we are greatly concerned that there remains between 85 and 100 million unexploded mines scattered over 62 different countries, inhibiting the ordinary movement of civilians and the farming of fields as people return to their former homes as wars cease.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
ensure that the overseas aid budget contains a substantial allocation for de-mining training programs,
ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora persuade more countries to become party to, and gratify, the Inhumane Weapons Convention

ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora promote and support an amendment to Article 6 of Protocol II to prohibit the use, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of landmines.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that many Australians are concerned that the Federal Government is not supporting efforts to introduce a timetable for the elimination of nuclear weapons at the April extension conference of the NPT:
Your Petitioners ask/request that the Senate should call on the Government to do everything in its power to support such a timetable and help to rid the world of nuclear weapons.

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses widespread community concern about the ABC's decision to centralise daily current affairs coverage in Sydney.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate:
(a) note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition; and
(b) call on the Government:
to instruct the ABC to reverse its decision to centralise current affairs coverage in Sydney and:
to appoint a Tasmanian to the Board of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Federal Police Headquarters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that plans to move the Australian Federal Police Headquarters in Civic to a new site in Barton at an estimated cost of $50 million is too costly as well as damaging to the development of services and business in Civic.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should oppose the proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: King Island Dairy Products Pty Ltd: Restitution of Property

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BELL

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present a petition from 14 petitioners, which has been lodged with the Clerk under standing order 69 but which has not been certified because it is not in the proper form:

SPEECH.PARA: The President and Members of the Senate, Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, Canberra, ACT.
We the undersigned bring to the notice of Honourable Members,
THAT in the matter of the sale of the property known as,
The King Island Dairy, to, Transequity Ltd
an injustice was caused to the following:

PARA.TAB: (a) King Island Dairy Products Pty Ltd ACN 009 513 231
(b) Interlandi Wholesale Pty Ltd ACN
(c) The creditors of King Island Dairy Products Pty Ltd, including the taxpayers of Tasmania
(d) The Kirk Family
(e) The farmer milk suppliers to King Island Dairy.

SPEECH.PARA: BECAUSE of the actions of the accounting firm Touche Ross and Company acting under direction from The State of Tasmania the following occurred:

PARA.TAB: (1) In October 1986 the King Island Dairy properties were sold for $300,000. Three weeks prior to the sale the accountants Touche Ross and Co, who were acting as receivers for the secured creditor The Tasmanian Development Authority (as agent for the Minister), had declared in a signed declaration to the state Corporate Affairs office the properties were worth approximately $1.7 million.
(2) The sale price excluded valuation and payment for the Trade Marks and Brands owned by King Island Dairy, which were a valuable asset of King Island Dairy, then, as they are now.

(3) The decision by the State of Tasmania to seize the King Island Dairy and, through the receivers, direct its sale to Transequity Ltd, impacted on the small dairy farming community of King Island. There was no `safety net' arranged by the Tasmanian government to prevent abuse by Transequity Ltd of its dominant milk purchasing position above the milk suppliers. In the nine years since the sale it is estimated the King Island dairy farmers have received $2 million less for their milk than farmers producing milk for equivalent purposes in Victoria. This is an estimated price underpayment of approximately $100,000 per average King Island family dairy farm.

(4) When the Kirk Family tried to publish the story of the injustice, action was taken by the former Premier of Tasmania, Mr R.T. Gray and an associate Mr P.G. Morgan, to institute defamation proceedings against W.J. Kirk and Australia Post. Messrs Morgan and Gray obtained injunctions in early 1989 restraining W.J. Kirk and Australia Post from publishing and distributing material concerning the sale of the King Island Dairy. At the date of this petition neither Mr Gray or Mr Morgan, have taken their defamation proceedings to trial. The injunctions remain.

In a separate action Agricorp Ltd and Butterfields Cheese Factors Pty Ltd succeeded in obtaining judgment from Master Wheeler in the Supreme Court of Victoria against W.J. and R.E. Kirk, for defamation. Master Wheeler entered judgment against the Kirks after declining an application by the Kirks to enter a late defence. The Kirks declined to pay the judgment debt and were made bankrupt on the petition of Agricorp and Ors in 1994.
WE the undersigned, humbly request honourable members to deal with our grievance in the matter of sale of King Island Dairy as follows:
(A) A Private Bill for Restitution of Property to King Island Dairy Products Pty Ltd be drafted and introduced to the Senate.

(B) In addition to the Restitution the Bill might contain provision to retrospectively Statute Bar legal action by parties against each other or action by Government agencies against parties to the matter.

(C) A person be appointed to help the drafting of the Private Bill and to conduct negotiations with parties concerned to arrive at various ancillary agreements to ensure an even handed outcome in the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Signed by the Petitioners this 24th day of November 1995

PARA.TAB: Senator BELL—I would point out that this is an unusual petition in that it asks that the Senate take action to introduce a private bill, something which has not been done before. I say these words just to draw attention to what this petition does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I give notice that 15 sitting days after today I shall move that the following delegated legislation be disallowed:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Plant Breeder's Rights Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1995 No 290
2.Air Navigation (Aircraft Engine Emissions) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1995 No 277
3.Lotteries Commission Act (W.A.)(C.I.)(Amendment) Ordinance 1995, Ordinance No 4 of 1995 of the Territory of Christmas Island
4.Occupational Health and Safety (Asbestos) Ordinance 1995, Ordinance No 5 of 1995 of the Territory of Christmas Island
5.Occupational Health and Safety (Asbestos) Ordinance 1995, Ordinance No 3 of 1995 of the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include the dual capacity of a minister, possible invalid retrospectivity, wide delegation of legislative power, discretions which may not be subject to merits review, strict liability offences, reversal of the usual onus of proof and the requirement to provide information which appears to be a breach of privacy. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee and the usual end of sitting statement about the work on the committee and a statement about the Approved Occupational Clothing Guidelines made under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The summary and statements read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Plant Breeder's Rights Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1995 No.290

SPEECH.PARA: These Regulations provide for the licensing of authorised testing establishments and for refunds of fees and insert some new fees.
New regulation 3A provides that the Secretary may authorise an establishment to conduct test growing. This appears to be an important discretion which could have commercial implications.

New regulation 4 gives the Secretary a discretion to refund or remit fees in specific circumstances although it appears that the intention is that the Secretary must refund or remit fees in those circumstances.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on whether AAT review is available for these discretions

PARA.EMPHASIS: Air Navigation (Aircraft Engine Emissions) Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1995 No.277

SPEECH.PARA: These Regulations regulate engine fuel venting requirements and smoke and gaseous emission requirements.

The Regulations provide for AAT review of the discretion to grant a permit exempting aircraft from provisions of the legislation. However, there does not appear to be any express provision under which decisions about conditions or times of exemptions are reviewable.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on the provision of such review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Territory of Christmas Island Lotteries Commission Act 1990 (W.A.)(C.I.) (Amendment) Ordinance 1995 No.4 of 1995

SPEECH.PARA: The Ordinance amends the functions of the Commission, provides for a levy on interstate lotteries or pools and provides that the Minister may enter into an agreement for collection of the levy by a State or Territory.
Under a number of the amendments, the Minister appears to act both as Minister and Commission. The Ordinance also operated retrospectively to 1 July 1995.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on the operation of the dual function of the Minister and whether the retrospectivity was valid.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Occupational Health and Safety (Asbestos) Ordinance 1995 Ordinance No.3 of 1995 of the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands Occupational Health and Safety (Asbestos) Ordinance 1995 Ordinance No.5 of 1995 of the Territory of Christmas Island

SPEECH.PARA: These Ordinances regulate the use and handling of asbestos in workplaces on the Cocos and Christmas Islands.
The provisions in the Ordinances are the same for both Territories. The Committee noted the following matters:
(a)a wide delegation of the Minister's powers;
(b)significant discretions with commercially valuable connotations with no apparent review by the AAT;
(c)a number of strict liability offences which seem to be committed even if the person has not received a notice;
(d)an offence without an apparent penalty;
(e)reversal of the usual onus of proof in relation to various statements that may be in a complaint relating to an offence;
(f)a fee for an application for a licence as an asbestos removalist without any explanation; and
(g)the requirement for the asbestos removalist to supply information which would appear to be a breach of privacy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances Statement on work of Committee during the Spring Sittings 1995
Overview

SPEECH.PARA: During the present sittings the Committee scrutinised the usual large number of disallowable legislative instruments tabled in the Senate, made under the authority of scores of parent Acts administered through virtually every Department of State. Almost every legislative scheme relies on delegated legislation to provide the administrative details of programs set out in broad policy in parent Acts which authorise such delegated legislation.

The Committee acts on behalf of the Senate to scrutinise each of these instruments to ensure that they conform to the high standards of parliamentary propriety and personal liberties which the Senate applies to Acts. If the Committee detects any breach of these standards it writes to the Minister or other law-maker in respect of the apparent defect, asking that the instrument be amended or an explanation provided. If the breach appears serious then the Chairman of the Committee gives notice of a motion of disallowance in respect of the instrument. This allows the Senate, if it wishes, to disallow the instrument. This ultimate step is rarely necessary, however, as Ministers almost invariably take action which satisfies the Committee.

As usual, by the end of the sittings Ministers have given the Committee undertakings to amend many provisions in different instruments or parent Acts to meet its concerns, reflecting a continuing high level of cooperation from Ministers in its non-partisan operations. The Committee is grateful for this cooperation.

During the sittings the Committee scrutinised 879 instruments, which is an historically high number. Of these, 199 were statutory rules, which are generally better drafted and presented than other series of delegated legislation. The other 680 instruments were the usual heterogeneous collection of different series.

Each of the 879 instruments was scrutinised by the Committee under its four principles, or terms of reference, which are included in the Standing Orders. There were 96 prima facie defects or matters worthy of comment in those 879 instruments. The defects are described below under each of the four principles.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principle (a)

SPEECH.PARA: Is delegated legislation in accordance with the statute?
The principle is interpreted broadly by the Committee to include not only technical invalidity, but also every other aspect of parliamentary propriety.

Under s.48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 an instrument to which that provision applies is void if it prejudicially affects any person apart from the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth authority. The Explanatory Statement for one instrument advised that it operated retrospectively to 1 July 1995 to provide continuity for agreements in respect of gambling activities which expired on 30 June 1995. The Committee asked whether any person was disadvantaged by this, whether any activities were conducted without legal authority after 30 June, whether there was a legal hiatus after that date, and whether any person could have avoided a contract after that date. Another instrument, which was made on 26 September 1995, purported to forbid specified activities from 1 January 1995. The Explanatory Statement for another instrument advised that it did not operate retrospectively. This would have been the case if s.48(2) applied from the date of making an instrument, but it applies from the date of gazettal, which was 14 days later. Two other instruments did not notify the date of gazettal, although both provided for this to be done. On the other hand, the Explanatory Statement for another instrument advised that its retrospectivity was not prejudicial, although no retrospectivity was evident on its face, while another instrument was made on a date later than it was gazetted.

Under s.49A of the Acts Interpretation Act an instrument to which that provision applies may incorporate provisions of an Act or delegated legislation in force from time to time, but may only incorporate other material as in force when the instrument takes effect. The Committee ascertains that such incorporations are valid. One instrument incorporated an instrument made under a specified provision of an Act, with no indication of date of making, heading, or any other identifying reference. Another instrument incorporated a Schedule published by the Department, again with no reference to a date. Another incorporated a government strategy and other packages and initiatives, with no indication of the effect of changes to those programs. Another provided for a list of superannuation schemes and incorporated any future changes to the names of the schemes.

The Committee raised other aspects of validity. For instance, subdelegation of legislative power without express statutory authority is generally invalid. Two instruments subdelegated authority to determine conditions of service. It was not clear whether provisions in another instrument were intended to be legislative, in which case they would have been invalid, or administrative. Another instrument may not have complied with mandatory conditions required by the enabling Act. Another was made under the wrong provision, with the Explanatory Statement also advising that it was made under the same wrong provision.

Drafting of delegated legislation should be of the same standard as that of Acts. The Committee raised a number of apparent drafting defects. One instrument included obsolete expressions such as laundryman and kitchenman. Another may have been unnecessarily complex. Another provided for an offence but did not provide for a penalty. Another was numbered incorrectly. Another provided for the continuation of a provision which was a legal nullity. An Explanatory Statement included wrong references to legislative requirements.

Other instruments may have affected parliamentary propriety. One provided for the Minister to act in a dual capacity as Minister and as the Lotteries Commission, a number of provisions giving the Minister power to approve his or her own decisions. In another case there was an apparent delay of some years in a statutory requirement to make an instrument as soon as practicable. Another instrument did not provide criteria for the appointment of members of an authority which had considerable powers. Another instrument, made to correct an inadvertent error which affected members of the public, took 10 months to make. Another instrument provided for the Minister to delegate important powers to any person at all. Another instrument did not provide for any delegation, even although this appeared necessary. Numbers of instruments did not include a system of numbering or citation, which may be confusing to users.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principle (b)

SPEECH.PARA: Does delegated legislation trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties?

The Committee interprets this principle in the broadest way, to include every aspect of personal rights. During the sittings the Committee detected the following possible defects in delegated legislation.

Provisions of delegated legislation should not operate harshly or unfairly. One instrument provided for an application affecting business operations to be received within three days of the date upon which the instrument was made. Another provided for certain Commonwealth employees to elect to "contract out" of new beneficial leave rights in some areas in order to avoid new detrimental leave provisions in another area. In this case the Committee asked for how long the elections would operate and when it was intended that employees should come under the new beneficial provisions. Another instrument provided for people to comply with an October 1995 publication of the Department from 1 December 1995. In this case the Committee asked what notice and publicity the new publication had received.

Offence provisions should be reasonable. One instrument provided for a number of offences punishable by fines of $50,000 to be heard by a court of summary jurisdiction. Some of those offences, punishable by such large fines, were strict liability offences. Some of these strict liability offences were inconsistent with similar offences which did not involve strict liability. For instance, some offences were committed if a person did not comply with an issued notice while others were guilty only if they did not comply with an issued notice which was actually received. Another provision reversed the usual onus of proof in relation to various statements in the complaint relating to an offence.

Fees and charges set by delegated legislation should be reasonable and their basis explained by the Explanatory Statement. One instrument doubled virtually all fees without explanation, in one case to $20,000. Another set a new licence fee at $2,600, again without explanation.
Retrospective provisions, even if valid, should not be unusual or unexpected. One instrument provided for retrospective operation from 1992 of aspects of a public sector superannuation scheme.

The Committee also protects personal privacy. One instrument provided for the mandatory inclusion of the date of birth of certain employees on a list, although this did not appear to be necessary for the purposes of the list.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principle (c)

SPEECH.PARA: Does delegated legislation make rights unduly dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to independent review of their merits?

Many instruments of delegated legislation provide for Ministers, statutory office holders and other public officials to exercise discretions. The Committee believes that such discretions should be as narrow as possible, include objective criteria to limit and guide their exercise, and include review of the merits of decisions by an external, independent tribunal, which would normally be the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Committee scrutinies closely instruments which provide for discretions which could adversely affect business activities. The Explanatory Statement for one instrument advised that certain companies would be required to report regularly to a government agency to demonstrate compliance with a standard. The instrument itself did not, however, appear to provide for this, or for review of an adverse decision by the agency. Another instrument provided for review of a decision by a surveyor employed by a government agency. The Committee noted that the Minister had statutory authority to give directions to the agency and suggested that AAT review, at least of the surveyor's decision, may be appropriate. Another instrument provided for AAT review of a decision not to grant or to revoke a permit, but not of a decision to impose conditions on a permit. One instrument provided for a discretion to refund fees where it appeared that the legislative intent was to give a refund in all relevant cases. Another provided a discretion to refund although the Explanatory Statement advised that a policy decision to return money on an agreed basis had been agreed with industry representatives. The Explanatory Statement for another advised that the effect of a discretion was ambulatory in effect, but the instrument itself did not provide for review of an adverse decision.

Other discretions affecting business which may not have provided for merits review included decisions to suspend a subsidy payment, to decide whether something was outside a person's control and to grant a licence.

Internal review of the merits of administrative decisions is usually not as satisfactory as external review by an independent body. One instrument provided only for review by the Minister. Even if the Minister could not delegate this power it may not have been satisfactory for the Minister to review decisions of the Department which he or she administers or of authorities within the Minister's portfolio. Another instrument provided not only for the Minister to review decisions which could affect business, but also provided for the Minister to delegate this power of review to any person at all.

The Committee also scrutinies closely instruments which provide for apparently unreviewable discretions which may affect personal rights. One such instrument provided for a discretion to decide whether a person was financially disadvantaged and another for a discretion to alter individual accrued superannuation benefits. Another provided for decisions relating to programs for the long term unemployed, whether a person was affected by a decision not to release a forest coupe, whether a person had unreasonably delayed taking certain action and whether a person had taken reasonable steps.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principle (d)

SPEECH.PARA: Does delegated legislation contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment?

The Committee does not raise this principle as often as its other three principles. Nevertheless, it is a principle which goes to the heart of parliamentary propriety and complements the first principle, that an instrument should be in accordance with the statute.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Approved Occupational Clothing Guidelines made under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee wishes to report briefly to the Senate on its scrutiny of the Approved Occupational Clothing Guidelines, which provide for employee income tax deductibility of such clothing. The Guidelines, which affect great numbers of Australian wage and salary employees and which also have an effect on the national revenue, were not of the quality which the Senate would expect from legislation made by the executive under the authority of an Act of Parliament.

The Guidelines were made under section 51AL of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which provides that expenditure incurred by an employee in relation to a non-compulsory uniform or wardrobe is not tax deductible unless the clothing was entered on a Register kept by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. The section also required the Minister to formulate Guidelines setting out criteria for the entry of clothes on the Register. The first set of Guidelines came into effect on 1 September 1993.

The present set of Guidelines amended the old Guidelines in respect of a number of matters. The new Guidelines were made by the Minister on 7 June 1995 with no express commencement date, although the Explanatory Statement did advise that transitional provisions then in force expired on 30 June 1995. The Guidelines consisted of 57 consecutively numbered clauses, some of which were in italics, some not in italics and some in both italics and non-italics. Some of the clauses were also partly in bold. A Note at the start of the Guidelines stated that the material in italics was explanatory only and did not form part of the Guidelines. Nevertheless, clause 3, in italics, provided:
"3. These Guidelines supersede those of 1 September 1993 and are effective as of 7 June 1995. The changes in these Guidelines are not retrospective."

The Guidelines were, however, subject to s.48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, under which an instrument has no effect if, before gazettal, the instrument purports to affect rights or impose liabilities on any person other than the Commonwealth. The Committee ascertained that the Guidelines had not been gazetted until 21 June 1995, so it appeared that the Guidelines may have been void for prejudicial retrospectivity. There was also the advice in the Explanatory Statement which appeared to state that the old Guidelines were in force up to 30 June 1995. The Committee raised these concerns with the Minister. The Committee also gave a protective notice of disallowance of the Guidelines, in order to preserve its options.

The Minister advised that the new Guidelines were made to take account of concerns from employers and uniform suppliers that the original Guidelines were difficult to apply. The new Guidelines would make it easier for genuine corporate uniforms or wardrobes to be admitted to the Register and so gain tax deductibility. For instance, the maximum number of colours and shades that could be used in a design was increased from five to eight, the minimum size of corporate identifiers on accessories was reduced and there was greater flexibility for differing uniforms where the employer maintains separate public identities. Another clause which provided that single items of occupational clothing, other than full body garments, would not be admitted to the Register, merely stated in another way the equivalent clauses in the original Guidelines.

The Minister further advised, however, that there was one minor area where the new Guidelines were more strict than the original ones. Corporate identifiers must now be permanently affixed in a different way. The Minister advised that this difference had not, in practice, affected adversely the rights of any applicant seeking admission to the Register. This is because the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, which administers the Guidelines, did not reject any applications dated between 7 June and 21 June 1995 which would have satisfied the original Guidelines but not the new ones. Also, any applications approved between those two dates which would have satisfied the new Guidelines but not the old, would be eligible for tax deductibility.

The Minister then advised that the Guidelines had actually commenced on gazettal on 21 June 1995. This was because the paragraph in the published text of the Guidelines which stated that they commenced on 7 June 1995, was expressed to be explanatory only and was thus not part of the Guidelines proper. The Minister therefore advised that both from a technical legal viewpoint and in practice the old Guidelines continued to operate until 21 June 1995, and that the difference between the date on which the new Guidelines were expressed to take effect and the date of notification in the Gazette had no prejudicial impact upon the rights or liabilities of any person.

The Committee agreed to accept the Minister's advice and to remove its notice of motion of disallowance. The Committee agreed, however, that the situation was far from satisfactory. The Minister expressly advised that the published commencement date for the operation of tax deductibility for occupational clothing was wrong, which is an undesirable outcome for such an important document ultimately affecting large numbers of working Australians. The Committee also noted the Minister's advice that no person was actually disadvantaged, but observed that this appeared to be because for two weeks in the last month of the financial year the TCFDA apparently administered both the old and new Guidelines simultaneously, albeit applying only the relevant beneficial provisions of both sets of Guidelines. The Committee noted that this generosity was not universal in taxation matters.

The Committee's scrutiny of the Guidelines illustrates how the Committee operates to carry out the mandate of the Senate to ensure that delegated legislation is of high quality. In the present case the Guidelines, while valid, left something to be desired from the viewpoint of sound public administration. The Committee makes a special statement whenever it considers that there is an aspect of its scrutiny on which the Senate should be more closely informed and the Approved Occupation Clothing Guidelines are such a matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Summary of Parliamentary Consideration of Amendments to Therapeutic Goods Act, 7.11.95
29 March 1995

Amendments to the above Act were introduced into House of Representatives as part of Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill No. 1 of 1995 which also had amendments to other Acts including the Child Care Rebate Act.
House of Representatives passed the above Bill.
8 June 1995
Second Reading and Committee stages proceeded in the Senate with questions being raised on a range of completely different areas contained in the Bill.
9 June 1995

Senate returned the Bill to House of Representatives as a divided Bill so as to ensure that disparate matters contained in the Bill were dealt with in separate Bills. The decision of the Senate to divide the Bill was taken without dissent.
20 September 1995
The Government introduced into the House of Representatives the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1995.
28 September 1995
The Bill was passed by House of Representatives.
16 October 1995
The Bill, retitled Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1995 (No. 2), was read a first time in the Senate.
19 October 1995

The Government sought to have the Bill dealt with in the lunchbreak. Senator Harradine stated the lunchbreaks were for Bills which were non-controversial. This matter was clearly controversial between the House of Representatives and the Senate since the House of Representatives had failed to deal with the divided Bill. If the Government wished to have the measure debated then it should list it as a priority Bill.
NOTE:

When the House of Representatives received the 9 June message from the Senate it could have, on the next sitting day, debated the measures and sent them back to the Senate which would then have dealt with them prior to 30 June 1995. The Government is entirely responsible for the consequent four month delay up until 16 October. It is responsible for the delay since then because it could have listed this matter for debate at the usual time of Government Business and the Senate would have had to deal with the matter. Senator Harradine has made clear previously his concerns with the Therapeutic Goods Administration and no doubt would want to pursue these concerns whenever legislation of this nature arises. Had the Government chosen to bring the matter forward at the usual time and not cause the delays this would have been over and done with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you might ask: why has the government delayed debate on this bill and not given it proper priority, even since October this year? The government knew that whenever the Therapeutic Goods Administration Bill came before this chamber I would be raising the very serious issue of a breach of undertaking given by the Therapeutic Goods Administration and the Department of Health at the time in respect of RU486 and abortifacients. Those undertakings were given as far back as 1988. Since the government will not deliver those undertakings which were acknowledged by the former minister, Senator Richardson, as having been breached, I intend to ensure, by way of amendment, that something is done about it and that proper ministerial responsibility is placed on the minister concerned.

PARA.TAB: That is not appropriate for debate at this point in time, but I think I have made the point that there have been long delays in the parliamentary consideration of this matter. I know the opposition is concerned about those delays. I am certainly concerned about those delays. It is on the government's shoulders to ensure that those delays are not countenanced any further and that the matter comes up for consideration at a time which would enable the bill to pass with the amendments, hopefully prior to the end of this session.

I urge the Senate to vote accordingly. I admit there are other urgent bills and other people might have other priorities but, for me at least, I believe this matter, because of the long delay, ought to be given some higher priority than it has at present.

Motion (by Senator Bourne) proposed:
That the Senate—

(b)expresses:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have in front of me the original form of the motion that was circulated in the chamber today. I am not sure whether or not it is up to date. If Senator Bourne agrees that this is the motion before us, I will move an amendment to it. My amendment would be that we delete the words `and again prove the illegitimacy of its occupation of Tibet' from the motion.
—The motion I have proposed is the amended motion.

—I thank Senator Bourne for clarifying that the motion is in the form that I wish it to be in. It has been government, opposition and Australia's policy for decades to recognise the government of the People's Republic of China in Beijing and recognise that Tibet is one of the provinces of China. It is appropriate that those words have been omitted from the motion because otherwise that element of the motion would have been contrary to the standing policies that I have just referred to.

PARA.TAB: The only other remark I wish to make about the substantive motion relates to the word `only' in that part of the motion which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . support for the candidate recognised by His Holiness the Dalai Lama as being the only legitimate Panchen Lama . . .

I sympathise entirely with religious freedom and with the terms of this motion, but I do not believe the Senate of Australia is in a position to pontificate that there is only one religious heir to the deceased Panchen Lama. We would be trespassing upon the religious freedoms of the Tibetan people by saying that there is only one possible heir. I draw back from that arrogance and leave my remarks as they stand in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Neither the Chinese government nor any foreign country should be endorsing or disendorsing any religious decision made by the Tibetan people. I recognise that the Dalai Lama is the religious head of the Tibetan people. I am aware that there were at least 20 candidates considered by the monks to be the new Panchen Lama and that there were four finalists. I draw back from the arrogance of this Senate in choosing between those candidates. That should be left entirely to the appropriate religious authorities in Tibet.
