SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)that the War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague has insufficient resources to bring to justice a satisfactory number of the perpetrators of war crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia, and

(ii)comments by the acting deputy prosecutor of the War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague, Mr Graham Blewett, that war criminals from the former Yugoslavia are presently in Australia, and that Australia should initiate its own investigations and prosecute war criminals who are found in Australia; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Australian Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to commence work immediately on a legislative regime that will provide for the bringing to justice of the perpetrators of murder, rape and the destruction of cultural property in the former Yugoslavia, and
(ii)to establish immediately a special investigations unit to investigate and prosecute these crimes in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is no longer just an observer to the events unfolding in the former Yugoslavia. We are now a central player. Not only has Australia been chosen as a favourite destination for nearly 14,000 refugees from the war zone, but hundreds of Australians who left to fight in the civil war are now beginning to return home. The Refugee Council has recently stated that it is absolutely impossible with our screening procedures to prevent war criminals coming in with those refugees.

PARA.TAB: Australia is therefore not just becoming a haven for witnesses to atrocities; it is fast becoming a refuge for those who have carried out the atrocities. The refugee community is well aware of stories of their former tormentors being seen in the psychiatrist's waiting room, at the English language class, at the school gate, at the shops and at the markets. These rumours are supported by the special prosecutor to the International War Crimes Tribunal in Holland, Mr Graham Blewett, who has said that the existence of war criminals in Australia is not a likelihood; it is a reality.

So what is Australia doing about this problem? Australia has signed an agreement that allows us to send people accused of war crimes to be tried before the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague. But, with just two trial chambers and trials lasting up to two months, the tribunal will process a maximum of eight trials a year or only about 100 cases in the five years it is expected to run. It was for this reason that Mr Blewett has encouraged individual countries, including Australia, to establish their own investigations and prosecutions. A spokesman for the Bosnian Council of New South Wales, Dr Dzemal Hadzismajlovic, supports this call. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: We want to see the Australian government establish reliable mechanisms to prevent the entry of war criminals into Australia. We want to see the Australian government conduct serious investigations of the presence of war criminals.

I believe the Australian people do not want such people living in our community as if nothing has happened. Do we really want to risk people continuing to act out their hatred in Australia? In 1987 a special investigations unit was established by the Commonwealth to investigate and prosecute World War II criminals in Australia. There were massive inquiries. Amongst the 841 people who were the subject of such inquiries, 261 had died, 247 could not be located and in 191 cases the allegations could not be substantiated, mainly due to lack of evidence. The unit's special investigator, Mr Robert Greenwood QC, said:

If we had held war crimes trials when we should have, it would have been a completely different story. The accused would have been young to middle aged men: the witnesses memories would have been fresh and the documentary evidence easily retrieved.

I believe that Australia should learn from these mistakes. We should not make them again. The criminals have gained ground and the innocent in the Bosnian conflict who have fled are left in no-man's-land. In this respect, the whole evil machinations and deeds will have had some success. The haters will have won. The big job for us in Australia is to make sure the haters do not win here. I commend to the Senate the motion I have moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not imagine for a minute that there is a person in this chamber who would disagree with the intent of the motion moved by the Australian Democrats. Nobody wants Australia to be a hiding place for war criminals from any sphere of conflict, including that of former Yugoslavia. Unlike our position in World War II, where graphic reports of the war were not as frequent as they have been in the war in the former Yugoslavia and even in the Vietnam War, for example, we have seen daily on our television sets the consequences of the devastation that war brings.

PARA.TAB: I raise that point to indicate that I think there is a much greater awareness now in this generation than there was in the past of the atrocities that are committed, sadly, during a war, of the desire to do something about that and certainly of the desire not to allow Australia to be some sort of hiding place. That is obviously something everyone would agree with.

However, it is another matter to move from the sentiment of a motion that says, `Yes, that's a goal that we want to achieve,' to say that the detail of the motion is how you would want to get to that end. I note, for example, that the Democrats say, `The Senate should call on the Australian government to commence work on a legislative regime that will provide for bringing to justice the perpetrators of murder, rape and the destruction of cultural property in former Yugoslavia.' I do not think you could draw a broader net if you possibly tried.

I am sure Senator Spindler understands that there might be murders completely unrelated to war. Certainly, sadly, it is the experience in every nation that there are rapes completely unrelated to any particular war. While this is certainly not a matter about which we want to jest in any way, to have a crime such as the destruction of cultural property seems to me to be a lawyer's superannuation fund, to say the least, in that it is an inadequately described offence, if I can put it in that sense.

We agree very strongly that Australia should not allow itself to be a hiding place for these people who commit these atrocious crimes and that we have a role to play in bringing these people to justice. Senator Spindler rightly pointed out the moves that were made last year to contribute to that. He may be right when he says that the moves are not enough and that there is not enough funding and capacity so that the war criminals can be dealt with as swiftly as they should be in The Hague.

He is certainly right when he points out the difficulties that the special investigations unit, established in the late 1980s, had because of the time delay. There was an enormous amount of extra effort required in checking and rechecking evidence and needing more people to back up a point because of the time delay. Evidence goes stale; memories fail. That is not so much of a problem now, and he is right in saying that these matters have to be attended to as swiftly as possible. But that does not mean that we should necessarily set up a special investigations unit now in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do?

—There may be a number of other ways in which we can cooperate and contribute. For example, following the upcoming election—which I expect will be in February or March—one thing we will most definitely do is upgrade the screening process. It is one thing to say, `Let's chase the perpetrators of these crimes.' I wholeheartedly agree with that. But there are also some other steps that can be taken. Let us try to put up greater barriers to ensure that a lesser number of these people get in and that a lesser number of them ever hope to attain Australian citizenship.
—They're here now.

—Yes. Senator Spindler, you have made your points. But since you so rudely interject, I will respond. You say that they are here now. But surely you do not deny that there may be more to come. Also, presumably you would not disagree with setting up a much better screening program than already exists and perhaps targeted to this particular area.

PARA.TAB: Under this government we have seen—as I am sure you would be aware, Senator Spindler, through your experience on the Legal and Constitutional References Committee—completely inadequate screening processes for people of a criminal kind coming into this country; those who shift in and out quite freely to engage in their criminal activities. They are simply not doing the job and they drastically need to be improved.

In summary, we support the intent of the motion. We do not believe there would be anybody in the nation at large, let alone this parliament, who alone would disagree with the intent of the motion that war criminals should be brought to justice—and brought to justice as swiftly as possible. We do not support the motion primarily because we believe it is inappropriately drafted, and that it is not clear yet that it is appropriate for us to set up a special investigations unit here.

But we do acknowledge that there are other things that need to be done and raise, just as one example in the limited time, vastly improved screening processes. I understand, Senator Spindler, that that does not deal with the people who are already here. But it does do something about stopping any more of these people taking advantage of us and using our country as a hiding place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved by Senator Spindler is timely. But I wonder whether all of the matters that should be considered in this area have, in fact, been considered.

PARA.TAB: The human rights subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is currently conducting public hearings on the issue of former Yugoslavia. We already have had a number of pieces of public and private information relating to war criminals and, indeed, the need to enhance the standing and the resources of the War Crimes Tribunal. That obviously has been acknowledged by people right across the board. Of course, there are some who have not done so but, generally speaking, that has been the gravamen of much of the evidence that we have received.

We have not yet concluded that hearing although, from memory, I think we have concluded the public hearings and the report is being written. I know that with these sorts of things it is important to bell the cat at a particular stage. But, whilst I appreciate what Senator Spindler has said, I would recommend to him and to other members of the Senate who are not members of the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to perhaps take cognisance of the report when it is brought down. I am sure that that report will be properly and adequately sourced, and its conclusions will be well founded.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are talking about here is the best way to achieve shared goals. There is not a contest in this chamber about whether people who have committed war crimes should be prosecuted; it is a question of how, in the circumstances of the former Yugoslavia, we should best proceed.

PARA.TAB: Unlike the previous circumstances which we have confronted, we have a circumstance here where the international community, through the UN, has set up a specialist tribunal dedicated to investigating and prosecuting allegations of war crimes in the former Yugoslavia. Australia has been very strongly in support of the establishment of that tribunal. In fact, we were one of the very first to take legislative action in response to it. The International War Crimes Tribunal Act, which commenced only a few months ago in August, enables Australia to fully assist and comply with requests from the tribunal. It provides for various forms of assistance, including, if necessary, the taking of evidence in Australia for tribunal purposes, the surrendering of suspects in Australia to the tribunal for trial and the sitting of the tribunal in Australia if it so desires.

I think the key elements of what might need to be done in Australia, or by Australia, are in place through the proper mechanism, in this instance the specialist UN tribunal. The government has established a good working relationship with the tribunal and we are in a position to respond quickly to requests for assistance and to pass on information about sightings and follow them up. The tribunal has recently commended the Australian government for the excellent cooperation and assistance it provides.

I am aware, and the government is aware, that there have been recent allegations of sightings of war criminals in Australia, and we must all accept that it is at least possible that some alleged war criminals may have entered Australia. It is virtually impossible to totally preclude this, especially in circumstances where the individuals may have gone to great lengths to create false identities. However, a substantial amount of effort is being devoted to this task through the work of an interdepartmental committee which maintains an active and systematic approach to identifying possible war criminals who may seek to enter Australia.

We as a government have procedures in place to ensure that the opportunities for suspected war criminals to enter Australia are minimised. We also have a comprehensive legislative regime and administrative procedures to ensure that appropriate steps can be taken if war criminals from the former Yugoslavia are in fact found to be here in Australia. This is a regime which was extensively debated in the parliament last year and earlier this year. That legislation was supported by the Australian Democrats, who expressed the desire, which I think we all share, to see war criminals published and noted that the prosecution of charged people should proceed as quickly and effectively as possible.

The most effective manner, in the view of the government, and I think correctly, to address war crimes allegations in relation to the former Yugoslavia is by way of the special tribunal set up by the international community to deal with these matters and to which the UN has devoted significant resources. It is suggested in this motion that the tribunal is insufficiently resourced. The resourcing of the tribunal is of course, at the end of the day, a matter for the UN General Assembly, but Australia has argued strongly in that forum for proper resourcing of the tribunal.Although there have been some difficulties in resolving budgetary issues, the tribunal is now up and running and is actively pursuing around 3,000 investigations.

Therefore, the proposal to establish a domestic regime for investigation and prosecution is, while I would not in any way doubt the good intentions lying behind it, fundamentally flawed. It would require, for example, a diversion of Australian resources away from the international tribunal to a domestic tribunal, where we would need to train specialist staff and develop contacts for investigations and where we would confront significant difficulties in gathering admissible evidence abroad and securing the cooperation of witnesses. We would confront the possibility of duplication of work between Australia and the tribunal, as Australia could be asked at any time to defer to the jurisdiction of the tribunal, and I think it would be appropriate that we gave priority to that. Difficult issues would arise as to the adequacy of existing legislation.

No-one is suggesting that the war crimes occurred in Australia. When we had to deal in different circumstances with suspected war criminals from World War II, the practical difficulties in mounting successful prosecutions for conduct engaged in outside Australia were made very clear. That would make investigations and trials practically impossible and prohibitively expensive.

I note that Justice Einfield, when recently giving evidence to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade human rights subcommittee—and this is to some extent what Senator Harradine was referring to—referred to the problems with the World War II prosecutions and the difficulties in trying to conduct trials in Australia. He noted that we have to be realistic about the limits of our legal system and that we should be helping duly constituted tribunals to do their job rather than setting ourselves up as a substitute international tribunal. I agree with Justice Einfield's observation that the proper role for Australia is servicing and helping to make successful the international war crimes tribunals established for these specific purposes.

This is not an analogous situation to the World War II special investigations unit. That was a controversial decision, but it was one that the government supported. It was an attempt worth making. In that case the government took the view that it was not prepared to extradite suspects to face trials in countries which were then behind the so-called Iron Curtain. Therefore we put in place mechanisms to permit trial of the offences in Australia because there was not an alternative mechanism to have those trials which was acceptable as a level of justice to the Australian government.
In these circumstances there is no such reluctance to extradite. We would be prepared to extradite—and the International War Crimes Tribunal Act makes explicit provision for such extradition.

The government considers it is not necessary or appropriate to set up a special investigations unit when adequate, effective and preferable mechanisms are already in place. A specialist unit—the tribunal—has been set up by the international community to bring justice to the perpetrators of war crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia. The Australian government fully supports this approach as being the most suitable way to deal with this issue.

The tribunal is fully operational, and Australia is totally committed to providing maximum assistance to the tribunal. Whilst almost everybody in Australia and everybody in this chamber would support the objective of ensuring that war criminals are dealt with effectively and strongly, it does not mean that anything we might do in that regard is justified. We have to work out the best way of achieving the proper and shared goals. The procedure is already in place for cooperation with the international tribunal. That remains the most effective way for Australia to act in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens—Senator Chamarette and I—feel, on balance, that we are unable to support this motion. A lot of issues are involved. There is a lot of information which is extremely difficult for us, from this distance, to make a decision on. We are not sure that an attempt to prosecute war criminals for events that are still occurring or have occurred in another country will in any way solve the problems in Australia. On balance, we are unable to support the motion.

—in reply—In response to some of the matters raised, let me say that I believe we should not let the technical drafting difficulties raised by Senator Vanstone stand in the way of the substantive issue. I appreciate what was said by Senator Harradine about the inquiry by the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I wonder how long it will take to get that report. Once again, I am concerned about the delay.

PARA.TAB: The statement by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) ignores the fact that the deputy prosecutor is an Australian. The Hague tribunal has requested Australia to assist because the deputy prosecutor is of the view that current procedures are inadequate and are not working effectively and that the resources are not there.

As for the matter of expending resources in Australia, I believe that is well within the framework of our responsibilities of law enforcement in Australia because we are talking about people being here, living as part of our community, who were those perpetrators. If the situation is—and I have not heard anyone dispute Mr Graham Blewett's allegations—that that process is not working well, then I believe it is our responsibility here in Australia to apprehend those people and, if it cannot be done in the Hague then, if necessary it should be done here. It is in the interests of our community and I believe it is also in the interests of the ethnic communities concerned who do not want these sorts of people living as part of their communities or as part of the Australian community.

I regret that at this stage there does not seem to be support for this motion. I advise the minister that I will certainly keep pursuing it. I will want to see evidence of the government's effectiveness in actually identifying, apprehending and extraditing those people who have been sighted in Australia by many people, eyewitnesses, who claim that these people are war criminals and have participated in those atrocities. I will be interested to see what the government's record on these matters will turn out to be.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in tabling the report of the operation of the Australian National Training Authority and its national strategy on vocational education and training, which was referred to the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee on 6 March 1995.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee recognises the importance of the partnership between the Commonwealth, states and territories in the establishment of ANTA three years ago. The agreement has enabled the considerable injection of Commonwealth funds, the so-called growth funds, into the vocational education and training sector. This sector over the previous 10 years, which was completely under the control of the states, had languished with lack of growth. What has happened in recent years has, I think, started to re-establish a proper balance between the higher education sector and the vocational education and training sector.

PARA.TAB: Evidence that the ANTA concept is a step forward did come out right across the hearings. No-one in any of the evidence suggested that we undo this arrangement and go back to the pre-ANTA situation. However, the committee recognises that while there has been progress in the first three years of ANTA's operations, a number of problems have been revealed with the way in which ANTA is going about its business. That does need finetuning and modification. To this end, the committee has made 20 recommendations for the improvement of the operation of the ANTA agreement.

The most important of these concerns the use of growth funds, the successful measurement of outcomes, the development of a national strategy and the role of industry. With regard to growth funds provided by the Commonwealth, the committee was very concerned to find that very little of the 20 per cent of funds that had been distributed, or supposed to have been distributed, on the basis of performance required by the agreement was actually taking place.

Much more than the 80 per cent of the funds intended for growth were being distributed by ANTA on a population basis. One of the unfavourable outcomes of this was it was disadvantaging the smaller states. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the full 20 per cent of VET funds be distributed as originally intended by the agreement on the basis of performance in relation to objectives of the agreement.

Further, in recognition of the difficulties that the smaller states and territories are likely to have, the committee recommends that the formula used in the allocation of growth funds be sufficiently flexible to take into account the particular characteristics of individual states and territories, particularly with respect to their size and population distribution. To encourage ANTA's national emphasis in the use of funds, the committee recommends that of the growth funds currently available, ANTA increase the proportion that is allocated to cooperative arrangements between the states in either curriculum development or rationalisation of training courses.

At the heart of the evidence taken in hearings was the vexed issue of the measurement of outcomes in comparing performance of state and territory systems in delivering vocational education and training. It is very important to know that states are maintaining effort when Commonwealth funding has been increased. However, the very crude state of the outcome measures means that no meaningful conclusion can be reached at this stage. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the Commonwealth parliament should extend beyond 1995 its recently relinquished power to intervene in cases where states and territories have failed to meet the obligations under the agreement and that ANTA set up a unit from within its existing staff for the express purpose of developing suitable outcome measures. This is still one of the great problems for resolution.

In this report, as in an earlier report on accountability of Commonwealth money in state-Commonwealth education agreements, which the committee tabled earlier this year, we discovered that it was very difficult to establish evidence one way or the other because of the way in which the various states—indeed, as we discovered, the way in which the Commonwealth government—collects statistics. Trying to get any meaningful information out of those statistics is very difficult because of the way they are collected. That is relating to inputs into education.

There is also the question—this is the crucial question—of outputs. That is really what you want to know. Is the money you are spending being effectively spent? Are you getting the outcomes that you are trying to achieve? Right across the whole system there has hardly been any work done on this. That is why we made this recommendation.

Senator Carr has been going on in many of these hearings about trying to prove whether effort has been maintained or not. Quite frankly, as someone who has some expertise in the use of statistics and education, you just cannot draw the conclusions that Senator Carr is drawing because of the inexact nature of the measurement system. In educational research the conclusions he has come to based on the data and the way the data is collected would be considered totally invalid. This was pointed out very forcefully in the hearings by Terry Moran, the head of ANTA. I invite people to look at Terry Moran's evidence on this matter because I think it puts paid to what Senator Carr had been saying well and truly. We do recognise as a committee that there is a need to develop such measures, particularly outcome measures—hence, our recommendation 6 on ANTA setting up a unit to bring this outcome about.

With regard to the national strategy in vocational education and training, the committee believes that there is much room for improvement in the process of consultation, particularly at the state and territory level, in the development of state training profiles. For this reason, the committee has recommended that ANTA devise improved mechanisms for the provision of advice to the state training authorities from various parts of industry, in particular, small business, from education and training providers and from individuals.

We did discover that the whole arrangements in ANTA were too narrowly focused and they did not take into account or work properly enough with the small business groups. They also did not really work properly enough with a broader range of educational provision that could be deemed not strictly vocational, but being in its very nature supportive of vocational training. We felt that with its funding of TAFE systems and adult community education, it would take a much broader view in what it included in its definition of `vocational'.

The other main recommendations respond to the way in which the ANTA board is set up. I understand what they were trying to do. They were not trying to get representatives from every group in the community to give this broad, comprehensive umbrella. But the feeling, after hearing the evidence, was that they have actually gone a bit too far the other way and that the work of the board would be very much enhanced if three groups in particular were represented. They should have an expert in vocational education and training as part of the board, and they do not have that at the moment. Representatives from the small business sector should be part of the board as well, because of the huge number of small businesses in this country. The other sector that we felt was neglected by the board's structure was rural and regional Australia; hence we have recommended accordingly.

I commend the report to the Senate. We feel, as I indicated at the beginning of my remarks, that the ANTA agreement has made considerable progress. It has put funding into this sector in a way that was very much needed. But at this point ANTA needs a little fine tuning in its representation and in its focus of effort. We believe the Commonwealth government, which has relinquished the power that it had for three years to step in and guide what happens in this agreement, should take up that power again, because we do not feel that ANTA is quite there. But if it acts on the recommendations we have made in this report, we believe vocational education and training in this country will be very well served. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee is a timely one. It is a report that indicates there is opportunity within the Senate committee system to do good work. This is not a view that I express on every occasion but I think this area demonstrates there are important questions that can be addressed. I think this inquiry differs from the disgraceful performance we saw with Bond University and a number of others. Once again, I thank the committee secretariat for their professionalism and hard work in providing such terrific assistance.

PARA.TAB: This report comes at a timely part of the proceedings in regard to discussions between the states and the Commonwealth. The current ANTA agreement is ending its term and we are entering into transitional arrangements which will see, through the COAG processes, new arrangements put in place. The Taylor review is due to report to the minister and will provide a very important policy base. This report that the committee has brought down will also provide a good policy base for discussion within government and, I hope, within the community at large.

This is also unusual in so far as the Labor senators and the Democrats through Senator Bell have come together to produce a minority report. So the majority report consists only of the Liberals, who have a natural majority on this committee. That must be understood. The Liberals had the opportunity to go much further than they have done here. They chose to reject those initiatives through the process. The simple reason is this: they have got an unfortunate, inherent vested interest in protecting a few lousy state governments which are absolutely obsessed with the destruction of the education system in this country. That is an enormous tragedy when we look at what is occurring in this country in terms of education.

Many issues were addressed in the Liberals' majority report—the confused roles of ANTA, the industry-led nature of it, the failure to coordinate between the different sectors, and the differences that exist regarding the main purpose of ANTA, which has now become not much more than a mechanism for the distribution of increasing levels of Commonwealth funding. In terms of that, the Commonwealth is now contributing 35 per cent of the total VET system in this country. A massive shift has occurred.

The problem with the majority report of this committee is that it does not go far enough. It identifies a problem and, like the Liberal Party in so many ways, hasn't got any solution and can't come up with the goods. It is all very well to point the finger. The real question in politics is, `What are we going do about it?' The real problem for the Liberal Party is that it does not know what to do about it, and that really is at the nub of this. The Liberal Party, unfortunately, has produced an anaemic, pale and undistinguished report. Its main problem is that it exhibits sins of omission.

Labor and Democrat senators are saying that there is a need to eliminate the unwieldy system of dual Commonwealth-state accountability mechanisms which allows the educational vandals in this country, like Jeff Kennett in Victoria, to smash what was once a very proud public system in such a way as to fundamentally undermine commitments that they have made through agreements and to demonstrate that they cannot really be trusted with the public dollar when it comes to education. The real problem is that they are now using Commonwealth dollars as a substitute for the appalling effort they are pursuing in Victoria.

We are suggesting that there needs to be a much more effective measure to ensure that the Commonwealth will is demonstrated in the VET system in this country. To that end, we are proposing that the Commonwealth ought to resume control of the VET system. We recommend that, if states can't come to the party in such an arrangement and if those administrative arrangements can't be put in place, the Commonwealth minister should resume the powers to intervene more effectively, and that would mean legislative change to the Australian National Training Authority Act 1992.

We are also saying that the focus of ANTA has to change. While it is a much better system than we have ever had, the focus has to change so that the educational component of education and training is given much greater emphasis. The narrow industry model in itself is not appropriate. There has to be proper consideration of much broader questions which go to the heart of a truly educated nation. Unfortunately, in recent times we have had an undue emphasis on the training notion. I see it in some ways as harking back to a 19th century notion of education which saw workers as nothing more than hands and did not seek the broader education of our population.

In that regard we maintain that there is a need for substantial changes there, that the Commonwealth ought to be directly represented on the board of ANTA and that there should be direct educational expertise on the board of ANTA. In that capacity there needs to be a much greater improvement in the management of ANTA in terms of its focus to ensure the states maintain effort and in terms of its philosophy in making sure it is a broader approach. In terms of its governance, both educational and administrative changes need to be made to ensure there is protection for those principles.

I think considerable attention has to be paid to the working conditions of teachers and employees in the VET system. The competitive tendering arrangements in TAFE have led to serious undermining of the quality provision of education in this country. So we are also suggesting there need to be improvements there.

Might I turn briefly to some of the remarks Senator Tierney made about my beloved state of Victoria and the notorious Kennett government. It was said that I have got some of these issues wrong; that somehow or another inputs were not necessarily related to outputs. What a silly notion! That means that the Liberals are prepared to essentially cover up for that economic and educational vandalism in Victoria which has seen $43 million taken out of the VET system in that state. Those are the state government's own figures. If it were not for the ANTA arrangements, cuts to the VET system would have been much greater.

The Commonwealth's intervention has of course sought to protect the people of Victoria. I think to some measure it has been successful. However, what is abundantly clear and now acknowledged by all is that Victoria has failed to maintain its effort and breached the agreement in financial terms. It has reduced its expenditure in 1995 and 1996 by $6.96 million and $6.84 million respectively. It is expected to breach that commitment in terms of recurrent expenditure in 1995 by $9.31 million.

It is all very well to suggest that things are hunky-dory in terms of the maintenance of effort. They clearly are not. As far as I am concerned, the provisions about the maintenance of effort are essentially a joke because they become defined and redefined in such a way as to become meaningless. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has expressed on many occasions grave reservations about the commitment by the states, particularly Victoria and South Australia, to the whole issue of their maintenance of effort and their commitment to a national scheme. That is really what it all boils down to: the states are prepared to enter into commitments if they think they will get more money. It is the old story about never get between a state premier and a bucket of money—a very dangerous course of action.

The Commonwealth has to acknowledge what the states are prepared to say but then enforce commitments legislatively to ensure they are honoured if we are to have a genuine national system of education and training in this country, genuine protection for the public dollar and genuine protection for the rights and obligations that citizens have to be involved in education. As far I am concerned, if fundamental social justice issues are to be protected, the Commonwealth will have to take strong measures to ensure that the states honour their word and do not sign agreements they have no intention of keeping. Unfortunately, it is a sorry state that that has occurred again and again in this area. When we go into the next phase, I trust that the Commonwealth is able—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This inquiry into the Australian National Training Authority is an important inquiry. It is important for the industry, those involved in training in Australia, those involved in education in Australia and the wider community. It is a pity the report, entitled Report of the inquiry into the Australian National Training Authority, had to arrive in two forms: a majority report, and a minority report which was endorsed by me and the Labor members.

PARA.TAB: I had difficulty because many parts of the committee's majority report rang true and were worthy of my support. In fact, I do support some of the recommendations. At the end of the day, the majority of the recommendations which were arrived at by me and the Labor members are the ones that expressed most closely the feeling that I had after participating in the inquiry.

This is a difficult area to participate in because, as those who are interested in this area would know, it is rife with acronyms and much jargon. This is perpetrated, I think, by a clique of information guardians. It is a bit hard to penetrate that to get into the issues—so much so that the report includes an appendix of acronyms, which occupies 1 1/2 pages. That makes interesting reading for anyone who is involved in this area.

I was uncertain about whether I could support recommendation 1 of the majority report, so I direct people's attention to that as being indicative of the problems that we have here. But I am, however, able to fully support recommendation No. 4. I think those who are listening would understand why this expresses some of the difficulty that I, as a Tasmanian senator, and others experienced in these areas. That recommendation of the committee states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the formula used in the allocation of growth funds be sufficiently flexible to take into account the particular characteristics of individual States and Territories especially with respect to size and distribution of population. Such a formula might include provision for special loadings.

I do not think I need to explain that any further. That is why we are member states of the Commonwealth—to make sure that the particular individual skills, abilities and traditions that we bring are recognised, and we are supported where the size of our population works as a disadvantage and an inability.

PARA.TAB: I interpolate here that I was part of a state government department at one stage which did not have the threshold of numbers able to encourage the training—and it was training—of building quantity surveyors in Tasmania. So we had to come to a special arrangement with a Victorian institute. It was at that time the RMIT. We had to make that arrangement so that we could have in our state the skills necessary, but we were not able to provide them in any of the Tasmanian technical institutions at the time. These are the sorts of things that, of course, are brought about by population limitations.
I support also recommendation 5, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that ANTA establish clearly the mechanisms by which State/Territory Training Authorities take account of the projections determined by NETTFORCE—
It is important to refer to appendix 1 to find out what that means—
and DEET's Area Consultative Committees in establishing State Training Profiles.

Some of those projections could be interpreted as being overstated and it is important to understand the mechanisms by which they are determined. Also, in a similar way, recommendation 7 asks that ANTA establish a reliable system of statistics. Of course, some of the debate that we have heard in the chamber this morning has been about which statistics are valid and how they ought to be taken into account. We all find difficulty when trying to interpret those statistics.

PARA.TAB: The other recommendation worthy of note is No. 17, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that schools explicitly contribute to the State Training Profiles and be given wider access to ANTA growth funds.

It is important also to note the minority report, which I supported. I draw attention to recommendation 7, which I will not read—senators can read that—and recommendation 8. I want to emphasise recommendation 9 because I have had some communication with ANTA personnel outside the proceedings of the committee, but also within the inquiry itself, which really asked a central question: what is the rationale behind some of the funding allocations that are made by ANTA, for example, funding allocated to develop a child-care traineeship in New South Wales when one already existed in Tasmania which had accreditation? Recommendation 9 states:

. . . that the National Vocational Education and Training System Agreement . . . be amended to require States and Territories to legislate the principles of the National Framework for the Recognition of Training . . . so that providers, enterprises and students are entitled to insist on national recognition of accreditation, registration and declaration decisions in any State.

This is so that there would be some consistency and transferability. The inquiry found that, to a large extent, duplication was inhibiting progress and development; it was also inhibiting initiatives. Of course, in an area which encompasses such a large part of our endeavours there will be some duplication and some petty, cross-sectional interests unable to reach a national agreement. But we felt—and I think the evidence was quite clear—that this was happening on far too many occasions and that there needed to be better coordination to resolve that.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry revealed other fundamental problems, and they included a lack of representation of small business and a lack of relevance of much of what industry based training was doing to small business. It also revealed a persistence with the notion that training is all that Australian workers need. Senator Carr was right to draw attention to that. The relevance of education, generic skills and also attitudinal aspects are very important because it is education on which we base the development of our ability to learn. Of course, when that is enhanced, then training becomes so much easier.

I felt at times that those participating and making decisions in these areas did not actually understand the distinction between training and education. Because of that, decisions have been made which overemphasise the mechanistic style of developing people's skills rather than enhancing people's capacity to learn and so develop their educational skills. That problem was revealed in the inquiry and, for that reason, I think it was important that the inquiry was conducted and that we take note of what was revealed.

The politics surrounding the inquiry were to be expected. We have to take some of that with a grain of salt. I think also that we have to remember that it is an area that engenders much passion. There is nothing wrong with that, provided that, at the end of the day, we produce a document and some recommendations which are noteworthy. I think we have done that. The inquiry can only be vindicated by the reading of the entire report, including the minority report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee on the examination of the annual reports of Telstra Corporation and the Australian Postal Corporation 1994-95, together with submissions and the Hansard transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the enormous workload today I would like to say only a few words on this report. These public assets are of enormous value. What strikes me as particularly important in the parliamentary process is the capacity of the parliament to examine these public corporations and to provide an opportunity for parliamentary representatives to question officials from these corporations in a way that makes them publicly accountable. That is the fundamental distinguishing feature between a public asset, a public business enterprise, and a private business. The enormous private power that is associated with private corporations in the telecommunications area means that we do not have a capacity to involve them in a parliamentary process.

PARA.TAB: It is very important for the Senate to be able to maintain this. Telstra and Australia Post make contributions in terms of the country's communications and technological advances—they provide enormous employment, they make a huge contribution to the public purse and they provide enormous investment because of their strategic place within the economy. For those reasons plus the issue of public accountability, it strikes me as an absolute abomination to talk of privatising these enterprises.

In the coming election, I welcome the opportunity to pursue that question with all the vehemence that we can muster. SPEECH.PARA: I will not delay the chamber too much. At the end of my speech I will, as Senator McMullan indicated, seek leave to incorporate a speech of Senator Ellison. Initially this was to be tabled as an order of the Senate under item 9 today, and we had been advised that there would not be much time to talk then. So Senator Ellison has provided me with a copy of a speech and it has been agreed by the minister, Senator McMullan, that that speech will be incorporated in Hansard. I will do that at the end of my speech.

PARA.TAB: The report of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Land Fund Matters covered some issues that were fairly controversial. The Senate this time last year and earlier this year debated at some great length—in fact I think it was the second or third longest debate in the history of the Senate—the establishment of a land fund.

Certain senators, particularly the Western Australian Greens, the coalition senators and on some issues Senator Harradine, had a range of concerns about the establishment of the land fund. In particular one of those concerns was the establishment of what has come to be known as a parallel program, and that is a system that allows a transition between the existing ATSIC land acquisition and management program and the newly formed Indigenous Land Corporation program.

As told to the Senate by the government and reported by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech, that structure would allow a transition between the existing land acquisition and management programs for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the scheme established for the land fund. There were concerns raised about that parallel program from various places, not the least of which was from the Northern Territory government and the Chief Minister at that time, Marshall Perron.

When the ILC was finally established with the passing of the so-called Land Fund Bill in this place earlier this year, ATSIC held a board meeting and, at that board meeting, made a decision to appropriate or apportion a significant majority—in fact, in excess of 85 per cent—of all of their land acquisition moneys into the Northern Territory for the next two years. That is something like $20 million out of a total of $24 million to be made available for purchases in the Northern Territory, virtually to the total exclusion of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders across the rest of Australia.

Senator Chamarette, from the WA Greens, a number of other senators and I raised concerns about this, as did indeed some of the government ministers. In fact there was a debate in this place on that. I think both Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Bob Collins expressed surprise at the decision and some concern. The Senate sought, on the motion of Senator Chamarette, to find out some of the facts pertaining to the decision made by ATSIC. We had certain documents tabled under an order of the Senate.

Subsequent to that, or about the same time, a number of other Aboriginal organisations—specifically the New South Wales Land Council, the FAIRA organisation and the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre—challenged the decision of ATSIC on administrative grounds in the Federal Court. Of course, subsequent to that, the Federal Court found that ATSIC had erred at law and overturned the decision. Of course, the situation now is that ATSIC is reconsidering it.

The Senate chose to establish the select committee, whose report I now table, to investigate the decision-making processes leading up to that. I do not want to canvass too much of the content of the report. It is the subject of a minority report, which has been signed by Senator Kernot, Senator Childs and Senator Chris Evans, who is on leave at the moment and who has associated himself with that report.

The majority report makes a number of conclusions. Firstly, just for the record, the committee found that the actions of ATSIC had been inappropriate, that they had led to discrimination against Aboriginals in other parts of Australia—and it made a number of recommendations. Initially, it recommended that, in dealing with Aboriginal land matters, there should be someone in federal government with responsibility for this area. We found, particularly with the native title legislation and the establishment of the land fund, that there were no less than five ministers, including the Prime Minister, who at some stage took some responsibility for these decisions. Clearly, no-one had any specific ministerial responsibility for that area, so we made that as one of the key recommendations.

We also said that there needs to be an improvement in the public transparency and accountability of these ATSIC board decisions. One of the great concerns this committee found was that many of the Aboriginal organisations, individuals and communities found it very hard to discover exactly what the board had decided—and the committee found itself faced with the same problem on a number of occasions during the inquiry.

Evidence was given to the committee by ATSIC officers and, indeed, on some occasions by the chairperson of ATSIC, Ms O'Donoghue, which would lead us to one point of view only to find out that written evidence, such as minutes of board meetings, may indeed be contradictory. Of course, we then had to go through the tedious process of trying to reconcile various bits of evidence which, on their face, seemed to involve some fundamental conflicts.

The committee also found on this matter of transparency and accountability that some of the records of various board meetings, tapes of the crucial ATSIC board meeting and handwritten notes of a consultative meeting with the Prime Minister held in June 1994 had been lost. We found this very regrettable. Indeed, evidence was given to the committee that some of the minutes of the crucial ATSIC board meeting were incorrect.

Evidence was also given that advice, given by ATSIC to the Indigenous Land Corporation, on crucial issues such as the percentage of money available for acquisition of land in the Northern Territory, was grossly misleading. We had to spend a lot of time trying to find out why such misleading advice had been given to the ILC on such a crucial issue.

The final recommendation, which I think is an important one, is that the Auditor-General conduct a performance audit of the ATSIC land acquisition and maintenance program. The minority report, which I have had only a brief opportunity to read, says that this is part of some sort of an ATSIC bashing exercise.I say to the Senate and to ATSIC: that could not be further from the truth.

You have now had the LAMP program operating for five years. You are now in a transitionary stage between that program and the situation where, within 18 months or so, the ILC will be operating all acquisition and management programs for Aboriginal people. You can clearly see, from the process which this committee has looked into, that there are a number of issues that are of serious concern and may need some structural reform.

I put it to the Senate—and the committee has supported this by way of recommendation—that this is an important time to find out just whether the LAMP, land acquisition and management program, administered by ATSIC, is performing, is meeting the needs of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders in a fair and equitable way; and, at this stage where the ILC is just beginning to get itself established, whether or not the Auditor-General in a performance audit can make some recommendations that would indeed help the ILC in this transitionary phase. So we see this as a constructive recommendation, certainly not as a destructive one.

In conclusion, in the short time remaining to me, I would put on the record my thanks to my other committee members—the Deputy Chairman, Senator Chamarette; my coalition colleagues Senator Troeth and Senator Ellison; and of course the Labor and Democrat senators who were on the committee. Most importantly, on behalf of all committee members, I would like to record our thanks to Sue Morton, the committee secretary. Sue has put in an incredible effort on this committee. She is under enormous stress. She is also working on a number of other reports for other committees I am on, and so I understand her stress. I also thank particularly the research assistant, Darlene Jonsson, who has just returned to Canada a couple of weeks ago. She also put in a fantastic effort in helping us on this report.
I commend the report to the Senate. I would now seek leave formally to incorporate the speech of Senator Ellison on this matter.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF THE SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN LAND FUND MATTERS SPEECH
INTRODUCTION
The Select Committee on Certain Land Fund Matters was appointed on 31 August 1995 to report on the following matters:

PARA.TAB: in the light of the Federal Court decision of 30 August 1995 which set aside the ATSIC Board decision of March 1995 `that in all the circumstances was so unreasonable that no reasonable decision-maker could come to it', to examine the process which led to that decision

SPEECH.PARA: and,

PARA.TAB: whether there were any other agreements between the Government, ATSIC and/or Aboriginal people arising from negotiations on the Native Title Act or the Land Fund Bill

SPEECH.PARA: BACKGROUND
ATSIC has, since its inception in 1990, administered the Land Acquisition and Maintenance Program (LAMP) which provides for the acquisition and maintenance of land for indigenous people.

This year the Indigenous Land Corporation Amendment Act (The Land Fund Act) was passed. It established a separate land fund for the purchase of land by indigenous people, and was to be administered by a new Indigenous Land Corporation. The Land Fund was set up to accommodate those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people who could not avail themselves of Native Title.

Despite ATSIC and the ILC both administering land fund programs, the Government decided that the ILC and ATSIC would BOTH receive funding for land acquisition and maintenance for a 2 year period, that being the years 95-96 and 96-97.

The reasons for this `transitional period' appear to have occurred because of the unique form of land title available to Aboriginal People under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act (ALRA) (N.T.). Where a claim under this Act is successful, the land is converted to unalienable freehold title, with the ability to veto any mining on the land. The land is managed by the relevant Land Council in consultation with the traditional owners and other affected Aboriginal people. As such it is regarded as a superior form of title.
Any claims under the ALRA, however, have an expiry date of June 1997 by which they are to be lodged.

Of course, the concern in the Northern Territory was that there would be in fact three regimes under which Aboriginal People could claim land i.e. ATSIC, ILC and ALRA (N.T.). More particularly, land granted by the ILC or ATSIC could be claimed under the ALRA and thereby converted to a superior title.
In order to address this concern, the Government included in the Land Fund Legislation a clause prohibiting any claim under the ALRA granted by the ILC.
Although the position with respect to the ILC was made clear, the position was not so with respect to ATSIC.

Mr Stephen Hatton (then Northern territory Minister for Aboriginal Development and Lands) in September 1994 warned that ATSIC could allocate funds for the acquisition of pastoral properties in the Territory, and that land claims over that land could then be made before the 1997 cut off date.

The question being asked was whether the extension of this two years was granted to enable ATSIC to use funding measures for land acquisition in the Northern Territory. This would enable additional land to be claimed in the Territory during that period, under the ALRA (NT).

This INTENTION was consistently denied by the Government and ATSIC. In particular, I asked Senator Evans the Leader of the Government in the Senate on 21st of March 1995 whether money could be devoted mainly to acquiring properties in the Northern Territory and whether that would deplete funds available to purchase a property in other parts of Australia. I asked the Minister whether the Government could give an undertaking that there would not be a heavy concentration on the acquisition of property in the Northern Territory over the next three years.

The Minister answered: `It is not our expectation that ATSIC will do anything other than maintain the normal pattern of land acquisition using those funds available to it. . . .' the Minister went on to say `I do not believe there is any basis for thinking that the kind of strategy outlined by Senator Ellison will be pursued' and he concluded that he thought `we could rely on good sense prevailing in that respect'.
Events following Senator Evan's answer are contrary to his assurances.
THE DECISION
A briefing paper was presented to the ATSIC board for a meeting in March 1995 and the board was to consider options for the ATSIC/LAMP program for the remaining 2 years.

The paper outlined 4 options. The preferred option was to `quarantine the entire amount allocated by ATSIC for land acquisition for the 2 transitional years for use for land in the Northern Territory'.

The option to be adopted was based on underlying assumptions that there be SPECIAL TREATMENT for the Northern Territory for land acquisition from ATSIC's Land Acquisition Program, in line with DISCUSSIONS WITH GOVERNMENT.
This flies in the face of Senator Evan's assurance and leads one to question what discussions were held, who in Government took part in them and who was privy to information from them.

The ATSIC board was tied 9 all over the vote to quarantine $10 million for the Northern Territory, $2 million was to be allocated to other national purchases and $9 million for land management. Chairperson Lois O'Donoghue used her casting vote (as well as her deliberative vote) to resolve the impasse.
FEDERAL COURT CHALLENGE

The ATSIC board's decision (in March) was challenged by the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council and the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre in June, 1995 and later by the Foundation for Aboriginal and Islander Research Action Aboriginal Corporation (FAIRA).

Both proceedings were heard together and on August 30th, Justice Hill found the decision by the ATSIC board in March was `an improper execution of power' and ordered the decision be set aside, as well as ordering ATSIC be restrained from making grants of money or the purchase of land.

The court's finding that the board's decision was `so unreasonable that no reasonable decision maker could come to it' is in itself, a strong criticism of the process that enabled the board to come to that decision.
When the decision is analysed, one can readily understand why the court came to its decision.

Since the establishment of ATSIC, 14.41 per cent of land acquisition funding and 24.16 per cent of land management funding has been allocated to the Northern Territory. Northern Territory land acquisition funding therefore represents 10.05 per cent of the total acquisition and maintenance funding available.

In contrast, the funding allocated to the Territory for land acquisition by the ATSIC board decision in March for the years 95-96 and 96-97 represents 83.33 per cent of land acquisition funding and 47.62 per cent of the total land acquisition and management funding available. This is significant departure from existing position without sufficient reason being given.
The inequitable distribution of assistance is immediately apparent.
AGREEMENTS

In relation to the Committee's investigations into whether there were any agreements between the Government, ATSIC and/or Aboriginal people, the Committee heard evidence that an agreement was reached in June 1994 between the Prime Minister and indigenous representatives, that ATSIC's LAMP would be extended for two years, until 1997. This coincided with the claim expiry for land under the ALRA (N.T.).
The existence of any other agreements has been denied by a number of witnesses and not enough evidence was available to the Committee to either accept or exclude their evidence.

One thing is clear and that is at a meeting between the Prime Minister and representatives of indigenous organisations on 16 June 1994 a proposal was put to Mr Keating that ATSIC be allowed to retain its land acquisition and maintenance function in ADDITION to the ILC for a two year transitional period.

There are now questions as to whether at some point a `deal' was made between the Prime Minister and Aboriginal representatives to circumvent the undertaking given by the Prime Minister to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory.
Mr Hatton's reaction to these arrangements, in evidence to the Senate's Finance and Public Administration Standing Committee was that:

PARA.TAB: `funds allocated in the Northern Territory would be available to purchase properties and subsequent claims under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act, which is contrary to the undertakings given to our government by the Prime Minister. Thus we have argued that all the funds should be dealt with through the indigenous land fund rather than some being siphoned off into the other land fund. If one was into conspiracy theories, one could suggest that was a way of meeting an undertaking without meeting the undertaking. It certainly smacks of that as far as we are concerned. . . '

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee therefore `does not find it probable' that there was any coincidence in the connection between the extension granted to ATSIC and the expiry of the 1997 sunset clause.

Les Malezer, the General Manager of FAIRA told the Committee there was a general knowledge during negotiations on the Land Fund Bill that the existence of the `sunset clause' was taken into account in relation to the drafting of the Land Fund bill and the decision for parallel ATSIC and ILC land acquisition and maintenance programs.
The evidence given to the Committee by Darryl Pearce the Director of the Northern Land Council should be noted:
`I actually raised the issue with the Prime Minister and put it across the table. . . '
`. . . we are not silly or simple enough to deny that we did not recognise the benefit to us.'
`We are not going to deny the fact that we recognised what opportunity available to us and I am sure that most people around the table would have recognised that.'

I do not dispute that Mr Pearce is genuine in his endeavours to get the best possible deal for his Land Council. The situation for ATSIC is another matter. ATSIC is charged with administering a land fund nationwide. As such, it should adhere to the principle of an equitable distribution of assistance across the country.
ATSIC'S DECISION MAKING PROCESS

The Committee also received submissions and evidence which raised serious concerns about ATSIC's decision making processes, and about the transparency of its actions and accountability to all its constituents.
There are indications ATSIC did not sufficiently regard national priorities.

Some serious problems with ATSIC's record keeping procedures have emerged, and were highlighted by discrepancies in minutes presented to the Committee and the Federal Court in relation to the board meeting in question.
Such bodies as FAIRA had to resort to FOI applications in order to find out what went on.
This is not a satisfactory state of affairs, where you have constituents of ATSIC having to go to such lengths in order to find out about decisions which vitally affect them.
COMMITTEE FINDINGS
In relation to the two terms of reference, the Committee found that:

PARA.TAB: at the time of negotiations, the parties did not directly admit that their agreement extended to the focussing of land purchases by ATSIC in the Northern Territory. Although this may be the case, it certainly was apparent to Government.

ATSIC did not fully consider the potential implication of its actions in relation to its constituents in all parts of Australia and failed to provide appropriate accountability and transparency in decision making.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee therefore recommended that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 be amended to provide measure to increase the transparency of ATSIC Board decisions and the accountability of the ATSIC board to indigenous people and the general community.

Having regard to the $100.0 million that ATSIC has spent on land, the Committee further recommended that the Auditor-General conduct a performance audit of the ATSIC Land Acquisition and Maintenance Program to assess whether the program is achieving its objectives.

The implication there is that we are trying to undermine ATSIC by trying to look at the areas that may have been present in them coming to a decision that we believe was not reached in an adequate way. The fact that it has been done with a majority and a minority report is less than desirable, but it does reflect the difference of view in the committee. TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this bill establishes a joint food standards system in Australia and New Zealand. It is the culmination of two year's careful and considered negotiation. It sets the pace for reform in this increasingly important sector of the economy. The new food standard system will promote trade in the food industry in both countries. It will also reduce costs.

New Zealand is now Australia's third largest trading partner. Trans-Tasman bilateral trade in food has passed the billion dollar mark. To maintain this growth, the government is looking to go beyond the closer economic relations arrangements. It is looking to remove trade barriers by establishing a single market in food.

In Australia, food is regulated by a co-operative commonwealth, state and territory arrangement set in place in 1991. This provides for standards to be developed by the National Food Authority, a commonwealth agency. This is a process that works well. It is characterised by open and transparent consultative arrangements. It enables all groups and interests to participate to ensure Australian food standards protect public health and safety and facilitate trade in a purposeful and lasting way.

The Authority recommends standards for adoption to a Council of Health Ministers which is known as the National Food Standards Council. If food standards are adopted by the Council, they are then taken up by reference and without amendment into the food laws of the States and Territories. This system is somewhat unique in its ability to respond quickly and effectively to the health and safety needs of all Australians.

At the same time, the food standard system is transparent and accountable. Public consultation, widespread public notification and parliamentary estimates processes all ensure that the food standards system is open to scrutiny and public input.

The New Zealand government has recognised the success of the existing Australian food standards system. Consequently, negotiations between the two countries have resulted in a proposed joint food standards setting system, based upon the existing Australian model, to deliver joint standards in the two countries. It is an innovative and exciting outcome.

A treaty has been negotiated. New Zealand will join the Australian system with as little disruption as possible. The obligations arising from the 1991 agreement between the states and territories will be preserved. Australia will recognise the needs of New Zealand as a sovereign nation.

The transitional arrangements in the treaty address bilateral trade issues. They provide the means for the Australian food industry to secure access to the New Zealand market. The arrangements have been carefully negotiated. The Australian food industry will not be disadvantaged by them.

Public health and safety will remain the paramount consideration for food standards. The provision of information to consumers, the promotion of fair trade and of trade and commerce in the food industry will also be taken into account. International standards will be considered where they are consistent with the other objectives. Consumers can be confident that the protection afforded by our food standards to the Australian community and to our industry will not be lowered. Standards will continue to meet Australian needs.

Australia enjoys an international reputation for its food standards and its food standards setting system. We have been able to capture a sizeable market share on our reputation for providing high quality foods. The new food standards system supports this.

All existing quarantine, hygiene and food inspection laws will continue to apply. Third countries will not be able to circumvent the rigorous systems currently in place. We will maintain our market edge as a `clean and green' food producer. Australia's international reputation in this area will be enhanced by the treaty. Our position in the region as a trading partner with New Zealand will be strengthened.
This bill provides for the establishment of a joint standards agency, the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Authority. It will have offices and operations in both Australia and New Zealand.

Standards developed by the new authority will be recommended to a joint Council of Health Ministers, the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council. It will comprise minsters from the commonwealth, New Zealand, the states and the territories. If food standards are adopted by the Council, they will be published in both countries and be adopted by reference and without amendment into food legislation in Australia and New Zealand. In Australia, this will occur through the already established mechanisms of the 1991 commonwealth, state and territory agreement.

The food standards system allows New Zealand to opt-out of a joint standard in exceptional circumstances. New Zealand, as a sovereign nation, has a right to determine its own domestic laws. However, the opt-out provisions are strict and with tightly defined criteria. It is expected they will only be used in very rare circumstances, if at all. The New Zealand member of the Ministerial Council will be required to provide a statement of reasons setting out the exceptional circumstances that cause New Zealand to vary from the joint standard. There is a also a mechanism to review of any decision to opt-out. This matter will be kept under very close and careful scrutiny. Both Australia and New Zealand recognise that the more the opt-out provision is used, the less effective the joint food standards system will be.

Decisions of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council will be subject to the regulation impact assessments required by principles endorsed by the Council of Australian Governments. The joint system also provides for the proposed trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Arrangement to apply to food so that the trade impact of non-uniform standards is minimised.
New Zealand will bear the costs of its participation in the Australia New Zealand food standards system, and so this bill is cost neutral to the budget.

I believe that after almost two years of negotiations, the Australia New Zealand food standards system represents an excellent result for Australia and the Australian food industry. It should remove a number of trade access issues which have been frustrating Australian exporters. It will reduce compliance costs and provide for a larger and more secure market in processed foods. The system will ensure that closer economic relations with New Zealand remain at the cutting edge of trade policy. It provides a worthy example for similar processes of trade facilitation in the APEC region and in the wider multilateral context.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
