SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We have had ongoing discussions on this matter. The reason for delaying this for one day was to continue discussions with the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) about how we could deal with this matter. She has asked that, rather than proceed in the way we had planned—that is, to take out 18(5)(c)—we take out 18(5)(c)(ii).

PARA.TAB: Before I proceed I need to get some indication from her as to what the government plans to do. That will determine whether or not I continue with the motion which will revive the previous clause, 7(5)(c), of the original regulations or whether we reach this compromise agreement with the government. The basic problem is that each of us has received conflicting legal advice on how to proceed. If we can speed up the process, we are only too happy to take the course the minister has suggested.

There are a couple of assurances I need from the minister before we determine which way we are about to go. Firstly, we need to have it on the record that what the government wants us to do will not cause further problems. We do not want the government to come back and say, `Hang on a minute, you cannot disallow such a small subclause. We have found this other rule. This will cause ongoing legal difficulties.'

The first assurance we need from the minister is that this swiftie will not be pulled and that we are looking at an alternative which is workable. Secondly, we need an assurance from the minister that she will introduce a new regulation which ensures, whatever the decision of the Senate today, that the new regulation, which will take effect from 1 April 1996, reflects the wishes of the Senate.
So that there is no uncertainty, I will read out the regulation we are seeking to disallow. It reads:
That from 1 April 1996 centres will apply the client's child care assistance percentage to 50 per cent of the rebateable fee to calculate the child-care assistance entitlement.

SPEECH.PARA: We want an undertaking that you will replace that so that there is an ongoing and very clear instruction for centres.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We are in the curious position of finding, as much as we can tell, two legal advices in conflict here. The government has a clear way to go—that is, we act on the advice from the Attorney-General's office and our legal advisers. We do not have the option of considering other opinions, although the legal people might. It is quite clear that there is confusion in this area.

PARA.TAB: As I said to Senator Lees last night, I grew up understanding that it was not possible to amend regulations and that deleting sections, certainly in Labor Party quarters, would qualify as an amendment. So I am not quite sure how we are able to do what we are doing. But we are advised on the best counsel that we can do this. Senator Lees's concern is that we do not move to a 50 per cent child-care assistance after 1 April 1996, that the government would be responsible for making sure a regulation was introduced to make sure the intention of the Senate was covered.

Senator Lees, I would like to give you that assurance absolutely. I sincerely hope I do not have to do anything about it on the grounds that you might get rolled in the next few minutes, but I think it is an agreed matter, following a lot of discussions. I certainly give you that assurance. As of 1 April 1996, if there were a need to maintain 100 per cent child-care assistance for the holiday period, I could assure you that could be given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend my motion—that is, instead of paragraph 5(c) insert paragraph 5(c)(ii).

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That paragraph (5)(c)(ii) of Guideline No. 18 of the Childcare Assistance (Fee Relief) Guidelines, as contained in CCA/12A/95/1 and made under subsection 12A(3) of the Child Care Act 1972, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I now seek to convince the Senate to ensure that we do have the numbers in order to remove what we see is the one regressive nasty, if you like, in this particular set of guidelines before us. By disallowing the subclause containing the measure, what we are seeking to achieve is to have the status quo remain. The minister has agreed that this is where we are heading and she has agreed to give an undertaking to ensure that the correct wording is reinserted.

PARA.TAB: As I said in the budget, the government announced this regressive measure which cuts the total amount of child care assistance or fee relief paid out by the government by $16 million next year. It is targeted, and this is our problem, at the people who can least afford it—the lowest income families: the lower your income the harder you will be hit by this move.

It is one of the most regressive measures anyone could possibly dream up, hitting hardest those people the government and the coalition like to refer to as the `battlers'. The measure that is hidden away in this particular subclause—and these regulations were tabled in this place on 16 October—is the change in amounts by which fee relief or child care assistance is paid by the government to parents for allowable holiday absences from 1 April next year. These allowable absences are for up to five weeks. What the government is effectively saying is that, while you are on holidays and your child-care place is on hold, it will pay only half the amount of child-care assistance or fee relief you are entitled to.

Superficially that argument is certainly attractive—that is, it is not fair for a family to have to pay full fees while their place is on hold while the family is on holidays and that centres do need some sort of incentive to fill places while its usual occupants are temporarily away. The government is suggesting that only half the fee should be charged. It is acting unilaterally to cut its contribution to the fee by half for holiday periods.

We have no problem in agreeing that a holding fee could perhaps be lower than a normal fee. We have no problem saying to services, `How about trying to arrange your fee structure so that you do charge lower fees for holiday absences and slightly more for the rest of the year.' Some centres are able to do that. As we talked to centres in lower income areas, we found that this was simply not a realistic possibility. The reality is that it is not simply an encouragement to achieve that. It is not about greater fairness or lower fees; it is about government savings and, inevitably for those centres that cannot accommodate this measure, higher fees for parents.

The government aims to save $16 million a year by the measure—by cutting its child-care assistance outlays. The money will not come from wealthy parents, but from parents who are eligible for child-care assistance—parents who, by definition, are less well off. I want to go through some specific examples so that people listening do understand how this actually works.

Fees are set by centres to cover a series of fixed costs. All costs over the year are taken into account. Those costs are divided by the number of places on offer over the year, including the times when some families may be taking holidays, because there is no way of knowing who will be taking how long and when. It is not a particularly mysterious process. Some parents can then get fee relief or assistance from the government to help pay whatever the fee is that that centre determines.

The government is saying that it only wants to pay half of the fee relief and half of what the families are normally entitled to for holiday absences. What is going to happen then? The shortfall in what that centre has budgeted for will have to be made up. For those weeks a family is on holiday the centre will only get half the amount of child-care assistance they budgeted for. They may be able to absorb it. In some centres where there are very few low income families—in other words, they rely on relatively little child-care fee relief—they may be able to do that. But it is community based centres which base fees on cost recovery that we are particularly concerned about, particularly those centres in lower income areas where there is a very high percentage of parents on fee relief and full fee relief.

Centres' fees are generally at around break even, particularly those in the community centres. They set a rate, which private centres must compete with. There may be some room for a few private centres in areas where there is a long waiting list to absorb some of these costs, but the evidence that has been placed before us is that there are very few centres that will be fully able to absorb them and the majority of centres will be struggling. Inevitably, the cost will be passed on to the parents. The parents will pay for the government savings of $16 million and the impact will be greatest, as I said before, in those areas which have the most children eligible for child-care assistance.

To look practically at how these fees will be passed on, let us look at a couple of examples using working families who need full-time care. Assume that the centre has an average fee of $140 a week. First, let us look at a family on $62,000 a year annual income. They receive no fee relief. They can go on holidays whenever they like and have no increase in their normal fee. This does not affect them whatsoever.

Secondly, let us look at a family on $35,000 a year. They get about 60 per cent of the maximum possible fee relief. Of the $140 a week that they owe, they would normally receive from the government assistance of around about $57, leaving the family to cover about $70 to $73 gap per week. This family goes on holidays for three weeks and the government says, `We are only paying half your assistance, half that we normally do—that is, $33.75 instead of $67.50 for each of those weeks.' The centre says, `You have to make up the money. Not only do you owe the normal $72.50 for the week, but an extra $33.75, which the government has declined to subsidise your fee by.' So for the three weeks that they are on holidays, that is an extra outlay of $121.25 that the family will have to find.

One possibility is that the fee could be spread over the entire year, which some centres have said is another way that they are looking at doing it. If it is spread over 50 weeks, arriving at the higher average fee so the whole bill does not come at once, that would increase the family's fees by $2 a week every week. So it would be a $111 bill up-front or about a $2 a week increase for a family on $35,000.

Let us look at the family that earns $25,000 a year. On that income the family is on full fee relief. It receives from the government the maximum child-care assistance of $112.50 per week to cover the majority of the centre's fees, leaving the family with a gap cover of about $27.50 per week.If this family goes on holidays for three weeks, the government says, `We're only paying half the assistance that we normally pay—we're only paying $56.25 instead of $112.50 for each of those weeks.' The centre says, `Sorry, we still have to charge you; where is the money?'.

Not only do you owe the normal $27.50 for the week but you owe an extra $56.25 by which the government has declined to subsidise your fee. So over three weeks that is an extra $168.75 which the family will have to find—that is, $168 for a family which earns about $450 a week. I argue with the government that that is a substantial amount of money. To suggest that it is inconsequential, that we are really only talking about small amounts of money, is not correct when we look at the level of income on which families have to manage.

If we spread this over the entire year, we would be looking at increasing the family's fees by about $3.40 per week, every week. So, as far as this measure is concerned, the poorer you are, the harder you are hit. On $62,000, there is no impact; on $35,000, it is $101 a year; on $25,000, it is $168 a year—and that is with three weeks holidays.

Have more children and the bill becomes more complicated. For example, if you are on maximum fee relief—that is, an income of about $25,000—and you have two children in care, when you take holidays your bill, under this measure, will increase by about $103 a week for each week you are on holidays; that is, for three weeks holiday, $309 or, spread over the weeks, $66.20 a week.

If someone is writing a dictionary and wants a definition of the word `regressive', I do not think we could find a better way of describing it than by looking at this measure. It certainly would be a perfect definition of `regressive'. You can put this through as many different scenarios as you like but it is $16 million out of the pockets of those who can least afford it. Centres in affluent areas across our cities and in our affluent rural areas where very few children get fee relief will be virtually unaffected by this measure. It is those centres in, for example, the western suburbs of Sydney and the northern and southern suburbs of my home city that will be worst affected.

We say to you, minister: find somewhere else to make your savings. That is also before pointing out what a financial and administrative nightmare this could well be for centres. As I said at the beginning of my remarks, by disallowing paragraph (5)(c)(ii) of guideline No. 18, we will see the status quo remain and we will leave the government to look elsewhere for these savings.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perspective is all. I find this argument by Senator Lees a really very interesting argument. It is actually contrary to a lot of the facts and it is certainly contrary to a lot of practice. I would like to take senators through what is the situation and why the government's intention to do this is one of the matters that we put through in the budget.

PARA.TAB: The savings for the government are $37 million over four years, so it is no small sum. Also, the Australian Law Reform Commission, when it did a thorough examination of child care about a year ago, highlighted the fact of an inequity between family day care, where they have always only had 50 per cent child-care assistance for holidays, and long day care centres, where they have been eligible for 100 per cent. As a matter of fairness and equity between the two sectors, it made the point that we should take note of this enormous discrepancy. That is another very persuasive reason why we should be moving to 50 per cent child-care assistance for holidays across all centres. You could well ask why families who have got comparable sorts of fees in family day care have 50 per cent child-care assistance for vacation care absences while people in long day care centres do not.

The next important point is that the charging practices of centres are the charging practices of centres; they are not a government responsibility. Senator Lees, I am sometimes enormously tempted to think about the benefits I could introduce into child care if I were setting fees, but we don't have that power and, I must say, on the whole, we don't want it. But we certainly have to deal with the confusion in the community when child-care assistance, which is to assist with the fees and to offset them, if you like, to provide fee relief, is a government responsibility but the setting of the fees that centres charge is entirely the centres' responsibility.

Senator Lees gave some examples of how centres can decide to take into account their costs and spread them over a year taking into account the needs of people for holidays and so on, and others who set a fee for when a child is there and keep charging it through the holidays. We have to also note that centres have been a bit slow to modify their charging practices. The changes to their charging practices have been initiated by government changes in child-care assistance, which is perhaps not the very best way of dealing with things.

You will remember that a little while ago many of the centres were discovered to be charging full fees and getting full child-care assistance for children who attended only two days a week. The industry as well as the government agreed that that practice had to stop, and it has stopped. It has made a difference to centres. It could be that no more children are going to the centres, but their charging practices have changed. If our child-care assistance contribution can assist centres in thinking about their fee setting processes, then I think that is a very good thing.

The first important point I have to say is that this is a budget measure with savings of $37 million over four years. The second important point is that it is a matter of equity. It was drawn to our attention by the Law Reform Commission that there was an inequity between family day care where there is 50 per cent child-care assistance for holidays and long day care where there is not that assistance.

The other thing I have to say, Senator Lees, is that we have given under allowable absences up to five weeks holidays, but we also have that buffer of 12 days for unseen circumstances. They will not change. They will still enjoy 100 per cent child-care assistance, as will absences due to sickness. It is fairly true that, for a large number of people using child care, they can anticipate when they will be taking holidays and the centres have the opportunity to provide those places to other parents who are desperate for access to child care.

In particular, we have the need and demand for vacation care. There are many families who may be able to get before and after school hour care during the school term, but do not have access to vacation care. The long day care centres could use those places for vacation care. It is designed for the children. It would be a splendid set up. They would get the child-care assistance for it. It would encourage the centres to market themselves, if you like, to a slightly wider community and get them income for their centre to keep it viable. It would also meet the very significant needs, particularly for vacation care, of the safe secure sort that families want.

On the evidence, something like 153,000 children would be very pleased to have casual occasional care; that is, people who do not want regular occasional care, but certainly are looking for casual occasional care. They would be on a list as saying, `Yes, please. We would be happy to use casual occasional care if it becomes available.'

Again we are asking centres to introduce that kind of flexibility because the vacation care is usually five weeks as a chunk. They can see that opportunity coming and could let some of the families who are desperate for child care in a casual or not in an ongoing way to fill those places. So we would be asking centres to appreciate the opportunities they have for extending the families who could use their child care, and I highlight in particular vacation care.

There are a couple of other facts that need to be put into your equation, Senator Lees. I do not wish to split hairs, but the maximum child-care assistance is about $96. The figure of $112.50 is what the fee is set at and then families have to pay the $16.50. So I think you would find the maximum assistance is $96. It doesn't make too much difference to the equation you gave at all. I just draw that to your attention.

Not all centres choose to force parents to pay full fees for holiday absences. The majority of both private and community based centres in Tasmania charge only 50 per cent holiday fees for holidays. In Queensland, the majority of community based centres charge 50 per cent holding fees for holidays. Even now they have set their charges at half rate for holidays. I am very pleased that they do it. I certainly encourage it.

The cases Senator Lees illustrates are really outrageous. I have no truck at all for parents having to pay more for child care when their children are not there than when they are using it. That is absolutely daft. I do not believe it is solved by leaving the 100 per cent child-care assistance there. It is solved by asking the child-care centres to drop their fees to correspond with the reduced child-care assistance.

I also take issue with your claim that families who pay full fees and get no child-care assistance are not affected because their fee remains the same. I can assure you that is not what parents write to me. They ask why they should continue to pay $140 week when their child is not using the centre. Parents understand there may be a case for some kind of fee to contribute to the cost and to make sure their place is there when they come back after five weeks, but why should they pay the same amount for child care when they are not using the centre? It is absolutely daft. I have all the sympathy in the world for people who find they pay more for child care when they are not using it. That is really crazy. It is not an issue of sheeting that home to the government; it is an issue of sheeting that home to the charging practices of centres.

I remind Senator Lees that right now the majority of both private and community based centres in Tasmania charge only 50 per cent holding fees for holidays. In Queensland, the majority of community based centres charge 50 per cent holding fees. So already a lot of centres have recognised that it is daft to be charging the same rate when parents are not using child care. I think these are enlightened charging practices, but they are not consistent across the whole sector. I would certainly like to see the remainder of child care centres, both community based and long day care, take note of what is already happening in some parts and move to doing it.

The situation in family day care is quite different. The provision of 50 per cent entitlement to child-care assistance for holiday absences is the standard practice in family day care. As I have already said, the Australian Law Reform Commission, in its 1994 review, drew this to our attention. It is important to note that in family day care only five per cent of schemes charge the full fees for holiday absences—I certainly think it is about time I knew which ones—and 95 per cent of schemes charge half the full fee or less for holiday absences. I think that is absolutely appropriate and absolutely something we should be encouraging.

If a recognisable 50 per cent child-care assistance consistent across the sectors will encourage that kind of rational charging practice across the whole of the long day care sector, I would have to support it. People who are paying more for child care when they are not using it have a very large right to complain bitterly, but I think it is important that they do not sheet that responsibility home to government.

The family day care scheme 50 per cent reduction is certainly very good evidence that, if you have a 50 per cent child-care assistance for holidays, you get a remarkable 50 per cent reduction of fees for the holiday period. As I have pointed out, there is an opportunity for families to look for vacation care. A lot of the people taking holidays from child care will be taking a four- or five-week block, as they are allowed to. When people have other children they often want that block to correspond to school holidays. Those holidays can be anticipated by the centre. They can offer those places to others looking for vacation care because they do not have the same opportunity for holidays. It will require perhaps a different bit of effort by child-care centres, but it is the sort of thing that families will appreciate enormously. It will help them during the period when they might be looking at a drop in income because of a slightly reduced holding fee.

I am not persuaded by your argument, Senator Lees. You can make the case, as you do, on the figures. Those figures are in large part right, but they depend on the charging practices. The government dropping its child-care assistance is not promoting regressivity. It is promoting fair charging practices by centres. As I say, I do not think people, whether they have full fee relief or none at all, are encouraged by a process that makes them pay more when their children are away from child care than when they are in it. People who get no child-care assistance would not be encouraged by a process which maintains very expensive fees that they would have to pay.

I also find it difficult to reconcile Senator Lees's argument that we should maintain 100 percent child-care assistance at centres when people are on holidays, taking their allowable absence for holidays, and yet see a significant campaign to oppose the 12-hour legislation that would allow more opportunity for more families wanting particularly occasional care. Of course, if those places currently used by occasional care were modified, then, of course, many more working families would have access to child care, too.

In all ways, while I understand exactly the sentiment behind Senator Lees's proposal in moving this disallowance motion, I am not at all persuaded by the argument because the regressivity disappears very significantly if the fees match the child-care assistance, instead of the child-care assistance being maintained at a high level just to keep those fees up. To do that will not result in a situation of equity. It certainly will not produce any savings, and it certainly will not encourage those centres to rethink their charging practices or their recruiting practices.

We know there are families that would love vacation care. We know there are families that would enjoy the occasional and casual care that those places would provide. We know most holidays come in blocks of three or four or five weeks and we know that they can be anticipated and planned for. As parents plan for them, so they can notify the child-care cares.

I think there is an excellent case to oppose this disallowance motion, to make sure that the child-care assistance is fair across the sectors, and to encourage the practice of reducing the fees during holidays, as is already happening in significant parts of the child-care industry, apart from family day care. I urge senators to oppose this disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will admit that the coalition have a certain unease about this measure, as with the other budget measures that were proposed for the child-care industry as of last May. We certainly have heard from the child-care industry that there has been a lack of consultation about these measures and I would like to place on record that the coalition have criticised these measures in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: However, the coalition will be opposing the disallowance of this measure and would like to briefly run through the reasons why we are doing that. I do not agree with Senator Crowley, firstly, that cost is the most important issue here. Cost, to be honest, should never be an issue when looking at the child-care field. The care of children and the ultimate welfare of the family should be the most important issue. The coalition considers that, in comparison with the 12-hour issue, which was another budget measure and which we have debated here at length in the Senate, that issue has far more impact on families over the whole year with regard to their access to child care.

I agree with Senator Crowley—amazingly enough, Senator Crowley—that vacation care under the existing government measure would then be available for others, as would occasional care in the sense of casual care. One would like to think that that is something that would be available for all parents throughout Australia, if and when they desire it.

I take your point about the existing inequity between long day care centres and family day care centres. In the interests of looking at, I would hope, one day a much more integrated approach between every sector of the child-care industry—and I am talking here not just about family day care and long day care, but also about pre-school centres—we would like to think that some of these inequities could be ironed out. As I said, we would like to distinguish it from the 12-hour rule, which is being looked at at the moment, because that is another issue. I do believe that centres may be able to absorb this extra cost and that, if spread over the year and parents can plan for it, there may not be as much of a financial impact as Senator Lees has indicated. That sums up the reasons why the coalition will be opposing the disallowance motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to respond to a couple of things that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) said in relation to the Law Reform Commission's report. It talked about aligning payments. Obviously, you can do that either way. I take your point that family day care can adapt far more easily to holidays because, to begin with, they have fewer children. It is often very convenient for them to close down or to make other arrangements during those periods, in some cases combining various family day care groups.

PARA.TAB: I wish to deal with Senator Troeth's point that what we really need in the child-care area is full integrated planning of all services available at local government, state government and federal government levels. The fact that we have this disallowance motion before us today is indicative of the government's method of planning which is to pick out particular measures that they hope will save money at budget time and not look at the overall planning in the particular industry.

I would argue that it is far more difficult for centres that have 30, 40 or more children to simply make other arrangements during holidays. As you have said, some are able to offer half fees. I think if we look at the suburbs and locations of those centres we would find that they are far more affluent than the centres that I am concerned about. Some areas simply may not be able to attract significant numbers of children for vocational or holiday care.

I will take Senator Troeth's point about the 12-hour rule, which is still rumbling around, a step further. How would the 12-hour rule impact on this situation? If we are looking at the situation at holiday time we could find that a mum could have three children home from school plus a younger child at home. If the 12-hour rule is in place she may not be able to take up vocational care for more than 12 hours a week. That will not help the child-care centres with their dilemma of how they are going to make up the money.

The Democrats stand by the motion. We believe that this is one of the most regressive moves the government could have made to find money. The minister seems to be suggesting that centres will not be encouraged to find other children or advertise. You have undone that argument by giving examples of those centres that are already doing this. I argue that many centres are trying to fill these places. If they do then they are able to offer the long-term parents reduced fees. Those parents will then claim less fee relief. I stress again that we are concerned about those centres in working class areas, those centres that are not in affluent suburbs where parents can simply absorb a few more dollars a week on their child-care bill. I am very disappointed to note that we will not have the numbers in the chamber to pass this disallowance motion.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I assure the Senate that I will guarantee that the regulations we have actually cover all situations. I promised to that do for Senator Lees had her disallowance motion been passed. I must make sure that what we have in place now remains in place and that centres understand that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney, together with the submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to the high demands that have been place on the printing unit at present, this report is being tabled in A4 format and will not be available in printed form until late tonight. In the interim, limited copies of the executive summaries to the report are available on request from the committee secretariat. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The opening of the third runway at Sydney airport and the closure of the east-west runway have shattered the lives of thousands of Sydney residents. The Senate established this committee on 8 March 1995 to investigate the noise burden generated by the government's Sydney airport policy and to explore possible solutions to the problem. The committee received more than 5,200 submissions and held 14 days of public hearings between July and November.

PARA.TAB: From the beginning, the EIS process was marked by ambiguity and confusion. The federal government decided to build the third runway in 1989 `subject to the satisfactory completion of normal EIS processes'. However, this decision was communicated to the Federal Airports Corporation as a decision to construct the runway `subject to it meeting stringent guidelines to be established through an EIS'. In other words, the Federal Airports Corporation believed the EIS was intended to minimise the environmental impact. The decision to build the runway had already been taken by the government.

The committee has made a number of recommendations concerning the environmental impact assessment process. In future, the government should clearly establish whether it is conducting an EIS to decide whether a project should go ahead or conducting an EIS to work out the best way of managing the impact of the project.

Many parts of the EIS were prepared to a very high standard. However, some of its key predictions were wrong, and at least one of them was demonstrated to be wrong at the time. The environmental impact statement predicted that prevailing winds would mean that aircraft would take off to the north only 13 per cent of the time. The actual figure over the past 10 years has been more than double the EIS prediction. This raises serious doubts about many of the noise impact forecasts in the statement.

Aircraft noise is measured by the Australian noise exposure forecast, ANEF, system. The committee has concluded that the ANEF system has serious limitations. It may be adequate for land use planning purposes, but it is not adequate for assessing the effects of changes in noise exposure. We have therefore recommended that the National Acoustic Laboratories thoroughly redraft the ANEF system in the light of the problems that have emerged.

The government has implemented a number of operational measures in an effort to minimise the impact of the noise generated by the airport. The committee has concluded that these measures have only marginally been effective. The Australian International Pilots Association has described them as `bandaid fixes'. The Sydney airport noise issue is a problem that requires more than bandaids or Dettol.

The committee believes the noise generated by the airport should be spread equitably. This goal can only be achieved if Airservices Australia can use all three runways at the airport. That means reopening the east-west runway.

The government has repeatedly rejected using the east-west runway more extensively on safety grounds. Independent advice to the committee suggests that the dependent use of intersecting runways is not only a safe operation but a common one. The American consultancy, Flight Transportation Associates, told the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: Incidents and accidents have occurred at airports with single runways, parallel runways and crossing/intersecting runways. No one configuration has been declared to present a higher level of risk than another. No one configuration has been identified as presenting an unacceptable level of risk.

The government's claims about safety implications for using intersecting runways are a recent innovation. Neither the draft EIS nor the EIS supplement mentions safety as a reason for not using the east-west runway in conjunction with parallel runways. Nor was safety a concern during cabinet's evaluation of the proposal.

PARA.TAB: The government has argued that increasing the use of the east-west runway would reduce capacity.The average movement rate on the parallel runway system is 58 movements per hour. This is comparable to the average movement rate that was achieved before the third runway was opened. Airservices Australia believes it will eventually be able to achieve 80 movements per hour. The committee considered a range of alternative runway configurations and concluded that the increasing use of the east-west runway need not reduce the airport's capacity.

The committee has therefore recommended the development of a new airspace management plan for Sydney airport. The new airspace management plan should examine the best means of using all three runways at the airport to balance safety, capacity and the equitable distribution of noise. The committee does not believe simops needs to be introduced at Sydney airport for capacity reasons.

As regards remedial measures, the government is currently implementing an acquisition and insulation scheme in the suburbs to the north of Sydney airport. Our most important recommendation in this area relates to the scope of the insulation scheme. At the moment it is restricted to the 4,200 homes within the 30 ANEF contour. The committee agrees with the final noise management plan that was prepared for the government last year. That plan recommended that the insulation scheme should be extended to the 25 ANEF contour.

As regards a second airport, the government has portrayed the development of Sydney West airport as an immediate solution to the Sydney airport noise problem, but the airport will handle only a small number of passengers and aircraft at first. There is still an urgent need to address the airport's infrastructure requirements, particularly the development of an airport rail link. The government is currently revising the environmental impact statement for Sydney West airport. The process must be open and transparent to maintain public confidence. It is essential that the government and its consultants do not make the same mistakes that were made in the Sydney environmental impact statement.

In conclusion, the existing mode of operations at Sydney airport can be described only as an environmental and social tragedy. The noise problems generated by the airport under the current mode of operations will not go away. It is the view of the majority of the committee that it can only get worse. I would like to thank all members of the committee for the dignified way in which the proceedings were conducted. On behalf of the committee, I would also like to express our thanks to the committee secretary, James Warmenhoven, and the staff who did a magnificent job in sifting through the thousands of submissions and compiling the final report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor members of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise—Senator Neal, Senator Childs and myself—have presented a minority report. I say at the outset that we are somewhat disappointed at the outcome of this inquiry; disappointed because it could have been a much more worthwhile inquiry. However, it was politicised from the start. It was politicised by the opposition even before the first hearings commenced.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer, the chairman of the committee, gave a notice of a motion in the Senate on 6 March in which he called for the reopening of the east-west runway and for the reintroduction of cross-runway operations at Kingsford Smith airport. The Senate select committee was set up on 8 March 1995. So from the outset there was a pre-determined view by the opposition which became a campaign by the opposition—both by the opposition members of the committee and in particular by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard—with the single objective of having the east-west runway reopened to cross-runway operations.

In that context a lot of other issues, such as Sydney West airport, were not in our view dealt with as adequately as they could have been. Therefore we believe particularly that the majority report leaves a lot to be desired in terms of endeavouring to cover the issues and is wrong in a number of key respects. I want to deal firstly with the east-west runway issue. As I said, this became the single cause celebre of the opposition. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, appeared before the inquiry on 25 July. He said that day that, as the honourable member for Bennelong, he called for the reopening of the runway. From thereon he campaigned at every opportunity on that issue. He nobbled his own inquiry and his own opposition senators.

The fact that this inquiry was political was very disappointing, because there were over 5,000 submissions from interested and affected residents as well as industry, councils, medical practitioners, unions, community groups, schools, churches, government departments, academics and many others. They came along, gave their evidence, put forward proposals and believed that something more positive might come out of the inquiry. But, with it always being directed back to this single issue of the east-west runway, I think one can feel disappointed with its outcome. I would say also, however, that the information compiled and presented to the committee will continue to be valuable in the future.

In the minority report we have detailed the long history of support given by the opposition to the building of the third runway. We have done that because during this committee inquiry what we saw was an attempt by the opposition to run as far away from the issue as they could in an endeavour to absolve themselves of any responsibility in connection with the construction of the third runway at Sydney airport and the resulting problems of aircraft noise.

The history that we have detailed notes that time and time again the opposition spokespersons urged the government to build a third runway. The issues that they used in urging that the runway be built were congestion and safety at Sydney airport—they put safety fairly and squarely on the agenda. They also recognised that, in the decision to build the runway, safety would be improved, and the number of residents affected by aircraft noise would be reduced drastically by half, by the concurrent downgrading of the east-west runway.

They cannot deny that. It was there from the outset. It was a pre-eminent factor in the EIS deliberations that the east-west runway would be downgraded. But they now try to rewrite history and do so only in a desperate attempt to garner support from people who may be affected by aircraft noise. To them it is a pre-election issue, a pre-election stunt.

Senator Parer says that independent expert advice was given on safety, and he quotes Flight Transportation Associates. That organisation, a US firm of consultants, did not give evidence to the committee at all. Rather, a letter, a submission was presented to the committee on its behalf. At no stage were its representatives cross-examined, nor was there any opportunity for the committee to test its proposals in detail.

But against that, we had expert evidence from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, from the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, from Airservices Australia, from the airlines and from the air traffic controllers—all saying that parallel runways were safer. Nevertheless, the opposition tried to distort the evidence of those groups by saying that they were arguing that cross-runways were unsafe. They never said that. What they said was that parallel runways were safer.

The evidence is clear that the reintroduction of the east-west runway, as proposed, would either reduce capacity, thus creating pressure to introduce take-offs to the north from the third runway; or it would reduce safety; or it would increase noise for residents to the north—or, indeed, a combination of those. We have come to the conclusion that we cannot support the reopening of the east-west runway on the various grounds and reasons that were put forward, because at the end of the day the expert advice we had was that the system we have is safer and more efficient—and government should not ignore the advice of such agencies.

I quickly turn to the EIS process. We agree that it left a lot to be desired. In fact, it could be described in many ways, particularly with regard to community consultation, as abysmal. We are quite clear in our view that the Federal Airports Corporation and other agencies failed in their duty to provide the community with correct advice. Indeed, it is clear that many were misled into thinking that their situation would be improved—but, as we know, it got worse. We have made some very strong recommendations as part of what we call a public interest package to ensure that that does not occur again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1994 had been, sadly, left at the bottom of the list, I had thought because the government was not keen enough to pass the bill. I believe the bill will be of significant advantage to the New South Wales royal commission into police corruption.

PARA.TAB: I indicated at some stage last week—I believe it was Wednesday—to the Australian Democrats that I intended giving notice of a motion in the chamber to indicate that we believed it was inappropriate for the bill to be left any longer at the bottom of the pile. The Democrats indicated they had had some troubles, not with the substance of the bill but because they wanted to satisfy themselves with respect to the guidelines that would be made under the bill. I understand they have now had the opportunity to see at least the draft of those guidelines and believe that, by and large, their concerns are going to be catered for. On that basis, they notified the government that they were happy to have this bill dealt with in a non-controversial way during the Thursday lunchtime.

There would be plenty of opportunity if I wanted to go on at length about this, suffice it to say that I think this bill will be of advantage to the commission. The minister might like to give a nod if he thinks that is right. Do you think that is right, Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely! It is a wonderful bill and I fully commend it to the Senate.

—Yes, thank you. It is a non-controversial bill and I am the one who has complained that it has taken too long to get it to the top of the list. I had thought it was the government's fault. I thought it was their indolence and slack attitude to police corruption that was allowing them to leave it at the bottom. I now understand that it was the Democrats who, with the threat of a notice of motion to expose their lax attitude to this, decided to come to the party. I think I will leave it at that and say the coalition supports the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked to put this on the record. On 6 March 1995 Senator Margetts proposed an amendment to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to enable married students to be eligible for qualifying for the higher independent rate of Austudy payment by virtue of marriage. The amendment proposed would operate to exempt this practice from those provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 which make it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of marital status.

PARA.TAB: On 24 March 1995 the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission granted a temporary administrative exemption from the marital status provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act for the provision of benefits under the Austudy scheme until 31 December 1996. The Green's amendment is therefore unnecessary.

The commission is presently coordinating a review into discriminatory provisions of the Social Security Act 1991. This review is required by section 40A of the Sex Discrimination Act. This factor was taken into account by the commission when it granted the Austudy exemption. The commission also noted that, because of linkages between social security benefits and Austudy benefits, it would be sensible to examine and amend the two sets of benefits in conjunction.

The Department of Employment, Education and Training, which administers Austudy, is to establish a working group to consider Austudy benefits. The establishment of the working group has been delayed, pending progress of the social security review. The department has advised that the working group will be established in early 1996 to consider criteria for independent status which are non-discriminatory in terms of the Sex Discrimination Act but which reflect the community's views on who should receive benefits. I commend the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill before the Senate will introduce amendments to five existing bills dealing with prudential controls over superannuation, the resolution of superannuation complaints issues, taxation, general insurance and life assurance. Following the passage of this legislation, the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal will now be in a position to hear disability cases. The original date was set at 1 November 1995. I think honourable senators will be aware of the long debates that we had in relation to the tribunal's capacity to hear medical issues.

PARA.TAB: Following today's amendments, the tribunal will also be able to handle complaints about the sale of life company superannuation products. The amended bill also provides mechanisms to overcome the High Court's Brandy ruling which involved `judicial decision'. The amendment bill now also binds insurers so that life companies can no longer opt out of their obligations in terms of disability and death insurance.

There are important provisions for auditors, who will now have to certify that a fund complies with the prudential rules for superannuation funds set out in the act and regulations and not merely provide financial audit reports. It was disappointing that a number of auditors decided to segment audit responsibilities into categories of financial audit, compliance audit and prudential audit and charge a fee for each.

It was always intended that auditors—not every auditor is able to audit a superannuation fund—had to provide not only a financial audit, but that within that audit there had to be compliance verification. That responsibility is now clarified under this bill. Auditors will also have to report suspected breaches of the law to the ISC and effectively become whistleblowers.

Some of the prudential amendments to the ISC give the ISC power to quickly apply to the court for the appointment of a receiver to protect members as well as providing broader inquiry powers to the ISC. There is also the closing of a loophole regarding the payment of surplus to employer sponsored funds. I would also like to draw the Senate's attention to a UK white paper on superannuation that deals with surplus. I think we have something to learn from the UK approach.

There are also a number of temporary decisions which are known as modification orders made by the ISC which will now rightly be transferred into SIS legislation before they lapse. I quote one of them: excluded funds are not to be classified as public offer funds, otherwise they would need a $5 million capital.

The broadening of the powers of the legislation give the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal the opportunity to consider complaints about the conduct of the sale of life office intermediaries in relation to superannuation products. This includes agent misrepresentation. There is also a further widening of the powers of the ISC and these extend to the conduct of independent financial planners. This is a major departure from corporation law, which makes security dealers rather than product providers responsible for investment advice.

In summary, the bill has four purposes: to expand the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal; the transfer of certain modification orders with interstatutory form; the audit requirement of superannuation entities to cover compliance; and a number of miscellaneous amendments.

Under the heading of `miscellaneous amendments' is the creation of a deputy chairperson and two part-time members of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. These are estimated to cost $270,000. Coming on board we will see specialist staff—for example, a medical practitioner. This is a desirable move, seeing that the tribunal will now deal with medical issues.

The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, I remind the Senate, is in the final throes of producing report No. 18, which will examine the first 12 months of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. The tribunal was set up to improve the efficiency of superannuation and to provide a low cost, informal and expeditious means of resolving disputes.

It was never intended that the tribunal was to be a final point of appeal since the agreed parties always have resort to the law, which means access through the ordinary court mechanisms. However, what is not generally understood by many about the tribunal's powers is that, provided the trustees have followed the due processes, applied the laws accurately and fairly and given written reasons for their decision, the tribunal must affirm the trustees' decision. I remind honourable senators that this provision is in the original SIS legislation, but it needs to be repeated. Drawing attention to this provision should refute a lot of wild claims which were made earlier that the tribunal would be inundated with work that it is unable to handle.

It is unfortunate that superannuation and retirement incomes appear to be high on the political agenda for the forthcoming election. For example, there are the comments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about certain investment managers being lemons. The Prime Minister's comments are unfortunate and they do not create confidence about the industry. There is also the recent appointment of an additional minister in selling the virtues of superannuation. Thirdly, there is the slant of the educational campaign involving the money tree. These education moneys could be much better directed. In the situation of the highly emotional atmosphere of an election, pledges can be given which are not necessarily in the best long-term interest of the superannuation industry or its members. I appeal to all parties to keep their cool and to try to keep retirement incomes and superannuation on a bipartisan basis, if possible, in the interests of long-term superannuation and not use it as a vehicle to attract votes to win elections.

The main criticism that people have with superannuation is that the government has used superannuation to collect a lot of additional taxation revenue currently collecting over $1 1/2 billion. The speed and frequency of superannuation changes, of course, has left a lot of people bewildered, even those people with expertise within the industry. There is also a need for time for consolidation. However, there are still legislative gaps to be filled. It is therefore useful to use this occasion to dwell on about five problem areas that the government needs to address in relation to superannuation.

Firstly, people with intermittent work histories, particularly women. I draw the attention of the Senate to report No. 17 of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation which deals with people who have broken work force patterns. I recommend that senators read the report. Also, we are expecting too much of superannuation in attempting to solve problems which are outside the jurisdiction of superannuation. Therefore, there needs to be tax concessional savings vehicles outside superannuation to provide a greater degree of flexibility and to enable draw downs for particular needs such as future education, housing, finance and sickness. The trustee nature of superannuation is an important measure and, apart from the smaller funds, the requirements for 50 per cent representation from the employer and from the employee represent some of the best features of industrial democracy. Trustees have now come to the realisation that they must take off their particular hats from employer representation or employee representation, and apply their minds to promote the best interests of the fund members in the long term.

The second need is the need for comparative member statistics. A recent valuable regulation is the requirement that information and financial statements should include a five-year compound average rate of investment return, together with the yearly rate of return over the same period of the fund. In addition to this, I believe it is necessary to add a new regulation which will require comparison with what is known as an industry average, because we do not want people to get locked into poorly performing funds. Such a regulation would require further changes to transfer protocols and further extension of capital gains exemptions and similar mechanisms to allow amalgamation for poorly performing funds or funds which have got into difficulties.

The third issue which needs to be addressed concerns a practice within the industry which is known as short selling. I believe this activity is an illegal practice and should be looked at closely, because there are several players who indulge in this practice. There is a possible exception where short selling is permitted and that is in the area of what is known by the technical term `put options'.

The fourth issue concerns accounting standard AAS25 issued by the accounting profession, whereby superannuation funds are required to report and allocate interest on a current market basis. This measure acts to prevent funds adopting appropriate long-term buy and hold strategies—for example, in infrastructure, products and bonds.

The fifth issue concerns a duplication and confusion in the regulatory regimes—for example, the regulation of superannuation funds where members' benefits are provided and defined by life insurance policies.

Currently, trustees of such funds must abide by two sets of rules for the purpose of disclosure to prospective members and standard employer sponsors. A standard employer sponsor is an employer that has elected to provide superannuation benefits for its employees under a contractual arrangement with a superannuation fund trustee. There are two sets of rules: firstly, SIS regulations plus circulars and determinations issued by the Deputy Commissioner Superannuation and, secondly, circulars issued by the Deputy Commissioner Life Insurance.

In the latter case, there are two further different requirements depending on whether the policies are single or regular premium based. The difference under the circulars issued by the Life Insurance Commissioner lies in the way in which the effect of the changes has to be disclosed to the members such that, in respect of regular premium policies which have initial expenses which cause a policy to have little or no value in the early years of existence, companies are required to provide a number of tables to show what one can expect to get back through the life of the policy if particular assumptions are borne out.

What is required is that there should be sufficient disclosure for a member to understand the impact of costs on his or her benefit, but if one's benefit is likely to be in the short-term, and the long-term is important, it is important that those benefit illustrations should apply whether one's contributions are of a single premium nature or a regular premium nature.

What is further confusing in the life industry is that although the Life Insurance Circulars are directed at life insurers for the purpose of providing adequate disclosure protection to prospective policy owners, the SIS has specific provisions which will require trustees to provide members with sufficient information to be able to understand the impact of the charges on their particular benefits. The ISC seems to have decided that, besides SIS, the provisions of the LIC also need to apply to trustees which administer funds of life assurance policies.

The sixth issue that requires attention has arisen as a result of the demise of the Excelsior Managed Superannuation Plan. Unless tax bill No. 2 is passed before the Senate rises, there will be a problem regarding reassessment of deductibility amounts of the pre-1 July 1994 element of allocated pensions. There are also potential capital gains consequences of Excelsior transfers that are made as a consequence of the asset securities passing to another fund, whether through redemption or specie transfer.

A difficulty arises with the involuntary transfer of a superannuation benefit, whether an allocated pension or a pre-retirement accumulation, from one superannuation fund to another. The way to overcome these inherent problems is to provide amendments to the legislation which enable the transfer to be on a `trustee to trustee' basis rather than through withdrawal and re-entry mechanisms. Unfortunately, there will always be instances where funds fail, or get into difficulties, and where investment moneys have to be transferred from one fund to another. I repeat: the changes required are to make the transfers on a trustee to trustee basis.

The seventh need measure is that when a superannuation fund is first set up the regulations provide that it must become a regulated fund within seven days—and there are no exceptions. This time frame is absolutely too tight. What is required is a situation where that period is extended to 30 days for the trustees to apply to have the fund deemed a regulated fund. Further, there needs to be a discretion available to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to allow additional time for exceptional cases or situations.

I take this opportunity to congratulate my colleague from the other house, the honourable member for Bradfield, David Connolly, currently the shadow minister for superannuation and retirement incomes, on his successful lower house amendment which was accepted by the government and is now part of the bill in the Senate today. I congratulate him on his initiative and success in getting that amendment through. On four occasions similar measures have been put in both houses—twice in the House of Representatives and twice in the Senate. The issue I refer to is the removal of compulsory retirement at 65 years of age.

Finally, since my colleague in the House of Representatives, David Connolly, will not be recontesting the next election arising from certain preselection decisions, I wish to thank him for his friendship going back to the days when I was a raw recruit on first joining the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in 1978, a committee which David chaired with great distinction. Over the years, David Connolly has made a very distinguished contribution to superannuation. It has been most noticeable in recent years when he has been the coalition spokesman on superannuation. I thank him for his contribution to the parliament, wish him well in his future career and good health and send best wishes his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, particularly in relation to the issue of disability claims in which I have had a great interest. In some ways, the whole initiative for the legislation arose because of a disallowance to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal which I moved some long time ago and which prompted a very good response from the government. In relation to that, I would like to reiterate an interjection I tried to make during Senator Watson's speech, because I want to underline that it was multi-party support rather than bipartisan support which brought this legislation about. It is very good when we get multi-party support for legislation like this.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank the government, particularly the government staff who are here today and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, the Hon. Paul Elliott, because of the way in which they responded. We did have some complaints about the time but certainly no complaints about the availability and helpfulness which was provided to us, certainly to me, in regard to these amendments.

What I would like to put on the record is that, although we certainly support and do not want to hold up this legislation in any way, we were made aware of just a few problems even with this legislation. I guess that there is no legislation that could ever be passed that would not have some points about it that one would want to raise, but these points were raised with us by a coalition of groups. Perhaps I could mention them: the Consumers Federation of Australia, the Consumer Credit Legal Service New South Wales Inc., the Consumer Credit Legal Service Victoria, Maurice Blackburn and Co. and the Superannuation Consumer Coalition. While they, too, do not want any delay in the legislation, because they certainly see the benefit of it, they are just wanting to signal a few problems which could occur as unforeseen consequences of the legislation.

It is worth putting these on the record, and my appeal to the government would be that it take these on board. I am sure that, over the coming months as we monitor the performance of the tribunal in relation to these amendments, we could keep our eyes on the issues that are raised and there could be a subsequent response from the government if they do prove to be problems.

These are some of the issues which have been raised. A major concern is with the restriction on access to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal for people with disability claims in relation to some issues. They are that these people are usually particularly disadvantaged and having to cope with the stresses of a change in their quality of life. Under the draft subsection 14(6B), the tribunal will be unable to hear a complaint unless the claim was lodged with the trustee within a year of the person ceasing employment.

There are some problems with this restriction. In some cases, the medical condition may not completely manifest itself within the one-year period, or the doctor may not make an assessment that the person is totally and permanently disabled within that one-year period. These people will have the time limit elapse before they are actually able to claim. There is also, on the other side of that, the potential for members to clog the system by making claims within the one-year period when they may not yet be diagnosed in order to preserve their entitlement to subsequently proceed to the superannuation tribunal. I am sure the government can take that on board and monitor that.

Another issue is that there is a low level of community awareness amongst fund members of their entitlement to claim TPD benefits under superannuation schemes. The Superannuation (Industry Supervision) Act 1993 does not require trustees to give notice to fund members of their entitlement to TPD claims on leaving the fund. So it is possible that the current amendments could actually create an incentive for trustees—and I am not suggesting they would do this, but one never knows—not to make members aware of their potential entitlements.
Senator Watson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just what I was going to refer to, Senator Watson, thank you. That is a good comment. At the very least, if the one-year period is to remain, there should be a government commitment to educating individuals as to their entitlements, which is exactly what Senator Watson is saying. I think that was a very good interjection. There should be a proviso enabling a claim to be taken to the tribunal where the failure to lodge the claim was due to the actions of the trustees. I do not want to infer that trustees might do this but, unfortunately, I have had at least one example of a constituent of mine, on whose behalf I acted, where the trustees were obstructionist in terms of this person pursuing their claim. It was settled in the end but the trustees could have been a lot more helpful. So we are signalling that.

PARA.TAB: The restriction could limit access to a low-cost forum, therefore, for a group who have a pronounced need for it. Access to justice is an ideal to be lauded and promoted. I understand that there are a large number of clients who could now be forced to litigate their claims in the courts at greater expense and cost to all parties if some of the things that I have signalled eventuate.

Another issue is the concern with respect to the question of the interpretation of sections 14 and proposed section 14A of the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993. It is unclear yet how these two sections will interact. There is a possibility that the tribunal will interpret these sections in such a way that some complaints currently before the tribunal in respect of the sale of life insurance products under section 14 will be excluded because they do not fall within the new regime for the handling of complaints for the sales of life office products, which will only apply from the date of royal assent. I appreciate that the intention of the legislation is not to exclude these complaints but, should the tribunal take such a restrictive interpretation, these people will be left in a parlous position.

There is no intention, of course—I certainly would resist any thought—that any of these issues should be raised in a way which obstructs the passage of this legislation, but my appeal to the government is that, in monitoring the legislation, it takes these issues on board, which, if the problems which I have outlined do arise, will enable us to attempt to correct them. My intention is that the tribunal will operate effectively, especially on the part of those who do not have the resources to go into expensive litigation in order to obtain justice.

These amendments will ensure that, when all other avenues fail, people have access to a low-cost independent tribunal in order to progress their search for justice. I commend to the government the questions which have been raised with me and, I have no doubt, with other people. I am sure that other people in this place have received the same letter. I am very happy to indicate that the Democrats heartily support this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In concluding the debate for the government, I thank Senators Watson and Woodley for their contributions. They touched on a number of issues relating to superannuation which are not directly dealt with by this legislation, but they raised a number of issues which are pertinent. I do not know whether it is my luck or not, but I seem to end up dealing with superannuation legislation in this place. Of course, having been chair of the select committee prior to Senator Watson, I must say—
—It started your illustrious career, Senator.

—Yes, thank you very much. I must say that it is a very good committee. The committee is an excellent example of a select committee doing its job in a relatively bipartisan way—certainly as bipartisan as you can ever get in this place—in dealing with the issues appropriately. We cannot say the same for some other select committees, but this is another issue.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge the role of the member in the other place, Mr Connolly. The Christmas-New Year period is coming upon us quickly, and I enter into the goodwill spirit by thanking the opposition. I am doing this because, for the first time in 13 years, the opposition has accepted this government's superannuation policy, and I thank the opposition for this. For 13 years, the opposition has argued against our superannuation initiatives. The opposition has bagged us and criticised us by saying that the government's initiatives will cause unemployment. There was a barrage of other criticisms, but, at last, after 13 years, the opposition has adopted our policies. The opposition is going to leave our initiatives in place if it is elected to government. There are a couple of question marks on a couple of issues, but at last the opposition has accepted the broad parameters of the government's approach, and we welcome this.

This is my first opportunity in this place to put that on record. We welcome the fact that the opposition has adopted this government's policies on superannuation. Why? Some people will charge that it is just political expediency: the opposition wants to narrow the differences at the next election. I think it is a sign of a couple of interesting things. Firstly, it highlights the lack of imagination and vision in opposition policy development—with the exception of you, Senator Watson, and Mr Connolly. I acknowledge that both of you, over the years, have taken a very realistic and practical approach when it comes to debating our policy. I cannot say the same for some other members of the opposition, but I acknowledge your roles and put that on the record.

I think this highlights the fact that, when the opposition wants to adopt policies, it looks to adopt them from the government. That is a very welcome position and I note that this is happening in numerous other areas. As I said, I want to end this debate and the year on an harmonious note. It is the time of Christmas goodwill. What better way to note the goodwill than by the bipartisan position we now have on superannuation?
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it is the Christmas season, I do not want to indicate a note of disharmony. However, after 13 years, certain contracts and arrangements with superannuation are well entrenched, and this is part of the reason why the coalition has moved towards accepting the superannuation guarantee charge. Further, the coalition does not want to create further uncertainties to superannuation. Frequency of change and the nature of those changes have been major criticisms of the current regime. A third reason is the difficulty in unscrambling the eggs created over such a long period of Labor rule. I thank you, Senator Sherry, for your acknowledgments; I wish the bill a speedy passage.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sherry) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Sherry)—by leave—agreed to:
That the order of the Senate agreed to on 29 November 1994 relating to the consideration of bills not apply to the National Food Authority Amendment Bill 1995.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the National Food Authority Amendment Bill 1995. The bill provides some of the enabling machinery to implement a food standards harmonisation treaty with New Zealand, and the coalition wishes every success for the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Harmonisation Treaty, which will be signed next week.

PARA.TAB: The trans-Tasman trade in food products is above the billion dollar mark and, therefore, of great value. In bringing this situation about, the bill is probably of more benefit to New Zealand than it is to Australia. However, in the other chamber both the shadow minister for health and human services and the shadow minister for consumer affairs, Mr Warren Truss, pointed out some of the problems which are related to the bill, although welcoming it coming before the parliament as a treaty before the legislation, which, as you know, is not a frequent occurrence in this parliament.

The trans-Tasman trade in food products is, as I mentioned, beneficial to both sides. This legislation has been rushed through parliament quickly and there has not been a lot of consideration given to it in the chambers themselves. Consumer groups have expressed some concern about a number of aspects of the legislation. One concern, for example, is the fact that the representatives are, effectively, appointed by the two governments. This means that, if government and industry have a representative from New Zealand, there is a risk that consumers' voices may be somewhat reduced. Consumers are concerned that the harmonisation process could lead to lower Australian standards in some areas and they are also concerned that, among the nine food code objectives outlined in the treaty to be signed, quality is not listed as a stated objective.

There are also transitional arrangements which cause concern, in that food which does not meet the Australian standards but does meet the New Zealand standards will be able to be sold in this country during the transitional arrangements. Further concerns relate to cadmium and heavy metals and these concerns were canvassed by Mr Truss in the other chamber. In conclusion, we need to be reassured by the minister that these concerns are being addressed, and I ask that the minister do so in his remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially, when we first looked through the legislation, for the reasons Senator Herron has outlined we were not prepared to see the National Food Authority Amendment Bill 1995 pass through this place as a non-controversial bill. We sought a number of assurances and a considerable amount of additional material from the minister. Our particular concerns centred around the fact that the bill deletes the words `providing it does not lower the Australian standard' from the objectives of the National Food Authority. These objectives are what the National Food Authority must consider when setting food standards.

PARA.TAB: However, after considerable correspondence and, in particular, a letter from Dr Andrew Theophanous—which I will quote shortly—the Democrats agreed that we would let this legislation pass through this place as non-controversial at this point in time. However, I must ask also for further assurances from the minister, in particular in relation to the disallowable instruments which, I understand, will come before us. The letter of assurance that we received from the minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian standard will not be lowered to an international standard and the quality of food will not drop. If there is any adverse impact on any of these high ranked objectives in particular, the authority is required to put the promotion of trade and commerce in the food industry, including issues such as Australia's clean and green reputation for foods, ahead of harmonisation with international standards. This ensures that Australian standards will not be lowered for the sake of harmonisation with international standards.

I ask now that the minister reiterate that we will indeed see before us disallowable instruments if any standards set by the authority are changed so that we in the Senate will all have an opportunity to discuss and debate any changes to ensure full and proper scrutiny so that the Australian public can benefit from these new arrangements with New Zealand.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
