TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to seek further advice and give you assurance on that last issue if I am able. We were not aware that an assurance was required here and now on that matter, but we will certainly attempt to get you the information and assurance on that issue.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank Senators Lees and Herron for their constructive contributions in this debate. There are some outstanding issues that require clarification and I am happy to provide assurances along these lines.

The treaty to harmonise food standards with New Zealand specifically exempts the specification of maximum residue limits for agricultural and veterinary chemicals in food, also known as MRLs. It also exempts, for the transitional period, the specification of maximum permitted concentrations for metals and contaminants, or MPCs, for cadmium. When the trans-Tasman mutual recognition arrangement between Australia and New Zealand comes into force, Australia will be able to seek a temporary or permanent exemption from their arrangement on environmental grounds or on the grounds that there is a risk to public health or safety.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Andrew Theophanous, who is responsible for the National Food Authority, hereby gives an assurance on behalf of the government that, if standards for MPCs and MRLs are not harmonised by the time the trans-Tasman mutual recognition arrangements come into force, then a further exemption will be sought to exclude MRLs and MPCs. Again, I thank senators on all sides of the chamber for their cooperation in support of this important legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 September, on motion by Senator Bob Collins:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with the Industrial Relations and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, I wish to go back to 1993 when the Industrial Reform Act was before us. There is no doubt that it was one of the most controversial pieces of legislation to ever be brought in here. I remember well when we were debating it that the gallery was full of people who were absolutely disenchanted with what the government was bringing before them, particularly with regard to the provisions that we are now dealing with—the unfair dismissal provisions. They were described—not by myself—by various commentators and people involved in the industry as being totally unfair, inequitable and unbalanced; and it was said they would create a bureaucratic nightmare.

PARA.TAB: In a moment or two I shall deal with that bureaucratic nightmare and put on the record some of the outcomes that have occurred as a result of that particular legislation. I also wish to move a second reading amendment, copies of which are about to be distributed, I understand, around the chamber. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

"but the Senate, whilst recognising that this Bill provides some improvement to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act, is of the opinion that, even as amended, the unfair dismissal provisions of the Act remain a disincentive to job creation, impose a very heavy burden on business, particularly on small business, and were enacted without proper prior consultation".

I particularly refer to the last words in that amendment, that they `were enacted without proper and prior consultation'. If we remember back to the Senate inquiry in 1993, one of the most consistent themes from every submission we received, even from some of the union submissions, was that there was a lack of consultation in putting that legislation together. Once again, in dealing with this side of it and in our discussions with ACCI, the National Farmers Federation, MTIA and a number of other employer organisations, we have had exactly the same concerns put to us. We have also had those concerns put to us by the state governments because this legislation has a very big impact on the operations of the state industrial systems. It would appear that, even though it was promised, there was virtually no consultation, and certainly no meaningful consultation with the states, in regard to the problems that have been created by the unfair dismissal provisions.

PARA.TAB: Just to recap, I mention the bureaucratic nightmare that has been caused with regard to the unfair dismissal provisions. I did ask some questions at estimates this year about this and at that particular time, 29 May 1995, following that legislation, there had been some 9,921 applications brought forward with regard to unfair dismissal. That now exceeds 10,000, and there is a significant backlog in handling those applications. That was not something that occurred under the previous system when they were dealt with much more fairly, much more swiftly and much more consistently.

While we on our side of the chamber certainly are not opposed to having provisions for people who have genuine concerns about what occurred with their dismissal or the ending of their particular job, we believe that this legislation needs further amendment in terms of the unfair dismissal provisions. It is worth noting that there is much debate about industrial systems and what is the best system in this country, but one thing is for certain: it does not seem to matter, and I do not believe it will matter, what system there is because there will be those who will claim that they have been unfairly dismissed and those who actually treat somebody unfairly in the workplace.

Whatever system we have, it will be necessary to have a proper, fair, easily accessible, cheap, quick way of dealing with these particular matters. To have this sort of log jam in our industrial system now really reflects just how poorly and how badly that legislation has worked. It was a point that we raised over and over again on behalf of a number of people at that particular time. The key aspects of this particular legislation will now commence in the Industrial Relations Commission rather than in the Industrial Relations Court of Australia.

We think that that is basically a change to the starting point. We do not believe that it is going to help significantly in terms of dealing with the fundamental problems with the application, although there will be more emphasis on conciliation when dealing with them. One improvement in this particular legislation, which I am quite prepared to recognise, is that it will now be looking at all circumstances involved in the case whereas previously it did not.

I have mentioned some of the issues surrounding this legislation. I will now re-emphasise them and put them in a logical sequence. First, at the Labor Ministers Council meeting in Hobart on 19 May 1995, the federal minister, Mr Brereton, indicated that no amendments to the federal act would be considered for at least 12 months or until after the federal election. These amendments have been brought in hurriedly and there has been no consultation. While I am not criticising Mr Brereton for bringing in what he has, I do say that he should have met the commitment that consultation take place with the states.

There are some amendments from the Democrats which I will briefly touch on. They concern costs of the court and the commission. I did make representations to Senator Bell to include, in terms of those amendments, both the court and the commission. He acknowledged that the Democrats would do that and we will be supporting those amendments. But with respect to the amendments being put forward by Senator Spindler regarding the National Labour Consultative Council we will not be supporting those. I shall make some comments with regard to those in a moment.

In terms of dealing with this legislation now, I thought it would be useful if I went over a few of the key points of where the coalition sits in terms of industrial relations, particularly in view of the fact that there will be an election next year. I particularly want to emphasise that we believe in the principle of the freedom of choice, across the full spectrum of what that means. We believe in freedom of association, whether you want to belong to a union or whether you do not want to belong to a union. We believe that people should have the choice of the type of industrial system they work under, whether it be a workplace agreement, or a certified agreement, or an enterprise flexibility agreement or an award. That will be a central plank of our policy position, as has already been outlined by Mr Reith and Mr Howard. I think it is very important to modernise, and to move at the pace that the rest of the world is with modernising the workplace so that freedom of choice is an essential characteristic of it.

The next point that I raise is the principle that all Australians be treated equally before the law. The principle in terms of being treated equally before the law is that they must behave equally before the law. One cannot help but note in today's newspaper, with regard to the unfortunate occurrences up at Weipa and the millions and millions of dollars that have been lost through that industrial dispute, the threats of possible further industrial action by, I think, the metals union.

Even though a decision was made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission last week with regard to the resolving of the particular concerns before that tribunal, it was not until yesterday that the decision was made for those striking workers at Weipa to go back. In our view, that is not good enough and that must be dealt with so that people behave within the law. The decision was made and the instruction was given. In fact, the instruction to go back to work was given on a number of occasions during the dispute but no notice was taken of it. We cannot have a legal situation where one side of the equation obeys the law and the other side just thumbs its nose at it as it chooses. That is what has been happening.

The coalition will maintain the current award system overseen by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The coalition will support the jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to deliver safety net wage increases for the lowest paid. The coalition will retain the certified agreement system but reform it to enable CAs to reflect more accurately the circumstances of individual enterprises.

The government system of enterprise flexibility agreements, we believe, and we said at the time of the legislation, has failed. It has not had the penetration that is really necessary for a modernised workplace, and we will change that and put in place workplace agreements. These workplace agreements will allow clearly and succinctly either individual workplace agreements or collective workplace agreements—whatever the employees in a particular workplace might choose to do.

Workplace agreements must pass a no-disadvantage test against fair and responsible community standards which will ensure adequate protection, especially for the low paid. Although this is not a total list—there will be further announcements in due course—these conditions will include the relevant applicable classification award hourly rate; four weeks paid annual leave; two weeks paid sick leave; 12 months parental leave; family leave in accordance with the AIRC decision; equal pay for equal work of equal value; and jury service. When we get back, we will—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the policy. Are you listening?
—When are we going to get the rest of it?
—Just quieten down a bit and just listen! You remind me of a puppy dog and when puppy dogs were made.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order, Senator Crane!

TALK.START.PARA: —They forgot to give you a tail and they forgot to give you some brains.
—Senator Crane, you might like to address the chair, please.
—I am addressing the chair.
—When are we getting the rest? Why are we waiting?
—Excuse me. Senator Sherry might also like to be quiet.
—I was provoked by Senator Sherry. So you address him, and then I will listen to you.
—I have just asked Senator Sherry to desist. I ask you to address the chair.

—We will be reintroducing sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. They will be reinstated. The fundamental failure over the last few weeks was due to the fact that there was no mechanism by which those third, fourth and fifth parties, who were innocently affected and held up, could take action to recover their damages. As I said earlier, the unfair dismissal provisions will be amended to ensure a fair go all around. Compulsory unionism will be abolished. Workers will have the right to be in a union, the right to choose which union they want to be in, and the right not to be in a union.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will permit the dis-amalgamation of unions where that is the desire of the unionists themselves. I emphasise what I said at the start of my comments in terms of that freedom of choice, and that is a fundamental part of our policy position. The coalition will make it an offence to attempt to force an independent contractor to join a union or to discriminate against the contractor on the grounds of union membership or non-membership.

I said that I would make some comments on the amendment of the National Labour Consultative Council. We believe that the National Labour Consultative Council does need reforming but we do not agree with the way the Democrats have suggested that it should be reformed. I believe that Senator Spindler is handling this particular aspect.

Senator Spindler's amendment—and we have not seen the final amendment—is similar to the amendment that was moved in 1993 when the IR reform act was before us. In regard to these suggested changes, we are concerned that there has not been consultation with the various members of the NLCC at this particular time. Nor has there been consultation with a number of other employer organisations, some outside the ACTU.

There has been no consultation with these organisations as to how a reformed National Labour Consultative Council should work. Nor has there been any discussion or consultation with any of the states as to how this will work. We believe that we should at least examine, when we look at what exists in the various states, whether there is a role for a state representative on this particular council.

The other sector that is totally ignored by the National Labour Consultative Council is the non-union sector. We now see that close to 75 per cent of the Australian work force is not represented by the union movement. We believe that we should at least examine whether there is a mechanism that can be put in place to give that portion of the work force an opportunity to have representation so that they can put their views about what they require in terms of dealing with any industrial relations matters before them.

For those reasons, we will not support those amendments. However, we give notice that when we are in government we will be looking at this. We will be getting the parties together to examine and upgrade the role of the National Labour Consultative Council. While the consultative council did have some forceful or useful activities under previous ministers, there is no doubt that since Mr Brereton has been the minister it has been almost a totally non-active council.

We do not believe these amendments go far enough. We do not believe that there is fairness between the parties as far as the unfair dismissal provisions are concerned. When we are in government we will address the particular further concerns that will be required to be dealt with under this legislation. We have seen over the last three or four months a real dose of the destruction that can occur when an industrial system goes wrong. We have seen what can happen when the balance between the parties gets out of kilter. We have seen unnecessary damage to the Australian economy in that particular time. We have seen action taken—led by the ACTU, I believe for political reasons, and secretly and quietly endorsed by the government—that was not necessary.

I once again make the point that had the minister, Mr Brereton, or the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), or any other minister for that matter, taken action under section 99(2) of the Industrial Relations Act, the matter could have been brought before the arbitration commission much sooner. The strike could have been avoided and we need not have seen the millions and millions of dollars lost as far as that legislation is concerned. Australia's industrial relations system is lagging behind the rest of the world. We are not meeting the productivity requirements that are required to be competitive out in the workplace. We, on our side of politics, have certainly committed ourselves to doing something about it. We will be addressing those particular issues as we go into the next election.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any questions?
—Where is Senator Bob Collins? Is he coming to question time today?
—We told you yesterday about his absence today.

—Nonetheless, we are grateful that the Leader of the Government in the Senate has called in today, so I will ask him a question. According to the World Bank, Australia fell from 19th in the world in 1992 to 22nd in 1993 in terms of international per capita income. Now the Business Council expects that we will slide even further. Why is Australia, one of the world's most resource rich countries, continuing to slide down the international league table? Is it because, as the McKinsey study shows, Australia's relatively low productivity is costing the country around $30 billion a year in lost opportunities, cut prices and increased wages, or is it simply that after 13 years of Labor this is as good as it gets?

—This is a pretty extraordinary question to ask in a week in which we have just had an announcement of a 1.6 per cent growth for this quarter, which indicates that we are absolutely on track to sustain a very substantial and, importantly, positive rate of growth for the period ahead, just as we have for the last 17 quarters, which is an Australian record since these statistics were kept. The Australian economy is in remarkably good shape in terms of all the basic fundamentals. You know what those fundamentals are, and I will be happy to repeat them.

PARA.TAB: The crucial further statistic that emerged this week is the balance of payments figures, external debt, the external payments account. The October figures of this morning demonstrate absolutely, again, that we are on track in terms of the current account deficit recording its sixth consecutive monthly decrease in trend terms and reaching its lowest level since February 1994 in such trend terms. It is absolutely in line with the government's budget forecast, despite all the scepticism, neurosis and angst that you were hurling at us for months on end. The parrots are not talking about the current account deficit any more—the caravan has moved on—because basically we have a structural environment in terms of our capacity to go on generating exports that will keep that merchandise account positive, making this not a problem of any significant magnitude at all.

All the other elements of our economic environment—productivity performance, investment growth, export growth and the capacity, at the same time as we are growing in all these respects, to sustain a wage environment, including the social wage—make us the envy of the other developed economies. There are fundamental disparities which exist between economies like North America, where you have a high wage environment and high levels of efficiency in many ways in the economy but a very poor social justice set of indicators running alongside that, compared with the dilemma faced, on the other hand, by developed countries in Europe where everything is doing fine in social justice terms and social equity terms but you have fundamental inefficiencies evident in that side of the economy. Australia has it right; we have the balance right in all those respects.

I have not seen the particular figures to which Senator Alston is referring. It is inevitable, given the explosive growth of so many economies in the East Asian region, that there would be some change in relativities in terms of income per head figures. That has been a fact of life throughout the course of this century. None of these things are ever static. In terms of the fundamental strength of the economy, the sustainability of the growth that we have in the economy, the way in which interest rates and inflation and all those other key indicators have a capacity to sustain growth on an ongoing basis in an employment reducing way, the way all those figures are coming together gives Australia absolutely nothing whatsoever to be ashamed about in terms of international comparisons; in fact, a very great deal to be proud of.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note your shamelessness. You are quite keen on reading editorials, so why is the Financial Review not correct when it says today:

QUESTION.PARA: The harsh reality is that, once the one-off bounceback in rural output and the unsustainable lift in stock levels are removed, the result is a domestic economy as flat as the proverbial pancake.

Why isn't Max Walsh correct when he simply analyses quite factually that domestic demand growth in the economy fell away during the September quarter, personal consumption expenditure grew at less than half the rate in September than in June, and private business expenditure on equipment actually fell in September compared with an increase in the June quarter? Why won't you come clean and face the facts that this country is going backwards, our standard of living is declining, our productivity levels are at record lows and the place has run out of steam? Why won't you face up to those facts rather than simply resorting to silly and irrelevant rhetoric?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing silly or irrelevant about the basic strengths of the Australian economy as I have described them. There is nothing silly or irrelevant about the fact that we have just achieved a 1.6 per cent quarter of growth following one per cent growth in the June quarter before that—a growth largely due to net exports as well as an increase in stocks, a growth that is obviously significantly attributable to the bounce-back of the farm sector, but which has a lot of inherent strength about it.

PARA.TAB: The fundamentals of the Australian economy are as rock solid and sound as they have ever been. If someone in the editorial department of the Financial Review wants to be a churl about finding something to complain about in order to accommodate the neuroses of its basic domestic constituency, not to mention the one opposite, so be it. But we are confident about the strength of the economy. We are confident, as we have to be, as any Australian would be, about an economy that has been growing for 17 consecutive quarters—an Australian record. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Indeed, it might be the last question to the present Minister for Trade that is asked from this side of the chamber. I would like to pay tribute to the way he has answered questions during his time here. They have been eloquent answers which have been put with well-turned phrases. They have been responsive, succinct and clear of any remarks that may upset honourable senators. Indeed, they have been typical of the quick, smart, responsive answers given by our ministers.
—I hope the question is a short one.

—It is a very short question. In fact, it is one that is very well put by the minister himself. What do recent data such as today's balance of payments figures indicate about the direction of Australia's trade performance?

—I thank Senator Cooney for his characteristically eloquent question. I hope nobody is under the misleading impression that I am heartbroken about the fact that this will be my last Senate question time.
—Not necessarily. We could be back.
—Do you want a bet?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—On a point of order, Mr President: is Senator McMullan giving notice to this chamber that, even if the parliament sits next year, he will prefer to stay overseas, like Senator Evans?
—There is no point of order. A good point, but not a point of order.

—It is interesting to put the current export situation in a bit of an historic context, because by some accounts Tuesday of this week saw an important anniversary in Australia's economic history. The historians suggest that 28 November 1795 was the first day of any commercial export from Australia—from the Hawkesbury region of New South Wales to India. It was the first recorded export in our post-European settlement.

PARA.TAB: So we are talking about 200 years of Australia as an exporting nation. We spent a lot of those 200 years missing a lot of good opportunities and surviving on the basis of extraordinary resource potential and failure to develop all the other opportunities, particularly over the period from the 1950s to the 1980s, when our sloth allowed a lot of good opportunities to go unremarked. But in the past decade we have seen a fundamental and qualitative change in our trade performance.

Let us have a look at some of the key figures in this last week which indicate the direction and the strength of the changes taking place. This supports entirely the point that Senator Gareth Evans has just made. For the first time in our history, last Tuesday's figures show that we have achieved a quarterly surplus in our trade in services, which is where the world's economic trade growth is most concentrated. That is a first in our history.

Yesterday we saw the release of the national accounts that showed net exports contributed 1.3 per cent to GDP growth. While people are saying, `Somehow or other that's a problem,' that is exactly the sort of growth Australia needs—growth generated by net exports. Today's balance of payments figures confirm a significant improvement in our current account outlook, which is causing so much anxiety for our colleagues across the way who wish things would continue to get worse. They continue to pray for disaster and get disappointed when they find any success.

These indicators suggest that Australia may well have stepped onto a higher economic growth path based on improved export performance, particularly compared with our record in the two decades up to the 1980s. For example, over the last decade, merchandise exports have recorded average trend growth of 8.7 per cent a year and manufactured exports have grown even more quickly, by 15 per cent a year. Elaborately transformed manufactures have grown by 17 per cent and services have grown by nine per cent.

So we are seeing that there is every indication that this higher growth path can be sustained into the next century. We have already broken the Australian record for sustained economic growth. The important thing to note is that our trade strategy and performance suggest that we can sustain that economic growth into the next decade with all the consequential benefits for jobs and living standards which follow from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. What is the government doing in trade policy to lock in these gains and build on them?

—In a minute one cannot be very comprehensive about that, but there are three tiers of trade strategy to deal with those issues: firstly, at the global level, through the World Trade Organisation, to which Australia will be adding by the conference we are holding in Brisbane in February to build momentum for further reform at the multilateral level; secondly, there is regional policy—most noticeably, but not only, APEC; and, thirdly, on the bilateral front, early next year I will be releasing the annual trade and investment development paper. At that time I also propose to outline a strategy to take advantage of the trade opportunities in our most prospective markets, together with an outlook for Australian exports to the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: That integrated multilateral, regional and trade strategy builds on the indications I mentioned before to confirm reasonable ground for optimism that exports will continue to pump into growth right through until the end of the century.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. According to Professor Bob Gregory of the Australian National University and long-term member of the Reserve Bank Board, the average income in the poorest of Australian households has fallen by almost $8,000 in real terms and in the highest earning households has increased by nearly $13,000 in real terms. Why, after 13 years of Labor, has income fallen in 70 per cent of the households and risen only in 30 per cent? Why, after 13 years of Labor, have over 750,000 households been added to the battler category with over one million battler households anticipated by the year 2000? Why, after 13 years of Labor, do we have more poor than ever before, with over 767,000 unemployed, with nearly two million of our people living in poverty and with almost 600,000 of those people in poverty being children? After 13 years of Labor, why can't the Australian people presume that Labor has lost its way? (Time expired)

—For an opposition whose leader cannot quite remember the commitment to maintaining pensions at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and has to stumble and fumble his way through any question he is ever asked on something that goes to the real capacity of people at the lower end of the income spectrum in this country to survive effectively and for an opposition who are as utterly indifferent as you are to these sorts of issues to make assertions of the kind that you have and to question the income distribution that has been achieved under us in this country not only demonstrates extreme ignorance as to what has been achieved over the last decade or more but also represents an extreme dose of cheek from you, given the events, as I say, over the last few days.

PARA.TAB: The whole point about income distribution within Australia is that it can be understood only in the context of the social wage, which is the means by which the government provides health, education, housing and child-care benefits to all Australians. The increases and the improvements in that social wage and in benefits delivered in ways other than through the wage packet have had a dramatic impact in redistributing income to those most in need. Recent research from NCSEM has found that the social wage has increased—

TALK.START.PARA: —Six hundred thousand children are living in poverty.

—Listen to this, Senator Knowles. The social wage has increased from $969 in 1982-83 to $1,677 in 1994-95. It is the case that low and middle income families benefit very substantially from the non-cash component of the social wage. For example, an average middle income family receives benefits now valued at $225 per week. That is on top of the 146 per cent increase in social security payments that has been achieved between 1983 and 1995. For example, additional family payments for children from 13 years to 15 years have increased by 146 per cent; rent assistance has increased by between 78 per cent and 137 per cent; the age pension, about which those on your side are so ignorant and indifferent, has increased by between 13 per cent and 14 per cent; and real household disposable income has increased by 41.5 per cent during the period between the March quarter 1983 and the June quarter 1995.

PARA.TAB: Again, the research by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling shows that during the 1980s the richest 10 per cent of the population got poorer, relatively speaking, and those with low and middle incomes in fact got richer. It is a matter of understanding the relevant components that go into the equation.

Preliminary results from the University of Melbourne study support that. They show that, once the impact of governmental intervention in the form of cash income support, the way the tax system operates and non-cash social wage benefits are all taken into account, the small increase in the dispersion of private incomes that has been evident since 1981-82 and to which you are referring is in fact reversed. It is reversed in its practical impact. In fact, the distribution of income was more equal in 1993-94, the last year for which the University of Melbourne study is applicable, than it was in 1981-82.

The facts are these: government intervention, our government's intervention, through the cash transfer system, through the tax system and through the social wage generally has increased the living standards of Australians across all incomes and contributed to increased equality in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I have never heard a greater clarification of how out of touch this government really is. My supplementary question will repeat some of those allegations—
—Allegations!

—Some of those facts—not allegations but facts. If everything is so good under your government, as you have just said it is, why has income fallen in 70 per cent of households around Australia? Why have 750,000 households been added to the battler category? Why are there 767,000 people unemployed and living in poverty? Why are there 600,000 children living in poverty if it is all as good as you just said it is? Your time is up. You have let people down. Why don't you shift on and have an election?

—Senator Knowles will not be told, but let me tell her: the household expenditure survey on which she is basing her figures provides only information based on gross income. It does not pick up the redistributive effect of the tax system or the non-cash benefits of the social wage. This survey and ones like it, including the OECD one which I think you referred to earlier—the Luxembourg income study, the international one—do not show the total picture in terms of the real income distribution and the real total picture as it exists when you take into account the tax system, when you take into account cash transfers and when you take into account all the other benefits of the social wage.

PARA.TAB: If you scratch anyone out there in the community who is receiving those benefits, you will get the answer that you do not want to have, and that answer is that this is a more equal society than it was when we came to office and it is a society and a country with a very proud record of social justice and distributive equality. Our record has been absolutely first class across all those fronts. You are just a bunch of shonks and will forever remain so. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, no doubt you will be aware of the keen interest which members of the Australian parliament, and the Senate in particular, take in developments in Burma and in the struggle for democracy which is currently going on there. Could you give the government's view on the latest reports that the political situation in Myanmar is deteriorating and that there is a risk that backward steps may be taken?

—There is a mounting concern, which I share, about current political developments in Burma, Myanmar, where the SLORC's refusal to enter into any kind of meaningful dialogue with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi since her release is causing increased tension.
—With you! You can't blame them for that.

—I am particularly concerned, as senators more sensitive than Senators Alston over there would also be, no doubt, by press reports that special army guards have been placed outside the houses of several National League for Democracy, NLD, leaders and that there is widespread speculation that some re-arrests may be imminent. Such a course, if it were to occur, would be a very serious development and a clear demonstration, if we have not had this already, that the release of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and the whole national convention process were not motivated by a genuine desire on the part of the SLORC to bring about democratic change in Burma.

PARA.TAB: The most obvious formal vehicle for that process of reconciliation and democratic change would obviously be the national convention, but the lack of confidence in the convention by the NLD is such that, following the opening session of the resumed convention a couple of days ago, on 28 November, the NLD has decided to withdraw its delegates.

As I have said on many occasions, the Australian government has reservations about the composition and process of the convention. We have encouraged the government of Myanmar, or Burma, to open up membership of the convention to make it more representative, both of the will of the people at large and also specifically the ethnic composition of the country, and also to permit within the convention more open discussion and debate of the issues that are vitally important to the country's political future. If this were done, the credibility of the process would manifestly improve and the chances of the convention's conclusions being accepted by the people of Myanmar, as well as being better recognised overseas, would be significantly increased.

So we urge once again the SLORC and all the political parties to proceed with caution, to address their differences through dialogue in a spirit of national reconciliation. Both the SLORC and the NLD remain on record as acknowledging the importance of national reconciliation; the important thing is to actually deliver it.

Can I say finally that the Australian government continues to urge all parties to proceed peacefully and to avoid any possibility of a repeat of the mass civil disturbances and violence, the extreme and outrageous violence, that marred Burma in 1988 and 1989. It is obvious that confrontation and violence are not going to resolve the current political problems in the country. Dialogue undertaken in a spirit of genuine reconciliation should be able to achieve the stated aim of both the government and the NLD, which is to establish a stable and peaceful multi-party democratic system of government. This is manifestly the desire of the people of Burma. It is also the desire of the whole international community. We all want to see that troubled country finally achieve the peace and prosperity that were promised in the years immediately after independence but which have been so long denied.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans also. It concerns a meeting of the ACT branch of the Public Service Union today, where unionists are complaining of the redistribution of income in the Public Service from the lower income earners to higher income earners. They point out that, since this Labor government assumed office in 1983, wages for lower and middle grades in the APS have fallen between one and 15 per cent, while real incomes for the highest grades have risen between 11 and 33 per cent. That is, all low and middle income earners in the Public Service have suffered big declines while the highest earners have enjoyed big successes. Why is this so? Why haven't you protected your own low and middle income employees? Isn't this neglect of your own employees typical of your attitudes and policies which have created such a gap between high and low income earners right across the country?

—I do not follow with the attention I obviously should the processes of the ACT branch of the PSU and I am not familiar with any current discontent that may have been articulated by them today or at any other time. I would be interested to hear what your side of politics is saying about that particular process within the Public Service, which has been one of steady improvement in conditions, as you would expect, over that period. It has been accompanied certainly by some increases in remuneration at the higher levels of the Public Services—increases in remuneration which we have not heard you challenge at any stage of that process because you have argued them to be, as we have acknowledged, necessary to maintain competitiveness at the higher managerial levels within the service with salaries and remuneration that are on offer outside.

PARA.TAB: The important thing is that those who are at the lower ends of the spectrum within the Public Service not fall behind the rest of the community in real terms, in terms of standard of living slippages. That is something we have been able to achieve for the Public Service in exactly the same way as we have been able to achieve it for the community as a whole—that is, through cash transfer payments, the operation of the tax system and all those other elements of the social wage that you simply refuse to acknowledge are currently very much part of the real equality of distribution of income and distribution of access to resources that exists in this country at the moment.

The Public Service employees are, in that sense, no different from the community as a whole and their remuneration would need necessarily to be looked at against exactly the background of those additional considerations that are the case for lower income earners absolutely everywhere else. If Senator Hill has a different view as to how this particular remuneration system ought to work for the Public Service, now is the time for him to be telling us about it, along with telling us every other aspect of your policy approach which at the moment you remain silent about. If you are not prepared to do so you should not be challenging what is a manifestly equitable and just system of income delivery that we have been able to achieve.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How can the minister justify, after 13 years of Labor, his administration leading to lower real wages for average earners and lower in the Public Service? The union's background material states:

QUESTION.PARA: The government's accords with the union have only served to redistribute income from the workers to management. Workers have increased their productivity since 1983; however, they have been rewarded with lower real wages.
How do you justify an administration that has rewarded workers in your employment with lower real wages?

TALK.START.PARA: —In public sector employment as everywhere else in the community, such small increase in the dispersion of private income as has been evident over the last decade, and is frankly acknowledged in all the research, is absolutely reversed when you take into account the operation of the tax system, the operation of various forms of cash income support and the non-cash social wage benefits, the health and education benefits and all the rest that we have been delivering. That is the way it works.

PARA.TAB: Every single safety net increase that I can recall being put before you has been the subject of either challenge or opposition. Absolutely no understanding of the way in which this system operates and how these benefits actually work to the advantage of the lower paid has ever been evident in any of your thinking, any of your performances, any of your behaviour, and it is not evident now in any of the promises that you are making to the Australian community. You are not making any promises. You do not understand the way the system operates. The way the system operates has been fundamentally fair and just for all Australian wage earners.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. This may be his last answer. The minister would be aware of the concern in Japan about red-back spiders which may have travelled in woodchip ships. In view of our obligations under GATT and the imbalance of our trade in pests and recognising that woodchip ships have provided Australia with such things as the Northern Pacific sea star, dinoflagellates and several species of seaweed, is the export of the red-back a deliberate step by the government to fulfil our GATT obligations? If so, what are we sending in the next woodchip ship—a couple of funnel web spiders, a few Ross River mosquitos and a root knot nematode? Will these be seen as primary exports or are you going to go into a bit of downstream processing?

—We may call for tenders for any suggestions as to what we might send. If you would like to nominate certain candidates who are running against you in the election for inclusion, we would be quite prepared to give that serious consideration. But it is a short list, so you will have to get in very quickly, Senator.

PARA.TAB: The only serious point I want to make in response to that profound and important question is: I do not wish to acknowledge in any way that the source of any possible red-back spider infestation in Japan is from Australia. It is very important that we do not. There is a serious probability that it came from other sources of timber, because we are not the biggest timber product supplier to Japan and we are not the only timber product supplier to Japan who has red-back spiders. I do not seriously want to acknowledge that point because it may do us some damage, although it is important to make clear that there is no current indication that the alarmist publicity in Japan has had any impact on our trade performance in the Osaka region.

In addition to that, for all the more substantial matters about policy on forests, I would suggest you listen to the statement the Prime Minister is making now, or give it serious and worthwhile attention at its conclusion, and to the forest product statement that will be made tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The teen unemployment rate, Minister, as you know, is currently 29 per cent—even higher than it was at the start of the Working Nation programs. How worse off we are is actually illustrated by the fact that, after the annual influx of school leavers onto the jobs market in December last year—that is, 1994—the rate was 27.7 per cent. Every December in the last decade, under your government's policies, the teen jobless rate has jumped an average of four per cent at the end of the school year. What fairytale will you peddle to the 40,000 school leavers looking for work but unable to find a job, who are destined to become officially unemployed at the end of this month?

—First of all, I want to again state the true facts about this definition of youth unemployment. I have said before in the parliament that the full-time teenage unemployment rate is 29 per cent, but that does not mean that 29 per cent of Australian teenagers are unemployed. That is because only 25 per cent of teenagers were available for full-time work in October—that is the last month we got the figures; 55 per cent were in school; and 13 per cent were in full-time post-school education. What we should focus on is the 95,600 teenagers looking for full-time work, which is 7.5 per cent of the total teenage population.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting, of course, that Labor has reduced this number from when John Howard was Treasurer, when the population was a lot smaller. He had 158,000 teenagers in 1983 who did not have a job, which amounted to over 12 per cent of the total teenagers. Again, and I have said this before on behalf of the government, this consistent idea that 29 per cent of teenagers are out of work, to imply that all of those teenagers are seeking work, is not true.

However, Senator Campbell asked this question because I suppose he anticipates this may be the last question time before the election, so he wants to try to have a hypothetical question about what the unemployment rate will be next year and what the number of young people coming into the labour market will be late this year at the end of the school year or early next year. All I can say to you, Senator Campbell, is that I am not going to speculate hypothetically what those figures would be. I would say that, if it were not for the Working Nation initiatives going back to May last year, there would be a lot more unemployed young people. I also have to say that it is all very well for you to criticise us—and that is the political point you wish to make—but for goodness sake, please tell us what you would do specifically other than reduce youth wages to $3 an hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question was about what the government would actually do for the 40,000 people. I do not think anyone around here is particularly interested in having a pedantic argument about how you define an ABS statistic.
—Oh, yes they would.

—Most people, Minister—and Senator Crowley, who interjects—are very concerned about a crisis situation in youth unemployment and concerned that the Working Nation statement that did come in May last year has actually seen an increase in teen unemployment, no matter how you define it. But the reality is that you have 40,000 school leavers who are likely to be destined to go onto the unemployment list. The coalition has already released a whole raft of detail about what it is going to do in economic policy, community employment programs and a whole range of other policies; so you may as well give up on that one. You happen to be in government now. You have been in power for 13 years and you have the biggest youth unemployment crisis in this country's history. What we want to know is what do you propose to do about it. You tried Working Nation and it failed. What are you going to tell these 40,000 young kids?

—In the first question that Senator Campbell asked he talked about fairytales. After listening to his supplementary the only fairytale I can think of is a Grimm fairytale, and it is the grim policies of the opposition. You have offered none. You have said in your supplementary that you have released a whole host of policy. I wish you would table them. We have documents that have been leaked. All they talk about is attacking the government. They do not give one specific recommendation on how you would reduce youth unemployment in this country.

PARA.TAB: The last one we can remember you talking about was 3 1/2 years ago when you mentioned that you would have the youth wage at $3 an hour. You have told us that that may not be the case. All I can say to you is that we would like to see your policies in detail released. All you have ever done is criticise Working Nation, which has substantially reduced long-term youth unemployment in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has gone up.
—It has been substantially reduced over the last couple of years, and you have offered nothing in its place.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, the honourable Senator Gareth Evans. I refer the minister to a letter from the Premier of South Australia to the Prime Minister dated 28 February 1995 which states that the South Australian government `does not accept the Commonwealth's decision to store the waste at Woomera range head until certain assurances are given'. The letter goes on to explain that these assurances are in relation to the federal government agreeing to discontinue the consideration of Lake Eyre for World Heritage listing. Did the federal government make any assurances that it would not proceed with the World Heritage listing of the Lake Eyre region to ensure that the South Australian government would become a temporary or permanent radioactive waste site or repository? If so, why was such an agreement made, given the current process to select a site for a permanent national repository? If not, can the minister assure the Senate that the World Heritage listing of Lake Eyre will not be sacrificed in the name of an expedient solution to the radioactive waste storage problem?

—I thank the honourable Dee Margetts for her question. The government has not given any assurances that it will not proceed with the World Heritage assessment process, nor does the government recognise any link between this issue and the issue of temporary storage of radioactive waste at Woomera range head. My colleague the extremely honourable Senator John Faulkner has made clear what the government's position is on the Lake Eyre assessment process—that is, that no decision will be made on whether to proceed with the nomination until all relevant assessments have been completed. These include the natural values assessment, cultural values assessments and, if World Heritage values are identified, a socioeconomic impact study.

PARA.TAB: As to the latter, the government is committed to seeing a full socioeconomic impact study of a possible listing completed before any nomination goes forward. Although I do not think it is appropriate to commence such a study before the assessment reports have ascertained whether world heritage values exist, Senator Bob Collins and Senator Faulkner have commissioned the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics to prepare a socioeconomic profile of the study area.

When the Commonwealth government has considered fully the results of these various assessments—the natural and cultural assessments of World Heritage values of the South Australian section of the Lake Eyre basin—it may then enter into negotiations with the South Australian government in terms of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment in regard to a possible World Heritage nomination. So that is the process that is under way. Once again, I do not think there is any foundation for the honourable senator's fears.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the very honourable minister. Originally the South Australian government were reluctant to receive radioactive waste at St Marys. They did agree; I guess reluctantly. What finally changed their mind?
—I do not know, frankly. You will have to ask them. I will take that question on notice—
—It is whom you ask—Olsen or Brown—as you will get a different answer, too.

—Yes, they are a pretty scrappy sort of government over there at the moment. Things have changed, of course, in recent times. But I will see what further information I can get in response to that part of your question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Earlier this week you told the Senate that Mr Graeme Campbell's anti-immigrant comments were disgusting. However, your colleague Mr Eric Fitzgibbon said that Tuesday's caucus meeting had a majority in favour of Mr Campbell and that, if the Prime Minister had put the matter to the vote, it would have been `quite embarrassing' for Mr Keating. Furthermore, caucus chairman, Mr Jim Snow, said of Mr Campbell:

QUESTION.PARA: He's got a lot of support in the Labor Party, he's got a lot of support in the community, a broad based Labor Party ought to be able to accommodate people like Graeme.

What is going on in the Labor Party? Is it not the case that, rather than finding Mr Campbell's comments disgusting, the majority of your Labor colleagues are happy to tolerate anything, condone anything, no matter how offensive, just to hold on to the seat of Kalgoorlie?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather pathetic to see poor old Senator O'Chee trying to make a silk purse out of a sow's ear of an assault on this particular issue. It is obvious that Mr Campbell's remarks have no sympathy whatsoever with the overwhelming majority of his caucus colleagues and of party members and, I believe, of people in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: How Mr Campbell is to be dealt with as a result of the positions that he has taken on this and other matters is a matter not for the caucus but for the national executive of the party, which will be meeting tonight. I am not going to pre-empt that process because it is proper that procedures and processes be followed that will produce a just result and a just outcome.

But I think you can reasonably assume that the values that we have been articulating, that we have made pre-eminently our own in public life in this country, are not going to be allowed to be prejudiced or threatened by positions being taken by people like Mr Campbell. Those views are absolutely at odds with the view that we have of the character of Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Fitzgibbon?
—Mr Fitzgibbon is departing our ranks in this forthcoming election. And Mr Fitzgibbon speaks for himself on this particular matter, as does Mr Snow or anyone else who has taken that view.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to further canvass matters which are properly matters for the party machinery. But I do not think you will be disappointed about the—well, you will be disappointed, I suspect, about the outcome that this matter will have, because it may not give you the further information that you may think you would like to have going into an election campaign; that is, ammunition which is utterly inappropriate for you to be flowing around, given the track record of your particular party.

TALK.START.PARA: —And your leader.

—I was not going to be tasteless enough to remind Senator O'Chee of the performance of his current leader in 1988. But that was the last time a serious figure in Australian politics seriously sought to play the race card. The fact that a fringe figure might seek to play such a card says something about the fringe figure concerned, but it says nothing about the mainstream Labor Party. A lot was said about the mainstream Liberal Party in those events of 1988. You ought to be ashamed of yourself.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Earlier on this week, on Monday, Senator Gareth Evans told me that there was nobody in the Parliamentary Labor Party who shared Mr Campbell's views on these matters. Now he says that they are shared by Mr Snow—
—The chairman of caucus.

—the chairman of the caucus, and Mr Fitzgibbon. How many others in the caucus share these disgraceful, bigoted views? And is Mr Campbell's position in the Parliamentary Labor Party endorsed and backed by Mr Kim Beazley?

—Mr Snow's views, I know personally, are absolutely rock solid on issues of race and immigration. He is concerned about the potential electoral backlash from a certain stream of opinion in his own electorate; he has expressed that view. That may well be the position that has been taken by Mr Fitzgibbon. They speak for themselves.

PARA.TAB: But I did not take them, and I do not think any of my colleagues took them, to be expressing views themselves which were those views of Campbell. They were taking the view that the party was a broad enough church to accommodate some pretty bizarre and wild and woolly opinions. It is absolutely defamatory of those two people to suggest that they in any way shared Mr Campbell's views—as it is equally defamatory to suggest of the deputy leader of the party that he would have any willingness to give comfort to such views.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. Is the minister aware of claims by a South Australian small businessman of political interference in decisions of the CSIRO? Can the minister inform the Senate of the validity of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of claims by a South Australian small businessman about political interference in the decisions of the CSIRO. I have here a statutory declaration sworn by Mr David Paul Battersby to that effect, which I now table.

PARA.TAB: Mr David Battersby runs a small advertising company in Adelaide. The statutory declaration relates to events last year after he had reached agreement with the CSIRO to erect advertising billboards on the CSIRO's property at O'Halloran Hill in the Adelaide southern suburbs. The CSIRO has confirmed Mr Battersby's claim that shortly before the contracts were finalised Ms Chris Gallus, the member for Hindmarsh, contacted the CSIRO complaining that a number of other advertising companies had not been informed of the arrangement. According to the CSIRO, and in their normally understated terms, they said:

ANSWER.PARA: The strong impression given was that Mrs Gallus would actively canvass against the proposals.

Mr Battersby found out about this intervention indirectly. He found out through a large Adelaide advertising company and, as a consequence, he then rang Ms Gallus. In his statutory declaration Mr Battersby states that she, in this case meaning Ms Gallus:

. . . told me the project was dead and would not go ahead, stating she had previously been on some CSIRO review board and had a lot of powerful friends at CSIRO who had assured her our contract would be terminated.
In the statutory declaration he goes on to refer to Ms Gallus saying these words to him:
. . . whilst I don't like to see anyone go bankrupt, from where I sit I just sent you under, you're playing in the big league now.

It is interesting to ask the question: why does Ms Gallus have an interest in ending this project? She told the CSIRO that it was to give other companies a chance to bid for the contract to erect hoardings, but when the matter was raised in the parliament last year she told the House of Representatives that it was `on the basis of my well-known interest in the environment'. Not only did she not mention the issues of the other companies in the parliament; she said:
Neither I nor anyone else, I believe, could have had anything of a commercial nature to gain in this matter.

The two explanations are not consistent. If indeed the environment was her concern, as she told the parliament, there could be no way that she could entertain anyone putting up a billboard in that location. But in fact she told the CSIRO her concern was of the commercial aspects of the contract that had led her to become involved.

PARA.TAB: I think what we have to consider against this background is that during the 1993 election Ms Gallus had a number of large billboards around her electorate, some in choice locations, which were provided by two of Adelaide's large billboard advertising firms, and these same firms are also recorded in the Liberal Party's 1992-93 declaration of expenditure as having made donations to the Liberal Party.

O'Halloran Hill is, by the way, in the seat of Kingston, which does not even adjoin Hindmarsh, and Ms Gallus was the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs at the time. The situation that I now have reported before me in a statutory declaration by an Adelaide small businessman is that Ms Gallus brought pressure to bear on the CSIRO to terminate a commercial contract and then misrepresented her motives in a statement in the House of Representatives. Now that there is a statutory declaration before me, as minister for science and minister responsible for the CSIRO at ministerial level I will investigate this matter to the full. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Faulkner, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, who seemed a little disturbed before that he was not getting a question. This may restore his confidence. Is the minister aware of the report by Traffic Oceania that significant amounts of traditional Chinese medicine sold in Australia contain ingredients from threatened species such as tiger, bear, rhino and leopard? Does the minister support commercial trade in products derived from endangered wildlife? Given that there has been evidence for some time of the use of threatened species in medicines sold in Australia, why has the government allowed this trade to continue unabated? What is the federal government doing to halt this trade which is causing an ongoing threat to many threatened species?
—I am aware of the many views that have been expressed to government on this issue. I am aware, as I hear regularly from the peak conservation organisations, including representatives—
—You will be hearing a lot more from them after Friday.
—You may be right. I suspect all those communications will be congratulatory ones.

PARA.TAB: I can say to Senator Woodley that that includes representatives of Traffic Oceania. I also say to Senator Woodley that recently in this chamber we debated at great length the issues you raised in your question, as you are no doubt aware, when I outlined, I think in very great detail, the very responsive attitude that this government has taken to such trade in those products.

I think that the government's record in this area is beyond criticism. I believe that nearly all in the conservation movement, and more particularly in the community, have accepted that this government has ensured that its responsibilities under CITES have been dealt with seriously and responsibly.

We have ensured that the legislative framework that we have in place in Australia reflects those responsibilities. I can assure you that in future we will apply ourselves with as much vigour as we have over recent years whenever matters of importance are raised in relation to the trade in endangered species.

I think that the record of the government is beyond criticism. In relation to this issue, Australia is perceived as a leader in the international community. I think that is accepted far more broadly than just by senators or members on this side of the house.

Our record is outstanding. It is acknowledged by nearly all. I would be very disappointed, Senator, if you were not one of those who acknowledged the efforts that I have made as minister and that this government has made in relation to this important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge your efforts. Whether they are adequate is the question. I would like to ask a further question about trade in endangered species. Did the federal government recently move to relax restrictions on the export of skins from saltwater crocodiles, which I believe are still an endangered species in Australia? If so, why?

—This issue is one that I have taken very seriously. It has been raised at Australia and New Zealand Conservation Council meetings. There has been a proposition from the Northern Territory that we take a different approach to rogue crocodiles. With a very stringent set of conditions that I have applied, I have enabled that trade to take place. It does not affect many individual specimens.

PARA.TAB: If it would be of interest to you, I am happy to provide you with a copy of the conditions that I have placed on the Northern Territory in relation to this matter. I can assure you that the move I made after very careful consideration and advice from the Australian Nature Conservation Agency has been accepted and endorsed by conservation organisations in this country. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: will the government unequivocally rule out using any money appropriated by the parliament in 1995 for the payment of costs awarded against Dr Lawrence and the legal costs for Dr Lawrence's court challenges to the Marks royal commission?
—The Minister for Finance has already addressed that question in parliament yesterday and I think given you a straightforward answer on it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw Senator Gareth Evans's attention to an AAP article of yesterday's date, which says:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it is understood the government is considering whether it could pay for much of the challenge costs out of the change left over from the appropriation bill to be approved . . .
I ask Senator Evans what he says about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not said anything about that and I do not propose to say anything now. The $243,000 in round figures that is attributable to Dr Lawrence's costs, her lawyers, before the various courts that are involved in those collateral challenges has been withdrawn from the appropriation as a result of your amendment in the House of Representatives. As I have said and Mr Beazley has made clear, we are not proposing to further pursue ways of paying that particular amount until after parliament has had a chance to further consider that issue. The $243,000 is attributable to Dr Lawrence's costs of her own lawyers in those collateral proceedings. I have made that clear. Mr Beazley has made that clear. If Laura Tingle or someone else in the AAP or elsewhere was suggesting something different, they have the bull by the wrong horn.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Can the minister confirm to the Senate that last night he signed a sporting cooperation agreement with his South African counterpart, Mr Steve Tshwete? What is the significance of this agreement with South Africa? How does the minister expect that sporting contacts with South Africa will strengthen in coming years? How will these sporting contacts foster a firmer relationship between the two countries?

—I can inform the Senate that the Australian government is currently hosting a visit by the South African sports minister, Steve Tshwete. It is a familiarisation visit but it is covering matters such as our sports development programs, elite training facilities and possibilities, and preparation for the Atlanta and Sydney Olympic Games.

PARA.TAB: I am also pleased that I was able to sign a memorandum of understanding yesterday on sporting cooperation between South Africa and Australia. We have several of these types of agreements, particularly with Asian countries. They are designed, from our perspective, to enhance Australia's sporting profile and build on our host status for the 2000 Olympics. In the case of South Africa, our agreement is designed to facilitate its re-entry into world sport in a way that enhances multi-racial participation in sport at both the grassroots and the elite levels.

I think it is natural for South Africa to turn to Australia for assistance in this regard. There are a range of circumstances, not the least of which is the fact that we have a southern hemisphere location, which really does strengthen our relationship. More importantly, I think we share some very strong common traditions in sports such as rugby union and cricket. I have no doubt we are going to have a strengthening relationship in sport over the coming years with South Africa, particularly in the lead-up to the 2000 Olympics.

At the signing ceremony with Mr Tshwete he informed me that this agreement is the first government to government agreement—the first bilateral agreement—that the Australian government has signed with the new South African government of national unity. It is also the first international agreement that South Africa has entered into in the field of sport. Both of those marked very significant events indeed.

The agreement will allow both countries to work on fostering the very close ties that have been developed since democratic elections were held in South Africa in 1994. The Australian Sports Commission has worked closely with Mr Tshwete's ministry and the National Sports Council of South Africa in re-establishing South African sport in the post-apartheid era.

Senators may also be aware of the very positive role that has been played by Australian teams when they have visited South Africa. Our rugby union and cricket teams have taken a very active role in visiting the black townships and involving themselves in clinics and training sessions. Mr Tshwete has assured me that it has resulted in an enduring affection for Australians and Australian sport as a result.

Thanks to the generous assistance of AusAID, the Sports Commission has an officer on secondment in South Africa who is assisting in the development of the Protea sport program. That is really an adaption of the AussieSports program in Australia. It is a highly successful participation program being introduced into the townships of South Africa. I can assure the Senate that Australian sport and Australian sporting links in South Africa are extraordinarily strong. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the treaty between Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia initialled at Dayton, Ohio earlier this month, which offers the best prospect for an implemented peace to emerge after all these horrendous years of warfare. What is the Australian government doing to strengthen the prospects of the treaty's implementation? In particular, I ask about UN sanctions and the conditional terms of the treaty for suspension of sanctions. Can Australia suspend sanctions temporarily or conditionally? If not, what is the timing and nature of Australia's action on this matter during the coming month? Also, in so far as the lifting of sanctions for one party to the treaty is conditional on alleged war criminals being actually handed over for trial by the International War Crimes Tribunal, what does the Australian government intend to do if sanctions need to be reimposed?

—My recollection is that there is a submission on my desk at the moment addressing the question of sanctions which I have not yet got to. I am not quite sure what it says, but I think we are in a position to respond now, at least partially, to a sanctions lifting exercise. But I will need to take that part of the question on notice and give Senator Teague a better answer. I am happy to do that as soon as possible, probably later today.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of Australian participation in the implementation of the settlement, while we have monitored developments in the conflict very closely and while individual Australians have obviously made a contribution, including with a number of humanitarian operations on the ground, Australia has not had a direct role in the peace process. We have believed all along that the regional powers in cooperation with the United Nations, and especially with some help from the United States, were the best placed to pursue a settlement.

We do not rule out making an appropriate post-settlement contribution in line with our approach until now, in which we have spoken out strongly against human rights violations, both bilaterally and in forums such as the General Assembly and the Committee on Human Rights. We have supported the international community's peace efforts, we have provided humanitarian assistance in the region—$7.7 million to the former Yugoslavia since the outbreak of the conflict—and provided resettlement opportunities in Australia, to date, some 14,000 persons, with provisions been made for an additional 7,600 this year.

We have also actively supported the operations of the international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. We have conscientiously applied UN sanctions to the extent that they have continued to be applicable, and we will go on doing all those things. We have not proposed, however, nor has there been any official approach about us, playing a more direct and substantial role in either the peace implementation force or the post-settlement reconstruction effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. It is my last question to Senator Evans before the minister is asking questions himself in a few months time. I come back to that part of my question which related to war criminals. I put to the minister that this is the first international treaty which directly addresses the seriousness of war criminals being brought to trial and that element of the treaty does see sanctions being reimposed on any party if the alleged war criminals are not handed over to face trial before the International War Crimes Tribunal. Is the minister sure Australia will be able to play our part in making sure that that important part of the treaty is implemented?
—Say yes, so we can go!

—You do not appreciate the sentimentality of this moment. I am obviously deeply moved by it. Let me just say this: we obviously believe that those indicted for war crimes in the former Yugoslavia, as elsewhere, must be brought to justice, and those who deserve to be indicted—of whom there are many, because of the shocking circumstances that we are all familiar with—deserve to be brought to justice. We will continue to play our part in ensuring that happens, including through observing any sanctions conditionality strictures of the kind you have mentioned. We were in fact one of the very first countries to take domestic legislative action to enable us to provide relevant assistance to the international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. You can absolutely expect us to maintain that record in the future.
—Mr President, perhaps for the very last time, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 November 1995, Senator MacGibbon asked me two questions about the performance specifications in the Coastwatch contract and also asked me to release the contract for public scrutiny. To save the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate the answer, of which a copy has already been given to Senator MacGibbon. The Senate should note that I table several documents which are material to the answer and which will also be incorporated.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: COASTAL SURVEILLANCE
On 22 November 1995, Senator MacGibbon asked me two questions about the performance specifications in the Coastwatch contract and also asked me to release the contract for public scrutiny.

The first of Senator MacGibbon's questions was ". . . in relation to pay load/range performance and in relation to operations under Instrument Flight Rules, what performance specification differences are there between the RFP and the contract signed with Surveillance Australia in relation to the Britten Norman Islander?"

For obvious commercial confidentiality reasons, I will not be making the contract public. However I am able to table that portion of the contract which relates to the aircraft performance requirements for Task One (the visual task) and the corresponding portion of the specimen contract from the Request for Proposals (RFP).

Senators will note that there are three matters on which the documents differ; a minor issue relating to the Global Positioning System, seating and the speed at which the aircraft is to operate. The specimen contract called for an operational speed of 130-150 knots indicated air speed, while the actual contract calls for an indicated air speed of 120-150 knots. Attorney-General's have advised that this difference in speed is permissible within the terms of the RFP.
All other performance requirements are identical.

There is no requirement in either the RFP, the specimen contract or the actual contract for the aircraft to operate solely under Instrument Flight Rules (IFR). The only requirement is that the aircraft be approved for IFR and the Islander complies with that requirement.
Senator MacGibbon's second question was, "Is the contractor fully meeting all the contract performance standards now that his equipment is on line?"
