Not all of the contractors equipment is on line. The aircraft for Tasks Two and Three are not scheduled to commence operations until I July 1996 and I January 1996 respectively.
In respect of the seven aircraft specified for Task One, the contractor is fully meeting its contracted performance standards for that Task.

On 21 November, Senator MacGibbon in moving that the Senate take note of my answer to a question without notice from Senator Colston, raised what was effectively a series of further questions about the Coastwatch contract.

In an attempt to bolster his claim that there is "public concern in the aviation industry about the awarding of the latest Coastwatch contract", Senator MacGibbon says that the Pilatus Britten Norman Islander is an aircraft "which is universally recognised as being quite unsuitable for the task that Customs wishes to use it for". He went on to say that "It is an aeroplane that is very slow, it has a very limited pay load and it has a limited range". He said that "it is very hard to see out of. . . and is very noisy".

Senator MacGibbon's reference to the aircraft's speed and range is, I presume, a comparison with the Shrike aircraft used by the previous contractor for the same task. It is true that the Islander does not have the speed or the range of the Shrike—but it does meet the speed and range requirements of the current contract. More importantly it meets the Coastwatch operational coverage requirements. It is neither very slow nor range-limited when measured against the task requirement. Senator MacGibbon's statement that it is "flat out making 115 knots on the cruise" is inaccurate. The aircraft operates at 120 knots.

With regard to visibility from the aircraft, it has been claimed that the fixed undercarriage on the Islander affects the observers' field of view. The fact that the undercarriage could not be retracted was, of course, known from the outset and allegations of the problems it causes have been overstated. Firstly, there is only one observer affected and that is the crew member who sits in the rear of the aircraft. This person also operates the onboard observer's computer and tactical radios. To help overcome the fixed undercarriage visibility effect, the windows of the aircraft have been significantly modified, including large bubble windows and full length glass on the rear door and the opposite side of the fuselage. The result is that effective searches can be carried out by the rear observer.

With regard to noise, the crew are all required to wear communications headsets for operational reasons. These headsets are special noise reducing headsets which effectively reduce the ambient noise level of about 95db to about 65db at the ear. This is well within OH&S guidelines.

Senator MacGibbon says that "the aircraft does not possess any effective air conditioning". On this point he is totally wrong. The air conditioning system has been fully tested in tropical conditions and meets the contractual requirement that it maintain a cabin temperature to a maximum of 25(0)C and 60% humidity on a 32(0)C 70% humidity day with all equipment operating and five crew on board.

Senator MacGibbon said that the Islander "cannot take off under instrument flight rules with a load that it can under the visual flight rules". What the Senator omitted to mention is that this is true for most light aircraft. I would also point out that the contract does not require operation under instrument flight rules.

Senator MacGibbon referred to allegations that the company (by which I presume he meant the new contractor, Surveillance Australia) "sought to get an increase in the maximum all-up weight of the aircraft which was denied by CASA, or the Civil Aviation Authority as it was known at the time".

On 28 August 1995, in my written answer to a Question on Notice from Senator MacGibbon, I said Surveillance Australia did apply to the then CAA for approval to operate the Islander at a weight greater than its certified maximum take-off weight.
However, this application was NOT denied.

Surveillance Australia withdrew the application on 4 August 1995 when it became clear, following a weight reduction program and a reassessment of the aircraft performance, that the Islander could meet the initial requirements of the contract within its certified maximum take off weight. In the interests of accuracy I should point out that the aircraft does not currently have the 100 kg growth capacity required within its certified maximum take off weight but that capacity is not required by Coastwatch at this time.

Notwithstanding my written answer to Senator MacGibbon, Mr Paul Phelan, a aviation journalist based in Cairns, has asked whether I was inaccurately advised on this matter and queried whether CASA did in fact reject the application.
I seek leave to table a letter from CASA confirming that the application was withdrawn not rejected.
Senator MacGibbon also stated that two Canberra officers found that the Islander was "completely unsuited to the Customs role".

Two Canberra and three Cairns based officers chartered a standard Islander in Cairns to evaluate it as a visual surveillance platform. At approximately the same time another two Canberra based officers flew in a specially equipped surveillance Islander in England. The Cairns reports indicated that the Islander, when measured against the Shrike was only about 55% as effective as the Shrike as a visual platform. On that basis these officers did not think that the Islander was an acceptable visual surveillance platform. The report from England gave a more optimistic view of the Islander as officers on this flight had the opportunity to use bubble windows and sit in special seats. Both these reports were considered by the Proposal Evaluation Committee which concluded that the Islander was not as effective a visual platform as the Shrike, but that it could complete the visual surveillance requirements outlined in the RFP.

I note with interest that Senator MacGibbon has made no comment in his criticisms of this aircraft about the significant difference in age between the Islanders which are new aircraft and Shrikes used on the previous contract, and offered for this contract, the newest one of which was built in 1976.

It is important that the Senate recognise, notwithstanding some disadvantages the Islander has when measured against the Shrike, that these have been taken into account in awarding the contract and in the Coastwatch program. Additional flying hours have been allocated to the total program and that increase, taken with the technology which has been introduced in the new contract, has resulted in an increase of 190% in the Coastwatch coverage.

I must confess to some frustration about the continuing campaign to infer that the Coastwatch contract evaluation process was faulty because the Islander was chosen as part of an overall package put forward by Surveillance Australia, and that the coverage provided under the new contract, is somehow inferior to that provided under the previous contract with a consequent risk to our coastline.

In particular I am frustrated by comments such as Senator MacGibbon's that the Pilatus Britten Norman Islander "is universally recognised as being quite unsuitable for the tasks that Customs wishes to use it for". In making this comment he is echoing a statement by Skywest, the previous contractor and an unsuccessful tenderer for the new contract.
Yet it is a fact that Britten Norman Islanders were offered as fully complying aircraft by three aviation organisations who were short listed for the Coastwatch contract.
Some universal recognition that the Islander is unsuitable!

Skywest wrote to me on 29 September 1995 saying that "the Islander aircraft, in particular, is unsuitable for the role envisaged and non-compliant for the specification contained in the original RFP and the resultant contract". The Company goes on to say that I have been misinformed by Coastwatch officers in this regard.

I found this a surprising allegation on the part of Skywest who, on two separate occasions in 1994, advised Customs in writing that the Islander was "mission compliant in full" and that "this aircraft is in widespread use worldwide as a low cost surveillance platform. It has well established credentials as a reliable and flexible platform".
I am unaware of any reason for Skywest to change its mind about the Islander since 1994 other than the fact that it did not win the Coastwatch contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Chamarette asked me a question without notice about ATSIC. Since she is not in the chamber, I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet: Involvement in Review of Native Title Representative Bodies

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette asked me without notice, on 29 November 1995:

(1) What involvement has the Office of Indigenous Affairs in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet had in the formulating of the recommendations of the ATSIC Review Committee on Native Title Representative Bodies?
(2) Is it true that this Review Committee has recommended that there should be only one representative body for each region?
(3) Has this been accepted as government policy?

(4) Why is it being proposed to reduce the options of Aboriginal communities to choose a body to assist them in native title claims especially when the Native Title Act, explicitly allows for more than one body to exist?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) An officer of the Office of Indigenous Affairs was a member of the Review Committee.

(2) Yes. The Review Committee made twenty separate recommendations relating to the operational jurisdiction of Native Title Representative Bodies: the primary theme behind the recommendations was that "a large regional level of jurisdiction for Native Title Representative Bodies [was seen] as being the most cost-effective, providing a sufficient population mass to generate organisational economies of scale and most effectively facilitating a representative capacity".

The Committee also considered that Native Title Representative Bodies should have sole jurisdiction over their determined regional areas, but acknowledged the position outlined by the Prime Minister in his second reading speech for the Native Title Bill in November 1993.

Notwithstanding the Committee's recommendations, and the desirability of an efficient representative body regime, the position as outlined by the Prime Minister remains—individual claimants or groups of claimants can go elsewhere if they wish.

(3) The Report was commissioned by and submitted to the ATSIC Board of Commissioners. The Board supports the thrust of the recommendations, because they provide the most cost-effective means to facilitate the coordination of available resources towards progression of native title claims in the area, and provide a strategic approach to resolution of these claims.

Nonetheless, it should be noted that determination of Native Title Representative Bodies is a matter for the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs under section 202 of the Native Title Act 1993.

(4) The reasons for the recommendations about the operational jurisdictions of the Native Title Representative Bodies are set out in Chapter 3 of the Review Committee's Report which is a public document.

ANSWER.PARA: Recommended:
Kaely Woods
A/g Assistant Secretary
Native Title Branch
30 November 1995

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 June 1995, I gave a preliminary answer to a question without notice from Senator Wheelwright relating to a number of allegations made in the parliament on 5 June by Mr Ken Aldred MP concerning paedophile activities by officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I am now in a position to advise him and the Senate as to the outcomes of the police investigations that have subsequently taken place. As it is quite a long response, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: ALDRED ALLEGATIONS OF PAEDOPHILE ACTIVITY BY DFAT OFFICERS

On 6 June 1995 I gave a preliminary answer to a question without notice from Senator Wheelwright relating to a number of allegations made in Parliament on 5 June by Mr Ken Aldred MP concerning paedophile activities by officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I am now in a position to advise him and the Senate as to the outcomes of the police investigations that have subsequently taken place.

Immediately following these allegations, the Secretary of the Department, Mr Costello, wrote to the Australian Federal Police asking that a rigorous, comprehensive and full investigation be undertaken by the AFP. The Secretary urged that, if necessary, the AFP investigation should revisit all former allegations and include visits to other countries to follow up the investigations. The Secretary subsequently wrote to all major media organisations and to NGOs that had indicated concern about these issues asking them to supply all relevant information they might have to the Australian Federal Police.

The Australian Federal Police has undertaken an extensive investigation of these matters which has by no means been confined to Mr Aldred's allegations. Personnel and security files of the Department have been reviewed as far back as the mid-1940s. Dozens of interviews have been conducted with Departmental officers, NGO personnel and members of the media. An AFP team has travelled abroad, liaised with other national police forces and judicial officers. AFP officers posted in Asian countries have also contributed to the investigation. It has taken dedicated AFP and Departmental sources some months to bring the investigation to a conclusion.
The AFP has now advised the Secretary of my Department of the results of its investigation into the three allegations made by Mr Aldred.
The first allegation was that the senior management of DFAT has tolerated and promoted diplomats known to be paedophiles.
The AFP investigation has concluded "that there is no evidence to support the allegation that the senior management of DFAT has tolerated and promoted diplomats known to be paedophiles".
The second allegation was that DFAT has obstructed investigation of this matter, attempted to prevent examination of relevant documents and deterred Departmental witnesses from providing evidence.

The AFP has advised that "during the investigation no evidence was revealed to substantiate the allegation that DFAT has obstructed investigation of this matter, attempted to prevent examination of relevant documents or deter Departmental officers from providing evidence".
Indeed, the AFP has advised that it is "satisfied that the Department has fully assisted the AFP to ensure that the matter was dealt with in an open and accountable manner".

The third allegation was that approximately 20 DFAT Senior Executive Services officers are engaged in paedophile activities in Australia and overseas. The bulk of the AFP report deals with this third allegation.

When asked by Police, Mr Aldred eventually named 16 officers of whom only 12 are serving officers of the portfolio. Of those named by Mr Aldred ten officers are or were members of the Senior Executive Service.
As to the remaining three, the situation is as follows:
In regard to 13 of the 16 officers named by Mr Aldred, the AFP advised that "no evidence has been identified which substantiates the claims made against them".

In relation to one officer, the AFP advised that a brief of evidence has been sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions for consideration as to whether criminal charges should be laid in regard to recent matters under the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Act 1994.
The Director of Public Prosecutions has, as yet, made no decision on this matter and no presumption should be made either way as to what the DPP will decide in the exercise of his discretion.

In respect of another officer, the AFP has advised that there was historical information from which it could reasonably have been suspected that he may have been involved in paedophile activities a decade ago.

This information was considered in the 1980s by the Department: a view was reached that the officer's account of events was a credible one, and that it could not be concluded that he had been engaged in paedophile activity.

The current AFP investigation did not identify any evidence of subsequent possible paedophile activity by this officer and there are no grounds for laying criminal charges. However, in the light of the AFP investigation, the Secretary of my Department is of the view that it may be necessary to reconsider aspects of the case and whether there has been any departure from the obligations imposed upon all officers by the Public Service Act. He is seeking legal advice on this aspect.

As regards one former officer who left the Department many years ago, the AFP has stated that no criminal action can be taken under the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Act 1994 because the information relating to that former officer pre-dates that legislation.

The AFP has advised that Mr Aldred was unable to provide any evidence to substantiate any of his allegations against the 16 officers. Any substantive information resulted from investigations and enquiries which were in place before Mr Aldred made his allegations on 5 June.

As was made clear at the time of Mr Aldred's allegations, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in no way condones and cannot accept paedophile behaviour, or indeed any criminal activity, by its officers. As the Secretary of my Department made clear through the media and a variety of other channels at the time, the Department hopes that all persons who have any evidence of such activity by any officer of the Department would bring it to the attention of the Australian Federal Police.

What was objectionable then, and remains objectionable now, was that Mr Aldred did not first take his allegations to the Police, but instead aired them in Parliament, identifying certain officers, and alleging cover-up of a network of officially condoned paedophile activity within the Department. In so doing, he has besmirched the name of a large number of officers of the Department and provoked unfounded fears and concerns about the integrity of the institution, its management and administration. If he had first taken the matters to the Australian Federal Police, they would have been fully investigated and the outcome would have been the same. That he chose otherwise is an unwarranted abuse of Parliamentary privilege.
I deeply regret that unfounded allegations were made against a number of officers of the Public Service and that they and their families have gone through undeserved suffering and harm.

Finally, it remains the Government's view that exploitation of children by paedophiles, in Australia and overseas, is particularly abhorrent criminal conduct. I repeat that calls made previously by myself and the Secretary of my Department that any person or organisation who has information in this regard should bring it to the attention of the Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at question time there was some debate about whether a statement by Senator Cook directed to another senator was unparliamentary. I took the comment to be, `What you're saying is false.' On examining the Hansard transcript, I find that the expression used was, `You know what you're saying is false.'

PARA.TAB: This is clearly unparliamentary since it involves an implication that a senator is deliberately making false statements. I apologise for this error of interpretation. It did, however, have no bearing on the statement that I made last week on the misuse of proper names to circumvent standing order 193.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I am grateful for your response, but I invite you to consider a number of things that I think are very important for people to understand if they are to have confidence that what is said on one side is treated equally when it is said on the other side. I understand from what you have just said that you understood what the minister had said to be a simple statement—`What you're saying is false.' I could readily accept that, with all the din and clatter that goes on in this place, it would be easy to not hear the first two words of his statement, `You know'.

PARA.TAB: It would be easier to hear it as, `What you're saying is false,' rather than what he did say, which is, `You know what you're saying is false.' That would be the case if a point of order had not been raised with you, which I did. I quite specifically said to you:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet you have allowed the minister to say, `You know what you're saying is false.'
I went on and pointed out that it was a clear imputation against all of this side, because it was a clear inference that the people on this side knew what they were saying was false.

PARA.TAB: We then had some interchange, because I think you were suggesting that I had not understood what you said the week before in relation to another matter. I indicated that that wasn't what I was saying. I actually put it to you in a separate point of order:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I rise on a further point of order—
accepting what you had ruled the first time—
What do you say, Mr President, if I say to you: you know what you're saying is false?

In other words, accepting that there might be some misunderstanding of what was said, but then trying on a point of order to get clarification on what I thought had been said, and we now know actually had been said. Your response to me then—on the second time I put to you the question, `What do you say if I put to you: you know what you're saying is false?'—was you would treat it with disdain. When I asked you, `Would you ignore it?', you repeated your point and said, `I would treat it with the disdain that it deserves.'

PARA.TAB: The matter was taken up again later in the afternoon. Even Senator Evans couldn't manage to avoid what was staring people in the face; that is, if you say, `You know what you're saying is false,' it is tantamount to calling someone a liar. He put it to you this way: `If the remark as turns up in Hansard actually is, "You know what you said is false," we might have to look at it.' At that point you said:

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I am happy to have a look at it. I certainly concede the point that you raised.

Mr President, can you explain to me why, when I raised it with you twice, including the preamble to the statement `You know what you're saying is false', you treat it with disdain? Why do you treat it with disdain when I raise it and with some respect when the leader on the other side raises it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact of life in politics that some of us are graceless some of the time, but Senator Vanstone, frankly, is graceless far too much of the time and has been again on this occasion. You, Mr President, had a proper look at the Hansard, checked your recollection and the record as to what happened and came in and made a perfectly graceful acknowledgment of error yesterday in the way in which you had initially responded to the matters put to you.

PARA.TAB: That error was based clearly on a mishearing of the original thing and I suspect that mishearing carried through into the subsequent exchanges that took place with Senator Vanstone. You have acknowledged the force of the basic point in issue here—that, if you make a statement that someone on the other side knows something he or she is saying is false, that is manifestly unparliamentary. That is the matter in issue. That is the matter that you clarified perfectly well by your statement today. Any further attempt to pursue this by Senator Vanstone is simply graceless, Senator. I think you, Mr President, should not trouble yourself with further responding on the matter accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of your ruling, I withdraw my statement of yesterday.

—In brief response to explain, I think the confusion was caused by the fact that Senator Vanstone did relate the matter to the statement that I had made last week and that was the point that I took up. I concede that I was incorrect in not responding favourably to the point she raised subsequently. The person who made it clear to me was not in fact Senator Evans but Senator Baume in a very clear distinction between the two statements. I thought he explained it very fully—and that was when I was prepared to concede—and Senator Evans then supported that.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to questions without notice asked by Senator Knowles and Senator Hill this day, relating to household incomes and Public Service salaries.

SPEECH.PARA: Both matters relate to aspects of the record of this government which I think will go down in history as demonstrating not only this government's incompetence but the way in which it has let down the Australian people. The two issues are, firstly, the ongoing mass unemployment and underemployment that we have in this country—many Australians will remember the role of this government in that, with over 600,000 Australians still out of work—and, secondly, the legacy for so many who have been in work that their real wages under Labor have fallen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—The Labor Party may laugh about it, but what I was referring to today was the lower income levels within the Public Service—the employees of the government, those with indirect responsibility of the government. We now know that the incomes of so many under this Labor administration have fallen in real terms. I would not be proud of that. If I was a Labor member of this place, I would be embarrassed by it. I have no doubt that the Australian people, when they face up to the choices at the next election and when they look at the record of this government both on unemployment and on falling real wages, will have but one choice; that is, to vote you out.

PARA.TAB: Look at the figures of unemployment. Sadly, we have been through the cycle. We have had our five minutes of sunshine. Going back to the last election, we had one million people unemployed. We had our five minutes of sunshine and some economic growth for a little while—economic growth that would have been sufficient to really eat into unemployment. Unfortunately, the figures have now turned around again.

Unemployment is on the rise. It bottomed out at 8.3 per cent; it has now risen steadily to 8.5 per cent. As I said, over 600,000 Australians are still out of work. But what about the unemployment rate for young people? It is three times that of the rate for adults. Unfortunately, that is on the rise again as well. It bottomed out at 27.1 per cent in February; since then it has risen to 28.1 per cent. Ninety-two thousand Australian adolescents are out of work. There are 92,000 young people in this country who are wanting work but unable to obtain it under the policies of this Australian Labor Party.

Of course, in the regions the position is much worse. The employment rate for adults is up around 13 per cent to 14 per cent. The unemployment rate for young people is up around 30 per cent to 40 per cent. There is no doubt why so many within the regions of Australia are angry about the record of this government.

As well, those who have been fortunate enough to maintain employment during this period have little to be grateful to this government for. I really do think it is fascinating. If ever this government responded positively to one sector of the community you would have thought it would be to its own public servants. The document that I have referred to from the Public Service Union—it refers to the redistribution of salaries within the Public Service, from the workers to management, under Labor—is really quite enlightening. When we look at the lower levels of salary within the Public Service—right from the bottom levels up to nearly $30,000, from an ASO1 up to an ASO6—we see there has been a fall in real income of between 9.6 per cent and 14.8 per cent since 1983. That is a fall of nearly 15 per cent in real income during the period of this Labor government.

The middle income range of the Public Service, $29,000 to $35,000, is still falling, but the fall is smaller—between five and 1.2 per cent. But for the better off in the Public Service, Labor's record is to have given them rises in real terms of between 11 and 33 per cent. So it is the same picture, whether you are in the Public Service or the private sector, under this government. The record for Australian workers, lower income workers, is that their wages have dropped. So much for the unions; so much for the accord! The record of Labor is that their wages have dropped, but for the better off, the well paid, their wages have risen.
That is what you ought to be so embarrassed about. The record of Labor has been that the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer. It is something about which you should be ashamed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Hill asked Senator Gareth Evans this question. It enabled Senator Evans to place some good news on the record of this parliament.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators would be aware that we currently have two Senator Evanses in this chamber, one of whom has not been with us in the last few days. I have it on very good authority that Senator Christopher Evans is actually sleeping at the moment after going through a traumatic experience which he and others who are parents would know about.

I have the pleasure of announcing to the Senate that this morning, at 1.45 Western standard time, Senator Evans's wife Miriam gave birth to Declan, weighing eight pounds five ounces. Declan is very well, Miriam is very well and there is some hope that Christopher Evans will survive the experience as well. I am sure all senators would join me and you, Madam Deputy President, in wishing all of the Evans family all the very best for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very important but nonetheless out of order.
—I cannot quite understand the relevance of what Senator McKiernan just said to the horrendous answer that Senator Evans gave both to me and to Senator Hill on related questions.
—Which Evans?

—Senator Gareth Evans, the one who is temporarily here. The point that was being made during question time is the plight of the battlers in Australia, the way in which their real incomes have gone down in 13 years of this government. To think that average incomes in the poorest households in Australia have dropped in the 13 years of this government by nearly $8,000 is nothing short of appalling. They do not even blush about it. They just make more and more excuses about it.
—They feel good about it.

—Yes, that is right, Senator Hill. They actually feel quite good about it. They are quite relaxed about it. They are equally relaxed to know that the income of 70 per cent of Australian households has fallen.

PARA.TAB: This is a political party that supposedly prides itself on looking after the battlers. They couldn't have done a worse job if they had tried. To let 70 per cent of households incomes drop over 13 years is just appalling and a disgrace. Let them go to the people and let the people decide. As well, after 13 years, they have put 750,000 households into the battler category.

The best estimates you can get, the very best estimates you can get, is that there will be over one million battler households by the year 2000. That is only four years away. Here they are, quite happy to come in here and have the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) saying that that is quite satisfactory and there is nothing wrong with it.

This is a political party whose Prime Minister only a handful of years ago said that no child would ever live in poverty. What has happened? Instead of keeping to that promise, they have broken that promise and left 600,000 children in poverty and 767,000 people out of work. Of course, the 767,000 people is a fictitious figure as well because what this mob have done is simply taken them off the employment queues and put them into all these other programs where they do now show up on the unemployment queues. The fact of the matter is that most of those people who are out there, sadly, still are not getting jobs. They are doing training courses or whatever. We are not saying for one moment that they should not be trained, but they should get a job at the end of it. What you have failed to deliver is the job at the end of it.

It was pointed out in a recent article in the Australian Financial Review that the pain is really showing in those low income households. Where are they getting their money from? The reality is that they are using their savings and their capital in every way, shape and form. They are borrowing money from their parents, brothers and sisters, relatives or anyone they can possibly borrow it from. They are hocking themselves to their eyeballs. They are having garage sales and selling off their assets because the Labor Party and you, Senator Murphy, have let these people down.

You should be ashamed of yourselves that you went into the last election saying that you were not going to increase taxes when you have clearly increased taxes right across the board. You have left these people worse off than ever before. Anyone running garage sales, pawn shops or whatever see people bringing their household goods in day in and day out. Why? They are doing it to pay the bills and to put bread on the table. You say that you are proud of your achievements. You should be utterly ashamed that 70 per cent of Australian households are worse off than they were when you came into office 13 years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen J.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Hill and Senator Knowles have referred to the issue of falling real wages and falling incomes because I now have the opportunity to put those issues into context. You should not take those declining factors on their own. What is conveniently overlooked by both Senator Knowles and Senator Hill are the increases in the social wage that have occurred under this government.

PARA.TAB: The importance of the social wage factors in any discussion on income distribution has been raised on several occasions. I am surprised that this is continually overlooked by senators opposite, including Senator Knowles and Senator Hill. Earlier this week in question time Senator Crowley gave a more contextual and relevant analysis of where Australia stands in terms of looking after its battlers.

Research by Dr Peter Whiteford in his paper `Family benefits and taxes: Support for children in a comparative perspective', which was published in the June issue of the Social Security journal and reported on in an article by Ross Gittens in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald, gives a much fairer comparison of where Australia stands with respect to its treatment of the Aussie battler. In that article, Ross Gittens states:
To make fair comparisons between countries you have to take account of all forms of assistance, not just some of them.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition conveniently does this when the figures suit them. The article goes on:

PARA.TAB: By international standards, our system treats low-income families very well. But high-income families aren't treated well at all. And, though our system isn't particularly generous in its treatment of middle-income families, its performance is about average by international standards.

SPEECH.PARA: The article states further:

PARA.TAB: In Australia's case, the gap between two couples' net incomes is 1.8 times—compared with the gap of three times for their gross incomes. So the effect of our family assistance system has been to reduce the "dispersion" of their incomes by 40 per cent.
And our system does more to direct assistance to low-income families than any other system examined.

SPEECH.PARA: Ross Gittens comments in that article:
. . . we could make our system more generous to high-income families—but only by making it less generous to low-income families. It doesn't sound like the right way to go to me.
It does not sound like the right way to go to me either. It appears that the sort of assistance that the opposition would like to put forward would factor more towards higher income families.

PARA.TAB: I will conclude my comments in this debate by putting to Senator Knowles and Senator Hill the comments of Bob Santamaria which I raised when answering Senator Abetz's points in relation to my submissions to the Lyons Forum. I think they accurately reflect what the Lyons Forum's policy is with respect to families. It seems to be the only indication of opposition policy that we can find. Bob Santamaria pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the contradictions between economic rationalism, with its stress on the individual maximising his interests, and pro-family rhetoric. "I resent it when people talk about giving the family priority and then pursue economic policies that cut the family's throat—

The inconsistencies with the opposition's policies are quite obvious, even to conservative commentators like Bob Santamaria. I think the comments about the answers of Senator Gareth Evans in question time were fairly hypocritical, and I rely on the more relevant statistics that I have put before the Senate just now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join in the debate on this issue because last night I read an article in the Australian Medicine magazine which documented how six million Australians are either entitled to or dependent upon a health care card, and that does not include dependants of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. If ever there was a statistic that was telling about the low income and living standards of Australian households, surely that statistic is it; it tells a terrible tale. It means that one-third of all Australians are living in families with incomes so low that they have to be supported with a health care card, with this welfare measure. Is that a measure of Australian living standards that this Labor government is proud of?

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans was breathtaking in his arrogance and, frankly, his ignorance about the economy in his answer today. He described the economy as being in great shape. He said, `The fundamentals of the Australian economy are as rock solid as they have ever been.' It was the most extraordinary answer.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that struck me is that it really does not matter what the state of the Australian economy is. The government will always say that it is in terrific shape or that what is happening is on course and according to forecasts, et cetera. When we went into recession in 1990 or thereabouts, the government said, `Well, that's terrific. We've got to have this recession. This is exactly what the Australian economy needs. This is to be expected. This is what we want.' Then when the economy recovered and we had a brief period of growth of six per cent, which everyone knew was completely unsustainable under this government's policies, the government said, `This is fantastic. Isn't this great? We've got the best growth in the world.'

Now that the growth, as evidenced by the national accounts yesterday, is back down to half of that—just over three per cent—that is terrific as well. It really does not matter what the state of the economy is—you think it is fantastic. You have absolutely no credibility when you come to comment on the economy. Senator Evans in particular, who many regard as having no knowledge of economics, is equally without any credibility at all.

The government, in the form of the minister representing the Prime Minister, is completely blind to the economic realities facing 18 million Australians. The economy is not in great shape. It is in very bad shape, as revealed yesterday by the national accounts. The worst part about it is the callous disregard which the government clearly has for the three-quarters of a million Australians who remain unemployed under its policies, the 8.7 per cent of the work force who cannot get a job under its policies. The fact is that the unemployment rate is actually increasing.

I gave evidence yesterday about the findings of the National Institute of Labour Studies, which show that the government have no hope of achieving their five per cent unemployment target by the year 2000. The best they think we can achieve by the year 2000 is about 7 1/2 per cent, and even that will require a growth rate of over 3 1/2 per cent, which you are not achieving on the basis of the national accounts, which, Senator Evans says, are in terrific shape. They give a growth rate of 3.3 per cent, which means that unemployment will continue to rise. More Australians will be out of work. Many economists have commented, on the basis of those figures, that unemployment will be over nine per cent by the early part of next year.
The economic realities are thus: we have massive foreign debt. We heard about Bob Santamaria. The News Weekly, which he is responsible for, talks about the state of the economy as follows:
Australia's net foreign liabilities, which include both the foreign debt and foreign equity in Australian companies, are now the third highest in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Out of all the economies in the world, we are in the third worst position when it comes to net foreign liabilities. Last year we had the highest peacetime deficit on the balance of current account—$24,000 million. Next year we are promised by the federal Treasurer (Mr Willis) that the balance on current account will amount to $27 billion—another record. The economy is in dreadful shape on that basis.

PARA.TAB: We have chronic budget deficits. The government cannot produce a budget surplus. The surplus it boasted about, which was always a false surplus, will not even become a surplus on the basis of the government's false accounting. Inflation is starting to rise again. We have chronically low savings rates. No wonder Rupert Murdoch described the economy as a complete disgrace. No wonder the Economist said that Australia is an emerging economy which is the next Mexico and which combines a third world economy with a first world standard of living. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Murphy this day, relating to a contract for the erection of advertising billboards and the Member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus).

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very serious matter. It is clearly the case that a member of the other House, Mrs Gallus, did interfere and cause the CSIRO to terminate an agreement they had with a small businessman who was entering into the advertising field and could well have caused him to go bankrupt. Mrs Gallus acknowledges and admits that she sought to interfere in the contract proceeding, which was to erect billboards on O'Halloran Hill in South Australia. She gave her reason as being one of environmental concern. That is clearly not the case.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Gallus would not have even known that Mr David Battersby and the CSIRO were proposing to erect billboards on O'Halloran Hill. The only people who knew that were people in the advertising area. Contracts had been let for advertising on at least two of the billboards. A company had been employed to market those billboards. Discussions that have been had, and discussions that I have been able to verify, will confirm that Mrs Gallus acted on behalf of one of those companies, sought to have the contract terminated on the basis of a complaint on behalf of those companies and sought to not allow Mr Battersby and his company to enter into the advertising area.

Mr Battersby, his wife and two children and the small company that they had were confronted with a debt of over $70,000—a debt that could well have bankrupted them and forced them to sell their home. The opposition, who continually claim to be the repositories of all propriety and integrity, should not allow this matter to go unnoticed in terms of Mrs Gallus's claim that somehow something came across her desk. I would like to read parts of Mr Battersby's statutory declaration, in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: I decided to ring Chris Gallus and see what her objections were. She stated that she was acting on environmental grounds, and that I didn't have Council approval. I asked Mrs Gallus whose behalf she was acting on as no council application had been submitted and as no site works were visible—
because they had not commenced—

only persons involved in the advertising industry would know about the development. She replied, "something had come across her desk". During the course of our conversation, she twice asked me how much rent I was paying CSIRO. Both times I told her that was private and confidential. She then told me the project was dead and would not go ahead, stating she had previously been on some CSIRO Review Board and had a lot of powerful friends at CSIRO who had assured her our contract would be terminated.

It is very important to understand the sequence of events here. A Mr Patchell of the CSIRO contacted Mr Battersby and told him that he had had calls from Mrs Gallus, and that Mrs Gallus was applying political pressure for the arrangement not to proceed. Indeed, when Mr Patchell spoke to Mr Battersby he said, that provided everything was in order, not to worry. However, he was then contacted again and told that the contract, the agreement, had been terminated.

PARA.TAB: I intend to pursue this matter. I intend to ask the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to conduct an investigation of Mrs Gallus's actions in this particular issue. It is not acceptable that such an event take place. As I understand, it has caused the CSIRO to pay a settlement to Mr Battersby. But more importantly, Mr Battersby could have earned a significant amount of income from these advertising operations. If that is the position which a member of the opposition wants to take with regard to small business people or people trying to create small business, then it is just not acceptable. I will continue to pursue this matter for as long as it takes to get to the truth of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it absolutely amazing that this government can spend such a large amount of time and such extensive resources in providing all the information they have provided in an effort to try to shaft a member of the opposition and a shadow minister, while not possibly being bothered to spend the time and resources in excess of the 30-day limit to give me an adequate answer to a question about one of their own—one of their own being Mrs Joan Kirner. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. What Senator Knowles is raising is not relevant to the question or the answer to the question. I make that point on the basis that I have been ruled out of order previously for attempting to do the same thing.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—There is no point of order, Senator Murphy. The matter is quite relevant to the issue that has been raised in terms of the way in which the government is responding to similar situations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The point of the matter is that I have asked about the meetings that Mrs Kirner was attending at taxpayer's expense, and I cannot get the answers. I asked, for example, in her capacity as Chairman of the Employment Services Regulatory Authority, what was the cost of her air travel; what allowances were paid; what was the cost of car transportation in each location; what were the other associated costs; and how long were the meetings for?

PARA.TAB: Of the answers that I have had given to me or that they have pretended to give to me, they have given me the travel allowance only to September—and here we are with tomorrow being 1 December. And yet they can shaft Mrs Gallus all they like with all of their resources. They give me the car transport costs until the end of August, and here we are with 1 December, as I say, being tomorrow. In answer to the question, `What were the other associated costs?' they do not know. In answer to question (e) `How long were the meetings for?' They do not know. In answer to (f) `What was purpose of the meeting?' they do not know. The same applied to her position in some other capacity for the federal government and any of its other agencies.

The fact of the matter is that this person, Mrs Kirner, is going around Australia at taxpayers' expense, swanning around in a Comcar, travelling first class. And what happened on the day of 13 September 1995? We have here that there was an ESRA board consultation held. Guess where?—Perth. What was Mrs Kirner doing that day? She was in the royal commission with Dr Lawrence. Dr Lawrence was in the royal commission all that day. If ever we have seen the footage come and go with Mrs Kirner holding her hand and collecting the flowers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who paid the fare?

—Who paid the fare? That is a good question. The taxpayer paid her fare. The taxpayer paid her fare; the taxpayer paid her accommodation; the taxpayer paid for her Comcar to swan around after Dr Lawrence. The minister cannot answer questions about that, and yet she is prepared to put in all the resources in the world to try to get Mrs Gallus. Why don't you do your parliamentary work properly instead of just running a schmucky campaign?

Dear Minister
I refer to the Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1995 No.257, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 21 September 1995.

The regulations provide for discretions which are not subject to external merits review. You will recall that there has been previous correspondence between yourself and the Committee about the aspect of the principal Regulations.

On 23 June 1994 the Committee wrote to you advising that it would refer to the Administrative Review Council for comment your advice that, if AAT review was provided, people would exploit those provisions to delay payment. The ARC has now recommended that decisions concerning the deferment, refund or remission of fees or charges made under the principal Regulations or the Meat Inspection (Fees) Orders and the Export Control (Fees) Orders, whether or not reconsidered by the Secretary, should be subject to merits review by the AAT.
The Committee would appreciate your advice on whether it is intended to amend these instruments to provide for such review.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
28 November 1995
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mal

On 22 September 1995, you wrote to me as a result of amendments to the Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Regulations (the Regulations) considered by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances at its meeting on 21 September 1995. In view of a recent recommendation by the Administrative Review Council, to the effect that decisions concerning the deferment, refund or remission of fees and charges under the Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Regulations, the Meat Inspection (Fees) Orders and the Export Control (Fees) Orders should be subject to merits review by the Administrative Review Tribunal, the Committee asked for my advice on whether it is intended to provide such a review.

The amendments which have prompted your present enquiry varied the provisions relating to the matters of which the Secretary must be satisfied or must take into account before remitting some or all of the amount of a charge imposed under the Export Inspection (Establishments Registration Charges) Act 1985, the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985, the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 or the Domestic Meat Premises Charge Act 1993. The actual discretion was provided previously, however, in amendments to the Regulations made by Statutory Rules 1994, No. 369.

As I have advised the Committee in response to an earlier query, refunding and remission of charges pursuant to subregulation 6(8) of the Regulations has consequences for cost recovery in relation to programs administered by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) on a commercial basis. The quantum of charges is fixed periodically, in close consultation with industry bodies, to reflect and recoup AQIS's operating costs. Having regard to the degree of consultation that takes place when charges are calculated and agreed, the question of remissions or refunds, which are only available under subregulation 6(8) when collections are surplus to cost recovery requirements, should not generally arise. Where, however, an over-calculation of AQIS's operating costs properly referable to industry has occurred AQIS and industry will agree the amount of the refund or remission payable. Any decision is made in close consultation with the relevant industry consultative committees. The industry consultative committees are the established fora for discussions with industry regarding cost recovery arrangements. The industry representatives are drawn from all sectors of that industry and each affected industry group is given the opportunity through the consultative process to provide input into decisions to return over-recovered revenue to industry.

I am generally supportive of the comments made by the Administrative Review Council and my colleague, the Minister for Justice, in recent correspondence concerning the desirability of external merits review of decisions made under the Meat Inspection legislation. I must have regard also, however, to the agreements reached with industry and law that might be affected by individual rights of appeal.

More widely, you will appreciate AQIS must make commercial decisions concerning relief from the payment of debts owing to the Commonwealth. I don't think this is appropriately a matter for merit review but rather a matter for the courts.

In the circumstances, therefore, as I have advised previously I do not consider review, by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the Secretary's decisions relating to remitting and refunding charges either necessary or appropriate.

A disallowance motion on the Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Regulations (Amendment) would be contrary to industry's request. A provision in the Regulations to refund is necessary if AQIS is to administer overrecoveries in line with industry's wishes. AQIS would not be able to meet commitments given to industry groups to refund over-recoveries in the future if the Regulations were to be disallowed.

Although not affected by the amendments to the Regulations considered by the Committee on 21 September, I will comment on review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions under subregulation 2B(2) of the Regulations which provision permits the Secretary to specify a later due date for the payment of a charge than the due date prescribed and permit the payment of charges by instalments and also AAT review of decisions under the Meat Inspection (Fees) Orders and the Export Control (Fees) Orders. Decisions under subregulation 2B(2) and the Fees Orders have also been raised by the Minister for Justice and the Administrative Review Council.

In relation to the review of decisions under subregulation 2B(2), I am of the view that the same considerations apply as I have indicated above in relation to decisions concerning the remission or refunding of charges under subregulation 6(8) of the Regulations. As for decisions under the Meat Inspection (Fees) Orders, consideration is being given to amending the review provisions contained in Part 6 of the Orders, in particular suborder 31.1, to take account of, amongst other things, concerns raised by the Minister and the Council. Decisions under the Export Control (Fees) Orders are presently subject to ultimate review by the Administrative Review Tribunal by virtue of the application, under order 19 of those Orders, of Part 20 of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders.
I am writing to the Minister for Justice also in the above terms.
Yours sincerely
(Bob Collins)
30 November 1995
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman

Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600

PARA.EMPHASIS: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CAPITAL AND THE EXTERNAL TERRITORIES—DELIVERING THE GOODS

SPEECH.PARA: In August 1993 the Joint Standing Committee was asked by the then Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the Hon Ros Kelly MP to inquire into and report on:

(a)the effectiveness and cost of current arrangements for the freighting of food, general supplies, building materials and other community needs into the Territories of Christmas Island, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Norfolk Island including:

TAB.TAB: (i)future options for servicing these territories;
(ii)the adequacy of existing freight discharge and handling infrastructure and systems into each of these territories; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)the frequency and cost of current passenger travel into Norfolk Island and options for the future.
The committee was also required to take into account commercial considerations in servicing remote localities in Australia and the self-governing status of Norfolk Island.

The committee was chaired by Mr Robert Chynoweth, MP and received 98 submissions from a range of individuals and organisations including those with commercial interests in the territories, mainland-based suppliers, members of the island communities and government bodies.
Public hearings were conducted in Canberra, Perth, Brisbane, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Norfolk Island.

The committee's report was presented in March 1995 and contained 26 recommendations. Key recommendations include the undertaking of cost of living surveys by the Australian Bureau of Statistics at Christmas, Cocos and Norfolk Island, calling for expressions of interest for shipping services to the Indian Ocean Territories, the examination of alternative freight-handling methods at Cocos (Keeling) Islands and the purchase of an Australian-built vessel to service Norfolk Island.
The government's response to each of the recommendations contained in the report follows.
