TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the government response which the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has just incorporated. It is a response to Delivering the Goods, a report of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories, which was asked to inquire into the effectiveness and cost of current arrangements for the freighting of food, general supplies, building materials and other community needs into the territories of Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Norfolk Island, and other matters.

PARA.TAB: I wish to confine my remarks this afternoon to the response to the recommendations on Norfolk Island. I was extremely disappointed with the response. I shall point out why in a moment. I was pleased that at least the government agreed with the recommendation that the area known as Kingston, a very important part of Norfolk Island historically, be excluded from consideration as a potential site for any new harbour or freight handling infrastructure on Norfolk Island.
We made one recommendation on ships that I believe should have been supported. It was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth make available a grant equivalent to the Ships Capital Grant for the purchase of an Australian built vessel, smaller than would otherwise qualify for the Ships Capital Grant, on condition that any proposed vessel would be used principally on the Norfolk Island trade for at least the first two years following commissioning.

We did that because we found in our inquiry it was not reasonable or practical to build a large harbour. I do not have the time this afternoon to go through all of the matters that we looked at. This proposal related to putting out to tender a ship for the purpose of providing a service to Norfolk Island, knowing that at present there is a doubt about the ships presently servicing the island.

PARA.TAB: The government said that there are still union purchase ships available and that it is not a matter to worry about. The response was that they disagreed with this proposal, which would be the cheapest option, to do something practical for the island. The government response was:

This recommendation was predicated on the assumption that union purchase vessels would soon not be available to service Norfolk Island. As these vessels will continue to visit the island for the foreseeable future there is not the same degree of urgency to provide a replacement service; rather, there is still time to consider all options in detail.

SPEECH.PARA: Fairyland! There has been a problem since the beginning of the century in servicing Norfolk Island. This was an opportunity to do something practical about it, at a cost that was reasonable for the number of people involved. I cannot believe that this has happened again.

PARA.TAB: I refer now to some parts of the report which set out some of the history. Paragraph 5.6 states:

Norfolk Island has suffered severely in the past through the defective opportunities which nature has supplied for the safe and speedy access from ships to shore . . . It is certain that unless some substantial improvements can be effected, the probabilities of the expansion of trade in the future will be seriously lessened.

SPEECH.PARA: Trade and tourism, I add to that. You might think that is a statement made recently. That is not so. That was made in a report to this parliament in 1914. It identified the lack of harbour facilities as a factor which had inhibited enterprise and trade on Norfolk Island.

PARA.TAB: A royal commission was conducted in 1975-76. Mr Justice Nimmo inquired into the constitutional relationship, which resulted in a measure of self-government being granted to Norfolk Island in 1979. He reported on a number of things, including air services, the state of the airport, the constitution, et cetera. One of his recommendations was that the construction of a small boat harbour facility be investigated. He said:

The physical difficulties which would be encountered in constructing a worthwhile harbour at Norfolk Island would be enormous, and the cost of undertaking such construction would be prohibitive, both in absolute terms and also when weighed against the benefits received . . . However . . . one should take care to distinguish between such a seaport on the one hand and a small boat harbour on the other.

SPEECH.PARA: How many reports do we need? In 1979 a measure of self-government was given to Norfolk Island and responsibilities were handed to the Norfolk Island government without doing anything about the infrastructure which enables them to get access to goods and passengers to the island. I believe it is our responsibility to do something about that, but not in terms of a grand harbour. We do not recommend that. We made a recommendation which would give some assistance to enable a firm to acquire a ship which could do this task. This was the cheapest possible option.

PARA.TAB: There was general agreement, as is reported in paragraph 5.37, that infrastructure for unloading passengers and freight by sea on Norfolk Island was primitive and in poor repair, which in turn prevented Norfolk Island from obtaining modern shipping services. It was apparent the Norfolk Island government could not afford to fund the substantial new port infrastructure. The chief minister said, and he is quoted in our report, on the question of freight handling facilities, `It is fair to say that we have been hampered for lack of funds.'

Yet another report comes to this parliament. Yet again the government has failed to recognise its responsibilities to do anything and puts it off. The first report was in 1914 and here today we get this response from the government which says, `Rather there is time to consider all options in adequate detail.' How many more decades have to pass before something is done to rectify this situation? I could scarcely believe it when I read that.

The government agrees to recommendation No. 22 in principle. It disagrees with the other recommendation which we believed was significant to enable things to happen more freely with Norfolk Island, that was to get rid of the export clearance numbers that operate at present. The government has rejected this proposal as well. I think that is a pity and unimaginative.

We also made a recommendation in relation to Australia Post, about the increase in prices of parcels to Norfolk Island. Parcels by post to Norfolk Island are part of the lifeblood of the place and, again, the government disagreed with that recommendation. It seems to me that the government either does not quite know what happens on Norfolk Island, what life is like there, or does not care. I am extremely disappointed that even if the government had not agreed to the precise recommendations that we have made, it has not even seemed to have recognised that there are things that need to be done on Norfolk Island in relation to its survival—getting goods and services there.

We heard evidence of occasions when they virtually ran out of perishable things. It is certainly important to its future that it gets tourists to the place in greater numbers than at present. Norfolk Island suffered enormously during the pilots strike and that has not really been compensated for. The air services are not as good as they could be.

I think generally those who read this report will be very disappointed with the government's response and its failure to recognise that the time has come to do something about access to Norfolk Island rather than putting it off again. It will not be that long before it is 2014. I would hope that it would not be 100 years between the first report to this parliament about the needs of the island and some adequate response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on a couple of government responses to the recommendations made by the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories in its report Delivering the Goods. First of all, I just want to briefly refer to recommendations Nos 3, 4 and 5 which relate to shipping into all of the external territories—Norfolk, Christmas and Cocos—but particularly in relation to Christmas and Cocos islands.

PARA.TAB: It is essential that the government is not blinkered or limited by its very close connections with the union movement in relation to shipping to Christmas and Cocos islands. It is essential that a shipping service is provided to Christmas and Cocos that serves both islands and serves them both effectively and at the least possible cost. The committee took evidence from a number of interested parties who all indicated that they could provide a good service, an efficient service and a cost-effective service to both Christmas and Cocos provided the government did not stand in their way.

That was one of the reasons why the committee recommended that tenders be called and expressions of interest sought in relation to providing a service without cabotage applying to the service. The evidence given to us by almost all of the people interested in this aspect suggested that the existence of cabotage was the factor prohibiting operators from providing a cost-effective service to Christmas and Cocos islands.

It is essential that both islands be served. I understand that the government is currently encouraging an operator from Darwin of all places to the Indian Ocean territories but only doing Christmas Island, not the Cocos islands. That will leave Cocos without a regular and reliable form of freight into the island. I do express my regret that the government has not been prepared to pick that up.

The government does say, in its response to recommendation 3—whilst acknowledging in its response to recommendation 2 that there is strong community support to include the scenario where Christmas Island is exempt from cabotage—that the federal government has reaffirmed its commitment to supporting existing cabotage arrangements. I think that is unfortunate.

The government does go on to say that they support the single voyage permit system, which does exist, and also point out that arrangements under the act presently exist for the issue of coasting trade licences and single voyage permits, as I have mentioned. They say that that provides sufficient flexibility to accommodate current options. I want to emphasise that because I suggest that it would be most inappropriate if the government, having supported the issue of trade licences and single voyage permits, at some stage gets pressured by the unions to re-look at those things because the unions are not getting what they want out of it.

I am disappointed that the government did not take a more pro-active approach to the question of cabotage. In that regard, I finally say that the essential thing is that the people of Cocos and Christmas islands do have a reliable, efficient and relatively inexpensive means of getting their freight to the island.

Leaving the shipping matter, I refer to the responses to recommendation 12, where the committee recommended that Cocos island's cooperative society be reconstituted under Australian law. I am pleased to see that the government has agreed with that. It is only sensible. The sooner the cooperative is brought under Australian law and can be dealt with, audited and monitored under Australian law rather than Singaporean law, under which it presently exists, the better will be the people of Cocos islands and the people who have to rely on the services that the cooperative provides at Cocos.

The government has also agreed with the committee's recommendation 13 regarding an inquiry into legal status, ownership and economic power of the co-op and its links with the Cocos Keeling shire council. I have expressed concern that the members of the board of the co-ops are almost identical to the members of the Cocos shire council. I cannot claim to be an expert under West Australian local government law, under which the shire now operates, but certainly under Queensland that would have had a fairly substantial conflict of interest concern in it.

It really is the case, without putting too strong a point on it, that the Cocos island cooperative is really the principal commercial organisation on the island and it is also almost one and the same as the council. It does mean that people wanting to set up in competition—people with a different view of how to run commercial life on Cocos island—find it very difficult. I am pleased to see that the government is prepared to look at that a bit closer.

The thing that impacted upon most committee members when we landed on Cocos was that it is a magnificently pretty series of atolls. The other thing to hit us was the number of coconut trees on the island. There is a recommendation that we should see whether we can do something with the coconuts—maybe get some coconut oil extracted. The government has disagreed with the specific recommendation made. I suppose it has gone halfway by saying that it will investigate the extraction of coconut oil as a commercial activity to give some employment and wealth creation prospects to the people of Cocos island.

In recommendation 19 the committee referred to the purchase of an amphibious landing vessel and the ownership of that. Particularly in relation to Cocos, but also in Christmas, the government has to be very careful that if it has the interests of the inhabitants at heart, it has to make sure that there is no conflict of interest between the stevedores, the people who load and unload and distribute goods, and to make sure that they always act in a way that is in the best interests of the people of those islands. There is a suggestion that the stevedores are in many instances representatives of the co-op and there is preference given in pricing and timing to freight which belongs to the cooperative to the detriment of other person's freight. I think it is important that with any new landing vessels, the ownership and the capacity to work should be very carefully considered.

Senator Reid also referred to recommendation 26, in which the committee recommended that the requirement for export clearance numbers for supplies sent from mainland Australia to the external territories be abolished without any change to their duty-free status. In its response the government has disagreed with this recommendation, claiming that the cost of doing this is not really their fault.

Overwhelmingly, the evidence given to the committee was that these export clearance numbers did not seem to serve a purpose that could not be achieved in some other way, but they did add very considerably to the cost of freighting goods not only to Norfolk Island but also to the Indian Ocean territories as well. I am disappointed that in that regard the government was not prepared to pick up the recommendations of the committee. I generally support those comments made by Senator Reid in relation to many of the other responses to the recommendations of the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This response is timely. I had intended to ask Senator Collins a question today if he had been here in relation to this very matter. I was going to refer Senator Collins to the recent controversy regarding the shipping service to the Cocos and Christmas islands. I would have referred him to an article in the Australian dated 25-26 November 1995, which was entitled `Union plot to sink Cocos shipping'. In that article the Minister for Transport in Western Australia accused the federal government of lobbying for Darwin to service the islands and said that the Maritime Union had been doing the government's dirty work.

PARA.TAB: The questions I was going to put to the minister were: could the minister confirm or deny whether any Keating government ministers had been involved in lobbying for Darwin to service Christmas and Cocos islands? Furthermore, was the minister aware of the preference of the people of both islands that the current dedicated island service, that is, Cocos Traders, remain operating from the traditional port of Fremantle in Western Australia? I might add that any transfer of the shipping service from Perth to Darwin would result in a loss in the region of $55 million to Western Australia.

I was further going to ask: has the government done any comparison of the adequacy of the services and benefits to the community offered by the two competing services operating from Darwin and Perth respectively? It is my belief it would be more cost-effective to operate from Fremantle than from Darwin as, for a start, there would not be the problem with freight that goods in Darwin would experience.

I also would have asked the minister to investigate and act upon claims by the Western Australian Minister for Transport, Eric Charlton, that the maritime union was being used industrially to close the shipping service currently operating between Western Australia and the islands. The Cocos traders have operated between Fremantle and the Cocos and Christmas islands since the state shipping service ceased earlier this year. They have been operating very well, I believe, in the interests of people on both islands. Unfortunately, it looks as though the Cocos traders will not be given a single-voyage permit for the month of December.

I believe the federal government has been involved in lobbying for the Darwin service. I refer to a draft set of minutes from the Christmas Island Chamber of Commerce dealing with a meeting held on 9 October 1995 where the chairman indicated that a meeting had been held with Mr Warren Snowdon, the government member for the Northern Territory, on 12 September 1995. There were others in attendance. At this meeting the chamber had raised the shipping issue. It was reported that Mr Snowdon had stated that from information he had received `we could forget utilising a Clunies-Ross vessel' as it would not leave the port of Fremantle and he would be surprised if it was worked by Christmas Island stevedores. That points to a federal government involvement in treating preferentially a competing service. I note that in the article in the Australian that I mentioned, Mr Snowdon said:

SPEECH.PARA: What we are about is trying to provide competition in the marketplace and a cost-effective service to Christmas and Cocos islands.

I ask the government to do just that. I ask the government also to have regard to the wishes of the people on both Cocos and Christmas islands and give the Cocos traders a fair go in their submission to carry on conducting this service.

PARA.TAB: I also question whether the competing service will offer a regular service to the Cocos Islands or whether it will be more of a regular service to Christmas Island alone. I think that is a very important point. It was raised in the committee's report Delivering the goods. Freight and shipping are vital to these two islands and the government has a responsibility to look after the interests of the people on both those islands.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE ON AUSTRALIA, THE WORLD BANK AND THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND

PARA.EMPHASIS: INTRODUCTION

SPEECH.PARA: In 1991, the committee requested the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to provide terms of reference for an inquiry examining Australia's relations with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF), highlighting those aspects of Australia's relations with them which would be in Australia's long term economic and trade interests.
The inquiry's terms of reference were as follows:

`Australia's relationship with the World Bank and IMF and the opportunities for Australia's participation in Bank and Fund projects, highlighting those aspects which would be in Australia's long term economic and trade interests.'
Public hearings were conducted in 1992 and 1993 and the committee's Report was tabled in the Senate on 30 September 1993. The Report made thirty-two recommendations.
The government welcomes the committee's report.

The World Bank and the IMF were established under the Bretton Woods agreement in 1944 to help in post-war economic reconstruction and development (the World Bank) and in restoring and monitoring international monetary stability (the IMF).

The organisations have played a central role in global economic development and in international monetary affairs. Over the past fifty years, the World Bank and the IMF have become important sources of multilateral financial and technical assistance and economic advice to developing countries. They are leaders in debates on international monetary and economic issues (the IMF) and on development issues (the World Bank) and both have considerable research activities relating to finance and development. They assist developing countries in designing and implementing social and economic policies that seek to promote development in ways that are outward-looking and consistent with the development of open international trade and financial systems. The Fund and Bank are important catalysts in mobilising private and official capital for investment in developing countries. In recent years, the World Bank has been giving priority to reducing poverty and to addressing social and environmental aspects of development. Both the Fund and Bank are active in assisting the economies in transition in Eastern and Central Europe which are in the process of moving from centrally planned to market based economic systems.

Neither organisation has been without its critics. They have been criticised for the conditions they have agreed with recipient countries for the provision of assistance (particularly economic conditions, such as monetary and fiscal targets). They have also been criticised for not requiring that projects or programs take more account of social and environmental factors.

Some projects and programs have indeed been less than they might have been. However, it is also important to note that the outcomes of programs assisted by the Fund and Bank depend not only on the terms of assistance agreed by the organisations with governments, but on the effectiveness of implementation by those governments.
The organisations are important to Australia for their support of sustainable economic growth and outward looking economic policies, globally and within Asia and the Pacific.

A significant proportion of Australia's total aid expenditure goes to the World Bank. In 1994-95, around 11 per cent of Australia's official development assistance was provided to multilateral development banks, including the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. Australia's financial contribution to the capital resources of the World Bank and the IMF has been supplemented, in the case of the World Bank, by substantial voluntary contributions to the concessional lending arm of the World Bank, the International Development Association, which provides funds on highly concessional terms to the world's poorest countries.

Since the committee reported, the government has agreed to contribute $A30 million, over an extended period beginning 1997-98, to subsidise the provision of funds for structural adjustment programs to the poorest countries on highly concessional terms by the IMF, through the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF). The government's decision to contribute to the enlarged ESAF is in recognition of the useful role ESAF has played in improving the economic performance of some of the poorest countries.

Through our membership of the World Bank, Australian businesses have opportunities to supply goods and services procured by operations of the Bank. Australia also benefits from its annual consultations with the Fund under Article IV arrangements, when the Fund provides advice to the government on Australia's economic policy stance.

Through helping to create improved policy environments in developing countries in Asia and the Pacific, both organisations complement, directly and indirectly, the effectiveness of Australia's bilateral aid program.
The government considers it important to monitor the operations of the Bank and Fund on an ongoing basis to ensure:
(+)that they use their resources in an efficient and effective manner, both administratively and operationally, to ensure the best value for the scarce development dollar;
(+)that their operations are effective `on the ground' in terms of sustainable development impact;

(+)that World Bank policies are consistent with Australia's development concerns, particularly in the areas of economic policy advising, in poverty reduction, the environment, and social and human resource development, including the role of women in development;
(+)that the Fund promotes international financial stability and economic growth;
(+)that Fund supported programs take account of wider social considerations, such as by the incorporation of "safety nets"; and
(+)that Australia is able to take full advantage of procurement opportunities in projects assisted by the Bank.

To this end, Australia's Governors to the Bank and Fund have taken an active role in the organisations' activities; this is supported by the Executive Directors representing Australia on the Executive Boards of both organisations. This involvement is the main channel for the continuing support and guidance that Australia provides to the Bank and Fund. The government draws substantially on its departmental resources, particularly in the Treasury, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Agency for International Development and the Environment Protection Agency for supporting these activities. Furthermore, it welcomes the interest taken and advice provided by non-government organisations in the operations of the Bank and the Fund.

Many of the committee's recommendations are directed to ensuring that the organisations more effectively meet Australia's objectives. For these reasons, and in the context of ongoing monitoring of the Bank and Fund activities, the government welcomes the Report of the committee and endorses many of its recommendations.
The government's response to the individual recommendations follows.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1:The committee recommends that Australia join the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The question of whether Australia should join MIGA depends on a number of issues. The demand by Australian investors for insurance has so far been met through the Overseas Investment Insurance facility provided by the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC). However there would be some benefits to Australian business from membership and there is a case for Australia to support the role MIGA plays in promoting economic development. The government will reassess the case for Australian membership of MIGA against the budgetary costs involved.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2:

The committee recommends that details of the Fund's Article IV consultation with Australia be included in the Treasurer's report to the Parliament under the International Monetary Agreements act 1947. The Treasurer's report should also include the reasons why Article IV consultations have not been placed on the public record in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government recognises the benefits of greater public disclosure of Fund-related matters in building better understanding of the Fund's role and activities. The government supports efforts by the Fund to expand the amount of information it releases while not impeding the ability of national authorities and the Fund to hold confidential discussions or to ensure that member governments receive a frank assessment by the IMF of their countries' economic policies. Australia supported the decision taken by the Fund in 1994 to make publicly available background documents for Article IV and program discussions that contain information on recent economic developments, as well as statistical appendices and annexes.

PARA.TAB: A summary of the outcome of the Fund's 1994 Article IV consultations with Australia was included in the Treasurer's 1994 Annual Report to the Parliament on Australia and the IMF.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3:The committee recommends that Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia produce a discussion paper on the role of the International Monetary Fund in the management of the value of the Australian dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The value of the Australian dollar is determined essentially in the market place. It is not set administratively, although the Reserve Bank does undertake foreign exchange operations on occasions to try to counter what it sees as unwarranted or disorderly conditions.

PARA.TAB: While the IMF may discuss with Australia broad monetary and exchange rate policy issues, the IMF has no role in the management of the value of the Australian dollar.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4:The committee strongly recommends that Australia's full entitlement to additional shares in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) be taken up so as to maximise our influence within the Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:For budgetary reasons, the government decided that it would not subscribe to its full entitlement of equity in the IBRD. This decision was announced in the 1993-94 Budget. Australia will continue to support strongly the Bank's objectives and activities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5:The committee recommends that multilateral aid should be a separate component of the aid budget. A special mechanism should be established for dealing with MDB contributions so that payment does not take pockets of money out of the bilateral aid budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:Contributions to international organisations are already identified as separate components of the aid budget. In its determination of the total aid budget, the government considers both the multilateral and bilateral components and the interaction between them.

PARA.TAB: In the context of the 1994-95 Budget, and following consultations between AusAID, the Department of Finance and Treasury, the government has introduced revised planning arrangements on forward commitments which will contribute to the appropriate management of pressures arising from commitments to the multilateral development banks.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6:The committee recommends that the government guarantee that the position of Australian Executive Director in all international financial institutions be advertised publicly and that expertise in development and development finance issues be an essential criterion for selection. Selection panels should be broadly based and must include an appropriately qualified member with development experience in addition to Treasury and Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade officers.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government will continue to advertise publicly for applicants for Executive Director positions in the Bank and the Fund, and will ensure that members of the selection panel are suitably qualified, including with development experience. Experience in or sound knowledge of development and development finance issues will be included in the selection criteria.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7:The committee recommends that the Bank be encouraged to devote more resources to procurement data collection and management with a view to improving the quality of its statistical reporting.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government will continue to seek improvements in the Bank's statistics on procurement, with the aim of obtaining more precise, comprehensive and usable statistics.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 8:The committee recommends that Australian agencies be encouraged to improve the timeliness and level of their statistical reporting.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government will direct its agencies to address the timeliness of their statistical reporting on Bank procurement, in order to provide a reliable supplement to Bank statistics.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9:The committee recommends the preparation and distribution of a pamphlet by AUSTRADE of guidelines to Australian companies on how to meet Bank tender requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:AusAID and Austrade have published a booklet entitled 30 Billion Reasons to Enter the Market: Doing Business With the Multilateral Development Banks and United Nations Agencies: A Guide to Procurement Opportunities. This plain-language guide was launched by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, the Hon. Gordon Bilney MP, at the first of three procurement seminars held by Austrade and the World Bank for Australian firms in Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane in March 1994. Since its initial distribution at the seminars, the booklet has been provided by AusAID and Austrade to other interested firms.

PARA.TAB: A further series of seminars was staged in 1995 including substantial events in Sydney and Melbourne which were opened by the Hon. Gordon Bilney MP and the Minister for Trade, Senator the Hon. Bob McMullan, respectively.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 10:The committee recommends that AUSTRADE and AIDAB investigate mechanisms, such as business consultative groups, to encourage the formation of consortia to bid for Bank projects and to better link consultants with suppliers.

Response:Austrade's various industry Business Development Units and industry associates, such as Austenergy, Austmine and ARIC, are encouraging the use of such mechanisms with businesses dealing with the Bank.

PARA.TAB: Further, Austrade has reconstructed its Projects Group to provide additional resources to assist Australian companies, consultants and suppliers to win business from the major infrastructure developments—particularly those which are occurring in Asia. A significant part of these resources will focus on World Bank and Asian Development Bank opportunities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 11:The committee recommends that Australia press the Bank to adopt similar measures to the OECD mixed credit guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:Procurement under loans provided by the IBRD and IDA is subject to the Bank's procurement guidelines which are consistent with the OECD guidelines.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 12:The committee recommends that AUSTRADE and the offices of Australia's Executive Director must increase their efforts to: enhance the knowledge and competitiveness of Australian companies of Bank tender opportunities; and increase the awareness of both Bank and loan country procurement personnel about Australian products and services that meet their requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:Austrade's Bank project dissemination system, known as IPIN, is trialling the electronically-generated notification of World Bank, Asian Development Bank, and other project opportunities direct to firms. Austrade will advise its users when this enhancement is available, which is anticipated sometime in 1996.

PARA.TAB: Seminar presentations by Bank representatives and specialist Austrade staff will continue to be held in Australia. Past seminars have been successful in reaching a broad cross-section of the Australian Business community. World Bank procurement seminars were held in major cities in March 1994. The high-profile Aid Business, Good Business seminars held in Sydney and Melbourne in April 1995 also featured, among others, a senior World Bank representative who briefed participants on the Bank's procurement procedures as recently amended.

Australia's Alternate Executive Director supports Australian businesses' efforts in their dealings with the Bank, including advising Bank personnel of relevant Australian capabilities. The government will arrange for Australia's Alternate Executive Director to meet with industry during his consultation visits to Australia.

The government will ensure that overseas staff from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Austrade will inform host countries of the availability and relevance of Australian products and services.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 13:The committee recommends that programs such as the Metal Trades Industry Association (MTIA) visit be continued and expanded to include as many companies as possible. Annual visits by a delegation of Australian business people to Washington and project identification missions into recipient countries should become a regular feature of contact between Australia and the Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government sees merit in appropriate industry activities, including missions, which expand contact between Australian companies and the World Bank.

PARA.TAB: Austrade advises that there is particular value in directing effort to making contact with in-country executing agencies which are responsible for setting up procurement schedules, evaluating bids and awarding contracts.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 14:The committee recommends that the co-financing facility be developed and that AIDAB draw closely on the National Trade Strategy in identifying projects that will maximise trade and commercial benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:A cofinancing facility was in operation within AusAID from 1982 to 1987. A review of the facility was undertaken in 1987. Following the review, funding for the separate facility ceased and cofinancing was integrated into allocations for country programs.

PARA.TAB: A 1994 AusAID review of cofinancing reaffirmed that there are advantages in retaining the programming of cofinancing in country programs. AusAID accepted the review recommendation that cofinancing be addressed through the adoption of a three-pronged strategy aimed at creating (i) the policy and procedural climate to facilitate cofinancing activity; (ii) the capacity to monitor and to assess progress with the implementation of activity policy; and (iii) a point of responsibility in AusAID to facilitate cofinancing.

AusAID is drawing on the bilateral and sectoral strategies in the National Trade Strategy in identifying prospective cofinancing projects that will maximise trade and commercial benefits consistent with development objectives. Total expenditure on AusAID activities cofinanced with the World Bank is estimated at about $A15 million per annum. Included in this figure is funding for project implementation on a parallel or joint basis as well as for a number of special purpose trust funds to enable the Bank to utilise Australian expertise for project preparation work, including the Australian Consultants' Trust Fund and the South Pacific Facility.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 15:The committee recommends the maintenance of the Consultants' Trust Fund at the current level and the establishment of a Consultants' Development Fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government intends to maintain the Consultants' Trust Fund.

PARA.TAB: However, Austrade has received negative reactions from consultants over the establishment of a development fund of the type envisaged. Consultants consider that such a move may jeopardise their claim of impartiality and may have serious implications for Bank recruitment of Australian consultants, given that Bank procurement procedures attempt to avoid specifications favouring a particular country.
Given these concerns, the government does not intend to pursue the Consultants' Development Fund at this stage.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 16:The committee recommends that the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Treasury adopt a broader perspective when assessing and reporting on the appropriateness of Bank and Fund activities.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government notes that these departments consult widely, including with other agencies, in the preparation of advice on matters relating to the Bank and Fund.

PARA.TAB: For example, proposed Bank projects with possible significant environmental implications are referred to the Environmental Protection Agency and to non-government organisations through the Australian Council for Overseas Aid for advice, with comments passed to the Bank prior to discussion in the executive board. When the response of Bank staff is inadequate, the issues are pursued in discussion in the Board.
Regular meetings are also held with non-government organisations through the Australian Council for Overseas Aid on policy issues currently under discussion and development.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 17:The committee recommends that the government strive within the Fund to achieve a poverty alleviation focus in structural adjustment lending. Within the Bank the government should press for full implementation of the Bank's poverty alleviation policies in its structural adjustment lending and for more resources to be directed to evaluating the poverty impact of these loans.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government agrees that poverty alleviation should be a major concern of both institutions, while recognising that the role of the Fund will inevitably be more indirect as a consequence of its primarily macroeconomic focus. The Treasurer has stressed this fact in his addresses at meetings of the Fund and World Bank.

PARA.TAB: The government agrees that Fund-supported reform programs should have an appropriate mix and phasing of economic policies to reduce any adverse effects of reform measures on the poor. However, the government recognises that some adverse effects on prices and employment cannot always be avoided, particularly in crisis situations. The government encourages efforts by the Fund to incorporate social safety nets in Fund-supported programs.

With regard to World Bank operations, the government emphasises the importance of poverty alleviation, particularly with regard to structural adjustment lending, and supports the Bank's policies which aim at enhancing procedures for the evaluation of poverty measures. The government has supported the Bank's policy to report annually on the poverty impact of its operations and, as noted in its responses to Recommendations 18 and 19, will provide an assessment of these measures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 18:The committee recommends that the Treasurer's Annual Report to the Parliament under the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Act should include details of the government's efforts to enhance poverty alleviation by the World Bank. It should also evaluate the impact of these efforts.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government's efforts to influence the practices and policies of the Bank occur through statements at Annual Meetings, bilateral contacts with Bank management and staff and participation in discussions in the Executive Board. An indication of these activities, and their effectiveness, will continue to be included in the Treasurer's Annual Report to Parliament.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 19:The committee recommends that the responsible Minister report annually to the Parliament on the expected poverty impact of all structural and sectoral adjustment loans approved by the Bank and the Fund over the preceding period.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The primary focus of the Fund's operations is on remedying macroeconomic imbalances and structural problems as pre-conditions for sustained growth. The incorporation of policy advice on (and financial support for) the development of "safety nets" into Fund programs has been designed to ameliorate the effects of adjustment measures on affected poor groups. The government will seek advice on the effectiveness of safety nets in Fund supported programs and to the extent practicable, these matters will be included in the Treasurer's reports to Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Bank produces annual reports on the poverty impact of its operations, including structural and sectoral adjustment operations. An assessment of these reports will be included in the Treasurer's reports to Parliament on the World Bank.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 20:The committee recommends that the Australian Executive Director exercises a more stringent oversight of Bank loans to ensure that the Bank takes a more active role in evaluating the impact of its programs upon the environment and the population.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:Reflecting the government's concerns on these issues, the Executive Director representing Australia at the Bank will continue to maintain a stringent oversight of Bank loans and encourage the Bank to take a more active role in evaluating the impact of its operations in these areas.

PARA.TAB: The Treasury will continue to seek comments on environmental aspects of projects proposed for World Bank financing from the Environment Protection Agency and, through the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, non-government organisations. These comments will continue to be passed to Australia's Executive Director at the Bank.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 21:The committee recommends that Australia strongly press the Bank and the Fund to strengthen advice given during loan negotiations to take greater account of poverty, population growth, land redistribution and the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:In the long run, both the World Bank and the Fund contribute to ameliorating social inequalities by fostering sustainable growth. Additionally, they now incorporate measures in adjustment programs which seek to protect the interests of the most vulnerable during the adjustment period. Beyond this provision of "safety nets" in respect of adjustment lending, the Bank implements programs with a specific poverty or environmental focus and, as a matter of general policy, has moved in recent years to make the alleviation of poverty and environmental concerns more central to its operations. The Bank's assistance for population activities has also increased in recent years. Members of the IMF/World Bank Development Committee in April 1994 recognised that the Bank's policy dialogue and wide operations give it a unique opportunity to promote population policies. The government endorses the committee's recommendation in the context of the Fund's and the Bank's ongoing relations, including in loan negotiations, with developing countries.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 22:The committee recommends that Australia urge the Bank and Fund to give greater priority to the implementation and supervision of projects and to evaluate the effectiveness of their loans.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The Fund is not a project lender and this recommendation is more relevant to the activities of the Bank. However, the government endorses the view that the Fund should be encouraged to evaluate the effectiveness of its activities and it will continue to pursue this matter with the Fund.

PARA.TAB: As regards the Bank, aid effectiveness was discussed at the Development Committee's meeting in October 1994 in Madrid at the request of the Australian government. The committee in its Communique of that meeting endorsed a series of guidelines for developing countries, donors and multilateral agencies to improve aid effectiveness.

The Bank is also implementing the recommendations of the Wapenhans Report which seeks improvement in a range of Bank operations including project design, implementation, supervision and evaluation; the central purpose being to improve the quality of the Bank's activities. The government strongly endorsed these measures and will continue to encourage the Bank to carry out its planned reforms in implementation and supervision of projects.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 23:The committee recommends that Australia support the proposal to establish an independent inspection panel to investigate complaints about adherence to the Bank's operating rules and procedures in relation to projects it supports. The committee further recommends that Australia should urge the Bank to make public panel recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:Australia supported the proposal to establish an Independent Inspection Panel. Under the Operating Procedures agreed by the Bank's Executive Board, the Panel's recommendations are made public together with the Bank's response to them after consideration by the Board.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 24:The committee recommends that Australia urge the Bank and Fund to make public their internal and external audits to enable effective scrutiny of their operations.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government notes that the Annual Reports of the Bank and Fund contain audit reports of independent accountants on the financial statements.

PARA.TAB: The government will monitor the adequacy of these audit reports and will urge the organisations to provide more comprehensive and transparent advice if necessary.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 25:The committee recommends that Australia support the new issue of special drawing rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:Special Drawing Rights (SDR) are an official reserve asset created at a time when global reserves were regarded as being inadequate and an impediment to economic growth. In April 1993 the Managing Director of the Fund proposed a new issue of special drawing rights. This proposal led to lengthy negotiations over a range of possible options for such an issue, either on a general or selective basis. At the IMF/World Bank Annual Meetings in Madrid in October 1994, the Treasurer stated that equity and fairness required that all members have an entitlement to Fund resources, and that an SDR allocation would be of assistance to many of the poorest developing countries as well as the countries in transition. He called on all members to work cooperatively together to try to bring about a satisfactory resolution and indicated that he could support a small general allocation to all members under the existing Articles as well as a special allocation to those members that had not participated in previous allocations.

PARA.TAB: However, agreement was not reached at that time or by the time when this response was prepared.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 26:The committee recommends that Australia take more initiative in the development of Bank and Fund policies so as to increase the effectiveness of the institutions in stimulating growth of employment, equity and environmental responsibility in all member countries.

Response:The government endorses the efforts by the Fund and Bank aimed at increasing their effectiveness in addressing these important issues. It will continue to examine closely Fund/Bank policy and practices with a view to improving further their effectiveness.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 27:The committee recommends that Australia's Executive Director open discussion within the Board that the Bank be permitted to raise funds in international capital markets beyond a limit set by its funded and contingent capital and as a multiple of that capital base.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:Each year, the Bank's borrowing levels are examined in the context of the Bank's prudential policies which, themselves, are subject to regular review. The government endorses the view that the Bank should make the best possible use of its borrowing capacity against its capital and reserves, in a manner consistent with maintenance of a sound prudential framework.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 28:

The committee recommends that there be more public exposure and discussion of the operation of the Bank and Fund through the establishment of a permanent working group (IDC) to monitor Bank and Fund activities and to brief the relevant departments, non government organisations (NGOs) and the Parliament. This IDC should take the form of an Advisory Council on International Development comprising Treasury, DFAT, AIDAB, academics and NGOs

SPEECH.PARA: Response:There is already established a regular meeting of high-level officials' from Treasury, DFAT, and AusAID, following suggestions from an earlier committee. This is supplemented by formal and informal inter-departmental discussions. There are also regular meetings between departments and NGOs, including debriefing meetings following Fund/Bank meetings.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the government established in 1993, an Advisory Council on Aid Policy to facilitate dialogue between the government and the Australian community on the objectives and the direction of Australia's overseas aid program. The Council is chaired by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs and is drawn from a broad cross-section of Australian society, including business, non-government organisations and the media.
Given the arrangements currently in place, the government is not convinced of the need for the establishment of another advisory group on international development.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 29:The committee recommends that our Executive Director press for wider contact between the Bank, Fund, and Australian non government organisations and academics through regular information seminars.

Response:The government will encourage the Executive Directors to continue to facilitate such contact, while noting that the Fund and Bank staff already regularly brief academics, parliamentarians and NGOs both here and in Washington.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 30:
The committee recommends that our Executive Director press for greater availability of Bank and Fund documentation to Members of Parliament

SPEECH.PARA: Response:Material, such as the Fund's World Economic Outlook, Annual Reports of the Fund and Bank, staff research and occasional discussion papers are available publicly and available to the Parliamentary library.

PARA.TAB: The Bank announced on 26 August 1993 the adoption of a new information disclosure policy which has substantially increased the range of information available to parliamentarians and members of the public. The government will continue to monitor the effectiveness of these arrangements.

As noted in the response to Recommendation 2, the government is supportive of efforts by the Fund to expand the amount of information it releases while not impeding the ability of national authorities and the Fund to hold confidential discussions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 31:The committee recommends that information on Australia's voting patterns on Bank and Fund decisions be included in the Treasurer's annual report to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:It is rare for votes to be taken in the Bank and Fund Executive Boards, although during the year there are a number of resolutions submitted to Governors for formal vote. The Treasurer's Annual Reports to Parliament on both the Bank and Fund contain an account of the major resolutions voted on by the Treasurer as Governor, together with Australia's position on major policy issues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 32:The committee recommends that the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate write to the Presiding Officers of the Parliaments of the countries which at present supply the Executive Directors of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank inviting them to attend a preliminary meeting in Washington to establish an inter-parliamentary assembly to monitor the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank and that they invite the Secretariat of the Interim and Development Committees to provide the conference secretariat for that meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: Response:The government is sympathetic to the objective of establishing arrangements whereby the Fund and the Bank can better inform parliamentarians about their development activities.

PARA.TAB: The President of the Senate, the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the former Treasurer, the Hon John Dawkins, wrote to the World Bank and the Fund regarding the establishment of an inter-parliamentary assembly. The organisations indicated their readiness to cooperate and to meet with any such assembly.

Subsequently, the first meeting of this group was held in Washington in November 1994 and was attended by 22 parliamentarians from 17 countries. Mr John Langmore MP attended for Australia. It is intended that the meeting continue as an annual event under the title the "International Group of Parliamentarians Involved in the Oversight of the IMF and World Bank".

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that in this government response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund it acknowledges there have been criticisms of certain projects and programs. It indicated that some projects and programs have been less than they might have been. The response states:

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is also important to note that the outcomes of programs assisted by the Fund and Bank depend not only on the terms of assistance agreed by the organisations with governments, but on the effectiveness of implementation by those governments.
The organisations are important to Australia for their support of sustainable economic growth and outward looking economic policies, globally and within Asia and the Pacific.
Page 2 of the document also states:
A significant proportion of Australia's total aid expenditure goes to the World Bank.
It points out that in 1994-95, the figure was 11 per cent. It notes:

Since the Committee reported, the Government has agreed to contribute $A30 million, over an extended period beginning 1997-98, to subsidise the provision of funds for structural adjustment programs to the poorest countries on highly concessional terms by the IMF, through the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility.

It is very important that we look at this. The joint committee observed that a number of submittees to it were concerned that many of the structural adjustment programs were having a deleterious effect on the poorest of the poor. This is one thing that has concerned me, quite frankly, about structural adjustment programs. It is not only the absolutist economic rationalist approach that is sometimes taken by some people in these organisations; it is also the fact that the cost burden and the taxation burden are unduly weighted on the poorest of the poor, either indirectly, through increased costs of commodities—basic commodities such as food, clothing, shelter and so on—or in regard to the taxation system itself.

PARA.TAB: I raise this because the structural adjustment programs and policies that are developed by the World Bank are also adopted by the Asian Development Bank. Honourable senators will recall that we have paid $69 million to the structural adjustment program, the ADB program, for Papua New Guinea. The question is: what will be the outcome of those structural adjustment policies? In respect of direct taxation, this can only be imposed on land, labour and capital. The structural adjustment programs appear to be unwilling to target capital. I suppose in one way that is probably understandable because capital is a moving target. People who do have the capital can go offshore. But more attention should be given to that.

Yes, they will tax labour, but mainly pay as you earn. That is one of the reasons why there is a drop in earnings in a number of these situations, particularly amongst the pay as you earn workers. Those who are able to so manipulate the results of their labour, as it were, are again a moving target.

Apart from those two aspects, there is only one other to be considered, that is, land. In my view the structural adjustment programs do not deal effectively with taxation on land. I was speaking recently to a person who was very much involved in the area of international banking who happens to live in Manila. When I raised it with that person he said, `Yes, I do live in a fairly up-market suburb of Manila and we pay a pittance in taxation on land.' Many of the politicians in that country also live in this particular area.

I do believe that is one area that is very much neglected, because in developing countries, as in developed countries, the people with the money—leaving aside the farmers for a minute, Senator Boswell, before you jump in—have got the land, particularly the high value land in the metropolitan areas. Indirect taxes do not present a moving target. They are can be imposed, but they are imposed unequally on the poor.

One of my concerns also is that many of the people in these international organisations tend to blame the victim and say, `There are too many of them. Put the money into developing anti-HCG, RU486 and those sorts of abortifacient drugs. That will settle the problem.' It is the Third World women who are suffering under these particular programs.

They suggest that these research programs are done by WHO. You might hear that in a debate coming up. But, in fact, it is done by HRP, the human reproduction program, which is funded largely by the World Bank, the UNDP and the United Nations Population Fund. The executive agency is the WHO, but the funding and the focus is that of the World Bank and of the population controllers.

I believe we should be more concerned about looking at whether or not the structural adjustment programs are assisting the poor out of their tragic poverty in developing countries. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
