DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Human Services and Health: Commonwealth Disability Strategy

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force Veterans' Residences Trust

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Pursuant to resolution of the Senate of 13 February 1991, I present the following government documents which were presented to Acting Deputy President Colston after the Senate adjourned last night:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Department of Human Services and Health: Commonwealth Disability Strategy—First Progress Report.
Royal Australian Air Force Veterans' Residences Trust—Annual Report 1994-95.
In accordance with the terms of the resolution, the publication of the documents was authorised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer particularly to the Department of Human Services and Health: Commonwealth Disability Strategy—First Progress Report 1995. You will recall that the Commonwealth Disability Consultative Council was asked to report on the implementation of the Commonwealth disability strategy which resulted from the passage of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992.

PARA.TAB: My sole reason for standing is to draw attention to the report. It was to report on the progress that the Commonwealth has made in the implementation of the act in its own instrumentalities. This resulted because of Senator Patterson's attention to the detail at the time when the act came in. We discovered during estimates that, with all the fanfare that went on in relation to this act—and we certainly support the act—the major deficiency was the employment of disabled people within the Commonwealth government's own departments. Out of that came the appointment of the consultative council.

This report is only reporting on the first year of the 10-year program, but I think it is important to bring to the Senate's attention the categories of the overall results as reported in this first progress report. They are: significant progress made, 14 per cent; some progress made, 35 per cent; no progress reported, 38 per cent; no response to item, 13 per cent. It is sort of damning with faint praise. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The employment of people with a disability in the Australian Public Service is steadily improving.
Considering the base it came from, it has to improve. Further on the report states:
Very few departments provided useful information on the consultation process in the disability field and most did not report progress in this area.
I merely want to report that to the Senate and acquaint senators with the very slow progress that is occurring in this regard.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 13 of 1995-96: Financial Statements Audits—Results of the 1994-95 Financial Statements Audits of the Commonwealth Entities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This Audit Office audit of the results of the 1994-95 financial statements audits of Commonwealth entities covers, as the title indicates, the whole range of Commonwealth reporting. It is useful because you get a view of a trend—and, fortunately, it is an improving trend—in financial accounting by Commonwealth entities. For example, this report indicates that inadequate accounts and records resulted in audit qualifications in only three Commonwealth entities. Nonetheless, more than 1,500 recommendations were made to management across a fair range of matters.

PARA.TAB: The report notes that the incidence of qualified audit reports issued has continued to decline, and in 1994-95 represents only about four per cent of all audit reports issued. Nonetheless, there are some matters that concern me, in particular the summary of risk assessments in this document. The comfortable feeling I got when reading the summary of the report about how things were improving disappeared a little. For example, in the Department of Defence it is evident that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department has developed fraud control measures which require modifications to meet current organizational requirements.
If they need modification, I hope the government will do something about them because the Auditor-General, in the detailed part of this report, indicates:
The Department has advised that the existing Fraud Control Plan is of limited relevance because of continuing organizational and structural change.
Significant matters reported to the Department for prompt attention—
that is, by the audit office—
included management and accounting for assets, inventories and employee entitlements and recording of guarantees and undertakings.
This is of some substance, because the department has in-service inventories valued in excess of $3.6 billion, all of which are recorded on manual systems.

PARA.TAB: The other department that concerned me—I can deal only briefly with each department—was the Department of Human Services and Health. It was reported:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department was in the process of finalising a comprehensive risk assessment.

After all this time, one wonders why it is in only the process of doing it and why in fact it has not actually done it. The risk of fraud is enormous. One would hope that this Auditor's report will encourage the department to proceed at pace with this. I will deal shortly with the Department of Human Services and Health in relation to another audit report, so I will not go on about it now.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the Australian Customs Service, the Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: Risk management activities, while critical to its achievement of revenue collection goals, have not had a clear strategic and corporate focus despite the contributions made within the agency.
This is a serious matter because the Australian Customs Service has an annual activity base estimated at $24 billion. The Auditor-General notes:
The current version of the Fraud Control Plan was devised in 1993 and is due for review.
But even under that plan there was `no assessment made of the risks to revenue of the export of goods out of Australia'. It continues:

Diversion into home consumption or substitution of transhipped or underbond goods reported to ACS as being intended for export could potentially have a significant revenue loss effect. The ANAO considers that ACS has not properly assessed the risks that the export of goods in these categories poses to the revenue.
In relation to areas of revenue forgone, the Auditor-General concludes:
In relation to passenger motor vehicle manufacturing and textile clothing and footwear concessions, risk management processes were in need of review.
Another matter of concern within the Customs Service was:

The ANAO noted improvements in password controls in 1994-95. However, weaknesses were still apparent in respect of control over utility programs which have the capability of overriding or bypassing system security features. In addition, utility programs were not being properly controlled across a number of systems. ACS advised of remedial procedures which were designed to overcome the security concerns noted.

We all know about the significance and the consequences of people breaking into allegedly secure computer systems. It is of major concern to find that these systems of the Australian Customs Service, where, as I said, something like $24 billion of revenue is involved, are capable, apparently, of significant improvement before they can be seen to be as safe as they should be. The Auditor-General says:
These procedures will ensure that access to powerful utility programs will only be provided under supervision in emergency situations.

Another of the bodies that I must say I was concerned about when I read the summary of this report was ATSIC, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It seemed to me the Auditor-General was dropping the ball a bit, unusually. All he said in this section was:
The Commission indicated a strong awareness of the need to manage risks.

That looks like weasel words for saying they do not have a system. I would have hoped that a stronger position might have been taken, particularly when we look at the text of the report and find that in 1994-95 ATSIC's operating expenses were $951 million, its operating revenue was $37 million and the Commonwealth forked out $940 million. It is a lot of bickies. Look at how badly some of it seems to be administered, according to the Auditor-General. For example, in relation to the community development employment program, CDEP, the Auditor-General says:

Reviews undertaken at regional offices identified a high number of instances where supporting documentation for new participants could not be located. This lack of supporting documentation raised doubts as to whether all payments made by the Commission in relation to CDEP were in respect of eligible participants.

It is absolutely essential that you should know whether the people you are paying money to are the people you are supposed to be paying money to. That seemed a very soft way in which the Auditor-General dealt with this matter at the beginning of this report. On the issue of grant acquittals, the Auditor-General says this of ATSIC:

Although some improvement was noted in relation to the acquittal of 1993-94 grants, excessive delays in the provision of adequate acquittal documentation by many grantee organisation remains a problem. The Commission has engaged a consultant to investigate the acquittal process and a report on the results of this investigation is expected shortly.
I have asked several questions in Senate estimates hearings about this matter of acquittal, and I am still awaiting appropriate responses. These matters are of some concern.

PARA.TAB: I turn to a different department: the Australian Taxation Office. I must say I would have expected everything to be Simon Pure in relation to this department. The Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: Risk management strategies were soundly based and aligned with corporate objectives.
But then the report went on to say:
Accountability for risk management practices and reporting on taxation revenue will require ongoing review.
Once again, that seems to me like the sorts of words you use when the system is not good enough—that is, if you are being very friendly and do not want to say that the system is not good enough.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Auditor-General for the report. It is most useful material and once again continues the Australian National Audit Office's outstanding record of providing the parliament with the information which it should have. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report No. 14 of 1995-96—Performance Audit—The Sale of CSL—Commonwealth Blood Product Funding and Regulation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is also an interesting audit report. It is a shame that former Senator John Coulter is not here to deal with it because he had great concerns about some matters relating to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratory and its sale. I am particularly concerned about some elements of it, and I want to deal with them here.

PARA.TAB: First of all, I should mention the sorts of problems the Auditor-General mentions. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Insufficient information was available to the ANAO to determine whether the issue of indemnities to CSL—
by the Commonwealth government—
outweighed the financial and supply risks that the Commonwealth would have been exposed to if other options had been pursued.
He says:
There was no quantitative assessment of the potential liability of the Commonwealth for product indemnities provided to CSL pre-or-post sale.
He said:
DHSH did not provide a documented briefing to the then Minister before committing to the PFA—
that is, the plasma fractionation agreement—
. . . Public reporting of the outcome of the CSL sale was provided in press releases and commentary in Annual Reports of the DoF and the DHSH.
I agree with the Auditor-General when he says:
For improved accountability reasons, the ANAO considers that the outcomes of major asset sales should be timely and comprehensively reported—
one would hope to the parliament—
including the financial outcomes and full details of any ongoing Commonwealth commitments.

I say `Hear, hear' to all that. I know the government has not been too good at bringing its asset sales to completion. It keeps making huge alleged contributions to its budget from asset sales, but they rarely seem to turn up. This is one that actually did turn up, but we find that they have made a bit of a mess of it. There is a most extraordinary situation involved here which I would like to deal with. The audit report states:

. . . CSL was indemnified by the Commonwealth against claims by persons who become HIV-positive or contract an AIDS-related condition or hepatitis through the use of a CSL plasma or diagnostic product sourced from Australian blood or plasma and manufactured during the terms of the PFA and DPA.

PARA.TAB: Indemnities provided to CSL raise accountability issues, given the potential risk of future calls on Commonwealth budgets. The ANAO was advised that Cabinet did not specifically consider, nor was it formally advised of, the nature and scale of indemnities provided to CSL under the agreements signed in December 1993. DHSH advised the ANAO that:

SPEECH.PARA: Cabinet was aware of the indemnity issues when it took the decision to sell CSL. Comments provided by the Department of Finance and the Treasury and in recommendations/findings of the consultant to DHSH (contained in an attachment to the Cabinet Memorandum), raised the matter of the provision of Commonwealth indemnities.

PARA.TAB: The ANAO considers that it would have been much more judicious to have fully briefed the DHSH Minister on the specific details of the agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: The report goes on:
DHSH advised the ANAO that:

Hansard statements by the then Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health . . . (Dr Theophanous) indicate that the Executive Government was aware of the indemnities issue—
they were aware of the indemnities issue, but not the specifics of the indemnities—

In Dr Theophanous' case, he expressly supported the provision of indemnities by reading into the Hansard of 27 October 1993 the terms of a letter to CSL from the Departmental Deputy Secretary. Senator Richardson also raised the issue of indemnities in correspondence with Mr Peter Costello MP concerning the Commonwealth's position on the provision of an indemnity to CSL on CJD-related claims.
That is a major problem and one that former Senator Coulter raised in this place. The department went on to say:
The events referred to above occurred well before the execution of the plasma fractionation and diagnostics agreement.
The Auditor-General expresses this further concern:

PARA.TAB: The ANAO noted a number of unique features concerning the indemnities which highlight the need for appropriate accountability processes. First, the size of CSL's exposure to legal claims is unknown.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a contingent liability in the budget which may be huge—who knows. He goes on to state:

The DHSH 1993-94 Notes to the Financial Statements state in relation to contingent liabilities that the Department was involved in 201 cases covering a wide range of litigation, including cases relating to the supply by CSL of blood products which were allegedly contaminated by the HIV/AIDS virus and relation to Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD). DHSH was unable to put a value on the quantum of damages arising from these days.

PARA.TAB: The ANAO found that DHSH did not commission any actuarial studies to quantify the potential liability of the Commonwealth for product indemnities pre or post sale.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that there are a lot of problems. The department did mention, for example, that the nature of the claims involve medical conditions which may not show up for a prolonged period and may involve future generations. In any event, the government has agreed that there should be a settlement of all Australian HIV/AIDS claims. That decision has been made for reasons of public policy although CSL has not been found negligent in any of the actions which have proceeded to court. However, what is the cost of all this? The report states:

PARA.TAB: The cost to the Commonwealth for HIV/AIDS claims between 1989-90 and 1994-95 amounted to $28.6 million. The Commonwealth agreed to contribute to these costs provided that it was consulted and agreed to the settlement or defence of each claim and that each claim was individually assessed for its legal validity. There have been no reports of the transmission of AIDS-related conditions through blood products since the introduction of viral inactivation steps in 1984. Claims in respect of hepatitis are possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The report states further:

PARA.TAB: The ANAO considers that the Commonwealth could have been better protected through the utilisation of economic incentives on CSL to adopt quality and safety measures above mandatory standards, as CSL will bear the full costs. If the status quo position is maintained, the Commonwealth may potentially bear the costs of litigation arising from any shortcomings in current processes.

SPEECH.PARA: Finance says that it is in CSL's best interests not to let that happen. I found this report into the sale of CSL and this question of indemnities to be very important. This certainly should provide a lesson to other Commonwealth bodies that are being sold off. When the coalition is in government we will examine very closely the implications of this report when we come to implement an asset sales program which is to be run competently and effectively and as indicated rather than in the chaotic style employed by this government.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: PRESIDENT'S REPORT TO THE SENATE ON GOVERNMENT RESPONSES OUTSTANDING TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS
PREFACE

PROCTEXT.PARA: This document continues the practice of presenting to the Senate twice each year a schedule listing Government responses to Senate and joint committee reports as well as responses which remain outstanding.

The practice of presenting this schedule to the Senate follows the undertaking by successive governments to respond to parliamentary committee reports in timely fashion. On 26 May 1978 the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Withers) informed the Senate that within six months of the tabling of a committee report, the responsible Minister would make a statement in the Parliament outlining the action the Government proposed to take in relation to the report. The period for responses was reduced from six months to three months in 1983 by the incoming government. The Leader of the Government in the Senate announced this change on 24 August 1983. The method of response continued to be by way of statement. Subsequently the Government has advised that responses to committee reports will be made by letter to a committee chairman, with the letter being tabled in the Senate at the earliest opportunity. The date of the presentation of the Government's response to the Senate has been taken as the date that the response is presented, not the date of any correspondence with the committee. Senate legislation committees are often required to
report on the provisions of bills. Only those reports this category that make recommendations and therefore require a response are listed in the schedule.

The schedule does not usually include reports of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works or the Senate Standing Committees on Appropriations and Staffing, Selection of Bills, Procedure, Publications, Regulations and Ordinances and Scrutiny of Bills, though such reports will be included if they require a response. Government responses to reports of the Public Works Committee are normally reflected in motions for the approval of works after the relevant report has been presented and considered. Responses to reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are usually made in the form of Finance Minutes which are tabled by the committee. Where a response has been made by way of Finance Minute, the date of presentation has been appropriately annotated.

SPEECH.PARA: STATEMENT BY THE PRIME MINISTER, THE HON P.J. KEATING, MP
THE FUTURE OF OUR FORESTS
30 NOVEMBER 1995
Mr Speaker, I seek leave of the House to make a Statement on forest policy.

Mr Speaker, today I announce the Government's broad policy direction on Australia's forests and forest industries. I am also announcing several related initiatives vital to the future of our native forests and the industries which depend upon them. Full details of these measures will be released tomorrow by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, and the Minister for Resources.

Mr Speaker, Australia's forests are a defining feature of our landscape, a priceless element of our environment and heritage, a national resource of immeasurable proportions—and a profound national responsibility.
All Australians have a stake in these forests. All of us have a responsibility to insist that they are properly managed and carefully conserved.
They are a national treasure and their management must be ecologically sustainable and economically clever.

Our native forests are of inestimable conservation value. They are vital repositories of biological diversity—indeed, new species of plants and animals are still being discovered. They are a haven for endangered species. They are vitally important as water catchments, they influence our climate and act as carbon sinks to limit the greenhouse effect.

Just as importantly they are places of unique and unrivalled beauty. They are aesthetically and spiritually important to us. They are important to our sense of belonging to this land. Our respect for and enjoyment of them is part of our communion with Australia.
Mr Speaker, the national interest quite simply demands that we protect our forests.
This same national interest also demands that we use the forests intelligently for the things we need and for the communities that live with them.
Our forests have economic significance. They are an important renewable resource, contributing to the wealth of the nation, and providing us with essential commodities.
Many Australians, and many Australian communities, depend on our native forests for their livelihoods. Whatever we decide are our priorities, their interests must be attended to.

This perception of an irresolvable conflict between the environmental and commercial values of forests has produced deep divisions in the Australian community. The debate presents itself as a conflict between absolutes: the absolute necessity to protect these priceless parts of our environment, and the absolute necessity to protect Australia's economic interests and the well-being of Australian working men and women.

The conflict is easily understood. No Australians want to see these forests destroyed or damaged beyond repair. Nor do they wish to see the economic interests of Australia damaged or the livelihoods of their fellow Australians threatened.
We on the Government side number ourselves among these Australians.

No policy is going to satisfy everyone. Neither side of this debate can expect to get everything they want. The aim is to see that Australia is the winner, that the Australians of the next century are the winners. In the end, the essential goal is the protection of the long term national interest.
Mr Speaker, it is towards this goal that the Government has steered a course.

Our cause will be greatly advanced if, on both sides, the debate is conducted with the national interest in mind. We should all remember that no-one in this conflict has a monopoly on truth or virtue, or a mortgage on concern for the future of our forests. Those who presume they do and claim it exclusively will only debilitate the efforts of people of good will to find the best solutions.
We recognise that this is a debate which will of its nature arouse great passions. But, equally the solutions and the path to them cannot be other than rational.
We will not find solutions without cool thinking and a genuine desire to find common ground and a degree of shared good will.

Mr Speaker, if the task of devising a national forest policy which meets community expectations is made difficult by polarised opinion and emotion, it is made even more complex by the fact that, under our Constitution, the States have the primary responsibility for land management, including the management of our forests.

Many in the Australian community expect the Commonwealth to take more responsibility for Australia's forests than the Commonwealth has the ability to take. It is expected of the Federal Government that we develop an effective national policy, yet the Federal Government does not effectively have the power to do so. What powers we do have can never deliver the long term changes we are seeking—to the reserves, to sustainable management and to the industry—without the States.

The recourse to the Commonwealth Government underlines the failure of interest groups to secure the appropriate undertakings from those who do manage forests in Australia and that, of course, is the State governments.

In lieu of actual powers, the Government has taken the lead in developing with the States a cooperative approach to managing and protecting our forests. This policy has depended upon the States recognising that there is a national interest to be served, and success in the long run will in large part depend upon the States continuing to recognise this.

Mr Speaker, we started on this difficult journey towards a common approach to forest management with the development of the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, to which all State and Territory Governments are now signatories.
This was itself no easy matter—and some parties have only more recently joined.
Embodied in that Statement are the shared economic, social and environmental objectives which all governments have made a commitment to achieving.

Through the National Forest Policy Statement, the Commonwealth and the States agreed to the ecologically sustainable management of Australia's forests. Realising that we did not know enough about our forests, the Statement provided the basis for thorough, cooperative assessments of their values, leading ultimately to the concept of Regional Forest Agreements with the States. These Agreements offer the real possibility of a long term framework for the protection and management of these important national assets.
As an idea it is probably unique in the developed world.

The Policy provides for the development of a National Forest Reserve System, which would ensure the protection of high conservation value areas required to maintain biodiversity, old growth and wilderness values.
Earlier this year, the Commonwealth through a panel of scientists, developed a set of criteria for determining which areas should become a part of this system. They include;
a broad benchmark of 15 per cent of the pre-European distribution of each forest type to be protected within the reserve system.
retention in reserves of at least 60 per cent of existing old growth, increasing up to 100 per cent wherever practicable for rare old growth
and
protection of 90 per cent or more wherever practicable, or areas of high quality wilderness
These criteria are recognised as at the leading edge in world terms.

But, Mr Speaker, before we can arrive at a position from which we can negotiate Regional Forest Agreements and, through them, a comprehensive, adequate and representative National Forest Reserve System, we must put in place interim protection measures for forests which might be required as components of such a reserve system.
The device we are using for this is a Deferred Forest Area or DFA process.

The Deferred Forest Areas process has been designed to provide the appropriate degree of interim protection needed for the longer term RFAs. It is not meant to be the last word on which areas would be logged and which would be turned over to forest reserves. Rather, it was meant to provide an essential building block on the way to Regional Forest Agreements. The decisions to be announced tomorrow therefore, are but the first step in a longer, more rigorous process. But for the forests, a giant step.

For most of this year, the Commonwealth has been negotiating with New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, and Western Australia to identify forest areas to be protected pending further assessment in the development of Regional Forest Agreements.

In cooperation with these Governments, the Commonwealth has recently concluded a very extensive consultation process in which interested individuals and groups have had their say in an open and transparent process. Through their contribution they have been able to influence the outcome and, I am pleased to say, our Deferred Forest Areas are the better for it. At the same time, I believe, these consultations have underlined the fact that the policy approach we have chosen is undoubtedly the right one.

Through the Deferred Forest Areas process, we have delivered a positive and I stress immediate outcome for all Australians who have a stake in our forests—which is to say, albeit to varying degrees, every Australian.
As a first step, the decisions we have taken this week offer sound conservation outcomes as well as predictability for our forest industry.
We have taken a precautionary approach, so as to ensure that future reservation options are kept open.
Cabinet has agreed on the areas of state forest to be deferred. Detailed maps of these areas will be released tomorrow.
Our objective has been to ensure that options for establishing the reserve system, based on criteria developed by the Commonwealth are not foreclosed while longer term assessments are conducted.
Mr Speaker, I am confident that we have achieved this objective.

In the next few weeks, the Commonwealth expects to sign Deferred Forest Agreements with the States I have mentioned. I will be writing to the Premiers later today inviting them to enter these Agreements.

I have on a number of occasions talked about creating in Australia a forest reserve system the equal of any in the world. With the signing of these agreements, we will have taken a huge step towards this objective.
Mr Speaker, the management of those parts of the forest estate outside the reserve system is just as important as the reserves themselves.
The Government is committed to ensuring that the management of these areas, some of which will be available for harvesting, is truly sustainable.
As part of the longer term process, we will be joining with the States in a thorough review of forest management and codes of practice.

Our aim is to ensure that the full range of values we attach to our forests are maintained in perpetuity. We must adopt the view that these precious assets are held in trust for the future, they are not ours to neglect or degrade.
The forests industry should be a model of ecologically sustainable development. Our objective is to ensure that it is.
Mr Speaker, the annual turnover of Australia's wood and paper industry based on native forests and plantations, is in the order of $10 billion, or about one per cent of Gross Domestic Product.
The Government believes it is imperative to have a viable wood and wood products industry.
Investments of between $4 billion and $6 billion are at present under consideration. Industry and unions predict between 15,000 and 25,000 potential new jobs over the next decade.

The associated Wood and Paper Industry Strategy also to be released tomorrow sets out the Government's long term vision for this industry. It is the Government's aim to transform it—to make it both internationally competitive and ecologically sustainable.

As part of this transformation, we will encouraging increased investment in value-adding processes for wood and wood pulp, and give priority in issuing woodchip export licences to applicants who invest in domestic processing. We are determined to sharply improve domestic value-adding of residues currently being exported as unprocessed woodchips. We will, through this industry, expand job opportunities in regional Australia.
We will clear the way for value-adding to forest residues by the release of strict environmental standards for Bleached Eucalypt Kraft pulpmills.
And through Regional Forest Agreements to be developed with State Governments, we will provide industry with increased assurance about resource supply and greater regulatory certainty.
We will continue to remove duplication in environmental impact assessment processes at the Federal and State levels and reduce administrative and compliance costs.
Through AusIndustry, we will provide additional funding for enterprise development to firms in the wood and paper industries, and so promote best practice and competitive efficiency.
We will provide additional assistance to small and medium firms in the wood and paper industry who are seeking to move into new markets or upgrade existing facilities.
And through the Wood and Paper Industry Council, we will develop industry sector approaches to investment and improved import replacement and export performance.
Underlying all of these initiatives is a fundamental commitment to sustainable job growth and opportunities for Australian workers.

Mr Speaker, while the Government is committed to the long-term sustainability and prosperity of the native forest based industry, special recognition will also be given to the increasingly important role of plantations and farm forestry.

These sectors represent the best sources for future growth in the wood and paper industry. Plantations already supply a significant proportion of our total wood and paper products and major value-adding investment proposals are currently under consideration.

In 1995, the industry set a target of trebling the current plantation resource by 2020. The Government supports and welcomes this initiative. It will act to remove impediments to plantation establishment and establish a policy environment which will help industry to realise this target.

Mr Speaker, every effort has been made to minimise necessary disruption to the timber industry arising from the Deferred Forest Areas process. State Governments have been asked to re-schedule logging operations away from deferred areas. However, the Government recognises that in some cases re-scheduling may not be possible and that logging operations will be affected.

Accordingly, the Wood and Paper Industries Strategy contains details of a generous Structural Adjustment Package which will provide financial and other assistance, including retraining, to proprietors and workers in the timber industry, those detrimentally affected by the Deferred Forest Areas process.
Mr Speaker, we are especially conscious of the disruptive effect on some operators and communities of these changes. We will do all that we can reasonably do to help.

Mr Speaker, let me turn to the vexed question of the woodchip export licences. Applications for woodchip exports for this year were about nine million tonnes. However, as indicated last year the Government wants to reduce the amount of wood exported in this unprocessed form. The Government has therefore decided on a much lower volume for this year which will be 5.25 million tonnes. This amount is a fair and consistent down payment on that objective.

Licences will be issued for 80 per cent of that volume. The remaining 20 per cent will only be available in regions where there has been significant progress towards Regional Forest Agreements with State Governments.
Details of this year's ceiling will be announced tomorrow by the Minister for Resources.
The Government has made a commitment to phasing out woodchips exports by the year 2000 from areas not covered by Regional Forest Agreements.
We remain committed to diverting these exports into further domestic value-adding. The industry is on notice that unless we get the progress and the agreements, woodchip exports will be phased out.
Those on the extremes of the debate—in the timber industry and among their more uncompromising opponents—should understand that the Government will not waver from this course or these decisions.

Mr Speaker, no Australian government has ever made such a conscientious attempt to resolve this huge and vexed issue. Most governments would run a million miles from it. We have been at pains to strike the right balance; to find the means by which environmental and economic necessities can be reconciled in the national interest; the means by which a profitable industry and prosperous communities can be reconciled with our responsibility to preserve a unique and magnificent part of our natural heritage for our children and the Australians of the 21 century and beyond.

Mr Speaker, it can be done. This statement demonstrates that driving an intelligent course can reap substantial and permanent benefits for both sides of the debate and for the nation—more substantial and more permanent than any we might derive from pursuing one direction to the exclusion of the interests of the others.

The moral comfort of extreme and certain positions may be warming to those who hold them, but they do not confront the real moral challenge, to deliver real, worthwhile, lasting and democratic solutions. Ones that everyone can respect.
Mr Speaker, no-one should be under the illusion that with these decisions the difficulties and sensitivities surrounding the issue will disappear. Of course, they won't.

But I hope the process will decidedly help to create a more cooperative and analytical environment. An environment in which the common goal of the protection and renewal of our forests can be achieved with a forest products industry that has a future based on sustainability and ecological decency.

Mr Speaker, this statement will bring us much much closer to ecologically sustainable management of our great forests. And, with it, much closer to meeting our responsibilities to the Australians of the next century and thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had today the tabling in the House of Representatives of a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on forests. It was very difficult to fix a time when this government was going to make its final statement. Senators will notice how the deadlines have constantly changed. Earlier in the week we were told that the statement was going to be made on Friday then we had the Prime Minister make the statement today. The previous week we were told that the statement was going to be made on Monday. We can see in this area, like so many other areas of government policy, considerable policy confusion.
—You have some responsibility for this.
—Why don't you listen for a change? It was quite interesting—
—What are you going to do? We are waiting to hear your policy.

—What we had, of course, was what you purported to be your policy that was brought down today. What we got was another vacuous statement from the Prime Minister. As Mr Howard pointed out in the other place, I thought so effectively, the difficult decisions in the forest area have been, as we always see with the Labor Party, flicked past the election.

PARA.TAB: How nice it was to hear Mr Keating complaining about the volume of woodchip exports from this country. Mr Keating expressed in his speech great concern about the volume of woodchip exports, but the reality is that Mr Keating is the champion woodchip exporter. If you pull out the figures, you find that no other government in Australian history has had policies which have effectively created and allowed such an extensive volume of woodchip exports. Most Australians, of course, would far rather see more of these woodchip exports processed on their own shores and value added here in Australia.

It is intriguing that for some 13 years this government has held the levers in office. You would have thought that after 13 years we would have had a clear forest policy—a policy which gave Australians the confidence that there was a world-class reserve system being protected and gave the forest industry the confidence that they had a sustainable timber resource available to them to ensure security of supplies. But we had neither. So, after 13 years in government, they are still grappling around to create a policy so that most Australians can have confidence that their high conservation value forest has been protected and the timber industry can have confidence that they will have continuing supplies. And we did not get it today from the Prime Minister.

I have counted up and it seems to me that since last December we have had seven statements on the forest industry—seven statements from the Prime Minister and his ministers on the forest industry. I think all of us were hoping that maybe we were moving to a position where there would be greater certainty, where people would have confidence that at last some progress was being made. I think that is why Mr Keating's statement today was so disappointing, so vacuous, so full of general comments.

When we get down to looking at the specifics there is even some doubt. Mr Keating in his statement said that the volume of woodchips would be cut this year. I checked with the forest industry, and their advice was that the volume of woodchips specified by Mr Keating in his statement for next year, of licences to be issued, is the same as the volume of woodchips which are being exported this year. So why not stand behind what you are doing? Why pretend to the public that you are doing something when, in fact, a most cursory look at the figures and a check with appropriate authorities shows that you are not doing it? I do not know who happens to advise Mr Keating on these matters, but I have to tell you that I think there will be considerable concern in the Australian community about the pretence that Mr Keating has put over this paper.

What we needed above all from Mr Keating was some truth and frankness. No-one doubts in relation to forest policy issues that there are some difficult choices which have to be made and there are difficult balances which have to be achieved. No-one pretends that it is easy, but is it as hard as the Labor government has made it over 13 years? We have had, of course, occasional outbursts of peace in our time. In 1988 we had an MOU signed with the Tasmanian government, which Senator Sherry will remember, which was meant to deliver peace in our forests. In 1992, Senator Sherry, we had the national forest policy statement signed by all states, with the exception of Tasmania, which has since signed on. Again, that was meant to lead to a settlement in the forest industry. Today, of course, we have had another statement.

It is a self-evident truth that the great growth in the forest industry and the potential we have will largely come through farm forestry and plantations, yet the rate of plantation establishment in this country is amazingly low compared with other countries. Mr Keating and his advisers would have known this for a long period of time, so the problem is: why haven't we had the plantation establishment in this country that we are seeing, for example, in countries like New Zealand? One reason is that no-one has any confidence in any long-term policy in this country under a Labor government.

Labor has made the problem worse by its own politics. It has seen over the years that it can use the forests to divide people, so the debate has become hugely politicised. As I said earlier in my remarks, it was always going to be difficult because choices and balances have to be struck. Once you get out and you politicise it the way your Prime Minister has done it, no wonder it becomes even more difficult. So when things get too hot, you then try to pull it all back. But the trouble is, Senator Sherry, that your Labor Party in its approach, as I said, has so politicised the issue that the problem becomes immensely difficult.

We were hoping today to get a very clear sign from Mr Keating on the general policy approach, which we hoped would lead to greater certainty in the industry, greater certainty amongst the conservationists and then the timber interests. I do not think we got that from the policy statement today. So the debate, unfortunately, will perhaps not go to a lower level, but will continue as people continue to look through the Prime Minister's statement, read between the lines and try to interpret just what he is trying to say. Mr Howard made an extensive reply to Mr Keating's speech in the House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —No policy, though!

—I invite Senator Sherry to read it very carefully. Senator Sherry, I think Mr Howard not only told a few truths about the nature of forest policy under your government but clearly outlined the direction in which a Howard government will be taking forest policy.

PARA.TAB: I point out to you that this was to be an important statement today. It was clearly a very rushed statement. Mr Keating was clearly worried. He wanted to attempt to end his day in parliament—perhaps the last day that this parliament will meet before the election—on a high note. Regrettably, as so often in the past, Mr Keating has once again failed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) today, all I can say is: let's hope the detail is a little bit better than today's statement leads us to expect. I begin with one point made by Senator Kemp—that woodchip volumes are not going to be decreased. Indeed, it looks as if it is the same as ever, onwards and onwards.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp raised another point, about why we are dragging the chain in regard to the number of plantations that we should be seeing in this country. I would suggest it is because this government continues to prop up our industry in the native forests. Of course, people are not going to invest in plantations, despite the fact that they grow far more quickly and are far more efficient, and it does mean that they are not as valuable as they should be because of the undercutting of their products by products that come out of our native forests.

Having listened to the Prime Minister's speech I can say that none of the Democrats' worries has been relieved in any way. We are still more than a little concerned that it will basically be the status quo with a little bit of trimming around the edges. It has not quelled our fears. While there were a lot of nice media grabs and very short, succinct statements, I do not think many in the conservation movement are going to be at all pleased with what has been said and what has been seen so far.

Yes, the Prime Minister did talk about things like biodiversity, a national reserve system, restructuring of the industry and retention of high quality wilderness and old growth forests. But, of course, there was a qualifier, and this time the qualifier is, as the Prime Minister said, `where practicable'. Until we see the maps and see what precisely the government is talking about it is very difficult for us here to comment on whether we have any solutions in the long-term to those difficult problems.

Surely here in Australia—a first world country and a very wealthy country, where most people are at least reasonably well off—we can protect our forests. Surely it is completely practicable and morally correct. As far as workers' jobs are concerned, the real long-term jobs are in places like Mount Gambier in my home state. The forestry industry there is well and truly established.

It has been proven that most of the sawlogs in this country are indeed already coming from plantation wood and that countries overseas are better at utilising trees grown from seed exported from here—our eucalyptus in plantations—than we have been. It has been proven over and over that the native forest sector is declining, that its debts are increasing and that the economics of plantations mean their use will inevitably eclipse native forests. Even with all the subsidies we have for native forests, the industry there has a limited life. An area I know very well is East Gippsland where the significant amount of remaining rain forests is largely outside any existing reserve system. Are we going to continue chipping and cutting our native forests to the point where there is simply none of that remaining?

We agree with a number of the statements that the Prime Minister made relating to how imperative it is and how important it is that we have good pulp and paper industry strategies here. Indeed, that is why the Democrats have personally now given the Prime Minister two copies of our wood products industry policy. But still we see no move on the part of the government to seriously support the plantation industry.

The Government is also looking at value adding, and indeed it does far more value adding than the native forest industry does now. The Democrats are not convinced of the need to continue to export woodchips. It makes no economic sense and it certainly makes no ecological sense when we can see what is happening with our plantation timbers. They are already value adding, and value adding significantly.

At present the financial status of the industry is not healthy. Consulting economist Francis Grey has identified 23 types of effective subsidies going to the native forest industry. This includes low royalties, state government subsidies, possible tax exemptions and loopholes, road building, various infrastructure supports, port facilities, forestry commission support, non-payment of monitoring fees et cetera. There are accusations of rorts and inefficiencies. Penalties are very rare, I know from visits to both East Gippsland and the wombat forest recently. There, penalties are virtually non-existent despite blatant breaches of licence requirements.

A recent report released by Dr Andrew Dragun, senior lecturer in law, economics and public policy at La Trobe University, found that the Victorian government spent $90 million on logging of the native forests for a return of $40 million. In other words, the Victorian taxpayer subsidised the industry to the tune of $50 million a year. Dr Dragun goes on to say that a reasonable estimate of the annual subsidy when all costs are taken into account could well be in the order of $385 million. So really, as he said, it is a form of a social welfare payment.

The combined debts of the forestry commissions across Australia are now over $5 billion. Some of those debts are welcome because they are actually helping to establish plantations. I point out the successes in my home state. It is only South Australia that has very little debt, and I argue that that is because we source 90 per cent of our sawlogs from softwood plantations.

According to John Dargavel from the ANU and statistics from the ABS and the census of population and housing, jobs in the wood and wood products industry have declined by 20,000 over the last 20 years. At the same time, there has been a substantial increase in wood production, showing that forestry protection has not resulted in declining production or employment. While some sections of the industry claim up to 80,000 people are employed, according to the 1991-92 ABS manufacturing and establishments data—the latest figures available—employment in the logging, saw-milling and pulp and paper manufacturing sections is approximately 35,000. Of this, only 613 were employed in woodchip plants.

The national forest policy statement was supported by a wide cross-section of the forest industry. It was also signed by the state governments across Australia—with the exception initially of Tasmania, but they have since agreed—and it contains a recognition of conservation values. It contains this quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Until the assessments are completed, forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

Senator Faulkner last year recommended that 1,300 coupes from those areas were likely to have old growth or wilderness value and should be investigated. The Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) set aside only 85 of these areas. It was only after significant public outcry that this was eventually increased by 509, which comprises approximately five per cent of the 1995 concession area.

PARA.TAB: The national forest policy statement also demonstrated the intention to put in place a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system by 1995. It appears there have been no areas reserved under this scheme so far. Indeed, it will not be until we see some of the details tomorrow that we are really able to comment on that area at all.

Surely it makes good economic sense to keep our native forests intact. Not only do they provide habitat, including for endangered species, but also they hold the soil together, provide organic matter and are used for ecotourism. Indeed they are crucial to the water catchment.

Here again I move to far East Gippsland. I hope, when we see the maps tomorrow and the detail, included will be the Betka river catchment area, which is the only water supply for the township of Mallacoota. If that is not included, then there is severe risk not only to the long-term population of Mallacoota but also to the tourism industry there. There have been a number of Christmas seasons already where water has run dangerously low. If we have the catchment area logged—it has already started to be logged—then we can see up to a 50 per cent reduction. Scientific tests have already been done to show that a considerable reduction in water volume is likely, as well as some major question marks over water quality.

A hectare of old growth mountain ash clear-felled may produce $270 of woodchips on a one-off basis. A generation later it may produce half as much because the regrowth, if anyone has had a look at what happens to these forests after they are logged, is very sparse. According to Read, Sturgess and Associates consulting economists commissioned by the Victorian government, if that same hectare is left unlogged it produces more than $6,000 worth of water year after year.

In the few moments left to me I will just briefly again touch on the softwood market and the plantation industry. The market for softwoods is steadily increasing, while the use of woods sourced from native forests has been declining. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to the government for allowing this debate to continue and for giving up its time for us to respond to the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I actually felt that his statement was full of fine words. I did not quite agree with Senator Kemp that it was vacuous. On looking further at it, I realised that in a sense his assessment was closer to the truth than mine; because, essentially, the government has once again gazumped the coalition over a major policy initiative. The ALP has implemented an industry focused forest plan. Forest protection has just lost out; so, in that sense, it is rhetoric and it is vacuous. It was very fine and moving. I can imagine the office of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) contributing to the first half of the speech and the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) to the second half.

PARA.TAB: As to what will be the outcome, clearly I am afraid that the plan the forest industry has before it will entrench woodchipping and be the phasing out of our old-growth and high conservation value forests, rather than being what all in the Australian community hoped for: that there be a genuine phase-out of woodchipping from our native forests, particularly those of high conservation value. Once again, just like the other rational economic agenda items of enterprise bargaining, privatisation, superannuation and international trade liberalisation, the ALP has stolen the conservative agenda out from underneath the coalition.

We are indebted to Mr Howard for pointing out that the reduction of the woodchip exports, over which the Prime Minister shed crocodile tears, was not such a substantial reduction at all. So we are indebted to the coalition for at least observing that the government is not following its rhetoric with actions that would ensure the protection of our precious forest heritage. This is a disastrous result for both forest protection and the long-term interests of the industry and workers. Many will say that this is just the ongoing rhetoric of the Greens and the environment movement. But we keep saying it because the forests keep getting trashed. Nothing ever changes—just the rhetoric.

I do not agree entirely with Senator Meg Lees when she says that this is the status quo. I think in one sense it entrenches the status quo, which is that our forests are being chipped at enormous rates and are slowly disappearing; they will never be the same again. Regrowth is not the same as an old growth or a high conservation value forest. It becomes a monoculture; the diversity is lost.

A 15 per cent reserve system based on a comprehensive, adequate, representative basis will not save the precious values that the community is asking the government to protect and show the necessary political will towards. What it does reveal is that the national forest policy, which it implements one step further, has always been and still is an unsatisfactory strategy. It always has been—and now we can see it—about entrenching woodchipping. It does not protect those precious values that the community sees being shipped out on enormous trucks. We see these great big logs going to the sawmill in the south-west of Western Australia, and we see the piles of woodchips at the Bunbury port. We also see it in other parts of Australia. People are horrified. It is a sacrilege to be doing it.

There is no talk in the Prime Minister's statement of stopping woodchipping. All the talk is about entrenching woodchipping and just removing it from export to downstream processing within the country. That still ensures the utter disappearance of our high conservation value forests. We see, basically, that there are no restrictions on plantation based woodchipping. This just sets up the plantation industry to experience, in 10 years time, exactly the same problems that the native forest timber industry is experiencing now.There are very minimal reductions, as I have said, in the woodchip quotas for next year, while opening it up to open slather woodchipping after the regional forest agreements are in place.

There is another thing we should note today: Mr Keating has done a Pontius Pilate; he has washed his hands, once and for all, of the federal responsibility to intervene and protect the precious values of our native forests. He has abrogated that responsibility to the states. Not only that, but he did a mean thing in the sense that he blamed the conservation movement for not being able to bring the states around to see the need for protection from logging. He first blamed the conservation movement for not being able to negotiate with the states. Then he said that the federal government was not prepared to use its powers to overrule the wrong things that the states were doing and that the environment movement should have been able to stop the states from doing.

What is more, Mr Keating is entrenching by the process called regional forest agreements that the states be given the authority, from now on, to approve the woodchip licences. That is a tragedy of mammoth proportions. It is one which is slowly dawning on those who are listening closely, beyond the rhetoric of the Prime Minister's statement.

The Greens are dismayed but not surprised with this being a bad decision; it has been the child of a bad process. There has been a forest auction going on—and, once again, it is the forests and our future that have missed out. Basically, the forests, which should have been our future, really have become the now of the wood products industry; that is what they have become. The government has shown today, beyond any doubt, that the national forest agreement is about entrenching woodchipping in Australia and not about the protection of our magnificent forests.

The way the government should have acted was reflected in the private senator's bill that I presented earlier this week. Our bill was a benchmark and a starting point. It is a way of assessing what the Commonwealth is prepared to do in terms of its genuine commitment for the forests. It should include the clear powers of the Commonwealth; instead of letting them go, they should be used.

The government has moved away from all three components of our bill. The first was a phase-out of woodchip exports; they would cease by the year 1998. In fact, our quotas were a four million tonne limit on export licences in 1996, two million in 1997, and then 1 January 1998 there would be a nil export of woodchips.

Another component was that protection from logging apply immediately on woodchipping of forests with old-growth values, wilderness values, world heritage and national estate or interim register of national estate areas, rainforest or areas containing endangered species, as specified under state and federal laws.

The government has not committed itself to a substantial reduction of export woodchipping. It has simply said that it will allow the states to keep doing it at the same level it is now occurring. It has not protected properly the qualities of the areas for which protection has been asked by the community. Also, its industry strategy is simply an industry strategy; it is not a transition strategy to assist those workers who will be genuinely disadvantaged if there were to be an act of political will to save high conservation value forests.

There is no doubt that there is a need for a transition strategy; there is no doubt that there are people who will require that assistance. But they will not require it on the basis of the statement which has now been put out by the Prime Minister. I think that is why the minister for environment has rejected the term `transition' when we talk about a transition strategy.

The way the government could have acted, as I said, was set out in our bill. It has failed to do that. What it is doing will not solve the problems. Its smooth rhetoric will do little to reassure the community at large who have clearly shown where they stand: they do not want our precious old-growth forests turned into woodchips. The government stands condemned. They cannot be surprised when the consequences of their actions come home to roost.

The Keating government has told us that it has been working at finding a solution for forests for the last 12 months and has spent thousands of dollars in the process. Indeed, a solution is at hand. But this government needs to take firm hold of the Native Forest Protection Bill as a model in one hand and Dr Judy Clarke's plantations study in the other. Only then will the government find a foothold on the first step out of the current bureaucratic morass to genuinely protect the last remaining old-growth forests, once and for all. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Reynolds, I present the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies, entitled Regulation of Computer On-line Services—Part 2, together with submissions and the Hansard record of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the tabling notes incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The notes read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGIES
REPORT ON THE REGULATION OF COMPUTER ON-LINE SERVICES—PART 2, NOVEMBER 1995
TABLING STATEMENT BY SENATOR MARGARET REYNOLDS, CHAIRPERSON

The report I am tabling today is the Committee's second report on the issue of the regulation of computer on-line services. Since holding an earlier inquiry in April 1995 the Committee has invited submissions in relation to the adequacy of current measures to control access by children to obscene, offensive or otherwise undesirable material through computer on-line services.

The Committee received 37 informative submissions, which contained some 450 pages of evidence. Public hearings were held in Canberra in September and Sydney in October where the opportunity was taken to clarify many of the issues raised in the submissions.

What the Committee found was that material which would be refused classification in any other medium, such as in publications, films and computer games, can be found on-line. The Committee heard of there being depictions on-line of child pornography and bestiality which are banned imports into Australia under customs controls and are refused classification if presented to the Office of Film and Literature Classification. Witnesses stressed to the Committee that such material represents only a very small part of the total volume of material available on-line. However, the Committee takes the view that in the maintenance and protection of community standards action should be taken to ensure that otherwise refused or restricted material should not be available to children on-line.

Accordingly the Committee has recommended that it should be an offence to use a computer service to transmit, obtain possession of, demonstrate, advertise or request the transmission of material equivalent to the "Refused Classification" category.

The Committee also gave consideration to the issue of children gaining access on-line to material equivalent to the "R" and "X" categories to which their access is restricted in other media. It is a feature of many on-line services that, once connected, all information is available to all customers in the same way that, once broadcast, all television is accessible to all viewers. The Committee has given consideration to the likely effectiveness of on-line controls on children's access to restricted material based on its observations in the past of the fallibility of similar controls in the provision of audiotex and pay TV services. The Committee has concluded that the main control is prohibition at source and it has recommended accordingly.

The Committee noted that while regulation of material sourced within Australia can be subjected to Australian law, such on-line services as the Internet are of such a global nature that their regulation in Australia is necessarily limited by jurisdictional constraints. Unlike publications, films and computer games, which can be deemed to be "prohibited imports" at the Customs barrier, the contents of on-line services sourced from overseas cannot be vetted in any practical sense. Australian providers of access to such services were concerned, however, that they should not be held liable for the content of the material they are transmitting when they have no responsibility for its authorship.

The network operators and service providers in the 0055 audiotex industry had put similar arguments to the Committee in 1991 and 1992. On that occasion the Committee had acknowledged the legitimacy of their argument in principle, but had seen as an important part of their role the imposition of appropriate content standards on their "authors" through their contractual arrangements. These provisions would then be subject to enforcement action.

The Committee has made similar recommendations in relation to on-line services. It has called for the establishment of an industry-based body to adjudicate on claims of breach of content standards and, through the contractual arrangements between network operators, access providers, service providers and clients, impose realistic sanctions. The Committee has also called upon the Australian Government to pursue at appropriate international forums the concept of classification at source of all material placed on-line, based on an agreed set of classification standards.

The Committee believes that, in its recommendations, it has given the industry a sound regulatory environment in which its most positive features can flourish while appropriate attention is paid to the areas of greatest concern.

The Committee also recognises that the march of technology is placing in doubt traditional approaches to content regulation. With the likelihood of continuing globalisation of information and entertainment services in the future, through such technologies as satellite and broadband, the consumer of the future may have to take much greater responsibility for their choices. It is then the Government's responsibility to ensure that the consumer is suitably empowered to make informed decisions. To this end the Committee proposes to sponsor a conference of experts to examine how a program of widespread public education and debate might be fostered.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present report No. 29 of 1995 relating to the proposed York Park North office construction, Barton, ACT; the redevelopment of the Hinkler site, Barton, ACT; and the redevelopment of the Woolshed site, Barton, ACT. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for the discussion has expired.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report which I have just tabled concerns the proposed construction by Australian Estate Management of three office blocks in the Canberra suburb of Barton at a cost of $118.109 million. A majority of the committee has recommended that the redevelopment of the Hinkler Building site to provide a new headquarters for the Australian Federal Police should proceed at a cost of $39.158 million dollars. A majority of the committee has also recommended that alternative options for the location of the Department of Industrial Relations, including Civic, be examined. Details of this examination should be provided to the committee for further consideration.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the proposed development of York Park North, it has recommended that an office complex for the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories be developed at either the Tuggeranong or Gungahlin town centres. Details of the preferred site and proposed design should be provided to the committee for further consideration.

For the committee this was one of the most difficult inquiries of the year—we have had 25 this year—made even more difficult by the amount of interest it generated in the ACT by various groups and people. What also made it more difficult was the amount of lobbying that all members of the committee were subjected to.

The original proposal was for three office blocks to be located within the Barton area of the ACT. The committee has rejected two of these proposals for a number of reasons—the appropriateness of office buildings in this area and difficulties concerning the Canberra plan. One strong argument put to the committee was that moving a large number of public servants from Civic would result in Civic being devastated. The majority of the committee does not accept this view, especially considering that 10 years ago the fear was that Civic would be overpopulated and the government decided that once public servants moved out their place would not be taken by other public servants. This is now regarded as the `conventional wisdom' in Canberra.

In response to a question from the committee to the National Capital Planning Authority, we were advised by them that backfilling of vacated offices is permitted. The committee emphasises that there is no ban on public servants backfilling vacated offices. However, the committee is concerned at the combined impact of these three projects on Civic, while not sharing the rather alarmist views expressed by some witnesses.

The proposal of the Department of Industrial Relations on what is known as the Woolshed site has been rejected by the committee. The committee believes better use could be made of this land and the proposed car park structure would be inappropriate and not in keeping with the national significance of the Barton area. The committee is of the view that the proposal should not proceed on the Woolshed site and that Australian Estate Management should seek another site, preferably in Civic, to house the Department of Industrial Relations. A Civic location would partially meet the objections to the loss of personnel from Civic outlined by many groups, including the ACT government. The committee expects to be fully briefed on the new proposal for the Department of Industrial Relations.

The committee considers that the AFP has put up the most persuasive case for a Barton location. A majority of the committee believes the AFP proposal should proceed as planned on the Hinkler site. However, in coming to this conclusion, the committee regards it as regrettable that it will be necessary—this is something that disturbed me—to demolish the George Knowles building, which was refurbished only three years ago at a cost of some $2 million. That is one of the reasons why we have a minority report.

The third proposal concerns a new office building for the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. The committee does not see the need for this building to be in Barton and recommends that this building be placed in either Tuggeranong or Gungahlin, with an emphasis on Tuggeranong.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about Adelaide?
—Hobart would be okay. I cannot see any reason why not. They could get a bit of swimming practice in every night when they go home.

PARA.TAB: The committee is conscious of the need for dispersed work opportunities in Canberra and is also concerned at parking limitations and traffic pressure in Barton. The committee was surprised at the evident lack of coordination between the National Capital Planning Authority and the ACT Planning Authority which was displayed in these projects. That is the reason why in the final report there is a brief dissenting report by myself, Neil Andrew MP, Ray Braithwaite MP and Bob Halverson OBE, MP, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: These proposals should be deferred for the following reasons:
Because of the undue haste that these proposals were presented to the Committee by AEM
Because of the absence of any long-term planning for the future use of the Parliamentary Triangle and Barton
In view of the pending elections which may alter priorities of the Government of the 38th Parliament
In view of the fact that two of these proposals will require referral back to the Public Works Committee of the 38th Parliament.

We were placed under a considerable amount of pressure. I do not remember the committee having three important buildings included in one project before. If they had come as individual projects and we had had time, I think perhaps we may have been able to give it better consideration.

PARA.TAB: One of my major concerns—and it is shared by a lot of others—is the effect that three large buildings like these and the number of people in them will have on traffic flows in the Barton area, given the fact that in recent times we built the new DFAT building. I do not know how many people it will house. At a cost of over $180 million, it must house a large number. The Motor Traders building is also in the area. It must be evident to all of us who travel to the house on the hill that there is a fair amount of development going on in the Barton area.

We had evidence from the ACT government that they did not know whether they could provide the infrastructure there. There are two planning authorities in Canberra. I could never see the sense of that. We had a lot of evidence that there did not seem to be a plan for the whole precinct. One of the recommendations in the report is that a decent plan be organised for Canberra so that when similar matters come up in future we will know the effect that the movement of 1,400 public servants from one area such as Civic to another area such as Barton will have on that area. That was a major concern.

My colleague Senator Reid wishes to speak on this matter, so I will not continue for much longer. We are concerned about this matter. I do not know why there was this undue haste. The committee was quite happy to look at it again next year. The committee staff worked through the night so that this report could be presented to the parliament today. I do not know why there was this haste. Nevertheless, that is where we are at. I have presented this report to the Senate. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am responding to the report tabled this afternoon by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works relating to the proposed York Park North office construction in Barton, the redevelopment of the Hinkler site in Barton and the redevelopment of the woolshed site in Barton. As Senator Calvert indicated, the report was supported by a majority of the committee. There is also a minority report to which he has referred and which I urge the Senate to adopt. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate:
(a)rejects the committee's recommendation that the proposed redevelopment of the Hinkler Building site, Barton, ACT, should proceed; and

(b) rejects any proposal for construction of public works at Barton for eventual use by hundreds of public servants transferring from existing offices in Civic, until the Joint Federal/ACT Metropolitan Canberra Growth Strategy Review has completed its inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Calvert's final point, which was not the point I had intended to start with, was that the committee had no information before them of the impact on traffic movement in the area, with the bringing in of this enormous number of public servants, in addition to the ones coming in to the York Park development, which is nearly completed and will be occupied quite soon.

PARA.TAB: I shall go through the report and make several comments on it. It is an absolute mystery to me how this report could be before the parliament this afternoon when it quite clearly has been done in an enormous rush.
