I attended for part of both days of the hearings. One member of the committee commented that there were more people there than he had ever seen at a Public Works Committee meeting. Senator Calvert endorsed that. Many submissions were presented. Many matters which were raised before the committee have not been answered by the committee.

The question is: who is pushing this project? Presumably it is one or other of the ministers in the House of Representatives. Mr Walker is the minister in charge of Estate Management. Mr Kerr is the minister in charge of the Federal Police. I do not know whether they have been lobbying the committee.

From every indication over the last couple of weeks there was an expectation that more work needed to be done and more consideration needed to be given to this matter. Whiz bang, here it is this afternoon, to go ahead immediately! Is it the pea and thimble trick? `There are three buildings; we will see which one gets approved.' It is a bit hard to say whether that is the case.
Looking at the report in more detail, in paragraph 20 it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The lease for the headquarters building is due to expire in August 1998.

My understanding is that it was due to expire in 1997 but that a year's extension had been granted. But that is not the end of the lease. There are two further periods of five years each—that is, 10 years—which could be added to it. It is only five years since it was fitted out.

PARA.TAB: The significance of this building, which is presently occupied by the AFP, is that it is in Northbourne Avenue. It is a prime site in Civic. Once vacated, it is very likely that it will stay empty for a considerable period. That would be a matter of concern for the landlords. The important point is the impact on Civic of having that building, which is next to a small garden and which is in a central part of Civic and an important part of Northbourne Avenue, vacant when there is no need for it to be vacant and when there has been no consideration of the total impact on Civic. In addition, there are spaces which are already empty and other movements out of Civic which are to take place.

On page 9 of the report the committee refers to the issues that came before it: the need for the works, the cost of the works, wider planning issues, impact on infrastructure at Barton, impact on Civic and other issues. I do not believe the committee has adequately considered all these issues.
The report states that some ACT federal members of parliament expressed concern. Let me say that three out of four ACT federal members of parliament expressed concern about these proposals.

The committee recognised the concerns expressed during its inquiry regarding planning policies in the ACT. They seemed to ignore that by going ahead as they have in this piecemeal fashion. The committee noted that the Commonwealth and ACT governments have announced a joint review of urban planning. Let us wait at least for that report. Mr Howe, in conjunction with the Chief Minister of the ACT, instigated that review. We should not be rushing ahead with these things. They have announced that this committee is to review planning. I believe we ought to have the benefit of that information before we proceed.
At paragraph 40 the committee says:

SPEECH.PARA: However, this is an issue which for the longer term should be considered by the joint review referred to above.
They referred to the fact that these three projects take four per cent of the work force out of Civic. The report also says:
It became clear to the Committee that there is a general misconception that there is a ban on replacing Commonwealth staff moving from Civic.
The Committee was assured by the NCPA that no such ban exists.

That might have assured the committee, but it is not the popular perception which has been in existence for the last four years, since 1991 at least. That needs to be laid to rest and dealt with. It is the perception. The report also says:
. . . the Committee is concerned at the combined impact of these three projects on Civic
while not sharing the rather alarmists views expressed by some witnesses.
Why was there this rush to go ahead with it? The report also says:
The Committee also shares the concern expressed by the Master Builders Association (MBA) that the delivery method proposed by AEM will disadvantage the ACT construction industry.

The woolshed proposal, which is not going ahead, should have gone to the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories before it went to the Public Works Committee. But that did not happen either.

PARA.TAB: The dissenting report which Senator Calvert presented to the Senate refers to the undue haste with which the proposals were presented to the committee by AEM and other matters that ought to be taken note of by the parliament in saying, `Enough is enough. This does not go ahead at the present time.'

The key office users of space in Civic are the Commonwealth government, with 310,000 square metres; the ACT government, with 50,000 square metres; the private sector, with 90,000 square metres; a total of 450,000 square metres. As a result of these proposals, with AusAid and Defence moving out, 55,900 square metres of office space will be vacated, in addition to that which is already vacant in Civic. Another large building is under construction in Civic at present. There are no tenants for it. It will be a wasteland. This parliament is being asked to collude in that.

Civic is an important part of the parliamentary triangle and needs to be a significant part of the ACT. It needs to be in good order and it needs to be well housed with public servants. The impact if it is not is the degradation of the area. There will be a dramatic impact on Civic retailers and service providers. Car parks will be sitting there underutilised, plus the cost of putting car parking and other infrastructure into Barton.

Some will say that these are magic jobs in the construction industry. They will be in the construction industry, and that is important. If you look at the evidence given to the committee you will see that the construction industry was not saying, `Jobs, jobs, jobs. This must go ahead, no matter the cost to the rest of the community.' Everybody recognises that.

Already tenants in Civic have lowered rents to keep tenants there and there is a risk of institutional investment, not only in Civic but also in the ACT, being affected by this rash action. All I suggest is that the parliament defers going ahead with the project that is being recommended and the others as well until such time as the committee which Mr Howe has set up in conjunction with the ACT government has reported.

Mr Howe recognises that there is a significant impact on Civic from the action that his colleague ministers are seeking to take at the present time. He is seeking to do something about Civic and the general planning of Canberra, Gungahlin, Tuggeranong, Belconnen and even Woden as a consequence of what has occurred. I ask for the Senate's support for my amendment to the motion, that this project should be put on hold.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am not sure by which process we had this matter brought on at this time. I had no prior notice of it.
—It has been on the Red all day.

—Thank you for that. I worked that out. It is only by coincidence I happened to be in here when this matter came up about which I have a particular interest. It is a cause of some concern to me but it is a bit late to be worrying about that. We find ourselves with this amendment about which, as far as I know, the government had no notice, and it has significant implications that not very many people have had a chance to consider.

PARA.TAB: I understand we are getting towards the end of the session and people in the Senate are considering supporting it. I understand they have to make decisions quickly because that is the circumstance with which we find ourselves confronted. I am not sure that all the implications have been conveyed. Some implications have not been conveyed at all and some have not been conveyed accurately.

It is a complex matter, and there are competing priorities. There is a concern that there may be over development in Barton and that the infrastructure facilities in Barton are not adequate to cope with the addition of three extra buildings. That is what went to the Public Works Committee; it is not the recommendation we have before us. What we have before us is one building and it is essentially a redevelopment. We are not talking about a massive injection of a new number of public servants in Barton, although some.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not quite right. They are going to knock a building down and build a new one. That's not redevelopment.

—Read the words. It says `redevelopment'. That is what the recommendation says. I am referring to the recommendation. You might like to quibble about the English but I am simply saying, and you know, that the Hinkler building has had people in it before, so it is not entirely new but there will be an increased number. I accept that and I am not arguing that. I am simply saying that it is much less than what went to the committee, which was three buildings.

PARA.TAB: We have different recommendations with regard to the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories proposals. I am comfortable with the committee's recommendations with regard to both those options. I am not sure whether had I been on the committee that is exactly what I would have suggested, but I can see why they have done it and I am not uncomfortable about it. I can see some very positive elements about both of those sets of recommendations—that is, they are an attempt to balance the competing interests, but the amendment makes no attempt to balance the competing interests.

The competing interests are the concern about Civic, the concern about Barton, the concern about the decentralised development of Canberra, and the concern about jobs in the construction industry. That is the essence of the four elements. The committee has tried to balance those. It has got some continuation in the construction sector because of its recommendation about the Hinkler building redevelopment. It has some concern about the continuing strength of Civic by its recommendation about the DIR proposal. It has some recognition of the need for the continuing balanced development of Canberra, the disbursed development, because of its recommendation with regard to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories.
All the amendment does is say, `Let's stop.' The easiest thing to do is to say, `Let's not do anything' and pretend that there are no consequences of failing to do anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait.

—That's right—wait, which means don't do anything for a while. It is as if waiting has no consequences. What we have been working very hard to do in Canberra is, instead of getting a surge of construction, get a steady rolling program of construction. We have Russell, we have the redevelopment of the administrative building coming up next and this. These are very important. There is no doubt that the workers in the building industry, whose representatives I have discussed this with, regard this as a very important part of the continuing generation of jobs for building workers in this town and for those who supply to it and for all the ancillary economic activities that flow from construction.

PARA.TAB: The Public Works Committee recommendations already defer two of the three proposals. In an employment term, that is not ideal, but we do have to balance all the competing elements. The amendment makes no attempt to do that. It is an eloquent testimony to the influence of the building owners on the Liberal Party, but it does nothing about all the other significant issues that we need to confront.

As I say, I am not sure that what the committee recommends is what I would have done if I were on the committee, but it is a balanced proposal. It seeks to deal with the differing imperatives that it has on it and it is the only balanced proposal before us and it should be endorsed. It is a recommendation to the Senate. The Senate has the power to amend it in any way it chooses. If we reject this, it is not just an expression of view by the Senate; it has consequences and there are going to be people who would otherwise have jobs who will not have them because of a decision made in haste here.

I think that is something we should not do. The consequences of it will resonate beyond this Senate if we do do it because I will make sure of it. It is not the appropriate decision. I know, because they have been to see me, building owners in Civic are concerned about this. I understand their concern, but that is not the only interest we need to consider. It is an interest, not the only one.

I say to the Senate: do not blithely accept this—don't do it ignorant of its consequences; don't do it without taking into account the valid recommendations of the committee with regard to Civic, with regard to decentralisation into Tuggeranong or elsewhere and with regard to maintaining some momentum of development for the Hinkler building. For that reason, I oppose this precipitate and ill-considered amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We are now debating Senator Reid's amendment. I have had an enormous concern about the property development by the Commonwealth in Canberra for a number of years. I might say that concern goes back to the time when the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration had an inquiry into the Department of Finance and Trade—a reference to that committee successfully moved by Senator Robert Hill.

PARA.TAB: As part of our inquiry we had a meeting with the late Peter Wilenski and people from the Department of Finance and were shown the York Park proposal, which has become colloquially known as Gareth's gazebo.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gary's gazebo.

—Gary's gazebo, is it? Three years since construction commenced it is still not occupied, and on my advice it will not actually be occupied for another six months. When that project was but a set of plans and drawings at that meeting with Mr Wilenski, using my fading knowledge of property matters since I had been in that industry before I came into this place, I pointed out from the information provided to me that the building would not house the staff it was required to house; that because the York Park project was a maximum development of the site—in other words, the building took up the maximum allowable area on the site—there would be no room for any future expansion of that DFAT building, now known as Gareth's gazebo; and that, quite frankly, it was a poor proposal.

PARA.TAB: I understand from Senator Calvert, who is on the Public Works Committee, that that was the recommendation. I am a bit hazy on this, but I think a minority report was put on the York Park project. Senator Calvert is nodding. In the dying days of the last Keating government, just before the 1993 federal election in late 1992, cabinet got together and pushed it through and proceeded with the building of the building.

Senator Reid and Mr Acting Deputy President, we will not know what a disaster the York Park project is until people start moving into it. From the information I am getting back from little birdies that come to whisper to me about what is happening there, it is clear that the message I gave to Mr Wilenski and the people within DFAT who were pushing the York Park project back in 1992 is that it would be yet another unmitigated disaster of this Commonwealth government when it comes to building buildings.

We looked at the Casselden Place project in some detail; indeed, we had an Auditor-General's report into the Casselden Place building in Melbourne where this government proceeded to build over $200 million worth of building. The Auditor-General's report that was subsequently done after I raised the matters in this chamber time and again showed that this Commonwealth government had lost over $100 million on that one building in Melbourne. That was an enormous waste of taxpayers' money. As a consequence of that Casselden Place inquiry, Senator Spindler successfully moved a motion that there be an Auditor-General's inquiry into the Australian Estate Management Group, a business of DAS. I understand that that Auditor-General's inquiry has virtually concluded and is currently with AEM for comment. It will be tabled in this place early in the new year.

I know from my own investigations through estimates committees, and also through my experience on the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration when we did an inquiry entitled `Property management in the Australian Public Service', that AEM has a number of disasters on their hands. They have not performed well and the Commonwealth's management of its real estate assets is an international and national disgrace and disaster that is potentially costing the Australian people hundreds of millions of dollars. Hundreds of millions of dollars are being wasted by this organisation and the Commonwealth and the cabinet's poor decision making.

Quite frankly, the members of the Public Works Committee who try to keep a bit of a reign on this government's ad hoc decisions to build buildings around the place are up against AEM. They do a very good job, but they are up against it. When we get to the stage where this report is tabled in the Senate and Senator Reid, who understands the Canberra aspects of these decisions and the social and economic impacts of that because of her position representing the ACT in this place, you have to wonder what is the motivation of the cabinet and the Labor government about building a new building.

I say to the minister that you do not create balance in these decisions by putting up a proposal to build three buildings and then say, `Lets have some balance and compromise and only build one.' That is not a strategic, sensible way to go about making decisions to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in property.

I refer the minister to pages 12 and 13 of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee's report on property management in the Australian Public Service, which was tabled in this place in June 1995. I do not have time to read into the Hansard the pieces that I wanted to read, but I suggest to anyone who takes an interest in this decision and to all other senators that they focus on one thing. I will quote from the submission of the ACT Planning Authority, which is quoted in the report at paragraph 3.21. It talks about the data and the information that is available to both the National Capital Planning Authority and the ACT Planning Authority in relation to office accommodation rented by the Commonwealth in Canberra. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Until 1989, data were available on employment, floorspace and government/private occupancy from the National Capital Development Commission office inventory. This data base is now compiled and updated by the Building Owners and Managers Association, but it no longer includes type of occupancy.

The Department of Administrative Services produced an annual survey of Commonwealth office holdings by department, location, employment numbers and floorspace. The last year for which this information was obtained was 1988.
The Department of Finance publishes annual Australian Public Service employment by department, but this does not include location or floorspace.
Paragraph 3.22 says:

The ACTPA also pointed out that it is unclear `which Commonwealth authority is responsible for coordinating office accommodation and providing information about Commonwealth office accommodation needs and strategies to NCPA and ACTPA' and that it would welcome `liaison with the . . . agency responsible for Commonwealth government office accommodation in the ACT to obtain information about Commonwealth government office strategies, and data about employment and floorspace by location in the ACT.

I recommend that the minister, who is a senator for the ACT up until 30 June next year—up until the federal election—reads those two sections at page 13 of the report. I am sorry I had to read two fairly dry pieces of stuff into the Hansard. We have this great national capital. It is probably worth saying on St Andrew's Day to Senator Reid that prior to the national capital being here it was a very successful sheep station run by the Campbell family and, of course, it was resumed.

PARA.TAB: It is worth saying that in this quite magnificent national capital we do not have available any coordinated and strategic approach to the planning of the Commonwealth's office requirements in Canberra. That is an enormous problem. I say to the minister—this is why I am supporting Senator Reid's amendment to the motion so wholeheartedly—that we should wait to see what happens when the Auditor-General brings down his report on the AEM that has been ordered by this Senate. I may be incorrect, but he is bringing down a report on the AEM within a matter of weeks.

It is not a matter of putting off the decision because it is too hard. It is a matter of recognising that there is a lack of strategic approach and there are social and economic problems with this proposal. It is an irreversible mistake. When you put up a great big building like Gareth's gazebo or any major public office building, such as Casselden Place in your home town, you have made a mistake that is virtually irreversible. Once you have made the $100 million loss on Casselden Place, you cannot get the money back. You can forget about it and make it fade into history. If you build this building in Barton you have made an irreversible decision.

I say, firstly, lets develop a strategic approach to Commonwealth office requirements. Secondly, wait for the AEM report to see what it says about Canberra's office requirements and the Commonwealth government's actions and then address the problem of the accommodation for these agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The report of the Public Works Committee clearly indicates that they have not gone down one path. It is true that the committee does not run along a path that suggests that they accept every view the minister might have on developing buildings for accommodation for various government departments. We have over time been fairly clear in our views and suggested alternatives to those which the minister may have had at any given time. On this particular occasion we were not really happy with a couple of the projects. Indeed, the report suggests that they be given further consideration.

PARA.TAB: I guess the way in which you might suggest this matter should be proceeded with or handled depends on where you stand. It is very clear that those people who own office space in Civic want that office space to be kept full. They are concerned about people moving away and their profits declining or disappearing. There is nothing illegal or evil about that; it is a normal commercial position. But it does indicate, if you support that view, just where you stand on the matter, as distinctly against the view of the government that we should own our office buildings in which the departments are situated.

As I said earlier, the committee did look at this matter in a fair bit of detail and has come up with a proposition that we should have a purpose built building for the police in Barton. I think it is a good place to put it because it is in an area where there are a lot of other people who deal with legal matters. The placing of the building is geographically correct and it will provide the Federal Police with a very good building in which to work. They will have all the facilities they need so that they can produce a high standard of work.

I do not believe there is any need to put aside that proposition or to put it off while the other two projects are re-looked at. The committee said—and there was no objection to the proposition—that part of that reconsideration of the other two projects would be to look at the rental crisis in Civic. It was indicated to us that some of the rents being asked for that accommodation were on a level with the Bond building in Sydney which, I can assure you, most people would consider to be much more valuable for a tenant than a building in Civic.
I finish by saying I believe the committee gave full consideration to the matter. I think their proposition is meritorious and I think it should be carried intact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: a concern has been raised with me about whether we can amend this recommendation in this way at this time. The background that has so far been given to me is not adequate for me to make a judgment. At this stage I am not challenging it. I propose that we have a brief adjournment so that I can check this concern that has been raised with me. I suggest it be deferred till a later hour.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to complete the remarks I was making on this matter this morning. All I wish to say in conclusion is to thank the staff of the secretariat for the work they performed under what were trying circumstances over the last couple of days in getting such a voluminous report ready in time for presentation today. I thank the staff very much for their efforts.

—On behalf of the Australian Democrats I welcome this report of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney and its findings, with one notable exception which I will come to shortly. As the Senate will be aware, the committee was established following the opening of the third runway at Sydney's Kingsford Smith Airport and as a result in large part of an outraged community who feel their lives have been destroyed by altered air operations at KSA. I add for the record that it was only as a result of the combined efforts of the coalition and the Democrats in this chamber that the committee was ever established. I feel certain now that we were justified in our decision to have these matters referred to this parliamentary inquiry.

PARA.TAB: It was apparent from the outset of the committee's establishment that there would be a massive response to this inquiry. The community response in terms of submissions received was nothing short of remarkable, with the committee having received well over 5,000 submissions—an overwhelming number by any standard. One of the most interesting aspects of the inquiry was that for many noise affected Sydney residents it was the first opportunity they had had to tell their side of the story.

Having inundated the Federal Airports Corporation's noise complaints line, many Sydney residents were at the end of their tether when the committee announced this inquiry. They felt that until now no one had been listening to them or took any notice of what they had to say about how aircraft noise was destroying their lives. For many of them, this committee represented a release valve, an avenue through which they could finally be heard.

It is probably a sad reflection on our democracy that people have to resort to parliamentary committee inquiries in order to be heard, but what it certainly proves is the absolute failure of the environmental impact assessment process to adequately predict the impact which the new runway would have on residents.

On the subject of airport privatisation, it is a matter of some considerable regret to me that despite the overwhelming evidence presented to the committee against privatisation, a recommendation has been produced in favour of it. Under the circumstances I have dissented from this finding. I believe there is practically no international precedent for the private leasing of a nation's airports. Virtually all the major airports in comparable countries to Australia are publicly owned and operated and no consideration is being given to the private leasing option. The Democrats do not believe that private leasing would be in Australia's economic, social or environmental interests. There is well-founded apprehension in the community that under a private regime commercial objectives will overrule the public interest.

One of the worst features of the EIS process was the appalling way in which people appear to have been deliberately deceived and misled as to what the impact on them would be. This must never be allowed to happen again. The EIS on the third runway at KSA appears to have been nothing short of a sales and marketing job, with the aviation authorities failing totally in their duty to the public to ensure a decent standard of objectivity in assessing noise impacts. Aside from the obvious bias, the EIS seriously failed in the key indicators, such as airport moderating modes and taking into account basic factors such as long-term wind analysis.

A number of academics appearing before the committee confirmed the inadequate nature of the EIS. A matter of real concern was the fact that the EIS seems to have deliberately misrepresented and misused the available scientific literature. In light of these failures, the committee has made a series of recommendations in relation to the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek and the absolute necessity of conducting a proper and thorough EIS process in relation to that one.

Not surprisingly, quite a number of residents from western Sydney and local councils have expressed the concern that important environmental considerations were going to be overlooked in the same way as they were in relation to the third runway at KSA. It is essential that the government allay these concerns and ensure that the correct processes are adhered to in the development of Badgerys Creek if, indeed, that is to be the location of the second Sydney airport.

On the whole, I welcome and support the committee's recommendations, particularly those dealing with operational and remedial measures to be considered for implementation at KSA. Inevitably, much of the focus will be on the committee's recommendation that the new air space management plan be developed for KSA which examines the best way to use all three runways. It is my own view that the situation in which many residents of Sydney are now living is totally unacceptable in a civilised society. The people living under the concentrated flight path feel cheated and betrayed.

I think I am right when I say that no other senator on the committee lives under one of the flight paths. I do. I live under the east-west flight path. I believe the east-west runway should be reopened. In fact, it is my view that we should go back to where we were 18 months ago. It was safe then. We were only about six movements an hour under what we are now. We do not expect the new tower to open for some months.

I believe we should go back to where we were before the third runway was opened. We should go back to what was safe then and what was working then. There were only 55 movements an hour then. We should stop right there, work the airport at what it was working at for many months before then, and find another solution. That would mean opening the east-west runway again. That would mean that I would be living under it, yes. But it would also mean that those people who are living in hell, which is what they are doing, would not be living quite in hell any more. That is what I believe we should be doing.

I hope the community will take the opportunity over the next few weeks to have a look at all this and all the recommendations contained in the report, as well as all the evidence presented. In relation to the comments by Senator Forshaw which he attributed to the coalition about some coalition members wanting to hear evidence that the east-west runway should be fully utilised, yes, they did. Some government members were equally assiduous in searching for evidence that the government is doing the right thing and the current mode of operation should be maintained. Party political sensitivity was alive and well, and it was alive and well on both sides.

Having said that, I must also say that, under the circumstances, I was very impressed with the way members of the committee worked together. Any disagreements we had were polite and reasonable. I thank all members of the committee for that. Senator Parer was an excellent chairman. He was fair and reasonable. He was open to innovation, and we had a lot of innovation. We held hearings in the areas affected. We held hearings in places that I have never been to before. It was very interesting and it was something that we should be doing in more committees. It was a pleasure to work with him.

In conclusion, I would also like to record my sincere thanks to the secretariat of the committee. They worked very hard throughout this inquiry and they finally produced a thorough report in extremely tight deadlines. In particular, I would like to commend James Warmenhoven, the committee secretary. He is one of the most able and competent committee officers I have ever had the good fortune to work with over the years. Both James and Trish Carling, whom I have also known for a very long time, consistently displayed a remarkable level of patience under some very trying circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal Sen B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak to the report of the Senate Airport Noise in Sydney Select Committee. I have to say there was agreement on a number of things in the committee. There was agreement that the Kingsford Smith Airport is an essential part of the New South Wales infrastructure, that Kingsford Smith Airport is essential to the tourism industry and promotes employment in the region, and that the operations of the airport as a result of the noise and pollutants have made the quality of life for the residents around the airport less than it should be.

PARA.TAB: The major difference between the government and the opposition is that the government wants a solution and that really the opposition does not. The opposition sees the ill effects, the competing interests and the conflicts of different groups of residents as a political opportunity. The committee had a responsibility to find out what went wrong and to identify ways in which the process of planning and implementing major projects, such as the new runway, can be managed better in the future. This means both in the interests of good government and a safe and healthy community.

The majority report is marked not by objective assessment and analysis aimed at reaching a solution but by an attempt to ignite and exaggerate the difficulties and conflicts in the community. The opposition would have us believe that the difficulties arising from the conflicting interests between the airport operations and the surrounding communities only sprang up with the construction of the third runway and the reduced operations of the east-west runway. The truth is that the problem has existed since the construction of the airport.

By the 1970s and 1980s the airport was experiencing congestion problems. The curfew shoulder periods were introduced to try to resolve this issue in 1988. This was to meet the overwhelming demand on the use of the airport by both international flights bringing tourists and country domestic movements. About 17 million passengers were passing through Kingsford Smith each year and the airport just couldn't cope. The log jams were getting so bad that delays and flight cancellations were costing approximately $40 million, according to the industry.

The coalition during all their years in government did nothing about the adverse effects on residents surrounding the airport, nor did they try to resolve the congestion issue or to plan for their future. The Labor government's initiative to construct a new runway parallel to the existing north-south runway at Kingsford Smith and at the same time approving the development of the second major airport, Sydney West at Badgerys Creek, represented, in stark contrast, a fundamental approach to an extremely difficult issue. The two initiatives led to a significant increase in capacity and corresponding improvements in airport congestion. The improved capacity will go on to provide economic benefits for Sydney, New South Wales and Australia at large.

The coalition advocated the new runway prior to its construction and clearly understood that a reduction in the use of the east-west was part of the new operations. Its change of policy position came about since the public response and it saw there was a political opportunity. John Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, has been particularly hypocritical in his position. In evidence to the inquiry on 25 July 1995, the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: If you are putting to me whether I knew that the contemplation in 1989 was that there would be the downgrading of the use of the east-west, the answer to that question is yes. I have never denied that.

John Howard was a most enthusiastic and active proponent of the third runway. He supported the third runway and was fully aware of the planned reduction in the use of the east-west runway. There is no record in Hansard of John Howard ever raising the issue of aircraft noise as a problem prior to the new runway being opened in November 1994.

PARA.TAB: The EIS document at the very outset also repeated the conditions regarding the downgrading of the east-west runway as outlined in the joint statement of 22 March 1998. Not only did the opposition not criticise the original proposal to downgrade the use of the east-west runway but they are on record as recognising that the construction of the third runway would lead to a reduction in the number of residents affected by aircraft noise. Charles Blunt, who was in 1989 the federal opposition spokesman for transport, gave a fairly lengthy statement in regard to that, which I will not repeat because of time constraints.

The overwhelming evidence to the committee from all expert agencies, such as the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia, is that restoring the east-west runway to full cross-runway operations would either reduce safety standards or the rate of aircraft movements, or create a substantial additional noise burden on surrounding residents. We just cannot take the risk.

The majority of the committee also gives recognition to the difficulties by backing away from their original draft recommendation where they bluntly call for the reopening and extended use of the east-west runway. In fact, they replaced it with, frankly, fairly much of a nothing recommendation that runs roughly:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the Minister for Transport direct the responsible authorities to develop a new airspace management plan for Kingsford Smith Airport and, in conjunction, revise the airport's noise abatement procedures. The new airspace management plan and noise abatement procedures should examine the best means of using all three runways at Kingsford Smith . . .
If anyone could recognise that convoluted recommendation as a recommendation to immediately reopen the east-west runway, then they must have a very broad imagination.

PARA.TAB: Frankly, this committee report—and this is important—does not endorse the policy position of John Howard, nor does it endorse the policy position of the coalition. That is because the members of the committee in their honesty and in their integrity could not overcome the safety—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. We all table reports in this chamber and all of us in order to reach compromises make changes in drafts. I have to say this is the first time I have ever heard people in this chamber referring to previous drafts of reports. I just wonder whether there is an ethical problem we are now bumping into on the confidentiality of the committee. I think we have to be very careful here.
—What standing orders are you speaking under?

—I am seeking some guidance from the chair. I just wonder whether we are not treading into some areas where we should be a bit careful. Members of the committee want to indulge in free-flowing debate, but they do not expect that debate to emerge in the Senate chamber. I wonder if the chair could give some guidance on this rather important issue.

—On that point of order: I normally would not raise this sort of matter if it had been restricted to debate within the committee. It was not in fact debated in the committee—a draft that no member of the Labor Party had even seen was leaked to the Sydney Morning Herald.
—It was a public document.
—That is correct. It was on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—On the point of order, I suggest that the honourable senator exercise due care and proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially, notwithstanding the previous draft or anything that was contained in it, on the face of it the report does not endorse the position of the opposition leader. As I was stating when interrupted, I think this is because the honesty and integrity of the committee members did not allow them to see forward to be able to recommend on the face of evidence on the safety issue that the east-west runway be reopened.

PARA.TAB: The government has taken a number of actions in trying to deal with the problems that have arisen since the runway was opened in November 1994. They include the tightening of flight corridors, strengthening the after-hours curfew, initiating a major program of acquisition and insulation of properties, and also speeding up the development of the new airport, Sydney West. As my time has nearly expired, I conclude by commending to senators the package of reforms contained within the minority report and urge members to give them proper consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to speak on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney. At the outset, I point out it is the most unusual committee I have been involved in—not because we were not civil to each other but because we did not go through the ordinary processes of discussing the report because of the highly political nature of the issue. I hope everybody realises—and I will use due care—that we have not gone through the processes that every other committee that I have ever been on has gone through. Let us face the politics of it.

PARA.TAB: This was because we are in pre-election mode and in this case the opposition are desperate to, in a populous way, attract attention to their cause. I can understand that Senator Parer, as shadow minister for aviation, has had to switch and change as he has gone along and as the wind blows. In Mr Howard Senator Parer has a leader who defends Bennelong first, second and third and is doing everything possible to divert attention away from the real issues. The real issues are, as the minority report points out, there is a need to change the things that have been happening. That is summed up in the minority report, which puts forward:

SPEECH.PARA: The current noise reduction strategies, providing for sound insulation and the management of flight paths, such as restricting flight paths to the north of the airport so as to minimise the number of homes affected, and prohibiting take-offs to the north on the third runway, should continue to be pursued in order to reduce possible adverse health effects.

That is recommendation 9 and appears in the health section of the minority report. When that is taken with the positive proposals that we have for the development of Badgerys Creek, we can see that is the solution for all those people in Sydney who everybody acknowledges have been stressed by the developments that have occurred because of the inadequate environmental impact statement that did not represent fully the problems that Sydney people would face.

PARA.TAB: Our recommendations in the minority report go on to mention that the mistakes that have been made at Sydney airport should not be repeated with the Sydney West airport. In this case we recommend that we immediately pass the legislation that the opposition have not passed to cause delays in getting Badgerys Creek up and running. That very delay this opposition has caused means that people under the flight paths of Sydney airport will suffer longer.

We also propose in relation to the Sydney West airport that we ask the state Labor government in New South Wales to repair the damage that the Liberal coalition government in New South Wales caused at a state level by allowing estates to be built in the flight path area in the west of Sydney. Over the last few years the Fahey and Greiner governments have allowed estates to be built under where those flight paths will be, and people in the west of Sydney might be affected by that.

In addition, we have proposed that there be an improvement in the environmental impact system to make sure that we have the use of a public interest section and a regime applied to environmental impact statements so that the public interest can countervail the weaknesses that occurred at Sydney airport.

Because of an agreement with my whip that I will not speak at great length, I have time to refer to only the coalition's proposals. My colleagues have shown the hypocrisy of the opposition's proposals, but I just want to draw attention to why we say that we should prohibit the take-off of planes to the north from the third runway.

This week the opposition was sprung in an article in the Financial Review by Tom Burton headed `Coalition risks new airport noise protest'. He pointed out the fact that under the coalition government proposal—if they were to be in government—planes would be taking off to the north on the existing third runway. Of course, that is the secret plan. Although Senator Parer, as the shadow minister, was quick to deny it, I point out to the people of Sydney, particularly those people who will be affected, that this is just another way the opposition would, if they were ever in government, vastly affect them in relation to activity that has been banned.

Many people in Sydney to the north of the third runway have not realised that sinister, stealthy move by the opposition which has been telegraphed and then denied by a party that has no policy. Senator Parer had to admit today that the policy that the opposition would have is still hidden. The policy of the opposition is blown around from day to day according to the whims of their leader. Poor Senator Parer, as the shadow minister, has to keep picking up the pieces as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) changes his mind in his populous style of trying to attract votes and protect Bennelong first, second and third.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of comments relating to remarks made by both Senator Childs and Senator Neal. I indicated in my opening remarks that I wanted to thank the committee for what was really a very good committee. I want to take Senator Childs to task because Senator Childs said that this was a very unusual committee in that never before had a committee come out with a report that had not been looked at carefully by every member of that committee.

PARA.TAB: There is a reason for that, Madam Acting Deputy President. In a meeting of that committee, Senator Forshaw, who came to every single meeting of that committee, took the viewpoint that, rather than go through the draft report item by item and page by page, and in view of the fact that he was going to write a minority report, it would be better if he took the draft report away and wrote his minority report.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was because we couldn't agree on anything.

—Senator Childs, that is not correct. That was not the point. In fact, you have indicated, as has Senator Forshaw, that there are items of agreement, particularly with regard to noise forecasts and all these sorts of things. This was a request made to me by Senator Forshaw, and I was happy to accede to it.

PARA.TAB: Another remark was made by Senator Neal. She indicated that she did not have the chairman's draft report by last Friday. In fact, the chairman's draft report was given to the Labor members of the committee last Thursday. We attempted to do it by Wednesday, but at that stage I personally had not had the opportunity to review it. The report was given last Thursday to all members of the committee who wanted it. So Senator Neal's remark that no Labor member of the committee had that report by last Friday is clearly incorrect.

Senator Childs says that it was changed. Very minor details were changed. I gave Senator Forshaw my assurance—and this was in keeping with the relationship we had during the committee hearings, irrespective of the fact that we certainly had differing points of view—that if there were any significant changes to the report I would draw them to his attention. That was done.

I thought while I had the opportunity that I would quote an article relating to the issue of safety. Senator Forshaw has made it very clear in his response that no-one has ever claimed that the use of intersecting runways is unsafe. Let me say that that is not correct. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said it is unsafe. He used violent language to talk about the dangers of intersecting runways as did the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). Senator Forshaw has clarified that by toning down the language used by the Prime Minister and the minister. It is worth quoting from a recent article in the newsletter of the Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators of Australia which deals with Sydney airport. The article states:
Procedural changes that have followed the introduction of a third runway—

SPEECH.PARA: meaning the closure of the east-west—

at Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport are concerning Guild members in Australia. Former Regional Committee Chairman and Chief Pilot of Qantas, Ken Davenport, points out the "third runway" is a misnomer because when the new runway was brought into service the old-cross-runway became subject to stringent limitations.
It then goes on to explain to readers:

the original operations were conducted on two runways, 07/25 and 16/34 i.e. an east-west and a north-south runway system. A simultaneous operating system, SIMOPS, enabled both runways to be used at the same time, greatly reducing delays even if it did, on occasion, cause hair raising experiences for both pilots and controllers.

PARA.TAB: When the second runway . . . was commissioned, the east-west runway was closed for political reasons—

SPEECH.PARA: that came through time and time again in the evidence given to the committee—

and could be used only when the crosswinds on the other runways exceeded 25kt. A pilot could request the east-west runway for operational reasons but ran the possibility of a "please explain" to the Company, Civil Aviation Authority or the Minister.
It goes on to say:
I contend that undue pressure is being applied to pilots not to use the east-west runway when good airmanship would dictate this runway should be used.

PARA.TAB: All pilots of large, noisy jet aircraft are aware of the noise they generate and try at all times to minimise its effect on the community.

SPEECH.PARA: This came through in evidence given to us by pilots. They feel guilty because of a flight path situation which has been imposed upon them by this government and this minister and not their own requirements. It continues:

Minimum drag approaches are flown with minimum, or even no, reverse thrust on landing. Departures using downwind components and optimal climb procedures are also used. The pilots seem to be playing their part but where does it all end?

PARA.TAB: Pilots may reasonably feel that being forced into a take off with maximum crosswind component is questionable. We have all heard of windshear.

SPEECH.PARA: That is one of a myriad of statements similar to those made to the committee. Those statements are made by people who should know. The people who have not been listened to are international pilots and domestic pilots. One domestic pilot even apologised to the people because of the noise he was causing. It is not his fault, but he said he had no option.

PARA.TAB: The committee addressed all the issues. I believe the majority report is certainly a hard hitting report and addresses the issues front on. The recommendations in relation to noise and pollution give a balance. We are suggesting that the noise problem will not go away and with the passage of time will get worse unless it is addressed. Under the current configuration it is bound to get worse. No matter what the government or the minister like to think the problem will not go away. Those people have been subject to a barrage which they described to us as being like in a war zone without bombs.

The development of Badgerys Creek should go ahead subject to a proper EIS. There is no doubt about that. It will not address the problems at Sydney airport. The government cannot walk away from that. If it does, it will be to its detriment when it comes to the voting intentions of the people affected. I think they should take that on board.

I would also like to pay tribute to Senator Bourne, the deputy chair. She did an excellent job. She referred to the great work done by Mr James Warmenhoven, the secretary of the committee. I had never met James Warmenhoven before. I did not know Trish Carling. I agree entirely with Senator Bourne. I doubt in all the years I have been here that I have had the privilege of a better secretary or better committee. On behalf of the committee, I would like the clerks to convey our thanks to those people.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tambling

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I would like to raise a point of order in relation to standing order 37 and relating to the disclosure of evidence and documents. You have previously ruled on a point of order that was raised by colleague Senator Kemp. This related to Senator Neal. Standing order 37 reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: The evidence taken by a committee and documents presented to it which have not been reported to the Senate, shall not, unless authorised by the Senate or the committee, be disclosed to any person other than a member or officer of the committee.

In debate Senator Neal transgressed that standing order and referred to the contents of the drafts which were under consideration by the committee. As such she may have breached the issue that should be addressed as a matter of privilege and ought to be more properly referred by you to the President for further consideration. I think Senator Neal was in error to go into the detail of documents considered by the committee to be in draft form.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: I think the record will show that Senator Neal made it clear that she was referring to a leak which resulted in the majority report being in the pages of the Sydney Morning Herald. She was referring very much to that situation. I do not agree with the point that has been made. Whether the matter of the leak to the Sydney Morning Herald, which is a breach of privilege on the face of it, is considered by the President and referred to the Privileges Committee is another matter, but I do not accept the inference in the point of order that reflected on Senator Neal who was not in the chamber when the point of order was taken.

—On a point of order: I think this displays an incredible lack of courtesy that you did not notify me that you were going to raise this. I was listening to the debate on the television. I suppose courtesy is not something that is common even among the more senior members of the chamber. I suppose I should not expect it. I want to confirm what I said when the issue was raised in the first instance by Senator Kemp. I had not read the recommendation contained in the draft report. I was familiar with it having read it on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday. It has been referred to the Privileges Committee. Using the material on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald I do not think it amounts to disclosure of secret discussions that have gone on in the committee. There certainly were no discussions and this was not sourced from any document provided by or from the committee.

—On the point of order: I think the debate has moved on. I think we will have to examine very carefully what you said in your earlier comments, Senator Neal. My memory was that you did refer to earlier drafts. If you did not, the point is well made. That is why I rose on the point of order. My memory was that you talked about earlier drafts, and you then said that under normal circumstances you would not have followed this course. So we will look at the earlier comments that were made.
—I did refer to the earlier draft.

—The reality is that I cannot remember precisely what you said, and I suspect that you cannot remember precisely what you said, but the Hansard will record precisely what you have said. So people can look at that and draw the conclusions.

PARA.TAB: I think all of us are in agreement. I think one thing this very brief debate has shown is that all of us are in agreement that the discussions and earlier drafts of committees should not be made public nor debated. In fact, that is confirmed, as my colleague Senator Tambling has said. So I think we are all in that sense in blazing agreement.

The question really is: when you got up and you made those remarks, were you referring to a draft which appeared on the front-page of the paper—apparently leaked, I understand, or claimed to have been leaked—or were you referring to earlier drafts which had been before the committee? I think it has been useful because we have made sure that everyone understands that the discussions of a committee are privileged and to be kept in confidence. As I said, we will look to see what you did say in the earlier remarks. I might say it was a highly political speech as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: what a shock that someone made a highly political speech about aircraft noise in Sydney! This will be a stunning revelation to the people of Australia! They will be falling about with horror! As I understand it, Senator Tambling has asked you to refer this matter to the President for his consideration. It seems to me that, if a senator requests an Acting Deputy President to do that, that should take place. I certainly agree that the matter should be referred to the President.

PARA.TAB: I only stand on this point of order because I want to qualify Senator Kemp's enthusiasm about the unanimity of interpretation which we have here. I will await with interest the President's advice, but I am not joining with either Senator Neal or Senator Childs, nor do I accept that they interpreted the standing order in that way. They were simply providing the fact that qualified the nature of the point Senator Tambling had raised. I do not think we need to debate it any more in the chamber. I am quite satisfied with what I assume would be your view, Madam Acting Deputy President—that, Senator Tambling having so requested, you should refer it to the President and let us get on with the business.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: I would like to clarify one point with regard to this matter that is being considered as important. Senator Neal made the point that I had not extended to her other conventions and courtesies. I think it is important to note that I am the shadow minister on duty and, as such, was not able to leave the chamber. But convention and courtesy demand that she ought to stay in the chamber for the duration of the debate, and I think that ought to be the clear point.

—On the point of order: I just make a couple of quick comments, given that earlier Senator Parer had made some comments about what transpired. I think it is important for people to just be on the record, particularly given that it will be referred to the President. All I wish to say to clarify this is that the position was that the draft report—which Senator Parer said he had even not gone through and completely read—was provided to us. The difficulty was that because of the time constraints it was being provided on a sequential basis as things were printed, and it is a very voluminous report, as people have seen.

PARA.TAB: We were in the process of also endeavouring to write our report and having a look at what was to be the majority report. The problem, of course, was that what ended up appearing in the Sydney Morning Herald was a leak of a draft report which was not even in a final form at that stage and which nobody really had any real opportunity to consider. I think that is the point that really needs to be stressed in all of this.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—On the various points of order that have been raised, I will refer the matter to the President. As indicated by the minister, if a senator requests that, I will refer the matter to the President for his assessment and ruling.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: MAILING LISTS

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Earlier this month, the Lord Mayor of the city of Brisbane, Alderman Soorley, distributed Christmas cards to veterans using lists supplied by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. There has been a public outcry from many veterans who have been recipients of these cards. One of the grounds is that the Department of Veterans' Affairs had no right to release their names and, secondly, they were not approached for permission to have their names passed on as is required by law.

PARA.TAB: It is further alleged that the mail contractor who posted the list did not sign any contract, as required, to maintain confidentiality of the list—presuming, of course, that the action of releasing the names was a legitimate act by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In view of the gravity of the allegations that one or more major breaches of the Privacy Act may have occurred—particularly principles 9, 10 and 11—I am publicly calling on the Privacy Commissioner to investigate whether the Department of Veterans' Affairs has breached any of the provisions of the Privacy Act and make public his findings.
Consideration resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On the basis that I was the one who sought adjournment of this to seek further procedural advice, I thought I would just report back. While not every aspect of the procedural situation in which we find ourselves is clear, there does seem to be broad consensus that while there is no doubt about the capacity of the Senate to carry a resolution expressing its opinion about this report—and, in essence, that is what it is doing—it is probably not going to be interpreted as a decision with binding effect. Nevertheless, provided we all accept that the Senate can carry a resolution expressing its view—and nothing constrains it from doing that—we are in order, and there is no problem. While I will still be opposed to the motion, it is not a procedural problem that we confront.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Reid's) agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
Debate resumed from 29 November, on motion by Senator Cook:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the speakers' list just collapsed then, I will take the opportunity to speak on the appropriation bills until 7 o'clock or thereabouts. The bills before the Senate are the government's request for further appropriations—further moneys, to put it simply. What it really does spell out more than anything else is the collapse of the government's budget strategy.

PARA.TAB: We have in these appropriations a request for some $1 billion extra due to the government's unlisted expenditure, which now confirms that the government's budget will go into deficit this year, and that is regardless of the government at the last budget declaring that they would have this budget in surplus this financial year. Of course, that is just not going to be the case.

In fact, they were gilding the lily when they declared in the last budget statement that they would have a budget in surplus, primarily due to the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. They had estimated a budget surplus of some $718 billion. The likelihood now is that it will be a $718 billion deficit. That is a complete turnaround—a greater than a $1 billion turnaround.

We have had another collapse of a government strategy. In fact the budget surplus was the only strategy left to the government. Today we have had the government in this house, and indeed the other house, declare that we are entering the final days of the parliament before the election. That was obvious today when Senator McMullan pretty well announced that this was his final question time, as well as Senator Gareth Evans. The same theme ran through the House of Representatives.

Is it little wonder that the government now really does want to close the parliament down before the real economic results come in next year. No matter how much gloss they put on the national accounts figures yesterday, they know as well as every other commentator in the national media who has reported on this that underlying those national accounts is a set of very bad figures. I do not think it was put any better than in the Australian Financial Review editorial. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The harsh reality is that once the one-off bounce back in rural output and the unsustainable lift in stock levels are removed, the result is a domestic economy as flat as the proverbial pancake.

The government well knows that the next set of national account figures, the December quarter—which will be out on 30 March next year, around about the time of the election date—will of course most likely show a further slowing in the economy, if not a negative growth in the economy. This of course reflects poorly on the government's employment strategy.

PARA.TAB: We know now that unemployment is on the rise. It has shot up from its best level of eight per cent and is now at 8.5 per cent. That best level of eight per cent is no better than the level at the beginning of the so-called recovery. The unemployment figures have not improved at all. In fact the youth unemployment figures are trending up at some 29 per cent. This really puts the economy in a mess.

There are certain economic indicators that the government cannot run away from, that they cannot gild the lily on and that are really starting to bite now in the community in every household and every family. One of the most potent indicators of the standard of living is the GNP per capita. In comparison, Australia in 1983, according to World Bank data, ranked ninth in the world in terms of gross national product per capita. This gross national product per capita is recognised universally as a nation's standard of living. According to the most recent data released in 1993, Australia has slid to 21st in the world. So we are down 12 places in the term of this government.

The current account deficit, which we all know now is some six per cent of GDP, is the worst in the world. We used to come into this parliament and say that we were second only to Mexico; that our current account was fast approaching the disastrous state of the Mexican economy. Ironically, it prompted the Mexican ambassador to complain to the parliament for deriding his country. He was quite right. It was not long before Australia's current account as a percentage of GDP became worse than the Mexican statistic. That is a very embarrassing state of affairs.

Of course it now places Australia as having the worst current account deficit in the OECD countries. The Economist quite laughingly mocks Australia and says, `Guess who's looking like Mexico?' Who would have thought that Australia would ever be compared with the Third World country of Mexico in such mocking terms by such a leading economic magazine as the Economist. That is read by the international community and that is now how Australia is seen in the international community.

The figures get worse. With a deteriorating current account you get an increasing foreign debt. Australia has a record foreign debt of $180 billion, which again ranks as one of the world's worst. As far as our interest rates go Australia ranks, in regard to its prime rates, as the equal highest amongst the developed countries of the world.

I come back to unemployment, because all these statistics cascade down to what is the most basic effect upon the households and families of Australia. You may well talk about foreign debt, current accounts and GNP per capita, which often seem like lofty economic terms—indeed, they are lofty economic terms to the ordinary Australian family and household—but they cascade to an effect that Australians all know about: the unemployment rate.

There are very few people in Australia who have not been affected by the unemployment rate in this country. We have an increasing unemployment rate. There are some 800,000 Australians unemployed, and 29 per cent is the unemployment rate of teenagers. That has not only an economic effect but also a great social effect upon those teenagers.

It really is incumbent upon the government to take note of these economic statistics and the economic critics such as the Economist, the Business Council of Australia and the government's very own economic advisory body, the Bureau of Industry Economics. The bureau declares that the government have been too slow in progressing its micro-economic reform policies; that it has reached a stage of micro-economic fatigue.

This is borne out in the most stark way in a paper published by the bureau of economics in August 1995 called `International benchmarking: Waterfront'. If you cannot get your waterfront right you are never going to get your exports right. If you cannot get them off the wharves in the most efficient and competitive manner, or get them off at all, then you are never going to be able to compete internationally. Your business is handicapped from the start and it is just another additive cost upon business.

That report has some very telling statistics which really do reflect upon all other failures of the government in micro-economic reform. For example, the waterfront charges for containers in Australia are considerably higher than most of those surveyed in ports in New Zealand, Asia and Europe. The greatest concern with Australia's performance must lie with stevedoring productivity, where crane rates—that is, container moves per hour per crane—declined during 1994 and fell back to 1991-92 levels, recession levels.

Crane rates at the very best performing Australian container terminals were 18.5 moves per hour at Fremantle. That is equivalent to some of the poorest performers in Europe. So our best performance is seen to be equivalent to Europe's worst. The BIA survey of ship operators indicates that timeliness and reliability are more important than price. Moreover, the survey indicated that timeliness and reliability for the waterfront services in the Australian ports lagged well behind the overseas ports.

So we still have the same old problems on our waterfront—which you can relate back to the Maritime Workers Union. That union has had more strikes on the waterfront than any other union in this country. In the past 18 months they have had some half a dozen or more very costly strikes in this country—some of them pathetic and useless; most of them utterly unwarranted, as we saw only some weeks ago when they all went out in sympathy for their CRA comrades. That cost the country some $100 million.

It being 7 o'clock I will conclude my remarks, but I think it is worthy to say that the government's economic statistics and indicators have not improved. As we head off to this election, I think the people will answer them in the ballot box.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 7.00 to 8.00 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not that it is of profound significance to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I will be brief. I want to revisit the matter that I have spoken about each year for about the last five years, and that is the level of funding provided to the Department of the Senate, the arrangements which have been entered into, the resolution which was passed some years ago when former Senator Richardson was the chairman of the appropriate estimates committee and the lack of resolve to do anything about it, except to say that successive finance ministers seem to utterly ignore the resolution and the appropriations and staffing committee of the Senate and, on this occasion, ignore the recommendations and proposals adopted for funding which arise from a review of the committee's resources conducted jointly by the Department of the Senate and the Department of Finance.

PARA.TAB: A view has been put to the committee by the Clerk of the Senate, and has been accepted by the committee and in fact confirmed, as I recall, by the President that, with the present level of funding, there can be no guarantees and no certainty that the committee system will be able to function in an adequate and appropriate way. It seems that in this coming period, for the first time at least in my 13 or 15 years, or however long I have been here, the committees' work and the references they take will be subject to the level of funding. In other words, for the first time the committees will not be able to automatically accept references given to them by the parliament, given to them by the Senate, without considering whether or not they can be funded. The funding will dictate the level of activity and the contribution that the committee system makes in the Senate.

I have said for some time that there is something obscene about the fact that the capacity of a parliament to function depends upon the funding provided to it by the executive government. While one expects parliamentary departments to have some recognition of uniform and universal funding constrictions and restrictions, in my view it is utterly wrong that the capacity of the parliament—the capacity of the chambers and the committees—to monitor, examine, consider or contemplate the activities or the conduct of the executive government is controlled by the executive government through the purse strings. I well remember some years ago Senator Walsh threatening with respect to a certain committee that he would ensure the committee did not fulfil the wishes of the parliament because it assured the Minister for Finance that the funding would not be made available.

There is an excellent argument to be had that appropriations for parliamentary departments should be creatures of the parliament and not creatures of the executive government. As it presently is, we are going back to Charles I, who restricted the funding to the parliament and said he would have a capacity to close the parliament down because he would not give it any funding. He lost his head. We are in a situation now where, if it is the view, the wish or the commitment of the Senate to examine the functioning, activities and expenditure of the executive government, it can be prevented from doing so by the executive government. In other words, there is no separation in terms of autonomy between the two. I have always thought that separation of powers was an essential ingredient in the democratic process.

On this occasion the President of the Senate (Senator Beahan), following in the well trodden footsteps of his predecessors, wrote to the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) expressing his concern that the considerations and contemplations of the appropriations and staffing committee of the Senate had again been ignored, except to say that on this occasion a joint committee of review was ignored. The President said in his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee expressed its concern and disappointment at your failure so far to adopt fully the recommendations and funding proposals arising from the review of committee resources conducted jointly by the Department of the Senate and the Department of Finance, which recommendations and proposals were adopted by the committee on 21 June 1995.

The letter observed that the Department of the Senate made several concessions in the course of the joint review in the interests of reaching an agreed outcome with the Department of Finance. It continues:

The recommendations and funding proposals in the report thus represent a compromise on what the department considered was warranted. It was expected that, the review having been thoroughly conducted and its report accepted by the Finance officers, there would be no difficulty in adopting it. I urge your consideration of its remaining recommendations and funding proposals when the matter next comes up during consideration of the 1996-97 budget.

I have to say with the greatest of respect that is a vain hope. Nothing has changed. There is no indication that things will change. As I recall, the joint committee review was as a result of a meeting by I think the President and the Minister for Finance, and it was intended that it be a mechanism to ensure proper consultation between the Department of Finance and the Department of the Senate in good and healthy time prior to the construction of the budget. In past years funding figures have been set and put in place before the department or the appropriations and staffing committee have been given an opportunity to make a contribution. So we have advanced at least to having the facade of a committee to examine the funding arrangements.

PARA.TAB: The 23rd report of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing observes:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee has now received a letter from the Minister for Finance confirming that the government is prepared to offer funding of $1 081 000, $500 000 for standing committees and $581 000 to continue permanent funding for secretariats for two select committees, without adjustment for the 1 per cent absorption determined in the budget.

It is clear from the President's correspondence and from the committee's report that, not withstanding next year being an election year, there will be inadequate funding to allow the various committees to fulfil their obligations and responsibilities. For the first time in living memory committees could find themselves in the position where they will be given a term of reference by the Senate and will not be able to fulfil their obligations because of funding constraints. In other words, the obligations and responsibilities of the committees will be suspended because of a lack of financial resources. I find that grossly obscene, to say the least.

PARA.TAB: The rhetorical question I put to the Senate is this: what does the government propose to do about it in future? If the present process continues the committee system will be utterly neutered. The committee system will be restricted to a level of inquiry and investigation that the executive government judges appropriate.
