Whenever an external body controls, directly or indirectly, the monitoring of the activities and conduct of another body, you can guarantee that there will not be proper and free ventilation of facts and circumstances which flow from the conduct of the monitored body. In this case, it means that the government will no longer be accountable to the Senate.

I do not need to make the obvious point that committees are no more and no less than creatures of the Senate. They are a reflection of the Senate. When their reports are adopted they articulate the views, the commitments, the determinations and the resolutions of the Senate. If they are unable to function it means that the Senate as a whole—this chamber, set up to review and to contemplate; a second deliberation of legislation and activities of government—will no longer be able to fulfil its obligations. Once we arrive at that position the Senate, in many respects, save for rubber stamping legislation or rejecting it, will not have the capacity to make proper determinations and will fall to the ground.

I hope that the Senate addresses this question of how it will ensure that the committees have appropriate funding and that they are divorced and removed in some way from the outcomes of the government. At present we go, year in and year out, with the committee, through the President, writing to the Minister for Finance, expressing their disapproval and dissatisfaction at not only the funding but the process of determining that funding. Nothing changes; it stays the same.

To me, the time seems to have come where the Senate, through a committee of its own, ought to review the process of funding—not the level of funding, not the need for funding, not the need for resources. The committee ought to examine the process used and the methods used to determine funding for the parliament itself. Until such time as there is autonomy, whatever the constraints, on the part of the Senate in its deliberations and determinations of the level of funding, the Senate will not be able to function in the way intended by our forefathers and by those contemporaries serving within it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I go to what I intended to talk about, let me say something that I do not say very often. I agree very substantially with what Senator Crichton-Browne said about Senate committees and Senate committee funding.

PARA.TAB: The matter I want to speak about is one of the appropriations in Appropriation Bill (No. 4). It is the $7 million for the upgrading of the New South Wales showground facilities in order that they be handed over to Mr Rupert Murdoch. That $7 million could do an awful lot of things, including funding the committee system and improving hospitals, roads and schools. It is almost beyond comprehension that the government wants, effectively, to give that money to an ex-Australian—not even a current Australian—billionaire to help him construct a profitable theme park, profitable for himself, on what should be and still will remain, although it is leased, public land.

The Australian Democrats wrote to the government, asking 15 very specific questions on why and how the money for the showground site would be spent. The reply we received gave none of the detailed explanation that we sought. We asked the same very specific questions in the estimates committee hearings. Neither the minister nor the department head was able to provide satisfactory and detailed responses to those questions. We have asked additional questions at the estimates committee about the expenditure, but the committee staff, with the best will in the world—and they do have that—will not be able to furnish answers before mid-December.

We are left with a government request to approve the expenditure of a large amount of taxpayers' money, without adequate justification for doing so. There are other good reasons why the money should not be appropriated, at least until our concerns and the public's concerns are fully answered.

The details of the proposed studio raise serious concerns about the impact of the showground site complex on the showground site and the surrounding area. Over 1,000 cars will be introduced into an area which is already one of the most congested in Sydney. The studio complex will take over most of what is now public land in one of Sydney's most densely populated areas—one of the most densely populated areas in Australia. The complex will attract hundreds of people to the site on a regular basis, creating as yet untested impacts on the local environment. The showground also contains important heritage structures. We still do not know their fate. Until the government has fully assessed all the impacts on the area we cannot, in conscience, support this appropriation.

There are also concerns with the processes followed. The whole tender process for the showground site is now being investigated by the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption. Further, a legal challenge against the New South Wales government also questions whether the allocation of the showground site was tainted by a conflict of interest by one of the Royal Agricultural Society's directors, as well as the legal right of the RAS to sign a lease with Fox studios. The case also questions the legality of the New South Wales government's decision to use the state environmental planning policy process to rezone the showground site so it can be used as a studio complex. It would be totally wrong to appropriate that money until the concerns raised both by the ICAC inquiry and the legal action are resolved and the allocation processes are found to have been appropriate.

There are also now real doubts as to the benefits of the Fox studio complex. Premier Carr's promise of up to 6,000 jobs for the state is also looking a bit shaky, in light of the statement by the Fox studio's chief executive officer that the complex would create between 1,000 and 1,500 jobs and, of those, only between 550 and 700 will be in the film industry.

If the Gold Coast film complex is any guide, the studios at the Gold Coast complex have yet to generate a profit. The theme park in the complex is doing very nicely, thank you. Perhaps more tellingly, 70 per cent to 80 per cent of the studio users at the Gold Coast operation are from overseas. The promises of huge benefits the Fox studio complex will deliver for the Australian film and television industry must be seriously questioned.

In short, this $7 million appropriation amounts to a government request for money, with no detailed list of expenditure, after processes which are being questioned, to undertake work which has neither been listed nor costed, with potentially severe impacts on the site and the surrounding area which have not been assessed. I am very disappointed that the government would make such a request. I am equally disappointed that the opposition intends to vote for it.

Senator Alston was present at the estimates hearing and was as anxious as the Democrats to obtain detailed answers on why and how the $7 million would be spent. I can only ask why the opposition's concerns disappeared at some point between the estimates hearing and this debate, to the point where they support the appropriation but are asking the government not to hand over the money until ICAC has reported positively.

I can tell Senator Calvert, whose second reading amendment I am speaking to, that the government will hand over the money. It does not matter what we tell them, they will hand over the money. As soon as it is appropriated it is the government's to do with as they will.

The Democrats will not be voting for Senator Calvert's amendment. We agree with paragraphs (a) and (b), but we think the way to stop the government disbursing these moneys until such time as all of this is resolved is not to give it to them until that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather fortuitous that I am here to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) now because I will follow on from what Senator Bourne has said, which will lead me to the amendment I will move on behalf of the opposition. As Senator Bourne said, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) provides for a $7 million payment to the New South Wales government for infrastructure costs with the establishment of the Fox film studios at the Sydney showground site.

PARA.TAB: I can tell Senator Bourne and other senators here that I know the Sydney showground site reasonably well. As a former president of the Royal Agricultural Society of Tasmania, I have spent a fair amount of time at the Sydney showgrounds—in some areas more than others. I do know the difficulties that were being experienced at the showground. Senator Bourne quite rightly pointed out the parking situation. Nevertheless, over the years the Royal Easter Show has been one of the biggest events, if not the biggest event, in Sydney.

That facility has provided great entertainment for the people of New South Wales, particularly the country people, for many years. I know for a fact that many of the old show people—exhibitors, graziers and the like—are very sad to be leaving that particular area because it has been around for a long time.

I must say I am very pleased to see that the government is making $25 million available to help that happen. The alternative was to upgrade the old facilities which were, in some areas, becoming past the stage of being able to do anything with. I do not think anybody has any argument with the showgrounds moving out to Homebush. I do not think the Democrats have any problem with that. The coalition certainly has not. We support the appropriation of the $25 million towards the Royal Agricultural Society at Homebush Bay.

I am sure that my very good friend Trevor Smidt, who is still the president of show society of New South Wales, Jim Davidson, who put so much of his life into that showground, and Colin Sanders, the director, would all welcome the fact that they are moving out. What they can do now is set up a show facility that will take the Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales into the year 2000 with facilities that will be second to none in Australia. They can custom build everything they want, because at present there are certainly deficiencies in a lot of areas out there.

I had a feeling listening to Senator Bourne that she may have been briefed by Clover Moore on this particular matter. Because of some of the heritage buildings on the showgrounds and the facility it provides, it is a matter of local concern. Given all the changes that have been made because of the Olympic Games, I do not think there is any doubt that the eventual move out to Homebush Bay is generally supported.

The area of contention is the $7 million payment for infrastructure costs associated with the establishment of the Fox film studios. From the outset the coalition has welcomed the decision by Rupert Murdoch to develop a film studio in Australia. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, said on 9 November 1995, `The coalition welcomes the fact that Mr Murdoch has decided to make such a major investment in Australia, not least because of the potential opportunities it is likely to open up for the independent production sector.'

The reason we are moving this amendment is to draw attention to the fact that there is an inquiry. The New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption is investigating certain aspects of the New South Wales Carr government's dealings with Fox studio. It is concerned about certain matters in respect of the tender process. Senator Bourne has already raised that matter. That is the reason we are moving this amendment. We do not believe that the federal government should disburse $7 million of taxpayers' money until ICAC has publicly confirmed that all processes associated with the dealings between the New South Wales government and the Fox studios are legal.

I look forward with great anticipation to visiting the new Agricultural Society headquarters at Homebush Bay. I look forward to seeing some of the innovations that are planned. I had representatives from the Australian Showmen's Guild and the Royal Canberra Show Society in my office today talking about where the showmen's industry is going in the late 1990s to the year 2000. This opportunity to custom build an agricultural society complex where you can provide all the facilities that you normally have for a showground and to custom build entertainment areas happens very rarely.

I have been briefed on the way the Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales is going to promote the entertainment area of the showground, the sideshow area—the rides and all the rest of it. It is quite fascinating to know how this is going to be done. Areas will be designated by the types of rides, the quality of the rides, the quality of the eating houses—`joints' as they called—so the public will have the best entertainment facilities.

These areas will be called precincts. So you will be able to walk into an `Adrena-land' where you can go on the Gravitron and all those rides that make you feel sick. I will be looking with great interest at what happens at Homebush Bay. I think the money that is being spent by the federal government on promoting and helping that facility to move is very significant. We do have concerns, as the Democrats do, about the $7 million. That is why we are moving this amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1995-96

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 2, page 15, Division 807, Other Services, item 2, Dr C. Lawrence—legal costs in relation to the Marks Royal Commission, omit "556 463", substitute "259 095".

2.Pages 9 to 31, omit each amount that incorporates the amount appropriated under item 2 of Division 807 in the Schedule, substitute an amount equal to that first-mentioned amount reduced by $297 368.
3.Clause 3, page 1, subclause (1), omit "$576 326 463", substitute, "$576 029 095".

The amendments seek to reduce the payment to the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, for legal fees; first of all to $495,095 and then, after a deduction of $236,000, which is the expected payment from the Western Australian government, to the final amount of $259,095.

PARA.TAB: It will be necessary to make some comments on how the Democrats have arrived at this position. In the first instance, we are adopting a somewhat different view from the opposition on the issue of Dr Lawrence's legal expenses. We start from the premise that the Marks royal commission was an inappropriate use of executive power and that it devalued the status of a royal commission by using it solely for the purpose of discrediting a political opponent. I note that this position is also supported by the opinion provided by the Clerk of the Senate that it is inappropriate for an executive in this way to create a situation where parliamentary privilege is attacked.

We need to ask what wrongdoing was exposed by the commission, what laws were exposed, what corruption was brought to the surface, what misuse of public funds was established, what recommendations for future development of public policy arose out of the proceedings. These are the usual content of the report of a royal commission, but that was not why the Marks royal commission was established. In short, the $8 million spent by the Western Australian government on holding this commission was a waste of Western Australian taxpayers' money.

The only finding of the commission was that the evidence appeared to suggest that Carmen Lawrence lied. But from the very moment that former health minister Keith Wilson first suggested her recollection was wrong, that imputation was already public and it should have been left to the public to decide whether or not she lied. I must say the Australian Democrats have always taken the view that it would have saved a lot of difficulty, a lot of expense, a lot of toing-and-froing, including the time of this chamber, if Dr Lawrence had said, `Well, I've made a mistake, I'm sorry I did, but there it is.'

Since she did not, it is also open to us to suggest—and we have taken the view—that it might have been better if Dr Lawrence had resigned and if the political prestige and power of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had not been put behind Dr Lawrence to the extent of keeping her in office when all the evidence points to the position that she did lie to the state parliament of WA and carefully avoided placing herself in exactly the same position as far as the federal parliament was concerned.

The failure to do that, we believe, has devalued the standards of parliamentary behaviour and ministerial probity. However that may finally be judged, it does not affect the Australian Democrats position on the funding of Dr Lawrence's legal expenses. We have taken the view, previously set out in detail, that cabinet was entitled to make the decision to fund her legal costs. We extend that judgment also to the challenges that Dr Lawrence undertook to the validity of the inquiry. We do that on the basis that any citizen who finds herself or himself before a tribunal or a court is perfectly entitled and has the legal right to challenge the constitutionality of the law and the jurisdiction of the court or tribunal before which the citizen finds herself or himself. To that extent, our position also differs from that of the opposition.

However, where we differ markedly from the government's position on this one is in the quantum of the legal fees charged in the first place and which are now being claimed by the government in these bills so that the expenses can be paid. We believe there is no evidence whatsoever that in its decision cabinet took any precautions to set limits to the expenditure, to in any way put a monitoring process in place, to in any way control strategic decisions which inevitably had a result as far as costs were concerned and were reflected in increased costs.

This somewhat slipshod and cavalier treatment of expenditure out of the public purse for Dr Carmen Lawrence leads us to the position that we believe the Australian taxpayer, the Australian public, should not be expected to pay legal costs at these levels. We believe any payment should be based on the Western Australian Supreme Court scale rates, reduced by a further 20 per cent, to arrive at the level of expenditure which would be funded by legal aid if any Australian citizen found herself or himself before a tribunal and was seeking public assistance.

I note in passing that the fees that were charged, and I take as an example Mr Gyles QC, are at the very top of the range—$500 per hour, up to $5,000 per day. These are not the sorts of levels that would be available to citizens who were asking for public assistance through legal aid. The Democrats believe the minister should not be in any different position from that of an ordinary citizen in this situation.

On that basis we have deducted $68,000 claimed for travel and accommodation expenses for the interstate legal team, on the assumption that there would have been plenty of legal talent to choose from in WA, which also happens to be the home state of Dr Lawrence. We have left in an amount that could be apportioned to the travel associated with the challenges because, of necessity, they required travel to Sydney. But, after doing that, we have then measured the expenses. We would have liked a little more detail, but on the basis of the figures supplied we have then applied, as I said, the Western Australian Supreme Court scale rates and, for counsel fees, solicitors' fees, agents' fees, have deducted a further 20 per cent to arrive at the legal aid levels. We have then deducted only 20 per cent from the disbursements to make a proportionate deduction.

That arrives at a figure of $495,095, less the $236,000 to be paid by the Western Australian government. Thus we arrive at the figure of $259,095, which the Australian Democrats believe is a fair, just and reasonable figure. This is the figure that the amendments are putting forward as a substitute figure in the relevant places in Appropriation Bill (No. 4). I commend the amendments to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say at the outset that the coalition opposes this amendment and does so on the basis that it has itself an amendment to put forward in relation to the sum in question. I will just touch on what the coalition proposes. It proposes that the sum stay the same as mentioned in the bill, but that there be a definition in clause 3A of the bill so that it is made quite clear that this money is only to be used for any costs associated with Dr Lawrence's appearances before the Marks royal commission. The coalition has taken the stand that it will support the funding of Dr Lawrence's fees in that regard but only in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler has gone into the minutiae, so to speak, of the actual funding itself and dealt with the figures at hand. Although this decision was very much ad hoc, on the run and, I would submit, made without sufficient consideration or legal advice, it has been handed to the Senate as a fait accompli. It does deal with Dr Lawrence's representation before the Marks royal commission, which the WA government itself saw was important enough to have Dr Lawrence legally assisted in that regard.

That situation is very different to the challenges. The Commonwealth guidelines even allow for the funding of a minister who is acting as a defendant, but they make a distinction where the defendant is a plaintiff. There is a difference between defending an action and initiating an action. In this regard, that principle has application because Dr Lawrence was, as it were, the defendant or not the initiator of the royal commission. But she certainly was the instigator of the challenges in the Supreme Court and the High Court.

The detail that Senator Spindler has gone into really puts us in the position of being somewhat like a taxing master; that is, we have the bills before us. If you go to the Supreme Court or most courts, you can have your bills taxed. In this case the Attorney-General's Department has given evidence in estimates that it has scrutinised these bills and that it has gone through the bills to make sure that they are fair and reasonable.

I am not happy about the situation we are faced with, that we are having this handed to us as a fait accompli, but, nonetheless, bills have been incurred in the course of representation of a minister before a royal commission. At this stage it really is unsatisfactory to be going through bills with a fine-tooth comb. I have previously said that we should have this degree of scrutiny and this degree of thoroughness, but the responsibility for that lies squarely with the government. It is the government that has made this decision. It is the government that runs the Attorney-General's Department—not the Democrats and not the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is now our responsibility.

—It is our responsibility to ensure that these fees are paid only for the purposes that we have agreed to, and we have agreed that funding go to representation before the royal commission. That is why our amendment specifies that legal costs should be paid only in relation to the royal commission and not in relation to any actions taken in any court in relation to the Marks royal commission.

PARA.TAB: I am saying that it is really too late to go through the bills individually at this stage. The responsibility for that lies with the government. The fact is that the solicitors concerned could well substantiate their bill to the amount in question. They could well want to come before the Senate and justify their costs. By cutting the amount, I am afraid that we are doing that without any recourse to the solicitors concerned or without allowing them any justification of their bill.

In the ordinary course of events, there should have been clearer guidelines in place—and there is a Senate committee looking at that, as Senator Spindler knows. I think the guidelines that the Commonwealth has in place are insufficient in that there is lack of clarity and lack of transparency as to how a minister's costs are met. But, nonetheless, we are faced with a situation where, on the second last day of sitting, we have this put before us. It has been the coalition's view that there really is no alternative but to meet the costs for the representation before the Marks royal commission.

In relation to Senator Spindler's amendment No. 4101, which deals with an amendment to clause 3A, I think there is merit in his proposed subsection (1) where in principle Senator Spindler has set out that the payment should relate to the `legal costs of Dr Lawrence in relation to the Marks Royal Commission remaining after deduction from those costs of any amount paid or payable by the Western Australian government'. I think that is in principle a good amendment. It makes it quite clear that there is no chance of any double-dipping and that there is no chance of any overlapping of costs so that you have two governments paying for the same item of work.

With respect to proposed subsections (2) and (3), I believe the coalition amendment standing in my name is to be preferred because it is expressed in a way that has a degree of efficacy about it. In particular, proposed subsection (3) of my amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In this Act, any reference, however expressed, to legal costs of Dr C. Lawrence in relation to the Marks Royal Commission does not include legal costs (however constituted)—
I think that proviso really does makes it clearer—
of Dr C. Lawrence for or in relation to proceedings in a court in relation to the Marks Royal Commission—
`Proceedings in a court' would relate to the two challenges in the Supreme Court and the one challenge in the High Court. Senator Spindler's proposed subsection (3) simply states:
In this Act, reference to legal costs `in relation to the Marks Royal Commission'—
and that is taken from that part of the bill which refers to the payment of Dr Lawrence's fees—
does not include reference to legal costs of Dr C. Lawrence for or in relation to proceedings in a court in relation to the Marks Royal Commission.

It is very close, but I do not think that it is expressed quite as widely as the coalition amendment. I think the expression `however constituted' is to be preferred. That really doesn't allow anything to slip under the door, so to speak, or to slip through.

PARA.TAB: There really could be a combination here. I am suggesting that, should Senator Spindler's amendment fail, we move on to the amendments to clause 3A standing both in Senator Spindler's name and in mine. I would suggest that my amendment be moved in parts, discretely, so that we debate and deal with 3A(1), then 3A(2) and then 3A(3) accordingly. That is a suggestion I would make to the chair in relation to the progress of this matter. But in relation to Senator Spindler's amendment currently before the chair, the coalition is not minded to support the amendment for the reasons I have mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am open to the suggestion that was made about our second amendment. I do think my first subsection is better, and I am prepared to accept the argument on the other one. I will be happy to go along with that procedure. I think it achieves the basic purpose of ensuring that there is no double dipping.

PARA.TAB: I find Senator Ellison's arguments, however, on my amendment somewhat strange. He is trying to have it both ways a bit. He is saying there is a responsibility on the part of the Senate to scrutinise expenditure before it is paid out of the public purse, but it is not our job to carefully look at what we are being asked to pay. Either we have that responsibility, we discharge it and we look carefully at the reasons that are being put forward and we look carefully at the rates or we do not. While I said we might like to have a little bit of further detail, in actual fact what we have here is adequate for the purpose to which we have put it, and that is that the bills have shown the actual rates charged—the rates per hour, the rates per day.

The rates per hour and the rates per day are, as I said, at the very top of the range. That is not the sort of scale that can be expected to be paid for an ordinary Australian citizen. The question simply is whether the minister should be in a different position. I ask the coalition to very seriously reconsider the position that they appear to be adopting on that amendment because it is soundly based, logical, just and fair. It simply says that the rates that have been charged are far too high and do not correspond with what an ordinary Australian citizen would be able to obtain. We have two people here asking support from the public for legal costs. I think they should be treated equally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that I do not support Senator Spindler's amendment for obvious reasons: an amendment that has been circulated in my name rests on the principle that the payment has not been valid in any event. I will not speak to that until my amendment is dealt with. I want the minister to clarify the figures involved. I have done several sums and I keep getting different totals all the time. So my question to the minister is: how much was the total legal bill to which the cabinet committed themselves for Dr Lawrence's funding? What is the breakdown in terms of the defence cost, the challenge cost and the contribution of the Western Australian government? Has that Western Australian contribution been paid already? Has it been left out of the calculations on the basis that it will be paid, or is it somehow included in that amount? I am actually asking for four figures—the total cost of Dr Lawrence's legal funding with the subitems of the defence cost, the challenge to the commission cost and the contribution to the WA government—and information as to whether or not that has been provided.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are embarking here, first of all, on a procedure which is unique and unusual. I think it is unique that we are modifying an appropriations bill in a specific case because of legal costs incurred and because of, dare I say it, political points of view about the actual rather than so much about the costs.

PARA.TAB: These legal costs are high. The amounts of these legal costs have been brandished around the media as being high in order to attract spectacular attention in the community on the basis that somehow this is a bad thing that Carmen Lawrence is doing in incurring these legal costs by saying, `Look at the amounts. Aren't they high?' The amount of the legal costs is not a comment on Dr Lawrence. Dr Lawrence was doing nothing more than wanting to defend her interests before a royal commission that set out to put her in the position of a defendant and to destabilise, undermine and discredit her as a public figure. That is what happened.

If the costs of doing that are high, that is a reflection on the legal system and the level of legal costs—not on Dr Lawrence. Yet somehow or other Dr Lawrence seemingly is being held to be in disrepute for incurring such an amount. I think what this Senate ought to direct its attention to is where the wrong is in the first place. In the first place the wrong is with those who visited this royal commission on her. In that respect, I acknowledge what Senator Spindler has said about this royal commission. He has canvassed its merits, or its lack of merits, the processes that it undertook and its findings. He has expressed his perceptions of what proper conduct might be ethically and politically, and he has gone on to question the legal costs.

What he, as the mover of this amendment, has told us is that the Australian Democrats effectively in large part support the government's position about this. The Democrats demur on some elements of Dr Lawrence's conduct in terms of whether or not she should have stepped down since she was under a challenge of some sort. They seem to assume that she had something to clear up and, if she had cleared that up at the beginning of this process, maybe the process would not have gone on. They are presumptions. They are not presumptions that the government has; they are presumptions that the Democrats have. But I note and do welcome the views of the Australian Democrats about the pernicious nature of this royal commission and the manner of its conduct and its treatment of Dr Lawrence.

However, given those sentiments expressed by the Australian Democrats, I think this amendment then sits quite oddly. This amendment goes on to argue that the amount is too high and that the amount should be at the level of legal aid. I submit that that is a superficial argument. It is not true in the eyes of even the Western Australian government—the government who mounted this royal commission against Dr Lawrence. They have not applied this test in the settling of their fees to the extent that they have reimbursed her. So it is not a test, if you like, that those who set out to get her political scalp applied when it came to assessing legal fees.

There is at least a reason for that, and that is that ministers of the crown, in their accountability to the Australian community, bear, I believe, a far greater responsibility and a far deeper accountability than ordinary citizens do. They are entrusted with high office. They are reposed with major responsibilities. They are in the public spotlight. Their conduct is and is expected to be at an elevated level.

When they are being challenged it is reasonable that they ought to attract the best legal defence that they can have. That legal defence comes at commercial rates. We know of this legal defence and its costs that evidence has been given to a committee of this parliament that these legal costs are fair, represent the true costs incurred and are within the commercial rates that apply. That is the true measure of what the level of costs should be.

When you apply that measure you come up with a stunningly large figure. Again I point out that Dr Lawrence is defending herself against a royal commission attacking her and that was set up for that purpose. She is entitled to a quality defence. That is a basic right. Given the higher responsibility she bears, it is important that she be properly defended. The amount of the costs is not her fault. It is the cost of justice in a case like this.

In relation to the first point that the Australian Democrats raised about comparing this to legal aid, can I say that I do not think it is true in terms of the public responsibility and accountability that goes to a minister. Even the Western Australian government has not applied that level. I suggest that that might be a compelling argument to rethink.

More importantly than that, Senator Spindler has raised a second argument in this case which goes to the choice of counsel or at least the geographical location of counsel. He believes that Dr Lawrence should have found a lawyer in Perth to defend her in a proceeding being conducted in Perth. Let us look at that proposition.

Commissioner Marks is a resident of Melbourne and was recruited by the Western Australian government to conduct this royal commission after a national survey to find someone to coopt to do that job. They looked nationally and obtained who they thought was the best person in Commissioner Marks. They got him not from Perth, but from Melbourne. Moreover, when they looked for counsel assisting the commission they recruited Vanstone QC—I forget her Christian name; I apologise for omitting her Christian name—and she is not a resident of Perth, she is a resident of Adelaide. They obviously looked nationally in order to find a fitting person to be counsel assisting and they chose a resident of Adelaide.

On the face of these facts, what Senator Spindler is saying is that, notwithstanding that, Dr Lawrence should have found a lawyer from Perth. I am also a resident of Perth when I am not living in Canberra. Most lawyers in Perth at one time or another have been associated with royal commissions, in the first instance, mounted by Dr Lawrence into what is styled WA Inc. and subsequent events.

I think it is entirely appropriate that fresh blood be considered in order that someone could appear before this commission to defend Dr Lawrence's legitimate interests. You would not find fresh blood among the legal fraternity in Perth. With the greatest respect to them—and I admire several of the practitioners in that community—all of them have had their hands on this sort of case at some time or other. To the second argument that she should have picked up someone on the local scene, I think that in the circumstances, with the greatest respect Senator Spindler, that is not appropriate. That is another reason for inviting you to reconsider.

Senator Ellison has moved an amendment. Understandably and quite reasonably—and I do not criticise it—when he was speaking to Senator Spindler's amendment he did so by promoting his own and sought across the chamber to invite you to join with him and he preferred what he called the greater merit of his to yours in achieving that outcome. I do not think Senator Ellison's amendment is appropriate either, nor do I think it goes to the actual point you wish to raise. I understand that point to be your conception of a principle about legal aid being really a determinant as to the level of payment and, secondly, insistence—and reasonable insistence in my view; one that I do not disagree with you on—that there should be no double dipping.

The quality of what Senator Ellison is going to is another matter again. Speaking on behalf of the government—and I of course have a vested interest in this—on the plain facts of the circumstance it does not seem that you have a coincidence of interest with the coalition either. Senator Ellison in expressing his views, which he did in a quite persuasive manner as he normally does, let slip an observation which I think is revealing. That observation was that in these sorts of proceedings that Carmen Lawrence had to face up to she was in the nature of a defendant. I think the Hansard will show that the word `defendant' was used.

Of course, in a royal commission there is no such thing as a defendant. It has been the government's argument that Carmen Lawrence has been cast in the role of a defendant. I think Senator Ellison is quite right in calling her a defendant, because that was indeed the nature of the proceedings. She was made to be a defendant. When a royal commission was supposed to be there to discover the facts she was put in the dock as someone on trial about her probity. The proceedings, to the government's mind, did not follow the processes of inquiry. Rather they followed the processes of a prosecutorial process as if there were a trial. I do not know whether Senator Ellison reflects the views of the coalition in this because this is the point the government has been making all along, but it is revealing that he should use that term in relation to this matter.

This whole story is a sorry story. The government believes it should never have occurred. The $8 million or so that it has cost Western Australian taxpayers for this royal commission is a travesty and an outrage and it should never have occurred. But, because it did, there are costs of justice, and costs of justice for significant public figures in terms of their national accountability, too. The Western Australian government does not argue that that should be at commercial rates because that is the level that they have tested this in. These figures are high, but let us not fall into the populist trap of saying these figures are high and it is outrageous that they should be paid. What is outrageous is that this matter occurred at all. In the government's submission—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was outrageous for Penny Easton, too.

—We have debated that whole issue. I do not intend to debate it tonight again, but to simply stick with a statement of our position. You ought to give pause and consider withdrawing your amendment. But, if you do not, my position will be to vote against it.

—Could I ask the minister whether the government or cabinet, in making the decision to fund the costs, considered the levels at which the charges for legal costs should be made. Was the government consulted about where the counsel was coming from or who it should be? Did the government put into place any monetary devices as to costs and was the government at any stage during the proceedings before the commission consulted about strategic decisions which inevitably would result in a variation in costs? In other words, how close a control did the government keep on the costs of this case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This raises an important consideration for the government. The government was not on trial here; Dr Lawrence was. The government made a determination to meet reasonable legal costs for her defence, but they left the selection of counsel to the person who was the subject of the royal commission, that is, Dr Lawrence. We did not intervene and decide on behalf of Dr Lawrence what we believed to be her best interest. We thought the appropriate thing was that Dr Lawrence, as the victim of these proceedings, should decide that and she made the selection of counsel, not the government. It was for her to decide on instructions to her counsel how her defence was best to be mounted. It was not for us to intervene in choosing how best to defend her interests. Indeed, it may well be on at least one view that we are not in a position to have made those choices anyway, had we been of a mind to, because the corporate knowledge of these circumstances was knowledge peculiar to Dr Lawrence and her experience.

PARA.TAB: So, to answer those questions, no, we did not cap off these fees. We did not say, `We're prepared to support you in order to protect your interests and ensure that you are justly treated, but only to the level of X and, if it costs more, then we depart from the principle.' We did not say that. We did not say, `Dr Lawrence, you will only have this counsel or that counsel.' We said, `Dr Lawrence, you're under attack. You select the best person that you have confidence in to protect your interests.' In terms of monitoring that, we did not put restraints and conditions upon it. What we would like to have done, but were not in a position to do, is put restraints and limits on the actual royal commission itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I rise on a point of order. Could I just ask this so that I understand: how are you judging whom you call next? I ask that, quite frankly, on the basis that I do not seem to get a very good call when you are in the chair.

—I will take that point up later on because I am not able to respond to it right now.

—That is fine, but I thank Madam Chair for giving me the call. I rose at the same time as Senator Spindler rose because the minister has not answered the question I asked him, and I am just wondering whether he is planning to do that. I just want to reiterate, perhaps in a more logical fashion, that I would like to know: what has the Western Australian government given to date? TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did hear your question, Senator Chamarette, and I have not avoided it. I just cannot find the document in which—
—You did—you just didn't answer it.

—I did not answer it because I could not answer it truthfully because I did not have the document in front of me in which the information was contained. I cannot find it among my papers now, but it is my understanding that in answer to an inquiry—I think, from Senator Spindler to the Minister for Finance—some details of this matter were given, and it was that document that I was going to table. —Much as I am very fond of most of those on this side of the chamber, I find something vaguely bizarre about those that they accept as public funds to be provided to Dr Lawrence and those which they do not.

PARA.TAB: But before I get on to that—and Senator Cook has had something to say about the commission, as well as the funding for it, in terms of relevance—I thought the commission was totally and utterly justified. I do believe that the minister for health, the then Premier of WA, indulged herself in a petition, which Mr Halden was in large part the architect of, for the purpose of deflecting from her own difficulties—including a police investigation into her use of public funds, allegedly for trips she did not take, which rested comfortably in her account for a very long time and were only refunded when the police brought it to her attention.

I have to say that I have no time for Mr Halden. It is no shock to me that he is involved in this matter, because he tabled in the state upper house a document which claimed that I was anti-Semitic. It was a document which was a fabrication and a creation of somebody sitting behind a computer, which I thought was perhaps the most despicable sort of concoction one could have invented. Mr Halden promptly tabled it in the state parliament with my name and initials at the bottom of it.

I believe—many may disagree; anybody who has read her suicide note will understand why I say this—that Penny Easton ultimately committed suicide or was led to her death as a result of circumstances surrounding that petition and the way that it was dealt with. I find the coalition's attitude at odds with my own for these reasons; they are slightly bizarre. Recently, Mr Eoin Cameron, the member for Stirling, had published in the West Australian newspaper a statement that he was seeking from Mr Walker, the Minister for Administrative Services, part of the cost of his legal fees, which he claims amounted to $5,000, when he was inquired into by the Australian Federal Police as a result of a complaint from me stemming from blackmail threats being received by me.

The Australian Federal Police found that the blackmail threats had been transmitted from the facsimile machine provided to Mr Cameron by the taxpayers of Australia in his electorate office. They also found a dirt sheet on his computer. They also established that two copies of those dirt sheets were faxed from his office to the President of the Senate, Senator Beahan, and to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins.

They also found large quantities of an unprocessed restraining order from my wife in vivid colours which was reproduced and redistributed by Mr Cameron and provided to him by Mr Viner QC, whom my wife had consulted as, she thought, a friendly lawyer. I will not go into the detail of how he improperly acquired that, the fact that the person who gave it to him is now subject to a charge under the Public Service Act of WA or the fact that Mr Viner then rummaged through the file when the clerk left the file, accidentally or by design, on the desk and then provided further information, which was the construction of a dirt sheet subsequently typed on a computer in Mr Cameron's office.

I find it odd that the Liberal Party has not disowned itself from Mr Cameron's suggestion that the taxpayers owe him a large part of his $5,000 as a result of activities which led the AFP to execute a search warrant on his office. I did not make a complaint about Mr Cameron, because he was not my first choice.

The Australian Federal Police said to me—I think I use their exact words when I say it this way—`Senator Crichton-Browne, these days to get a search warrant, not least on a federal member of parliament, almost requires grounds which will lead to a conviction.' They obtained in the most stringent circumstances a search warrant of his premises. The Federal Police do not seek these search warrants easily and they are not granted easily by those who have to sign off on them.

The Australian Federal Police then sent up a brief to the DPP looking for a prosecution, which could not succeed because it could not ultimately establish who pressed the button. I suppose it is not unreasonable to suggest that a burglar broke in, pressed the button and sent it off and nobody in Mr Cameron's office knew about it. I find no objection by the opposition about Mr Cameron seeking to use taxpayers funds to reimburse him because he suddenly decided that he needed legal advice.

If, for instance, the Federal Police visited my office with a search warrant because it had been suggested that I had been sending blackmail threats to the minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), I would hand them my keys, go down the pub and say, `Ring me when you are finished.' The last thing I would do is waste money ringing up and engaging a lawyer, unless I was visited by some anxiety and doubt as to what they might find. I would then ring Mr Malcolm McCusker QC. A royal commission was set up, in my view very legitimately, yet, as I understand it, the funding that has been severed goes to the question of, for instance, privilege.

My memory is—and I have not had time to research this—that following what was euphemistically described as the Murphy committee, which was chaired by former Senator Tate, subsequently the Minister for Justice and now ambassador to The Hague, certain evidence provided to that committee was raised and allowed as admissible evidence in, I think, the New South Wales Supreme Court. The then President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, joined the action and, on behalf of the Senate, made certain representations in respect of privilege.

I could get into some dispute, I suppose, as to whether or not it is a question for the Hon. Clive Griffiths MLC, the President of the Legislative Council in Western Australia, or Senator Beahan, the President of the Senate, or perhaps more particularly the Speaker of the House of Representatives. But I have long held the view that, when matters of privilege and matters of a similar nature are raised in jurisdictions, the appropriate presiding officers have an obligation and a responsibility to ensure that the proper interests of the parliament are represented.

If it is the view of the parliament, as articulated and reflected through the Presiding Officers, there should be counsel engaged. If you were going to argue about what funding was to be provided to the present minister for health, I would have thought you might have had some dispute about the level of funding for her legal fees before the royal commission—not the question of justiciability, or jurisdiction or the general question of privilege.

But, for some quaint reason—of course, of which I am not likely to be informed—the coalition have taken the view that we just chop off certain funding. I think they have chopped off the wrong funding. If we were having a debate tonight about other funding, I would find myself probably in a different circumstance.

If we are going to argue about the level of funding, it is my view that, given the seriousness of the matter—the political, moral and personal circumstances which will be visited upon Mrs Lawrence—she is entitled to seek, at the very least, quality representation. In my future litigation I will not be getting the poorest or the cheapest counsel; I will be getting counsel that can represent me in a way which provides me with the best opportunity of prosecuting my case. I think it is not an unreasonable circumstance that the same opportunity be allowed of the minister for health.

So I find myself, as one of my colleagues says, in a dilemma about the approach that the coalition has taken on this matter. But I would have felt much more comfortable if I had heard the coalition say, `We disassociate ourselves from Mr Cameron because he is asking for taxpayers' funds as a result of an investigation over very serious criminal matters including section 28 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act.' I think section 85Z also carries a gaol term of three years; a very serious criminal matter.

If they had said, `That's his bag, that's his lot if he has a warrant executed upon him'—presumably the Commonwealth police are conducting themselves in a way which they are expected to, and the public are entitled to have them so do—then I would have had more sympathy to the view being put. But it is not an argument that I have heard put.

To my knowledge—and I might be wrong; he might have locked himself in the loo, as is the wont of those from time to time who do not have the courage to make a decision—Mr Cameron voted against the proposal that the funding not proceed. My understanding is Mr Cameron's attitude is that he should get the money and that Dr Lawrence should not. I find the logic, the morality and the integrity of that kind of quaint in my own sort of humble, inarticulate way.

More importantly, I believe that the Presiding Officers—to the extent that this matter visits them, this parliament and members of it—ought to be looking at this whole question of privilege. When the rights of members of parliament or the public, or the responsibilities of the chamber, are before the courts, there is something to be said for making sure that the parliament has representation there to articulate and argue the views of the chamber. We, as I understand it, are being asked to support a proposal that makes sure we do not provide funding for that very reason. For my part at least, I find that vaguely curious.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to reply to the comments made by the minister in relation to my description of Dr Lawrence before the royal commission. The law, as it stands, has plaintiffs and defendants. You will notice I did not use the word `accused' or the words `in the nature of an accused'. But when you are involved in a royal commission, a coroner's inquest or any administrative inquiry, you are not in the role of a plaintiff, certainly, but you are more in the role of a defendant. `Defendant' is a clumsy term in relation to that but, nonetheless, it is the nearest the law can get to describing the person's position.

PARA.TAB: I suppose you could say that Dr Lawrence is a person who is affected by the royal commission. The Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, is a person who could be said to be affected by the royal commission and, of course, entitled to representation before the royal commission. Similarly, in the royal commission into WA Inc. people who appeared without changes laid against them, or without wearing the tag `defendant', were given representation because of the possibility of an adverse inference—and you do that in a very general sense.

So my description `in the nature of a defendant', I believe, is the best law can offer in describing a person who is involved in a royal commission. Certainly, I was using that phrase to distinguish Dr Lawrence from being in the role of a plaintiff. That was taken in the context of the Commonwealth's guidelines which say you fund a minister if they are a defendant but you do not if they are a plaintiff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette asked me a question earlier in the committee stage. I have here—and I have only one copy of it, but I am happy to table it—a letter from the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, Stephen Skehill—it is signed for him—to Senator Barney Cooney as chair of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. It is headed `Additional estimates—details of Dr Lawrence's legal bills'.

PARA.TAB: Attached to that letter is a document headed Western Australian royal commission into Easton petition: details of the Hon. Dr Carmen Lawrence MP's legal costs to 20 October 1995. Those words are familiar to me because I just saw them on a document that Senator Chamarette and I were discussing a moment ago. This document, might I say, appears in every respect to be the same as the document we were jointly looking at, Senator Chamarette. I will table this document so it will be available in the records of this debate. The document starts with paragraph No. 1, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has received six bills from Dr Lawrence's solicitors (Dunhill Madden Butler) for work both in relation to the royal commission and in relation to Dr Lawrence's challenges to the royal commission.
That is, to the commission and the challenges to it. It goes on:
The total of the bills is $856,000.21 for work up to 20 October 1995. This figure includes—
and the word `includes' is underlined to emphasise it—
the amount of $236,020 claimed by Dr Lawrence from the Western Australian government in relation to the royal commission. Thus, the net amount claimed from the government to date is $619,980.21.

It encloses a table of the breakdown of the six bills. One other comment I make about these figures relates to the amount of $236,020 claimed from Dr Lawrence from the Western Australian government in relation to the royal commission. I am not aware of whether or not the Western Australian government has acknowledged that and is committed to paying it. All I can say to the Senate is that that is what Dr Lawrence is claiming from them, as I understand it, given the indications of what they will meet as legal costs that they have already offered. At this stage I am not able to advise anyone because I do not know what the outcome of that is and whether it has been accepted by the Western Australian government.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 2, page 15, Division 807, Other Services, item 2, Dr C. Lawrence—legal costs in relation to the Marks Royal Commission, omit "556 463".

2.Pages 9 to 31, omit each amount that incorporates the amount appropriated under item 2 of Division 807 in the Schedule, substitute an amount equal to that first-mentioned amount reduced by $556 463.
3.Clause 3, page 1, subclause (1), omit "$576 326 463", substitute "$575 770 000".

I am actually moving these amendments in honour of St Jude, who is the patron saint of lost causes, only to put on record a matter of principle. I know in advance that there is not support for this in the chamber, but I do think it is important to exert a principle. Maybe the Greens should adopt St Jude as our patron saint. We live in hope, though.

PARA.TAB: The Greens have consistently opposed the payment of Dr Lawrence's legal costs because we believe there is no precedent, legislative basis and, arguably, no constitutional grounds for making such a payment. We have never criticised Dr Lawrence on that account because we have acknowledged—I have acknowledged it before this place—that we believe the Marks royal commission was a disgraceful political exercise. We believe it was a misuse of executive power by the state government, relying upon information provided by Dr Lawrence's own adversaries within her own party. Nevertheless, we also believe that the federal government's plan to use public funds to defend this political attack is a further wrong which does not make a right.

If we make this payment, where does it end? We are throwing the coffers of the Commonwealth open to ministers for their unfettered use. I feel that it would be hard to argue that this is the intention of the constitution.

The coalition was initially very concerned about the payment of these costs. I believe the Democrats were also, and I think Senator Spindler has referred to it. It appears that their resolve has weakened and an arrangement has now been made—or a deal been done, if you want to put it in harder terms—in the other place to pay the defence portion of the legal costs. I would be interested to hear the reasons for that position. No doubt this will occur later on when the opposition supports the amount they are prepared to contribute towards Dr Lawrence's legal costs.

The Democrats have put forward a proposition that costs should only be paid at the level of legal aid. If we believe that the payment of the costs was valid in the first place, then possibly we would have been supportive of such a move. It is interesting to note that there has been no attempt to cap Mr Griffiths's costs to the legal aid level in Appropriation Bill (No. 3). The Democrats amendment helps us to see the level of privilege that is operating in this case. It shows that there is one law for the wealthy and powerful and one for all other Australians, who must rely on legal aid funding or their own resources.

It has not been easy to maintain a firm stance on what the Greens see as a very important principle whether cabinet and executive decision making should be imposed upon the parliament as a fait accompli and various attempts made to force political parties, perhaps through fear of some kind of political repercussions, to support the expenditure. It has not been easy because, personally, I have not wished to identify myself with the kinds of slurs and attacks that have been made on Dr Lawrence. At times I have been cast in the role of a Western Australian woman against a Western Australian woman and I find that offensive. It has also been reported that we have sympathy for the financial burden that Dr Lawrence may have to bear if these costs are not covered and such reports are unfair.

The arguments have been rolled out in an attempt to obscure the questions that lie at the heart of this matter, which is why we have moved the amendments. Should the parliament establish a precedent that the Commonwealth purse, the taxpayer's purse, fund the constant slanging match between the political parties? Should we perpetuate the adversarial nature of the political culture? Should we ignore these sleazy episodes in our political history which are the product of a valueless and self-serving system? Should we ignore the warnings about the very constitutionality of making such a payment?

Once again, the self-serving interests of all involved have been glossed over. For the coalition's part, the establishment of the commission and the harassment of Dr Lawrence in the parliament and the media furthered their agenda to damage the government in the lead-up to an election. The government, in turn, has sought to cast the coalition as the evil villains conducting a hate campaign against the minister. In the skirmish to gain the political advantage, both truth and justice have been eclipsed.

But throughout this sordid process it remains clear that there is still no basis for the parliament to make this payment. I firmly believe that the Labor Party and, in particular, the cabinet have a responsibility in this matter. The Labor Party cannot be surprised that its own avidly used political tactics have come home to roost. So long as the adversarial two-party system is maintained, these incidents will continue.

The cabinet, for their part, did a grave disservice to Dr Lawrence by leading her to believe that she would have a blank cheque for her legal costs. This is in spite of the fact that they had no authority to make such a commitment and repeatedly refused to produce any evidence that they sought legal advice as to whether she would be successful, the constitutionality of the allocation, or even any legitimisation of this appropriation. They were not even going to have it as a one line item in an appropriations account until the findings of the committee that has been looking at this matter brought it into very sharp relief that they had no possibility of gaining anything if they did not at least submit to the parliament for the use of taxpayers' money.

It has almost passed from memory now, but the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee are still considering the guidelines and conditions to ensure the legality and propriety of any use of public funds to pay the legal costs of members of parliament and ministers. I hope that this at least will be a positive outcome to this disgraceful affair.These guidelines will hopefully prevent this from happening again. It may then be that the community can have some measure of faith that the Commonwealth purse, the taxpayer's purse, will not be thrown open to parliamentarians for their unfettered use. It is for that reason that I have moved the amendments circulated in my name.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition, for reasons outlined previously, will oppose these amendments in preference to the other amendments I mentioned previously. I note Senator Chamarette's comment that the government went about this in a questionable constitutional and legal sense and that the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee indeed recommended that there be a single line of appropriation. I think that was the correct method to employ in this instance and, on that basis, the manner adopted by the government is legitimate. Senator Chamarette said that she ought to pray to St Jude for lost causes. My mother always said that, if you lost something, pray to St Anthony.

PARA.TAB: We would never accept the findings of the royal commission; we think it is entirely inappropriate. I do not believe the findings of the royal commission because of my personal knowledge of Dr Lawrence. That personal knowledge of Dr Lawrence does not extend to any detailed knowledge of her personal financial affairs, but this is a very large bill. One of the principles that I have thought we have always stood on is that there ought to be an ability to fund the cost of justice so that justice can be done. If you don't fund it, justice is not be done. In this case you would push an individual of reasonable means close to the brink of bankruptcy. If this amendment were carried, that is what would happen. I oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate, as the minister said, that he has been left to look after this matter while Senator Evans is away. He has not heard me repeat this argument on many occasions. I gave it in a very abbreviated form because I have repeated it on many occasions to Senator Evans and in this chamber. I did it in August. As I have done so several times, I am not going to burden my colleagues with repeating it. I ask the minister whether legal advice was sought as to the efficacy or success of the challenge that was put up to the royal commission and, if so, would the minister table that advice?

PARA.TAB: As is usually the case when such an endeavour is embarked upon, was there ever any opportunity to seek from the solicitor some kind of payment on the success of the case rather than simply payment whether or not the case succeeded? If you are arguing that it is legitimate for the entire amount to be provided by this parliament, that it has got precedent, legal basis and constitutionality, you should also be able to justify to the people of Australia via this parliament how well you stewarded that money and ensured that it would be used in a particular way. I would be very grateful if you could tell us, having decided that it was perfectly legitimate to ask for this money from the taxpayers' purse via this parliament, what accountability you have to ensure that it was used properly, that the minimum amount was used and that you had some chance of success, because that is where your position leaves you.

I want to respond to some other remarks that the minister has made. My reason for saying that there is no precedent is that the precedents that have always been raised to justify payment of the legal costs of ministers is that the ministers were actually engaged in the same post at the time a matter arose. However, we are dealing with a federal minister being charged in a state, under a state jurisdiction, over a matter that occurred prior to her becoming a federal minister. We have not got a precedent for that. We set precedents; we are setting a precedent. But it is quite a dangerous one. That is why there has been no precedent.

The `no legal basis' argument that I am speaking of is the one that Senator Spindler raised. The Democrats believe that it is a legitimate allocation of the money. After eight weeks, the government finally produced a justification for the payment which referred to the ministerial entitlements. Clause 4(4)(b) says that this amount is not limited to ministerial entitlements but can be expended on anything in the course of the minister's functions. What that clearly relates to is the minister's role as the minister for health. That is also the basis for questioning the constitutionality. It is an allowance that can be provided for the carrying out of her duties and functions as the minister for health. It is not an amount that is allocated to ensure her political survival.

Senator Spindler, I never meant to imply that the Democrats had changed their position. There is a disagreement between us in that you regard 4(4)(b) as a rationale that is sufficient for you to believe that payment should be made. In my view, if we take the particular interpretation that has been made of that, then we have all kinds of possibilities arising as to expenditure that ministers are entitled to have covered that does not actually occur in the course of their duties or role as minister.

It is a very dangerous thing. If I were a minister—which I would never anticipate being, thank goodness—I could ask for a house or any manner of thing. If I were sued for defamation, I could ask for things on the basis that I was a minister and that I would not be able to politically survive if I were not able to pay these costs or fees. So in my view there is not a basis there.

You also said that somehow we were operating on an expediency principle which defies your understanding as to motive. Maybe it is because it is not expediency at all, and there is no particular gain for standing up for something that is not supported in a popular sense. The reason we moved this amendment is that we want to put on the record that there is a view that the taxpayers' money should not have been allocated in this way. It should certainly not have been guaranteed up front. For those who believe that it was a legitimate use of taxpayers' funds, there is an onus to show how that is being spent and what endeavour was made to ensure that it would be spent properly and with due protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather unfortunate that we are forced to re-run the arguments that were run and reported in the Legal and Constitutional Committee report on this matter. We stated quite clearly our position that we do not suggest that the position we adopted would give carte blanche for a minister to have any activity for which he or she was investigated on or charged with providing the basis for a call for the expenditure of public funds.

PARA.TAB: We drew in this particular case a very cogent parallel between actions committed or said to have been committed in one parliament when the reason the inquiry was being established and the minister was being charged with certain matters and was brought before the inquiry was due to her presence in another parliament. While survival as a minister is certainly not a matter that should be taken into account, being able to continue her duties as a Commonwealth minister is one of the factors that the cabinet was able to take into account.
Amendments negatived.

That the amendment (Senator Spindler's), as amended, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that schedule 2 be agreed to.

—We wish to oppose schedule 2, along with another two parts. I have already addressed in my speech during the second reading debate the reasons why I do not think the Senate should agree to this appropriation of $7 million. I will sum up what I said in that speech.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the Sydney showground is public land. It is one of the very few areas of public land in what is probably the most densely populated area of Australia. Secondly, the Democrats and, indeed, the opposition have asked many questions about federal government funding of this venture at estimates hearings and outside estimates hearings. We have not received satisfactory answers to any of them. In fact, in most cases we have not received any answers at all.

The tendering process is currently being investigated by ICAC. There is currently a legal challenge against the New South Wales government over the legal right of the Royal Agricultural Society to sign a lease with Fox and over whether a conflict of interest has tainted the allocation of the site. The impact on the surrounding area of a studio complex with tours, cinemas and restaurants is likely to be disastrous. The extra traffic in the area will be a nightmare. During peak hours the traffic in that area is already a nightmare. I can barely imagine what it will be like with an extra thousand cars a day going through. The number of new Australian jobs which was promised appears to have been enormously overstated. The amount of new Australian film and television product is very unlikely to be substantial.

There is no detailed list of expenditure. The processes by which the site was allocated have been legally questioned. The work to be undertaken with this money has been neither listed nor costed, and potentially severe impacts on the area have not been assessed. Under those circumstances, I do not believe we should be allocating $7 million to this project. I do not believe we should be allocating $7 to this project. I urge the committee to oppose this schedule.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will be supporting this proposal to oppose this schedule. The reason is that we do not believe the funding was done in the proper way and we do not believe that proper process has taken place. It is not the appropriate way to spend taxpayers' money. It is the legitimate role of the Senate to take action when such illegitimate methods of spending money take place. So we will fully support the proposal to oppose the schedule.

—The coalition will not be supporting the proposal to oppose the schedule. We have made our position fairly clear in the second reading amendment that we moved in relation to the bill. We accept the proposition that the moneys are a legitimate expenditure provided that the government, as we said in our second reading amendment, should not disburse the $7 million until such time as the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales has publicly confirmed that due process was observed in the tendering processes and the like. So, subject to due process being confirmed, the coalition is supportive of the expenditure. For that reason, we will be opposing this proposal.
