TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the proposal put forward on behalf of Senator Kernot. The Commonwealth is providing assistance of $7 million towards the cost of rehabilitating the dilapidated showground site to provide improved water supply, sewerage and drainage, communications and electricity and remove fire and asbestos risks. Expert reports have estimated that the total cost of this rehabilitation will be $32 million. The balance of the costs will be met by the New South Wales government up to a maximum of $32 million. Any cost overrun will be met by Fox.

PARA.TAB: The development will mean that Australia will have the second largest infrastructure for film production in the English speaking world. The real benefits of the package of the Australian film industry is expected to be 750 jobs directly, 865 jobs indirectly and $85 million in production expenditure annually.

The film and television production industry has expressed, of course, considerable support for this proposal. The development will also bring substantial new investment to Australia and its film industry. The New South Wales government announced on 14 November this year that Fox would invest $120 million in the project over the next 11 years. The New South Wales government has also provided Fox with an incentive package largely comprising a temporary payroll tax concession. These incentives are similar to others that state governments all around Australia offer to attract investment. The concession will be available to all producers who make films on the site, not just to Fox.

The direct benefit to the New South Wales economy is expected to be about $212 million per annum after five years. The New South Wales government has said that Fox will lose access to certain parts of the site if the facility fails to meet these investment levels and job targets over 11 years. This is a major project with significant benefits to the economy. The studio will produce films for the international market and be a significant export earner. Establishment of a film studio will mean that the local film industry will not have to limit its creativity and expertise to low budget movies as it has in the past. The facility will be a major asset. It will include several sound stages, a variety of post-production facilities and backlot areas for external shooting.

Following discussions between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Premier of New South Wales, the Commonwealth has agreed to a one-off payment of $7 million to the New South Wales government to help defray costs for site preparation and infrastructure development associated with establishing a movie studio at the existing Sydney showground site. The Commonwealth has also agreed to provide $25 million to the New South Wales government for precinct planning, design development, bulk earthworks, services diversion, site works and related costs for a new showground at Homebush as part of the state's Olympic coordinating authorities construction plans.

Once the $7 million and $25 million appropriations are approved by the parliament, two agreements will be drawn up between the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) and the New South Wales Minister for State Development regarding the management and acquittal of the money—one for the $7 million appropriation and one for the $25 million appropriation. These agreements will be modelled on existing agreements such as the one between the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and the New South Wales government regarding Commonwealth assistance for development of Olympic facilities.

The Minister for Communication and the Arts is responsible for decisions concerning designation of the Sydney showground site activity and the Homebush relocation activity under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and its administrative procedures. If the minister decides to designate the activities, they will be referred to the Commonwealth Environment Protection Authority to consider what level of environmental impact assessment, if any, is required. The ministerial agreement concerning transfer of the funds to the New South Wales government will not be concluded until the environmental questions have been resolved.

Referral to the Australian Heritage Commission is only required where a property is listed on the Register of the National Estate. As the existing Sydney showground site is not currently listed on the register, referral to the Heritage Commission is not necessary. For those reasons, I support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that item 1 be supported in the form in which it is presented.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.After clause 3, page 2, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Payments in relation to Fox Film Studios and the Sydney Showground site are subject to a condition

SPEECH.PARA: "3A.(1) Payments out of such money appropriated by this act as is specified in subsection (2) must not be made unless—ind until the condition specified in subsection (3) has been satisfied.
"(2)The money referred to in subsection (1) is as specified in Division 814.

PARA.TAB: "(3)The condition referred to in subsection (1) is as follows:

TAB.TAB: a statement is to be tabled in each House of the Parliament by or on behalf of the Attorney-General stating that the Independent Commission Against Corruption has confirmed that proper and lawful processes were followed in the tender processes in relation to the proposed establishment of the Fox Film Studios at the Sydney Showground site and development of the new Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales site at Homebush, Sydney.".

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the opposition may find something they recognise in this amendment. As I mentioned before, our preferred option was that this payment, which has not gone through due process, which has not gone through any particular process at all from what I can see, should not have been supported. However, the opposition clearly pointed the way. They felt that the Independent Commission Against Corruption should have the ability to look at this. If the Independent Commission Against Corruption did have the chance to look at the way the tender processes took place in relation to the proposed establishment of the Fox Film Studios and if it found that it was not a proper and lawful process then the natural extension of that is that the Senate would not be able to grant that payment.

PARA.TAB: A very good editorial appeared on Wednesday in the Sydney Morning Herald called, `Doubts on the Showground' which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Confusion over the potential worth, in employment terms, of the proposed use of the Showground site is not surprising. After all, the project is still to be properly defined. What, for example, is the exact nature of its dominant feature, the entertainment complex of cinemas, restaurants and shops? Are there to be eight cinemas or 22? These things are not clear because the proposal itself has been changing ever since it was announced by the Prime Minister in October last year as a highlight of his Creative Nation statement.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating's announcement, presumably to give what never has been his to give, undercut the proper process of tender. To his credit, the former State Treasurer, Mr Collins, had insisted on a tender process for such a large and important piece of public land. But since the Government changed in March, Mr Carr and his Treasurer, Mr Egan, have treated Mr Keating's handshake deal with Mr Murdoch of October last year as having settled the matter, leaving only the details to be settled with Mr Murdoch's Fox Studios Australia.

This circumstance has tended to make secret what should have been dealt with by the public processes first of tender and then by normal planning and environment procedures. It has also led to a complaint to the Independent Commission Against Corruption. The complaint questions the probity of government action which invites expressions of interest for the site in certain terms but which then chooses to deal only with one party on quite a different basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore it certainly would not be logical if the opposition were not to support that because we are saying that the Senate could support payment of this money if it was found to be done by a proper and lawful process. But if IPAC, to which the opposition has said that they feel it should be referred, does not find that the tender was performed in a proper and lawful process, and it related to the proposed establishment of the Fox studio, surely none of us could or should support the appropriation of this money. Therefore I commend my amendment to the Senate. My preferred option was the Democrats' amendment. I cannot see any reason why the opposition would not be able to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting this amendment. It is only one part of what we would like to see before the $7 million is agreed to. As Senator Margetts said, the $7 million has been agreed to. I thank her for supporting my amendment that would have stopped that until several things had happened.

PARA.TAB: Not only is this tendering process currently being investigated by ICAC, but there is also a legal challenge. There is also the fact that there is not necessarily an environmental impact statement or assessment going on, although we hope that that may still happen in the future. Judging by the way this has worked in the past, I think it is highly unlikely. We were told about 6,000 jobs; it is now down to about 550 jobs or maybe 700. The last studio that was built in Australia, at the Gold Coast, is not even making a profit yet. We cannot imagine when this one will make a profit. If it does, it will be from the restaurants and the cinemas, not from other things.

There are a great many things which have to be investigated before this $7 million is passed over to the New South Wales government. One of the most important of them is ICAC. I believe that Senator Margetts's motion is a good one. It would at least put to rest one of the problems that we have with passing over the $7 million. Unfortunately, it would not put to rest the rest of the problems, and they are very substantial. As Senator Margetts has said, we have lost that first battle and I hope we can win the second.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it somewhat strange that Senator Margetts is moving this amendment on behalf of the Greens, given that the Greens did not support the coalition's second reading amendment which, I remind the Senate, expressed the opinion that the government should not disburse the moneys—the $7 million—that we are now talking about in relation to this amendment. The Greens opposed the coalition's second reading amendment that that money should not be disbursed until such time as ICAC has publicly confirmed that due process was observed in respect of the tender process for the use of the showgrounds site. These matters have been referred to ICAC.

PARA.TAB: We have a somewhat different view from the Greens and the Democrats on this matter. I understand that both the Greens and the Democrats are opposed to the development that is being proposed here. The coalition is fully supportive of the concept of the studio being established here in Australia. The current showgrounds site has been deemed, after pretty careful examination, to be a suitable site. Equally, the move of the showgrounds from its present site as a consequence to Homebush, particularly given the proximity of the Olympic Games and the relevance of the development of that site to the games, are all very sensible procedures and concepts.

The only doubt that we have had in the coalition is the extent to which the Commonwealth should get involved in developments of this kind and in the financing of them, as distinct from them being more the responsibility of state governments. That is where our hesitation about the proposal has lain rather than in the more fundamental objections that the Greens and the Democrats have to the whole concept of the development of the Fox studio at the current showgrounds site and the consequential move of the showground.

There is a big difference, in my view, between the second reading amendment that the coalition put forward and which was defeated because the Greens did not support it and the amendment now being moved in committee by the Greens. The big difference is that the second reading amendment expressed an opinion that the government should not disburse the moneys—the $7 million in relation to the present showgrounds site—until such time as ICAC has publicly confirmed that all the necessary proper processes had been observed.

There is a big difference between the parliament expressing an opinion that the government should not disburse moneys on the one hand and on the other hand the parliament saying that these moneys `shall not be disbursed unless,' because that puts a mandatory provision into the bill relating not to appropriation but to the actual disbursement of moneys. There is a difference between appropriation and disbursement. The amendment that is being proposed by the Greens blurs that and brings the two together in a way that is undesirable and would certainly have unfortunate precedents if it were to become a precedent, as it could.

So there are two reasons why we do not agree with this. The second and perhaps most important is the point of that blurring, the other being that we do not have an objection to the development that the Greens and Democrats have. We will not be supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will set Senator Short straight on something. The Democrats are not opposed to something being done with the site. We are not opposed to the showground being moved to Homebush. I have lived in Sydney all my life. I have gone to the Royal Easter Show at the showground most years of my life. I know that on Good Friday in particular it is very difficult to put one foot in front of the other. I know that site is now so run down that something has to be done with it.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Short does not understand and what really concerns us is that there are many questions about what that site should be used for and how it should be used. Careful consideration has not been made as to what that site should be used for.

The last Liberal government in New South Wales had, as I understand it, an open tendering process. They were down to a certain number of tenders. When the Labor government came in, they just threw it out the window. They said, `Merry Christmas, Mr Murdoch, here you go, it's yours. Don't worry about the others, we'll just stop this tendering process.' That is why ICAC is looking at it. There are many questions about this. We are not necessarily opposed to this but we want these questions answered. We want what is done with the site to be decided upon in a fair, reasonable and open way. We do not believe anything like that is happening at the moment. That is why we are opposed to giving that $7 million. I have heard what Senator Cook said; I heard almost the same at estimates. But it is not a detailed list of what should be going on at that site—what that money will be used for. Certainly, there is a very big difference, I agree with Senator Short, between the opposition's second reading amendment and this committee amendment by Senator Margetts. The big difference, I agree, is that this amendment requires the government not to hand over the $7 million until ICAC has said it is safe to do so. I think that is a very good thing. That is why I am voting for it. The second reading amendment said, `Here's the money, here's the $7 million, do what you like with it but we suggest that you don't hand it over until ICAC says it's safe to do so.' I suggest to Senator Short that that is not the way to ensure that what you want is going to be what you get. I think this is the way to ensure that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment by Senator Margetts. We do so for a very simple reason. First, let me say that the Senate is the states house, as the constitution provides. I always understood the Senate's purpose as the states house was to reflect the interests of the states in reviewing legislation from the people's house, the House of Representatives. What is being proposed here is a unique application of the states house—that is, for us to reach into a state and do some things on its behalf.

PARA.TAB: The bill provides for a permissible payment to be made by the Commonwealth. We are not bound to make it; we do not have to make it. We have got permission to make it should the circumstances be satisfactory. The circumstances that would be satisfactory would be the state of New South Wales meeting its commitments to the Commonwealth in terms of this matter.

What is being argued here is whether the state of New South Wales is conducting itself in terms of tendering processes in a proper manner. That is for the state of New South Wales to decide. What the Commonwealth has to decide is whether the terms of agreement between it and the state of New South Wales are being met. Clearly, senators on the cross benches feel passionately about this. That is a matter for them to take up in the state of New South Wales. They can do that if they feel passionately about it, but don't knock this off. We oppose the amendment and hope the bill passes.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —We refer to Senator Margetts's amendment on sheet No. 4042. The first proposition will be to affirm schedule 2, division 978, item 2. The question is that that item be agreed to.

—The decision to oppose the appropriation to the Department of the Treasury in relation to a loan to Papua New Guinea has not been taken lightly by the Greens. Our aim is to highlight the shortcomings in the conditions of the loan, which is part of the structural adjustment program organised by the World Bank, and the lack of consultation with Papua New Guinea on the economic changes that have been required as part of the loan facility.

PARA.TAB: In addition, we have concerns about the lack of scrutiny available to the Australian parliament in relation to this substantial loan to a foreign country. I do not deny that Papua New Guinea is facing a major economic crisis and that some form of financial assistance is required. The nature of that financial assistance, particularly the conditions attached to that financial assistance, is open to question and should be subject to debate both in Papua New Guinea and in Australia.

Unfortunately, the Australian government is supporting the World Bank's neo-colonialist approach by dictating the nature of economic reform that is considered appropriate for the people of Papua New Guinea. These conditions include the abolition of price controls on basis foodstuffs, with some prices increasing 200 per cent in a short time; the imposition of hospital fees, supposedly to assist in decentralising health care but, due to the virtual non-existence of rural health outposts, rural people are denied access to health care; a wage freeze and possible abolition of the minimum wage, which will make life very difficult given the increasing costs of foodstuffs; a weakening of foreign investment controls, which will potentially result in balance of payments difficulties—and, heaven knows what extra environmental costs—the retrenchment of 3,000 government employees and the privatisation of state-owned enterprises.

I raised many of these concerns at the recent estimates hearings of the Economics committee last week. Unfortunately, all my worst fears were confirmed. It appears that the Australian government has accepted all the assurances from the World Bank that the structural adjustment program will be of benefit to the economy and to the people of Papua New Guinea, despite evidence elsewhere in the world that the World Bank structural adjustment programs provide dubious benefits.

The National Coalition for Socio-Economic Justice in Papua New Guinea has called for their government to abide by the commitments in the Papua New Guinea constitution in relation to integral human development, equality in participation, sovereignty and self-reliance, preservation of the environment and natural resources, and preservation of Papua New Guinea ways.

The Papua New Guinea government needs to listen to these people and consult more widely on these crucial issues. The Australian government needs to take a lead in encouraging the World Bank to allow such consultation and not to impose conditions on a foreign government without some form of consensus. In addition, the World Bank needs to live up to the rhetoric it produces about the need for proper consultation with non-government organisations.

Mr Pirouz Hamidian-Rad, chief of the World Bank's Papua New Guinea team, has acknowledged that the structural adjustment program will not work if non-government organisations are not consulted and are not supportive of the program. He is right but, despite repeated attempts to organise some meetings, the World Bank has failed to live up to its commitment in this regard. Whilst I am aware that this loan has already been made to the Papua New Guinea government, using the advance to the Minister for Finance, the Senate's opposition to this appropriation will send a strong message to the Australian government that the conditions of the loan are inappropriate and need to be negotiated and that, in the future, loans of this nature should receive proper parliamentary scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —(10.50 p.m.)—The coalition does not support this amendment—the idea that we as a parliament should in this way act to significantly affect the development operation in Papua New Guinea. It is a loan to provide balance of payments assistance. I do not think it would generally be regarded by the Australian community as the right way to go about achieving with neighbouring Papua New Guinea the development it requires. The extent to which it dictates to Papua New Guinea the nature of its development is a matter I think Australia has to be very careful of.

PARA.TAB: This is a loan which is there to provide balance of payments assistance. I am not suggesting for one moment that there are not grounds on which Australia should look carefully at its negotiation with Papua New Guinea on the best way of providing assistance. It is a very topical issue at the moment and one which I think both countries are looking at.

In saying what I have said I am not suggesting that everything is sweetness and light in terms of the financial relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea but, to act in this pre-emptive way and in a way affecting almost $70 million, which is a very large amount so far as Papua New Guinea is concerned, would obviously be extremely disruptive and very damaging to the relationship between our two countries.

The relationship between our two countries is very important to both of us. By all means, let us, as two responsible nations, look at the best way of working together and the best ways of providing Australian financial assistance. But the coalition does not believe that this is the way to go about it. We will not be supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is precisely that the Australian government is dictating conditions, and the conditions that it is dictating are atrocious. If you mean such things as dictating that they must abolish minimum wages, that they must change their economy so that rural price imposts are something like 200 per cent to 300 per cent and that people will no longer be able to eat, that is not acceptable if you are talking about sovereignty.

PARA.TAB: But at the very same time the exact same amount of money that is being set aside, with an increase, in appropriations has just been allocated to the Parliamentary Electoral Development Fund in Papua New Guinea, known parochially in Papua New Guinea as the slush fund. Each parliamentarian—there are 109 of them in Papua New Guinea—now has around 600,000 kina and they can spend that in any way they like. It is seen by the people of Papua New Guinea as a means of corrupt vote buying. That is precisely the same amount of money that this is.

If it was being used and it could be seen to be being used in the ways that would assist the economy, I would have no problems. But the problem is we are imposing conditions and the conditions are draconian. We should be ashamed of them. The only nice conditions were about forestry, and they are not being abided by. Therefore, I do not know how in conscience we can do this to another country and pretend that we are assisting them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Margetts raised this matter because it is an important matter. I do not intend to talk very long on it at all. I have not involved myself in this debate thus far, but I do feel that this is a matter which should be given serious consideration. I understand the reason that Senator Short has indicated on behalf of the opposition that it will not support the motion. In fact, the money has been paid, as far as I know.

PARA.TAB: I agree with what Senator Margetts has said about structural adjustment programs imposed upon certain countries that eat into the very fabric of society and place heavy burdens on the poor. This is done to the extent that wages fall, incomes fall and prices go up for basic commodities such as food, clothing and so on.

I indicated this afternoon in the debate on the government's response to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade report on international financial organisations some of the problems in relation to structural adjustment programs. I indicated that even the taxation structures that are put into place do not contain the type of vertical equity, let alone the horizontal equity, that they should.

If you take income tax, for example, you can only tax land, labour or capital. In the case of capital, I observe that it is a moving target. If you attempt to place what the owners of the capital believe to be a too heavy burden upon them, they will shift their capital offshore. Labour can be taxed but what happens is that the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers pay the increases but the people that are getting income for their labour from another source rather than the pay-as-you-earn system are able to make arrangements to evade or avoid taxation.

I come to the third point which relates to land. In my view, I believe that there is too little insistence and focus on tax on land by those who develop these structural adjustment programs. I pointed this out to one person who is in a multinational financial institution and that person said that he and his family live in a very expensive suburb of Manila and they pay very little tax on their land. It just so happens that a large number of politicians also live in that particular area. The people who can afford to pay are very often the people who own the land, particularly in the metropolitan areas. They are not shouldering the burden. Again, I am concerned about the fund to which Senator Margetts adverted. That is a matter that ought to be considered very seriously.

I am also very well aware of the problems of infrastructure in Papua New Guinea, where the people in the outlying areas cannot, in many cases, get their produce to the markets. I am pleased that Senator Margetts has raised the particular matters. It is a bit too late to reduce that $69 million in this bill. I can understand the point made thereon by Senator Short.

TALK.START.PARA: —I merely point out to my good friend Senator Harradine that the much maligned price reforms on so-called essential items in Papua New Guinea this year included the reform of price restrictions on 11 commodities, including meat pies, alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and rubber thongs. They are hardly the things that one would describe as the essential elements of life. That was the reason why the prices were deregulated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this amendment by Senator Margetts for very much the same reasons that Senator Short put forward. This year, we are celebrating the 20th anniversary of the independence of Papua New Guinea. While that independence occurred under the Whitlam government, it was nonetheless a bipartisan decision of both major parties. It was freely acknowledged at the time that Andrew Peacock had played a significant role leading up to that independence.

PARA.TAB: This motion does not respect the right of a sovereign power and a neighbouring country—Papua New Guinea—to make decisions about its own domestic economy. Twenty years on from independence and from Australia ceasing to be a colonial power, it seems inappropriate now at this hour of the night in the Senate to revisit imperialism. The point of this motion would be to do that.

The government of Papua New Guinea has put together a comprehensive economic reform package in response to extremely difficult circumstances. Without adopting those measures, the Papua New Guinea economy faces collapse, with the burden likely to fall most heavily on the poor. Elements of the package have been agreed with by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. As the PNG finance minister has made clear, the reform program belongs to PNG, and it is in its best interests. That is an assessment that Australia shares.

Australia has encouraged the PNG government to implement economic reforms and has supported the IMF and the World Bank in developing a stabilisation and economic reform program for Papua New Guinea. Australia has provided $A69.4 million in government to government loans to PNG as part of a US $111 million IMF currency stabilisation facility. The economic reform program aims to restore macroeconomic stability, which is a prerequisite for growth in production income and jobs. It also aims to liberalise the economy, lift public investment and improve public sector efficiency, effectiveness and accountability. A further key objective is the promotion of sustainable natural resource development.

I will briefly turn to the poor. Both PNG and the World Bank have given considerable thought to distributional aspects of the program and have designed it to protect and advance the interests of the poor. Specific measures include locking in high proportions of government expenditure on basic health and education services; providing government services to rural areas; creating a social fund to support small-scale development activities through non-government organisational channels; developing a new anti-poverty strategy, with special attention given to the disadvantages faced by women in PNG; strengthening regulations governing forestry and fisheries; and providing more resources for monitoring and enforcement. That is part of all of this debate. For those reasons, the government opposes this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I pointed out earlier, the problem is that the nicer words of that package are not being implemented. There is nothing to say that Australia's payment of this is conditional on those things being done. It is all very well saying that we will provide funds for rural health when many rural health services do not exist. When health services are available, people are now being asked to pay for them and for basic schooling. Basically, that is what we have imposed. The bits that sound great are terrific, but they are not happening. If we talked to the people who are involved with development, they would be able to tell you that. Instead of Australia throwing the money in the air and hoping that it lands reasonably, if we ask those questions, we might be able to work out a package which does address and provide for those needs.

PARA.TAB: The problem is that what we have done is actually entrench conditions which will make local areas less viable and will in fact create more of the problems which we plough a lot of aid in to. What do we do in Papua New Guinea? We actually plough quite a lot of aid into providing funds for policing. Why is that policing being seen as necessary? Something like 93 per cent of the land in Papua New Guinea is still unalienated—that is, people still have the use of their land but they are being forced off it. When they are forced into the cities, there is no means for them to survive in many cases without reverting to some kind of illegal activity just to feed their families. Australia is ploughing so much money into what they call law and order schemes when in fact what we are doing is helping to create the situation which results in people taking desperate measures to survive.

There are alternative models. We have been told by people working in the non-government areas that there are alternative models. One of the things Australia does not do is actually help promote that. In recent times I have asked questions about money that has been provided to Bougainville which has not been spent. The alternative developments about Bougainville getting up and reviving their local economy have actually been dampened by the Papua New Guinea government because they would like the people in Bougainville to be continually dependent on the Panguna mine reviving. I do not see Australia taking any action to encourage that money to be spent on reviving the local economy.

If we are going to be saying that we are doing something to help the poor, let us actually help that to happen. Let us talk to or help communicate with the people working in those areas; do not just expect that top-down development is going to help the poor. We should look at the alternatives that exist. If we did consult in these areas of aid, we would not be ploughing the hundreds of millions of dollars that are ending up getting spent on the outcomes of what we are doing—that is, the law and order side of Papua New Guinea—instead of the grassroots development and local viability. That is the disappointment. I hear the nice words, but I do not hear anybody actually telling me whether there is anything whatsoever to indicate that any of our assistance has come to fruition.
Item agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bills be now read a third time.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to deal quickly with two matters. Senator Ellison gave me a warning that he would ask me a question concerning Mr Alan Griffiths MP and the Codd inquiry into the sandwich shop, and the payment of legal costs. I am sure that Senator Ellison has been called away from the chamber on important business, so he is not able to ask me that question. I seek leave to incorporate what would have been my answer had he been here and asked the question. I also seek leave to incorporate a letter from Mr Geoff Prosser MP to the Minister for Finance, Mr Beazley, and Mr Beazley's reply, which sets out details of those expenses.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Alan Griffiths MP—Codd Inquiry into Sandwich Shop—Payment of Legal Costs
The decision to make the payment, as an act of grace payment, was made by the Minister for Finance pursuant to section 34A of the Audit Act 1901.

The legal bill was subjected to close scrutiny by the Australian Government Solicitor's Office. In particular, two officers spent time examining relevant files held by Mr Griffiths' solicitors and detailed inquiries were made in relation to the bill.
The result of the Australian Government Solicitor's examination of the matter was that:

PARA.TAB: all the work covered by the act of grace claim was considered to be relevant to the inquiry;
the hourly and daily rates charged by Mr Griffiths' solicitors and counsel were reasonable, measured against prevailing commercial rates;
there was no particular item or element of the claim which could objectively be said to be unreasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government Solicitor's advice also drew attention to the following factors:

PARA.TAB: it was open to the inquiry, in addition to its specified terms of reference, to inquire into other matters which appeared to bear on Mr Griffiths' fitness to hold ministerial office;
the possibility of the inquiry investigating additional matters remained open until the very end of the inquiry;
in consequence, there was a need for Mr Griffiths to be pro-active in relation to his response to the inquiry and to undertake comprehensive preparation while relevant evidence was still available;

all the costs were incurred before Mr Griffiths received any advice that the Commonwealth would meet any of his costs. Thus he could not be said to have incurred costs merely on the basis that the Commonwealth would pay them;
the inquiry related to matters fundamental to Mr Griffiths' then future career as a parliamentarian and possible re-instatement as a minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government Solicitor's Office advised that it would be open to the Minister for Finance to reach the opinion that payment of the amount claimed would be appropriate.
In all the circumstances, it was clearly appropriate for the Commonwealth to accept Mr Griffiths' claim for costs.
Background:

Although the amount included in the additional estimates was $544,000, the actual amount which will be paid by the Commonwealth has now been determined to be $543,579.85. That equates the full amount claimed by Mr Griffiths.

The work was performed from 19 January 1994 to 14 February 1995 in relation to the above Inquiry. The Inquiry was established on 23 March 1994 and its findings were announced on 3 August 1995.
The further breakdown is set out in the table beneath. The units referred to are 6 minute units. The major categories of work are summarised beneath the table.

Initiating Inquiry—covers assessment of the known factual circumstances, legal advising in relation to the tenure of Ministerial office and options, preparation of resignation, formulation of options for subsequent action, seeking independent inquiry and notifying the Prime Minister and relevant authorities.

Harrison Trial—covers attendances at the Magistrates Court for the hearing of the Harrison Trial and associated conferences and analyses of the allegations and assertions made in the course of the trial relevant to the Inquiry.

Answers/Interviews—covers preparation of drafts, collation of material and interviews with Mr Griffiths, analysis of primary and secondary material including newspaper and media materials, activities subsequent to an interview by the Inquiry on 10 December 1994, the filing of formal answers and preparation of supporting files, and the obtaining for the purposes of the Inquiry of material from the Commonwealth Bank (financial records, cheque butts etc.) in relation to the ALP BB bank account and forwarding this material on to Price Waterhouse and general attendances for the purposes of an audit.

Conferring/Preparation—covers conversations and correspondence with various parties and their legal advisers, including the solicitor assisting the Inquiry, in relation to statements, and preparation for the Interview by the Inquiry on 10 December 1994, including a detailed source document required for further explanation of the answers given to the questions sent by the Inquiry to Mr Griffiths on 4 November 1994.
Police—covers liaising with the Australian Federal Police in relation to various matters of relevance to the Inquiry.
AEC—covers exchanges with the Australian Electoral Commission in relation to matters of relevance to the Inquiry.
Submission/Post Submission—covers analysis of Inquiry's draft report, preparation for an oral submission to the Inquiry and attendance to make an oral submission at Inquiry on 25 January 1995.
27 November 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —The other matter concerns a question asked of me in the committee stage by Senator Chamarette when we were debating Carmen Lawrence's legal fees. She has pointed out to me that I have failed at this point to answer that question. The two questions she asked me, as I recall them, are: when the cabinet decided to back Carmen Lawrence for her legal expenses, did it seek legal advice on any challenges she might make to the legality of the royal commission; and, if we did, would we table that legal advice?

PARA.TAB: The answer to that first question is no, we did not. The principle we held to here was that Carmen Lawrence was subject to an inquiry designed to attack her standing as a minister and that she should choose her method of defence. It was for and against her and she should decide her method of defence. That did not go to the government saying, `But you can only defend yourself this way or that way.' So the answer to the first question is no.

The second question was: did we monitor the expenditure? This was a question also asked of me, as I recall, by Senator Spindler. I replied to that question earlier this evening. In summary, the answer to that question, without going into the full detail of that reply, is no as well.
